I hate writing this update because I used to really love Apple Spice, but the last three times we have ordered lunch there have been multiple mistakes. For a place that does catering, getting 10 lunches right doesn't really seem like too much to ask.

Today, two people ordered bread bowls. They received a very small container of soup with a slice of bread. That is not really a bread bowl.

Me and one of my vegan co-workers ordered the southwestern salad, sans cheese. It came with chicken, and on the menu it states you have to pay an additional $1 for chicken, so it would definitely be something someone needed to ask for.

One of the lunches came as a sandwich instead of a wrap, and Heather W. was missing her cookie and her juice with her meal.

Apple Spice was nice enough to replace the mistaken items (brought corrected salads, brought the actual bread bowls - although, not with new soup, brought the wrap) and bring us an extra plate of cookies, but like I said, this is the third time this type of mistake has happened. 

It's pretty expensive, the Southwestern is not even very good, and once the order comes back wrong it delays my eating for an hour + and it is just frustrating.

I'm sorry Apple Spice... you guys are great but you need to get it together.

I was so excited when I found out Yalla was opening near my house- we were in need of a good Med Cuisine place there, and also, it is owned by Khoury's- my FAVORITE place to eat.  
We ordered a few things, the roasted chicken sandwich, Fatoush salad with Chicken, and the beef kabobs. 
The rice was out of this world! It has a little crispy thin noodles and a light oil.  The hummus was great and the Fatoush was so tasty.  My husband had no complaints about the sandwich..but we did have a couple downsides.  
The order was billed incorrectly.  And the cashier was very apologetic, but ended up billing me more, so that he didn't have to call his manager to fix it.  I felt that he should have just billed me the price he told me over the phone and comped his mistake.  Also, their Pita bread was not as good as i had hoped, tasted kind of old.  
I'll be back though.

UPDATE: 
I did come back, only to wait in line behind another customer for 10 minutes (at a counter btw) without so much as a "hello", or "sorry" from the cashier. The wait was so long becuase this woman could not get her order together and we were ignored so we just left. AWFUL SERVICE. Cashier should have acknowledged us, or offered to start our order while the customer ran out to her car, but no. Nothing. AWFUL! 
We went to Osaka across the street.

I went with a Chinese friend who ordered in Chinese.  When one of the dishes arrived and she didn't like the look of it she then shouted a lot at the waiter (in Chinese).  After that the food was exceptional.  Easily the best Chinese food I've had in Central Illinois.  (I admit, that's a low standard.)

However, I've never been able to recreate this experience.  And how I've tried!  I ended up asking my Chinese friend to write me a note in Chinese ordering these same dishes from the Chinese menu.  I show the crumpled and worn note to the waiter when I go by myself.  But the food is never as good.  I expect it was the shouting.  Now that my friend has moved away, I expect it will never be that good again.

Without my friend to help us, this is a mediocre place.

Pros:
* Friendly and fast delivery or requested items
* Very comfy beds
* Nice soaking tub( but can only fit one1) 

Cons: 
*None of the staff at check in were smiling or looking remotely like they wanted to see you or even be working there.
* No outlets by bed so had to get extension cords for my husbands CPAP
*Told had freezer but they only had a fridge sucked for breastmilk saving (sorry if that grosses folks out)
* No vending machines to buy a coke anywhere but their overpriced in room fridges
* Overcomplicated room switches and lighting systems.
* Bathroom sinks designed to get everything wet! 

The rooms remind me of The Hotel but I prefer The Hotel to Aria

I had been to one other Brazilian steakhouse a few years ago in Dallas and it was freakin amazing. However, Braza's wasn't great. It wasn't bad, but the food didn't seem freshly cooked; more like it had been under a warmer too long. Most of the meats were ok. The flank steak was great, chicken was good, sirloin was ok but sort of bland, the pork was good, lamb ok, alligator (yes, alligator) was not bad (my first time trying). 
The atmosphere was the most disappointing element of the whole experience, as the picture on their website made it look like a 4 or 5 star fancy restaurant, with a nice picture of a glass of wine -- however when we arrived, it looked similar to the interior of a Golden Corral (not exaggerating) - definitely not a place that is likely to impress your wife/girlfriend. Also, be prepared, the restaurant is actually split in half: one side is Indian and the other is Braza's; so, it had the thick smell of an Indian restaurant in the air- which kind of worked against our Brazilian appetites. 
I have to say the service was pretty good. The wait-staff was friendly and seemed to want us to have a nice time.
The pricing was about $40-45 a person, which I thought was a bit high for this particular establishment-- and I walked away feeling like if I was going to spend that kind of money, I could've done better elsewhere.

Staff manager isn't that friendly or helpful, and they never have what I want in stock. It is closer to my house than PetsMart, but after three unsuccessful trips I will just head to the competitor spot to get what I need.

"Well, I had held high anticipations for the culinary offerings at this establishment, subsequent to perusing the laudatory critiques. 
We were accommodated with remarkable celerity, yet our server, from the onset, comported himself in a manner suggestive of our presence being an imposition upon him. 
I opted for the scampi, which, alas, was somewhat overcooked, resulting in a regrettable incineration of the tails; however, the pasta and sauce accompanying it were quite palatable; my acquaintance, on the other hand, requested the cod, which, unfortunately, was excessively overcooked, prompting her to seek a fresh portion. 
As we approached the conclusion of our repast, we became cognizant of his lamentations, addressed to his colleagues (this was a decidedly vociferous conversation, as the staff members were situated behind the preparation area, en route to the kitchen), wherein he attributed our dissatisfaction with the fare to our own capricious nature. 
I, as well as my companion, shall not be returning, and we shall endeavor to dissuade our associates from patronizing this establishment, owing to the unremarkable cuisine and unprofessional demeanor of the staff."

I was compelled to dine at this establishment due to the temporary closure of Island Style, a restaurant I frequently visit, for renovations. Upon entering, I was struck by the unassuming ambiance, which did not augur well for an exemplary culinary experience. However, I chose to reserve judgment, focusing instead on the quality of the fare and hospitality. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the service was merely adequate, and the cuisine left much to be desired. Specifically, my spouse and I had to request the midday menu, which was not readily available. My primary grievance concerned the food, which lacked the robust flavors and vibrant hues characteristic of Sino-Asian delicacies. The pork and tofu hot pot was unremarkable, with an abundance of pork and a conspicuous absence of dynamic vegetation. Similarly, the shrimp pan-fried noodles were insipid and failed to impress. As a culinary expert myself, I can only surmise that the chefs at this venue have become complacent in their craft, resulting in an uninspired and unappetizing offering. In conclusion, my experience at this restaurant was thoroughly underwhelming, with nothing exceptional about the service and little to commend the food. It is unlikely that I shall return.

The food is good, but the times we've been here and had questions, the servers have never known how to explain items on the menu or even what's in it. When we ask, 'How would you explain Kenyan food?' Our waiter responded, 'Uhhh...it's similar to American food.' When we asked, 'What is Menudo,' he just froze up like a deer in headlights until one of us looked it up and said, 'I think that's stomach.'\n\nThe servers are nice and the atmosphere is quiet and intimate.  Unfortunately, they just don't train their staff well enought to know their product.

What do you expect when you see a sign for All You Can Eat Sushi for $19.95?  Less and mediocre food right?  Well that's what I expected and that's what I got! The sushi was blah and there was waaaaay more rice in the sushi rolls than there was actually fish.    So, don't get the all you can eat sushi deal unless you don't care how it tastes.

On the other hand, my friend ordered miso soup for $4.50 and that sucker was HUGE....not the typical small miso soup bowls....so that was cool.  

I skipped the sushi because I had an inkling it was going to be wack, so I ordered the Ah Sin Fried Rice (which was kinda wack too....not very flavorful at all).  I also ordered the Har Gow (shrimp dumplings) and it was surprisingly good....I've had better...but it was good.  

Oh and they charge you for hot tea ($8 for a pot that serves 5 people easily).

La Condesa, I give up on you. We try and try to excuse the terrible service, but no more. It's not worth it. It's too slow and inattentive and they just don't give a damn, so I'll take my $33 elsewhere.

This time we were disappointed by the food, too. We returned our horchata for being too thin and tasteless, and you brought us new ones after we finished eating. You drizzled a pretty crema all over the top of my torta (sorry, lonche). How do I pick it up and eat it? 

In the past we forgave the dirty tables and loudness because your cochinita pibil was pure bliss. But not even that makes up for the service. :(

"It is indeed a fortuitous circumstance that this establishment offers exceptional promotions on their protein-based products, as it serves as an inducement for me to frequent their premises, despite my reservations regarding the quality of their produce. The dairy products, in particular, appear to be consistently available at a reduced price point, which is a significant factor in my decision to procure them from this location. Furthermore, the meat and seafood departments often feature buy-one-get-one-free or buy-one-get-two-free deals, which present an opportunity too advantageous to ignore. However, I must express my dissatisfaction with the level of customer service provided by the staff, who often display a lack of cordiality and an apathetic attitude towards acknowledging patrons' presence. Moreover, the checkout process is unacceptably sluggish, consuming thrice the duration required at alternative retailers I visit. Notwithstanding these grievances, I shall persist in perusing their advertisements and taking advantage of their occasional bargains, while simultaneously maintaining my preference for alternate sources of grocery supplies."

Not my \"cup of tea\" -- too Yuppie for me!  Atmosphere way too \"sanitized\", and servers have little or no personality.  The food is fair but not worth the price IMHO!  What ever happened to pasta or pizza with RED sauce?  Seems they have every color and concoction known to man except red (well maybe one or two)- being of Italian descent I need red!!  I ordered from  the \"Small Bits Menu\" because I wanted a light lunch - believe me - it definitely was \"Small Bits\",  good thing they gave out bread because I needed a second helping of that just to let me know that I ate something!  My suggestion is to order from the dinner menu if you want a full meal - of course most folks are much more sophisticated than this old country boy and can figure out what most of the fancy California stuff is on the menu - sorry!

My breakfast and my boyfriends was very bland. We got the waffles and the blueberry lemon pancakes. The pancakes didn't even slightly taste like lemon and the waffles were mediocre. Although the presentation was nice, I won't be coming back.

Asthma and respiratory sufferers avoid this place like the plague.  It stinks to high heaven of cheap teen cologne.  The merchandise is still over priced and staff is dumber than a box of rocks.  On the plus side, it's a great place for decent men's sweat pants.  Just make sure you don't pay full price.  Also wash the clothes when you get them home,  they will stink like their cologne.
Do you have any idea how frustrating it is to cut a $50 ribeye with a dull steak knife?  My only memory of this place is having to saw my steak.
I came for the signature tamales and left wishing I would have gone to el sombrero.  the food was shlockely prepared and lacked flavor.  it was also lukewarm.  service was equally thoughtless.

"Each and every time I engage in a round of golf at this particular course, I invariably become incensed by some aspect of the experience. Today, it was the sluggish pace of play that aroused my ire. Typically, it's the unacceptably poor quality of service and the unpleasant demeanor of the staff that leaves a sour taste in my mouth, but on this occasion, all of the employees I had the pleasure of interacting with were quite cordial and accommodating. Nevertheless, we still managed to spend a whopping three hours navigating a mere 13 holes, with interminable waits of no less than five minutes at each and every hole. It's utterly preposterous to expect anyone to endure such an excruciatingly slow round of golf, and I would strongly advise against bothering with the vending machine situated on the fourth hole, as it consumed an exorbitant amount of time and proved to be a colossal waste of effort. Ultimately, we opted to abandon our game altogether, as I found it utterly impossible to reconcile the exorbitant cost of $30 with the paltry amount of golf we managed to play. As a self-proclaimed golf aficionado, I must confess that my elevated standards may render me somewhat prone to drama, but in this instance, I believe my indignation is entirely warranted, given the subpar quality of the experience."

"Satisfactory service was proffered, albeit with some culinary inconsistencies, specifically pertaining to the doneness of the steaks, wherein two were requested to be prepared medium rare, yet one was received in a state between medium and medium well, while the other was barely cooked to an acceptable temperature, thus rendering it essentially raw; meanwhile, the ambiance was characterized by a high level of noise and activity, although our server demonstrated commendable dedication to her duties, and it is likely that, given more time, she would have endeavored to rectify the issues with our meals."
Why is it that no matter what time you come in it is always at least a 20 min wait? They need to hire more people.

I couldn't agree more with some of the reviews I've seen on here. This is not the Wahoo's you grew up with in Cali. The fish is very dry and the green sauce stuff they serve is like some gross watery sour cream and herb combo. 

I've been here a few times for drinks and there is a particular bartender that's horrible. (Sorry, I don't remember her name!) When watching a fight in a mostly empty bar she came on shift and turned down the volume on the television and then changed the channel to some reality show. I asked for it back on and was ignored.  

I've also been here on at least two other nights where her service was lacking because she was too busy chatting up a customer to serve us or even bring us the bill to get paid. I finally had to tell her we were walking out without paying to get her to do her job.

Avoid this location unless you want a mediocre fish taco with crappy service.

This supermarket, a Best of Las Vegas recipient since its inception, serves breakfast on weekends, thereby constituting our destination on a recent morning. I found the market to be comparable to Whole Foods, albeit with more moderate pricing. We placed our order at the counter and subsequently retired to a table in the piano room, whereupon the food was delivered. Our easy over eggs were accompanied by bacon, wheat toast, and home fries. While the quality of the ingredients was satisfactory, the pricing was somewhat prohibitive, and the execution left ample room for improvement. Specifically, the toast lacked the desired crispiness, the bacon was unacceptably limp, the potatoes appeared tired, and the egg whites were unpleasantly watery.

I walked into this place and had a sense of de javu.  It was a standard buffet with all the little stations with food from around the world.  There wasn't a long wait, which I took to be a good thing, but I should have seen it as a sign.

The buffet was over priced, the food was only okay, and the service was terrible.  Our waitress never checked on us again after she dumped our orange juices on the table.  

I found out that my feeling of de javu was because I've actually been to this buffet before, but it was when it was at the Aladdin.  They simply transferred it to Planet Hollywood.  

There was a reason why there was no line for this buffet.  It sucked.  I can't believe I wasted by Sunday Brunch here.

Well as usual the rolled tacos lacked the quality of my first visit.  They were mushy in the middle and some parts of the tacos appeared maybe to not even been dipped into the fryer. The guacamole quality also not impressive this time and the cheese on the rolled tacos was not melted at all. Very concerned about prices for this item too as in most places you can get 5 of these for under 5 bucks always,  but they are 6.50 here with tax. Not worth it based on quality and not even a healthy dose of alcohol helped either.

Ah Aureole.  Lovely to look at, food divine.  Service?  Ridiculously bad.  Reservations at 930.  Get in, get seated.  Waiter disappears after leaving us with their malfunctioning tablet wine list.  Returns nearly twenty minutes later & is a bit annoyed that we haven't chosen our wine.   Because its clearly our fault the tablet isn't working.  Then he begins warning us (four times total) that \"we'll be closing soon.\"  \nAgain.  Food, magnificent.  So so so good.  But feeling directly pressured to hurry the heck up and get out after being abandoned by the waiter...um no.  We won't go back.

This particular establishment, known as Terrible's, happens to be situated in close proximity to my humble abode. Consequently, I have opted to visit this location on multiple occasions, primarily for the purpose of acquiring beverages of an alcoholic nature, specifically beer, upon my return home.

On a singular occasion, I availed myself of their car washing services, only to be left with an unsettling sensation that the cost incurred was disproportionate to the quality of the service rendered. Moreover, I have refrained from utilizing their fuel pumps due to the prices being somewhat elevated in comparison to those of neighboring gas stations.

Notwithstanding the aforementioned reservations, I must concede that the convenience store within the premises boasts an impressive array of merchandise, available at a reasonable tariff. Furthermore, the beer cellar, renowned for its exceptionally low temperature, is indeed a remarkable feature of this establishment.

Unfortunately, the parking facilities provided do not exactly qualify as expansive or straightforward, rendering ingress and egress somewhat arduous, particularly when the lot is congested and parking spaces are scarce. It is worth mentioning, however, that the staff members at this establishment, though remunerated at a rate commensurate with the minimum wage, generally exhibit a level of professionalism and dedication to their duties that is, at the very least, adequate.

Despite certain drawbacks, I shall continue to frequent this establishment, provided that the prices remain competitive.

Always have had good experience here but not tonight, dinner with group of friends had abysmal service. First waiter forgot our table and second waitress had a poor attitude when asked about very late food. Food was OK but definitely not as good as in the past.

This place serves Werner Enterprises truck drivers. I know cause I'm one of them. It's just the basics for what we need. I've stayed in worse places. So if you like a 5 star hotel, go somewhere else. It's a 2 star maybe a soft 3 star hotel. But there are plenty of food places within walking distance.
Nothing special about this place. The food is ok and the service is slow. Not enough space between tables so its almost like your having dinner with the tables next to you.

Food was ok but not the best.  I haven't gone there in almost a year and when I paid the bill I realized why I haven't. Almost $2.50 for a glass of OJ and they don't give free refills. Again, food was ok but there is definitely better.

Was craving wings and decided to drive a bit to get them.
They are good, but I find the rubs a little too salty. 
Had the Louisiana and Parmesan Garlic.
Ate the Lousiana, not the Parmesan Garlic.
The parmesan cheese smelled like an spoiled dish rag. You all know that smell. 
Stunk my vehicle up all the way home. 
Tossed right in the trash. 
Will NOT be going back.
Does the staff not have any olfactory senses?

This was my first buffet I've been since being away from Vegas for years. And this wasn't my best decision. 

My boys and I were wanted to grab a meal at a buffet before our night out in the city of sin.  Apparently, this was the closest one and had a short line. Once we got to cashier, I was in shock to hear how much an individual had to pay for buffet dinner. For the price for an individual had to pay, we could've got the 24 hour buffet pass. More buffets to visit at different hotels.

Once we paid, we waited a couple minutes for our table.  After our table was ready and then seated, our server took our drink orders. When everything was settled at the table, we were off to explore the buffet's offerings.

The selections were very limited since some stations were left unreplenished. With what was available, I had to make my $47 dinner worth it. I went for the grilled meats: kobe beef & prime rib, short rib tacos, assortments of sushi & sashimi, and beef Wellington. For dessert, I got mini churros and vending machine ice cream.

The pros:
- Short rib tacos
- Shasimi & sushi

The cons:
- Grilled meats were very dry, also the beef Wellington
- Mini churros were hard and stale
- Ice cream from the vending machine taste like any other buffet place back home

Our server was helpful but got all our drink orders wrong. I left full, dissaponinted, and unsatisfied.

I was told to check out this buffet while in Vegas, and I kind of regret I did.  I think there are two types of people: those who like buffets and those who don't.  I'm of the latter sort, and buffets remind me of eating in college mess halls more than enjoying the food.  But still, we went here for a Saturday brunch.  \n\nThe variety seemed pretty good - asian, italian, seafood, pizza, breakfast, etc.  I had an omelet which was probably the highlight of the meal.  Everything else that I tried was fine, but I was definitely limited by not being able to have the meat here.  The desserts looked nice but I didn't really like any of the ones I tried.  My fiance was more experimental, but he thought that most of the food was kind of pedestrian or mediocre.  Ultimately, both of us would have preferred eating less at a better restaurant in Vegas, but then again, I guess we're not buffet people.

"Having been apprised of an abundance of laudatory assessments, in conjunction with the perpetual throngs of patronage, I deemed it appropriate to subject this establishment to my own meticulous scrutiny. Alas, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as certain aspects of the culinary offerings proved to be somewhat disappointing. Specifically, the pork dishes were not adequately cooked, the enchiladas featured a questionable cheese substitute, and the marshmallows possessed a decidedly unpleasant flavor reminiscent of those from a bygone era (specifically, 1987, which appears to have been an inauspicious year for marshmallow production). Furthermore, I couldn't help but notice an unusually high concentration of severely overweight individuals within the premises, which only served to further diminish my overall satisfaction. Notwithstanding these criticisms, I must admit that the prices were quite reasonable, thereby providing a modicum of solace in an otherwise underwhelming experience."

In person, the staff can seem friendly or helpful. But over the phone, they don't even bother. They've called me to show up early only to switch doctors on me. The office isn't very clean. I had hoped to never go back, but they wouldn't respond to prescription refill requests and I had to go in person to fix the situation. First they told me I would need to come in and be seen every three months for my refills, but when I began to question this they folded and gave me my prescription. They seem like they want to force you to have as much done as possible to line their pockets with your insurance (hopefully) money. I'm back to hoping I never need to go back.

I experimented with this culinary establishment's offerings for the first time during the previous week, specifically on a Monday. My order consisted of their Kung Po chicken dish; however, I must admit that I did not derive satisfaction from consuming it, primarily due to the fact that the poultry was battered, which seemed incongruous with my preconceived notion of an authentic Chinese culinary experience. Furthermore, the accompanying sauce possessed an overly saccharine quality reminiscent of a sweet and sour variety, which only served to further dissuade me from expressing enthusiasm regarding this particular dish. Moreover, the cost of procuring this item proved to be greater than I had initially anticipated. Therefore, I would advise potential patrons to consider visiting alternative establishments specializing in Chinese cuisine, such as those situated along Leith Walk, in search of a more genuine and satisfying gastronomical encounter.

Pancho Villas has been around for a while, it seems to get enough business to stick around, but I am not entirely sure how... I have had better chili from several pubs and Illegal Jack's, cheaper too. Enchiladas and Fajitas were also uninspired and lacking a spice hit.

A friend said they make a great margarita, however if I need to be inebriated to enjoy the food I don't see the point of paying a restaurant price.

To use the description so handily provided by yelp; meh, I've experienced better.
The pizza wasn't horrible,  but the deal was awful.  The prices are extremely high at Dominos in general,  and their medium 2 topping is a rip off.  Low rating is for price vs.  Quality,  and value.

"The recreational aquatic facility boasts pristine cleanliness and aesthetically pleasing architecture, yet, it perplexes me as to why the management would opt to cement the pool decking during sweltering summer days in Arizona, rendering the surface hazardously slippery and uncomfortably hot underfoot. Witnessing a visitor slip and sustain a head injury, resulting in an ambulance being summoned to transport them to the hospital for treatment of a concussion, only serves to amplify my incredulity. Furthermore, the ratio of pool-goers to lifeguards appears to be disproportionately skewed, with approximately three guests to every one lifeguard, leading me to question the efficacy of such a safety protocol. Additionally, the standard operating procedure in the event of an injury, which involves the whistle-blowing mobilization of all fifty guards to expel every single patron from both the pool and surrounding area, strikes me as excessively zealous and unnecessary, especially considering the inconvenience and discomfort it causes for those simply seeking to retrieve their children or personal belongings. While I acknowledge the importance of addressing emergencies promptly, I believe it is unreasonable to cordon off the entire pool area, thereby precluding patrons from accessing their belongings or even hydrating beverages. In light of these concerns, I have decided against returning to this particular recreational establishment."

I think this restaurant is way over rated for the money spent.
On the upside,the waiter was very polite and professional and overall the food was
good,not great but good. One the down side of things, when a meal costs over
a hundred dollars a meal and  the wines start at ninety dollars I expect exceptional
food and exceptional service for these prices.All of the foods were served barely warm or cold, servings were small. they have two unisex restrooms and after waiting in line,most people left the restaurant to wash and relieve themselves.
The only thing exceptional about this restaurant is the appearence  of the way the
food was prepared,other than that.this is only a average restaurant.
Register service was not pleasant. I'm not sure if the girl who rang me up just didn't like me, but she was nice to everyone else until I got up to her.

We ordered a side of Mac n cheese for an appetizer. We both ordered fish since it was Friday, with side salads. We also asked for a cup of the soup of the day- clam chowder. The salads came out first, then 2 minutes later the soup arrived. 1 minute later the Mac and cheese arrived. We joked that the word \"appetizer\" seems to be beyond most servers. We had a few bites of our salad and our entrees arrived. Are you kidding me? We had so many plates on our table the waiter made a joke about it. I just looked at him like \"are you punking me\". To top this off 3 different servers seemed to be our servers plus the food runners. We had to ask several for refills of water. We also had to grab someone for salt/pepper and to just get our bill. They were all super friendly but it's super clear there is no leadership or management guiding them. The deco is great, the food was all good. We will try one more time, I always give local places a second try. These service issues must be addressed. Any pos system should allow a server to time when food comes out. Clearly there is a miscommunication between the servers and cooks, this is a management issue.

We used to really like this place as a good first stop in Vegas.  It has gone downhill - nearly all the way down hill.

It took 27 - yes, 27 - minutes for our waiter to come say hello and just take our drink order.  At that point, we ordered everything and asked for the check at the same time so we could make sure we didn't miss him again.

They've narrowed the menu and the choices aren't as varied, leaving off some things I used to like.

I had the bbq chicken flatbread.  The chicken was not only all dark meat, but half of it was inedible because it was all fat and tendons.  I guess if you order a burger it might be ok, but they didn't do this one well.

This place has a management issue, which causes a staffing issue, which causes poor customer service and wait times.  We won't go back, but hopefully they fix it for future crowds.

One star for great beer selection, though!

I asked for delivery. Ok, they did it with no problems and quick enough (30-40 mins). 
I chose just rolls. 
The salmon one was pretty flat, no taste. Californias were ok-ish.

When I gave money to the woman who delivered she took them and left without saying a goodbye or thank you

Meh

"It barely possesses the characteristic flavor profile associated with pho, nor does it exude an aroma reminiscent of the dish; I requested additional vegetables in my vermicelli, but the quantity provided appeared to be less than what is customarily offered by establishments in the absence of such a request; this particular dish was merely satisfactory; furthermore, the seating surface presented noticeable tears and fissures, which, upon sitting, caused discomfort, particularly when wearing attire that exposed skin, such as dresses or shorts."

This is a standard looking hole-in-the-wall Mexican food restaurant just like a gazillion others in Phx.  Unfortunately this one is pretty lame.  

I got two enchiladas, one chicken and one beef.  Neither meat is anything I'd recommend or buy again.    The dark brown sauce scared me and didn't taste much better than it looked.  Some sort of beef sauce I think.  It wasn't awful but it was nothing I want again. My copilot on this adventure said her chicken tacos were not so good either, and when we got back to the office she noted that we won't be trying that place again.

The place was super quiet for a Friday at 12:30pm. Punch machines were off, a 4yr old was scootering around behind the counter, and I think there were only two people working.  I wonder if they'll be in business next week.

We have had the misfortune of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and each time, the subpar service has failed to deviate from its consistent lackluster quality. It remains unclear whether the root cause of this inadequacy stems from an insufficient number of employees or an inefficient allocation of staff members between indoor and outdoor seating areas, leading to an excruciatingly sluggish pace of service. Furthermore, the culinary offerings are unremarkable and fail to justify a repeat visit, especially considering the superior alternatives available at neighboring establishments. Despite these shortcomings, the potential for a first-rate drinking establishment exists, awaiting the implementation of crucial improvements to surpass the competition.

"Culinary artisans who harmoniously blend their vocal talents with their gastronomical prowess invariably ensure an unparalleled epicurean experience, as the hospitable service staff fosters an ambiance reminiscent of a convivial family gathering. While the interior design may appear somewhat lackluster, this establishment possesses inherent potential. 

--The made-to-order Pico de Gallo boasts freshness and a piquant flavor, although its sodium content tends to overpower the palate, particularly when paired with corn chips. 
--The melodious strains emanating from the culinary domain serve as a harbinger of excellence, signaling that a delectable feast is forthcoming. 
--Although delivered, the flour tortillas feature only six ingredients, which is suboptimal. 
--Guacamole should never contain additives such as milk, which would compromise its authenticity and texture. 
--The rice, regrettably, is too minute, resulting in rapid desiccation and disappointment. 
--The cheese crisp, unfortunately, lacks crunch, while the green chili strips display freshness. 

DECOR REQUIRES REFURBISHMENT 
--The presence of extended beer flags suspended from the ceiling does not automatically create a festive atmosphere, especially when they fail to flutter in the breeze. 
--Mounted mariachi hats and diagonally positioned multicolored throw rugs do not contribute significantly to the overall aesthetic appeal. 
--While caballeros and damas are certainly commendable, the juxtaposition of McDonald's-style Men and Women signs beneath them seems incongruous. 
--Mirrored walls, reminiscent of the 1980s, are aesthetically displeasing. 

It is crucial to preface my assessment by acknowledging my corn intolerance, which limits my capacity to sample a significant portion of the menu. 
--This venue exudes a genuine local ambiance, which could benefit from a revitalizing transformation."

It is utterly preposterous to expect consumers to pay such an exorbitant price for a paltry double shot of espresso, truly it is. My recent visit to the Handsome Roasters Cafe, where I was served a double pulled by one of the proprietors themselves, only solidified my conviction that the prices at JPH are unreasonable, as the cost was significantly lower. Furthermore, my experiences at other esteemed establishments, such as Barista in Portland Oregon, where I was served by an award-winning barista, and at Coava, Stumptown, and The Refinery, all renowned for their high-end offerings, only further reinforced my belief that JPH's prices are unjustifiably steep. While I do appreciate the occasional indulgence in a premium coffee experience, I cannot help but feel that JPH's pricing strategy is pretentious and unreasonable, particularly given the plethora of more affordable options available. Perhaps the exorbitant rent or the prevalence of affluent clientele who are either trust fund beneficiaries or burdened with substantial student loans might explain the coffee shop's seemingly inflated prices. In any case, a dose of rationality would greatly benefit JPH's pricing model, in my humble opinion. As an aside, I must express my delight at the fact that LADRO is served at JPH, a pleasant surprise indeed.

I think Phoenix reviewers inflate the ranking of restaurants here to make it seem like there are a lot more real good restaurants (and there are, but Blue Wasabi isn't one of them) or they are simply very generous, or they have no idea what good cuisine is, or they give an extra star for creativity by having "blue" wasabi. I've learned to avoid listening to reviewers who give high ratings for average, at best, restaurants. 

What I like about Blue Wasabi - good service, decent drinks, different decor and look. 

What I don't like - For what you pay, this is average sushi. The sushi isn't cheap, so I had been expecting real fresh sushi. But, I was let down by the quality of the sushi and sashimi. The sashimi was actually better (but not saying much). But, the food here  was not as good as Sushi on Shea or Kyoto, both of which are considerably cheaper than Blue Wasabi. It's more of a scene place, somewhat trendy. But, I am not paying my money for the scene. I want good  food. And, frankly, Blue Wasabi falls short of that.

I was there on Friday night about 9:00.  Not very many people and it seems that this place is short staffed.  No hostess, and only 2 servers for this large place.  My server was very good - he gets high marks!  The food was another story.

I ordered the lemon sole, a side salad and that's all.  With tax and tip the meal came to $20.00.  The salad was nice and fresh and crisp.  The lemon caper sauce was tasty, the sole was not very good.  I did mention this to the server and he offered to replace it, but I didn't want to wait.  It was supposed to be "sautéed", the chef does not know how to cook fish!  It was fried and was crispy and tough.  Sole is a tender fish and doesn't need much cooking.  I was very disappointed in this dish and would not recommend it.  

As always, Mimi's does have good bread, but the rest of the food is not so hot.  This was what I thought a rather expensive meal (well not a lot, but more than $5 or 10!) and way not worth it.  Go elsewhere!

"It is truly perplexing to comprehend the rationale behind the ostensibly favorable evaluations bestowed upon this establishment, as my personal experience has led me to conclude that it is, in fact, quite unsanitary and antiquated. The ambiance is hectic, the service is excruciatingly sluggish, and the culinary offerings are merely lubricous and unpalatable. 

The prevailing sentiment among patrons appears to be that of a superlative dining experience, with particular emphasis on the purported affordability and quality of the Mexican cuisine served herein. However, I must respectfully disagree with such assertions, as my own taste buds have failed to detect even a modicum of gastronomical excellence. 

The salsa presented was conspicuously lacking in freshness, while the guacamole was devoid of any discernible flavor profile. Furthermore, the practice of placing packaged shredded cheese atop tortilla chips and salsa, rather than allowing it to melt, struck me as decidedly incongruous. 

My attempt to consume a taco salad was, regrettably, abortive, as I found the ingredients to be utterly unappetizing. 

In conclusion, if one's culinary preferences lean towards hastily prepared and inferior Mexican-American fare, then, perhaps, this venue may prove satisfactory. Nevertheless, I would strongly advise against entrusting one's dining experience to this establishment, as the likelihood of disappointment is, in my opinion, unacceptably high."

When I heard my manager said he was going to "treat himself" by going out to Blueberry Hill, I almost fell over in my chair. I mean, has he seen my other review of Blueberry Hill on Flamingo? Abhorrent! Wretched! This is a treat I would give to a used car salesman. Or Satan. Or someone else who's bad.

Nay nay, says he, you have to go to the one on Green Valley Parkway. It's 10,000 times better. I responded with a hearty "meh" and went back to work.

Today, however, I needed something to get the creative juices flowing, so I figured why not put Mr. Manager's words to the test. I got to the Blueberry Hill on Green Valley Parkway, and was promptly greeted and sat. In order to be most fair, I ordered exactly the same thing as I did at the last Blueberry Hill: Mexican-style chilaquiles and a Diet Pepsi. It was the same plate of mediocrity as the other one. I don't see how people rave about these places when I always seem to get plates full of mediocre.

On the upside, the service was a little faster. Not that much more friendly, but at least I wasn't waiting forever to get a refill on soda.

I'm sorry, I'm still not sold on these places. If I need comfort food ASAP, I'm sticking with Denny's.

"The multiplicity of sauces available at this establishment is rather unremarkable, and the diminutive size of the ribs, even in the case of baby back ribs, is certainly noteworthy. Furthermore, the other meaty accoutrements, including brisket (which, regrettably, exhibited an excessive degree of desiccation for my taste), pulled chicken, pulled pork, and smoked sausage, did not particularly impress. Notably, the sausage, which our server asserted was fabricated in-house, possessed a flavor profile strikingly reminiscent of a generic, mass-produced product, such as those obtainable from a Hillshire Farms packet purchased at Costco. The sole side dish that I consumed, the steak fries, while ostensibly possessing some semblance of skin, unfortunately, failed to deliver a palatable experience. In conclusion, there exist numerous superior options for barbecue enthusiasts in the Northwest Phoenix region."

Located on Fremont Street, and relatively proximate to the illustrious Golden Nugget, this establishment appears to have experienced more favorable days in the past. The sole motivation behind my visits to this venue is the affordable deep-fried Twinkies, which are available at an economical price point of 99 cents. Despite being cognizant of the fact that such culinary indulgences are not particularly beneficial for my health, I cannot resist the allure of deep-fried Twinkies. However, the cleanliness of the deep fry station and the quality of customer service could be improved. Specifically, the comment made by a staff member, "Don't forget my tip," struck me as somewhat brusque and unwarranted, thereby diminishing the likelihood of receiving a generous gratuity from me. In fact, the tip I left was a paltry 10% of the total bill.  

The ambiance of the establishment itself leaves much to be desired, with outdated slot machines that frequently malfunction and an overall atmosphere that seems to be in disrepair. Were it not for the antiquated gaming devices and the less-than-friendly demeanor of the staff, this venue might have garnered a more positive appraisal from me. As it stands, I would advise individuals who are interested in gambling or utilizing slot machines to avoid this location, as the wait times for assistance can extend up to 30-60 minutes. Nonetheless, the slushy drinks and deep-fried delights available at the rear of the establishment remain a redeeming feature.

The coffee is made to standard but the partners aren't very attentive or friendly. I've gone here a ton over the the past two years, at several times of day. I've tried engaging the barista in conversation and they tend to give short answer and that's it. The coffee and food is exactly what you would expect from Starbucks, though.

Just ate the seafood buffet tonight. It's not worth the price. The STEAMED crab legs were ok. The crab legs roasted in a sweet chile sauce was better. The cold crab legs near the cold seafood was a little salty. The lobster tails were small and slightly rubbery. But everything tastes better drowned in garlic butter.

The best part of this whole buffet was the desserts. The green tea cheesecake was nice and light. The creme brulee was just enough sweet and creamy to end a dinner. The bread pudding or whatever that was with the vanilla spice sauce was excellent.  The red velvet cupcakes were dry and tasted horrible.

Go somewhere else for the buffet. This one is very over rated.

For those with kids, it's not a very kid friendly place. The seating is a little tight. So, if you have anything larger than an umbrella stroller, it can be a hassle.

One star for the amount of food and options. One more star for the excellent service we received. But the rest, did not stand up to the hype we got about this place.

Not impressed. We went in around 4pm and there was only one table in there. Exterior was really original and set a good vibe, then we stepped inside and I felt like I was in a tattoo artists bedrooom. 

Took about 5-10 minutes for someone to come out of the kitchen to greet us and seat us which was not a good first impression. The salsa bar had good variety but was set up very poorly. The "togo" salsa containers you use to grab you salsas were so small you couldnt even fit a tortilla chip into it, We had to get a plastic spoon to get our salsa onto our chip because there was no metal utensils on the table. They didnt provide us little plates either so our table was a mess before we even started ordering.

As our tacos hit the table the first thing we noticed where that both mine and my husbands plates had big cracks on them. Flea market much?I got the smoked marlin taco which had the texture of canned tuna fish with a minestrone like vegetable concoction on top and the shrimp tacos, pretty decent. The corn tortillas were pretty flimsy though and resembled the storebought el paso brand.

Service was not the best either, our questions about the tacos were answered with finger pointing at the menu and blank looks like...uhh you dunno what achiote rojo is? 

All in all, the fact that we said we should have gone to chipotle instead says everything.

When I first started frequenting this place's Sunday night happy hour, I loved it.  I would go with a group of friends, and it was always a great time.  Over the last few months, I have seen a decline in the quality of food, service, and an increase in prices.  Happy hour is still pretty decent prices, and the food hasn't been bad, it just isn't as good as it used to be, unfortunate really.
Man, talk about an express rental of food, if you know what I mean.  I think this place is a little gimmicky and the food is just so so.

Nothing terribly memorable about this place. I'll admit that I wasn't as hungry as I should have been, and was kinda sorta recovering from a blackout the night before...so take the rating with a grain of salt, I suppose ^_^.

I got the breakfast buffet for about $15, which seems pretty standard for Vegas. Nothing really special about the buffet that I can remember, except that they had pizza, which made me really excited in the morning. Everything else was just your standard eggs, not-so-fresh bacon and sausage, hash browns, etc. I made it 3/4 through a plate before I grossed myself out, and I didn't get near my money's worth. 

But the service was great! My waitress gave me two big glasses of OJ so I didn't have to ask for another later hehe...very considerate. 

So yeah, if you're staying at the Planet Hollywood, it doesn't hurt to grab breakfast here. But I'd vie for breakfast over at Le Village Buffet in Paris instead *wink wink*

Cockroach crawled out of sprout plate... Killed it, hesitated to stay but did. They apologized, replaced food, charged me every cent for my food n to-go dinner. Used to come here every week, my fav pho diner, but I think I'll drive a little farther to Chinatown from now on...

Only because the male strippers were funny as hell just trying to be sexy but fuck... if we don't want a dance from you don't bother us... HIS NAME IS CHILI... ugly as hell guy who kept trying to give us deals so he can dance for us.. which none of us wanted... some of the guy dancers were really nice though.. I met a guy who was from San Jose, CA pretty funny.. but seriously main room girl dancers NO FUCKING SEATS.. WTF.. but we kept getting asked to join the guys who had bachelor parties but we didn't wanna sit with them.. and saw a guy getting a hand job by some ugly stripper... HAHHAHA.

The most awesome part of Pasqual's is their salsa -- mild, medium, hot, love it all. I think at one point in history they even called themselves a \"salsaria.\" The salsa makes me want to salsa dance even though I know I can't dance and I'm not even sure what salsa dancing is. That is how good it is, which is precisely why I'm so disappointed in Pasqual's today. With a large plate of nachos, they serve about a tablespoon of salsa in a tiny little cup. This happened last time, too, so we ordered extra salsa, but we got the same tiny little tablespoon cup. The chicken, the beef, the nachos, the tacos here are 3-star stuff, but I truly believe it's the salsa that makes it so. Gimme more!

Went this evening with a family member and ordered the $20 dinner for two.   Ordered the guacamole appetizer which was their tortilla chips (yum) and guacamole with corn, according to the waitress, no jalapeno's and not spicy.  First bite into the guac....whoa....5 alarm fire in my mouth.  It was full of jalapenos!!! and other spicy things. Then we got the 6 oz. sirloin, mine was well done as i requested but really burnt on one side.  It came with loaded mashed potatoes, which were great, and broccoli with god knows what they put on it, tasted very foul and rancid.  Service is always poor there and I don't know why I went back.  Today was my last visit there.
Horrible Service. Extremely slow to seat us... and feed us... and water us... and bill us... slooooow.\nWe won't be going back.

"Deplorable. With an uppercase 'B'. 

Based on the pizza we obtained, I find it challenging to believe that the individual responsible for its preparation has ever stepped foot in a pizza establishment within the NY/NJ region, let alone possess any familiarity with the culinary traditions of New York-style pizza. 

We placed an order for a half meatball, half pepperoni pizza, anticipating a product that at least vaguely resembled the depiction on the menu. However, what we received was a pizza that barely qualified as a distant cousin of the iconic Domino's franchise, albeit at a significantly higher price point. The crust was thick and doughy, the sauce more akin to a concentrated tomato paste than an actual sauce, and the cheese was overcooked to an unpleasant degree. Furthermore, the'meatball' topping consisted of ground beef haphazardly scattered across the cheese, rather than sliced meatballs as advertised. 

In short, a truly regrettable experience. My expectations were high, hoping to discover another authentic NY-style pizzeria in our town. Unfortunately, this particular establishment falls woefully short of meeting such standards. We shall continue to patronize our established favorites, leaving this disappointing venture to those who are less discerning in their culinary pursuits."

"Determined to procure sustenance via the drive-thru, I embarked upon an ill-fated culinary excursion. The inexperienced employee manning the window exhibited a profound lack of familiarity with the menu, leading to an interminable delay before I was able to place my order. Upon being instructed to advance to the pickup area, I endured an additional prolonged wait, during which time I could detect the pungent aroma of onion rings emanating from my vehicle. Upon arriving home, I discovered that the putrid scent had permeated not only the exterior of my food items but also the taste, rendering the ice cream unpalatably saccharine. Following a brief and futile attempt to consume the tainted dessert, I was compelled to desist, lest I succumb to a diabetic seizure, and instead opted to quench my thirst with water."

Food can be iffy some times. 
I usually order piccatta, and the one and only time I had their veal, it was very tough. 

Food is over priced, the atmosphere is the only thing going for this place.

Staff needs to be upgraded and trained all around.
In personality, service, and knowledge. 

Went to the bar and asked for a mojito. Bartender said she "couldn't" make it. When the manager (I believe his name is Mike or something... blonde.... light complexion.) came around and asked how we were doing, I had brought up the bartender not having the supplies to make drinks... Like a full bar should. He challenged me, by letting me know that they have fresh mint and it is capable.

Well, I got my 'mojito'. 
Makes me wonder if the bartender was telling me she couldn't make it because of the mint.... or that she COULDN'T make it...... because...... gag.

Last June, I set up a birthday of about 16 for my husband's birthday. I made a reservation at least a week in advance. Waiter / busser would throw the bag of bread on the table, and then hide. They could barely be found. Had to beg for refills.


We have had one great waiter in the 3 years we have been eating there, and that is only because I took my pregnant self and spoke to the manager and complained hardcore. He told me to make a reservation with him, he comp'd our meal, and I'm sure that is why we were treated so nice.

Customer service : I was not greeted when I walked in and there were two people standing there. One made direct eye contact with me and said nothing. The other woman said hello after I stared at the menu for a bit and asked me what she could get for me. I said I was not sure so she just walked away. \n\nFood: I ordered the number two lunch special which is a slice of cheese pizza, a salad and a fountain drink for 6 dollars. The sauce on the pizza was too sweet for my liking and the dough was too soggy. The salad was good, it was just lettuce, cherry tomatoes and carrots with a balsamic vinaigrette.

decent place. tvs, outside seating, and a roll of paper towels hanging on every table! i'm definitely a fan of pizza and beer, only you have to drink the beer there (draft- pretty good!), so take out doesn't afford that combination.  they have wine too.  their appetizers seem good, but i just had the pizza (with veggie toppings) which was just ok.  nothing too special here... maybe its location.

I come from the San Gabriel Valley... so of course my standards for dim sum is a lot higher than the average Joe. With that said, this restaurant's food was terrible. I could tell that some of the food was the microwaveable kind and none of it tasted flavorful or fresh. The skin of the Har Gow and Shau Mai was practically melting and falling apart. The white rice cake dessert that I love love love, was also falling apart. It all tasted overly cooked/steamed and had no flavor. I guess if you are in Vegas and want dim sum, then this is a good option for you. As for me, I do not plan on coming back.

Unfortunately my apartment complex caught fire, and I was forced to stay here temporarily.  My daughter, I and two cats came here. I asked for a \"handicap\" room, as my knee had gone out. While the neighborhood isn't the greatest, the train noise can be bothersome.  However, I loved the safety bars installed throughout the bathroom as I had troubles walking. \n\nOverall if I had to do it again, I'd stay at the Scottsdale location.

The place looks attractive from the outside and the inside. It was not full but a bit noisy on a Friday night, so we sat down on the (quieter) heated patio. The meal started well, with good bread and fresh salads. It went down from there. Overall, serving smaller portions of higher quality food would be the way to go.\nWe had spanakopita as a starter. Three pretty large pieces -- glad we ordered just one plate for two. It looked like a \"pocket pizza\". Too much \"cream cheese\"; I don't think it was feta. I missed the light layers of phyllo crust we should have gotten. \nThen we had the regular (beef) gyro and the chicken gyro, served with potatoes and rice. Potatoes were more like fries. I did not feel like having something that fat, I ate just a few pieces and was disappointed. The rice was not impressive--and the chicken gyro was not either. My husband liked the meal better than I did--I think he had read reviews of the place beforehand and his expectations were not too high. The service was good, the pace of the meal was good too. But I don't think I'll go back.
They are kind of hidden in Scottsdale Quarters upstairs next to Tanzy and iPic, so don't give up when looking for them!

I was disappointed with this place not because of the massage; which was good but this establishment has no staff. The masseuse is the receptionist, manager, and janitor. Every time a new customer comes in my masseuse leaves and arranges the massages for the customer. What was a hour massage took 90 min. We actually found this place after having AYCE Sushi at the end of the strip center, but I will not be back.

Peanut butter jelly time?  I think not!  Not sure why the PB&J is only part of the lunch menu, but if you want one for your child before 11 am, don't count on it.  The two employees were unwilling to convey anything to management (which we believe was utilizing the nearby couches for leisure activities) that it is more practical to prepare a PB&J rather than a smoothie.  The employees only knew to state that it was against company policy to create a PB&J before 11 am.  Anyway, I requested an egg sandwich with tomato and turkey and it was a rather unremarkable sandwich in that I could have easily prepared the same dish at home, but with superior quality due to the availability of Tobasco.  I inquired about Tobasco but was instead offered their homemade "chili" sauce, which possessed a flavor profile akin to pureed sundried tomatoes combined with chili powder.  While it was not unpalatable, I do enjoy the piquant sensation of Tobasco when consumed in conjunction with eggs.  Anywhoo, if that was indeed management relaxing on the couches, then shame on them for not defending their stringent PB&J policy and investing in a bottle of Tobasco!

I genuinely aspired to relish this establishment, given its favorable evaluations and reasonable happy hour prices...nonetheless, I simply did not.

The embellishment of the interior appeared somewhat deficient, and the booths were not particularly comfortable. The hospitality was adequate, yet not exceptional.

We opted for the Gyoza, which proved to be moderately satisfying. However, it was pan-fried instead of being deeply fried, thereby diminishing its crunchiness. Additionally, we requested a volcano roll and a rainbow roll; regrettably, the latter failed to impress, as the shrimp was somewhat rubbery, while the avocado exhibited a faintly aged flavor. Notably, they served us a thunder roll by mistake, rather than the volcano roll we had actually ordered. Although I had deliberated between the two options, I presumed it was my error and chose not to contest it. Nonetheless, upon inspecting the receipt, it became apparent that we had, in fact, ordered the correct item. The thunder roll was merely average. The tea and miso soup were, however, quite palatable.

In conclusion, our dining experience was merely mediocre, leaving us unimpressed and disinclined to revisit the restaurant.

"The sole reason for this establishment garnering a rating of two stems from my previous dining experiences here, whereupon the culinary offerings proved to be exceptional. However, on this particular visit, the service was subpar, to say the least. Upon entering, we were greeted promptly, yet the subsequent seating process transpired with a palpable sense of normalcy. As the restaurant gradually began to fill with patrons, our server seemed to vanish without a trace, leaving us to await her return for an interminable duration. Our initial beverages arrived in a timely fashion; the French press, in particular, was a delight to the taste buds. Nevertheless, the ensuing delay in service became increasingly pronounced, with five, ten, and ultimately fifteen minutes lapsing without any discernible attention being bestowed upon our table. My expectations for a more attentive experience remained unfulfilled, as the waitstaff continued to engage in leisurely conversation amongst themselves, oblivious to our presence. Ultimately, I elected to terminate my dining experience prematurely and depart the establishment, feeling disappointed and underwhelmed by the stark contrast in quality between this visit and my previous encounters with Postinos. It is with regret that I must conclude that I shall not be returning to the central location in the future."

I am an ardent devotee of Cirque du Soleil, having had the privilege of witnessing no less than six of their extraordinary productions, including the captivating O, the enthralling Ovo, the mystifying Mystere, the enchanting Quidam, the spellbinding Zarkana, and the mesmerizing Dralion. My curiosity was piqued by the notion of Zumanity, as the prospect of experiencing the sensual aspect of Cirque du Soleil resonated with the adult-themed ambiance of Las Vegas, which I was encountering for the first time since attaining the age of majority. Admittedly, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as I did not find the acrobatic feats to be as awe-inspiring as those showcased in many of the other Cirque shows. Furthermore, the choreography and musical accompaniment did not strike me as particularly memorable. Nonetheless, I must acknowledge that the comedic talents of the "clown" hosts of Zumanity did succeed in eliciting laughter from the audience, especially through their engagement with the crowd. The experience afforded by Zumanity diverges significantly from that of its Cirque counterparts, boasting a far more intimate atmosphere. For instance, the theater's diminutive size and the performers' warm greetings upon entry serve to create a sense of proximity and familiarity. It is worth noting that premium seating in the front row can ensure a heightened level of interaction during the performance, making it a factor to consider when booking tickets for Zumanity.

I liked the bar tops and the fact that it was nicely lit at this pub...that's about it.  Wait, the fries were pretty good...

My bf's brother got the fish sandwich with a side of wilted salad.  Yes, wilted because they had put the salad on the same plate as the fish sandwich, and the plate must have been placed under the heat lamp for quite some time prior to making it to our table.

I had the fish and chips, and again, I must admit that the garlic fries were pretty good.  The fish however, was not as good as I had hoped it to be.  The batter did not hold to the fish.  It was not fluffy and airy with the crisp to it.   

My boyfriend had the Bangers, bean and mash.  All three of us came to the agreement that the bangers tasted like breakfast sausage.  Very underwhelmed.

Will I be coming back to this Firkin place (which is a chained pub btw), highly doubted.

The food was excellent but it was very expensive for the portion sizes. For three of us at lunch, the bill before tip was $105 & we didn't even have drinks. Service was good too but again I can't justify the price.

"Peruse the critiques and it was a close call, albeit an unsuccessful endeavor, as we opted for the New York steak and veal scaloppini, in addition to a few mixed drinks...The steak, priced at thirty dollars per plate, was replete with excess fat and gristle, while my veal, which was cooked in a manner that did not resemble the traditional preparation of scallopini, was similarly marred by an unpalatable sauce that was overly reminiscent of gravy and brown in color...My martini, recommended by our server, possessed a saccharine quality, yet lacked the depth of flavor one would expect from such a beverage...Although the service was commendable, it is unlikely that we would revisit this establishment, given the plethora of alternative dining options available."

Sat at the bar for a quick glass of wine and to order some food to go. I ordered A glass of red wine. It was good, i don't know if it was worth 9$ a glass though. The bartender seemed a little mad I wanted half spinach, half romain on my Cesar salad. I'm picky, but I am nice about it. We ordered the spinach pear Gorgonzola pizza. It came out cold, and wasn't that amazing. Probably wouldn't come back.

I was staying at the Hilton Grand Vacations across the street and down a way. I ended up gambling at the Riviera every day. Most bartenders at the poker bar are very nice and helpful. Many of the dealers are just nasty! James and Bruce are awesome. After losing hundreds to Tang, without even a smile, I wonder why anyone would keep going back to 3 card poker. If I was with the guys and not my family, I would never play here!

"I am utterly dumbfounded by my decision to expend in excess of thirteen dollars for a duo of frothy beverages, which, while palatable, did not possess any extraordinary qualities that would have justified such an exorbitant price tag, particularly in light of the fact that similar products are readily available at a fraction of the cost in other establishments within the vicinity of Gilbert."

I was here recently with 4 friends after an Overture show.  The food was quite good, at least what we ate of it.  On a few occasions the server cleared the plates when there was still food on them.  The worst part of our experience was out waiter.  One woman is 8 months pregnant and ordered an mojito without rum.  The waiter looked at her with the most confused look and said \"so, you want it with vodka then?\".  She finally got it through to him that she wanted it without alcohol.  So then our bill came and we were charged $11 for this virgin mojito (the normal price with alcohol).  We asked him about this charge and he stated that there was no button for this drink without alcohol and the charge was for the mint and the labor.  We asked him to check with a manager, we waited 10 minutes and no manager came to our table.  So, we paid and left....angry.

We parked here and validated the ticket ourselves at the machine by the cashiers. When we left, we were told that parking was $3 and the validation was only for 3 hours. What? Boo.

I got propositioned by a weird tattoo shop owner outside the bathrooms. He had some silicon implants shaped like stars in his forehead. Weird.

We were gonna go to this "College Night" at the Canyon Club since one of our friends didn't have an ID and it was 18+ but they were charging a $10 cover. What the HECK? For underage people? What a rip-off, man. We just left.

Welcome to an excellent case study in why a nice property in a desirable, high-traffic location would be more than half empty during dinner.  Exhibit A: Three empty-headed hostesses so busy bantering wittily with themselves that it took them over two minutes to acknowledge my existence.  Exhibit B: I ordered a glass of Pinot and it tasted like it had been opened sometime during prior year.  I mentioned to bartender who said \"no, I just opened it\" rather than offering a replacement.  And what a Happy Hour: $1 off -- can they spare it?  Dinner portions were excellent, but food was mediocre, other than the super croissants: warm and delicious, but nowhere near enough to make up for the rest of the experience.  With so many other superb options in Scottsdale, I can't see this place lasting another year.  Spend your hard-earned money elsewhere.

This marked my second visitation to Tee Pee Mexican Food, and the experience proved to be somewhat analogous to the initial encounter, with only minor divergences. It is worth mentioning that this establishment boasts a rich history, having been in operation for an extended period of time. Upon arriving during the lunch hour on a weekend preceding Christmas, the waiting time was not excessively prolonged. The service provided by our server was quite expeditious and cordial. The salsa presented was replete with flavor, yet the vessel containing the complementary chips (while still hot) housed some of the smallest and most fragmented examples of such culinary delights. My green corn tamale was regrettably served at a temperature that could be described as suboptimal, bordering on frigid. The accompanying rice and beans were merely average in quality. In contrast, my spouse's carne asada burrito displayed slightly more promise, although it would not require an excessive amount of effort to reach such a level. If one finds themselves in a state of extreme craving, this venue may be worthy of consideration for its salsa, margaritas, or perhaps even a refreshing cold beer. However, it is advisable to temper expectations regarding the remaining aspects of the dining experience.

Don't go on a Thursday night! \n\nThey only open up the rooftop portion of the club and unless you are doing bottle service you'll be corralled into the center of the patio at least 15 ft away from the railing where all the good Vegas and people watching views are.  I was very disappointed with this club. I thought this was Vegas. Nightlife is suppose to be their thing. I've been to better clubs (even on a Thursday night) in Austin. The XS nightclub on a Friday night is ten times better. Don't even waste your time on Pure unless you can get in free on a Saturday night.

We visited this establishment on a previous occasion with our family while vacationing in Las Vegas and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves; thus, we were eager to return and partake in their culinary offerings once again. Upon our arrival, we opted for the all-you-can-eat option, and my father even overindulged to the point of experiencing discomfort. Needless to say, we were excited to revisit this restaurant and sample their delectable dishes.

Upon our return, we decided to commence our meal with alligator tail as an appetizer, which proved to be a delicious choice. However, the all-you-can-eat platters we customarily order were not as satisfying, particularly towards the beginning of the meal. It became apparent that the oil utilized for frying our fish and shrimp was not fresh, leading to an unpleasant taste. Fortunately, as our meal progressed and new batches were brought out, the quality of the food improved, and we were able to enjoy our dining experience.

In light of the above, I inquired about the oil used and was informed by our waitress that the chef did indeed replace the old oil with fresh oil towards the end of our meal. While this was reassuring, it was disappointing to note that the salad bar was not well-maintained and lacked attention to detail regarding cleanliness. Additionally, it would be beneficial to have identical items on both sides of the buffet to facilitate navigation and minimize spills. Nonetheless, we appreciated the fact that the plates were kept chilled.

Despite some drawbacks, our server provided adequate service, fulfilling her responsibilities effectively. Unfortunately, our enthusiasm for this restaurant has waned due to the inconsistency in the quality of the food and ambiance. It is worth noting that this establishment opens at 5 pm, so patrons should plan their visits accordingly to avoid disappointment.

I only ate here since I was staying at the W. 

I will admit. hot waitresses. 
but then again, u are in montreal. so nothing new there.

welp. thats all that this restaurant has going for it. They really try to go for fancy french-inspired dishes but they end up just trying too hard. The flavors don't reaaaally work. 

can't really say much more.. 

breakfast is okay though. pass!

When we arrived at McCarren and went to get the rental car, I initially thought \"hey, I made the right choice.  Look at these 5-6 people ahead of me in line while either one person or no one was at the other rental car sections all around\".  Not the case.  Why?  Later in the weekend I needed a car again, and went with Budget that time.  Budget's price was just as good as Dollar's, and Budget had nicer cars available.  Meanwhile, in this first experience, Dollar only had two people behind the counter.  I don't think I've ever waited in a 5-6 person line for soooooooooooooooo long.  It became painfully frustrating to the point that I considered trying to cancel the reservation on my smartphone and schedule a whole new one at one of the other car rental agencies there.  Not cool Dollar!
Atmosphere is great! Food is not. Had the pasta w meatballs which consisted of a bowl of gummy flavorless pasta w 2 small meatballs for $15.00. I left hungry and went home and ate a PB&J sandwich.

Shopping in a mall has become a thing of the past for me, but I have a gift card that has been burning a hole in my pocket so we decided to do some good old-fashioned shopping in a department store. The store is pretty outdated and I was little disappointed by the lack of inventory to choose from. \n\nI was pretty sad by how little enjoyment I had in this shopping trip. It felt like more of a chore than anything.

Like a lot of the other yelpers on here, I visited because I saw it on Man Vs Food. 
We arrived about 11am, and although it didn't look busy we had to wait 10 minutes to be seated.

I can't fault our server, she was attentive, knowledgeable, and very friendly. 
We both ordered French Toast, and just had coffee to drink.

Yes the portions were huge, and they had loads of pecan nuts on top, but the toast itself wasn't anything amazing, and costs a lot more than Denny's!

I wasn't that impressed - if I did go again I think I'd try one of the Hash dishes.

Slightly better than dominos/pizza hut/little Caesars but the price doesn't pay for quality and amount of pizza. Save your money instead for another pizza place. Seriously 20 bucks for a medium sized pizza?

Don't go.

The lamest buffet I've ever participated in.

If you're staying at the Gold Coast, just walk accross the street to the Palms buffet.

At least the food didn't hurt me belly. For that, I give it two stars.

It's a "UPS" store.... you bring in a package... they take it... you wave goodbye to it... you leave.

Sometime after that a big Brown Truck arrives and wisks said package off to its destination. 

This UPS Store was unremarkable... the guy behind the counter did his job... nothing more nothing less.

During a singular excursion, I opted to partake in a beverage from the establishment known as Orange Julius; however, my endeavors were thwarted by the non-functional state of the machinery utilized for the preparation of said beverage. Subsequently, I returned to the aforementioned venue accompanied by a contingent of colleagues, only to discover that the chocolate cone, an item I had been eager to sample, was not accessible. It is worth noting that throughout both visits, I failed to discern a supervisory or managerial figure who might have facilitated a more streamlined and effective ordering and delivery process.

I love going out for breakfast, but there are a couple of reasons I won't go back here.  First of all, too expensive.  My girlfriend and I each had eggs benedict and coffees, and it was 40 bucks!  Second reason, the portions are huge.  I am always disappointed to see such huge portions coming out of a professional kitchen, because I realize how much food is headed toward the trash bin each day.  If you must serve such huge portions, please advise on the menu ahead of time.  \n\nThe most important reason I won't head back here...  unripened fruit as a garnish on my plate.  Just serve me what's in season please.  If it is in season, a tomato in summer for example, please make sure it's fresh, local, and ripe.  I was shocked when the waitress asked me if I wanted to add tomato to my dish and then she served me a hard, barely pink slice of tomato.  It's in season people!  Where did this tomato come from, South America?

I am a consummate Nordstrom's Rack shopper, whenever a new one opens within a 2 state area (California/Nevada) I try and make it out.  All of the best stuff seems to come when a new Rack opens.  I have been to upwards of 15 Nordstrom Racks and some are certainly better than other, however, none are worse than this one.  The Men's Department is laughably small and the selection is rubbish.  There was nothing at all that I could find to buy.  In fact I was so disheartened that I thought a little shopping might cheer me up and I went to the Rack in Henderson and purchased 2 sweaters.  I had high hopes for this new Rack but I doubt I will make the journey back out to Summerlin just for this store.  Very disappointed indeed.

After a night out and skipping dinner, we were starved! We really wanted to try the Mexican restaurant in Aria but they were closing (boo!). After asking which restaurants are still opened we chose Lemongrass. 

The decor is pretty and modern. The booths are hard to get into though! You cant just slide in. On the table they have a cup with wooden/bamboo chopsticks. I personally think if it was an upscale Asian restaurant they'd be pretty and reusable but that's my opinion. 

We ordered Tom Kha Chicken to start which was awesome. They didn't spoon the soup into individual bowls which I thought was odd. I guess I'm just use to Asian restaurants doing that. For our main course we had black pepper prawns, sweet and sour chicken, some kind of curry, and I think Chow Fun. All tasted good but weren't outstanding. I guess I've had better Thai/ Chinese food with better service for cheaper back home. But then again I have to give them credit for being open so late. 

After adding some sodas, beers, and white rice the total was well over $100. Overall I doubt I will return even for late night grub.

This place can make you a bit claustrophobic, especially if you've frequented the  LV North Premium Outlets. Here's how it sizes up:

-Easier to park (but you might get stuck in some traffic due to lack of stop lights)
-Indoors so you can find some sanctuary for those hot Vegas summers (but it feels kind of claustrophobic inside)
-A lot of store selections (but I feel like the selection is much bigger at the North outlets)
-More food options compared to North outlets, including surrounding food options
-lacks that "touristy" vibe, so less tourists looking lost or toting their luggage

Despite the hassles of the North outlets, I still feel like I'd rather shop there. Although it was nice being indoors, it was easier to get to the main stores we wanted to go to by walking outside the building, but our trip was ultimately a bust.

Overall a very blah place. The atmosphere is clean and positive, but the staff are not super friendly. The prices are competitive, but not the greatest. My manicure has a lot of air bubbles!!
