If she at least greeted us or said something other than \"hold on\" and \"here you go\" to me, then I might've given this place 3 stars, maybe even 4. Customer service can really do a lot for a place and I just didn't experience anything good here. I will, however, be back in the future since this is one of the only coffee shops by my house and I'm always on the prowl for some study spots.

I had appt with Doctor Meghan How ever she din't  show up as she was Sick I get it everyone gets Sick However that is not the Point..Front Desk Judy she just had a straight additude she was definitely not happy to be there Overall she is Unprofessional, i even over heard her go to the techs and told them how stupid I was and how I gave her additude and other Nonsense  **OVERALL** patients should NOT get Treated like this. I was mistreated I got to my appt in time I waited one Hour to get treated How ever the service that I received from the asst and Doctor Michaels was Excellent. Judy needs some training on how to treat the patients with respect and By being more proffesional the other girls there as well very Unprofessional they need to stop talking about patients as we can all hear what they say..

Went for Sunday brunch. Ordered a Western Omelet - it was ok. Others at my table got the all-you-can-eat buffet, and seemed to enjoy it - I think this is a quantity over quality kind of place.\nOne highlight was the hashbrown casserole - very tasty!

I have been here three times now. For some reason a lot of my coworkers really like it. It's a popular lunch-time destination. 

They are known for their southern, Louisiana style dishes. I would say it's just pretty typical, heaving-tasting foods. Their gyros are not bad actually, but the creole with shrimp and blacken fish I had as a lunch special were just too salty and heavy for me. I'm sure some who love their soul food would appreciate it, but it wasn't for me. 

It gets pretty crowded during lunch hours, and the spaces are quite tight.

"I requested the piquant shrimp dish, which was advertised as possessing an intense, fiery quality, but upon consumption, it failed to deliver on its promised potency, lacking both the anticipated pungency and savory depth of flavor, yet despite this culinary disappointment, I managed to enjoy myself, albeit in spite of the uninspiring gastronomic experience."
decent at best.  if you know real cajun this place won't impress you but for the lack of any other option it's passable.  the Rat Toes appetizer is pretty good.

I have loved this Fry's since it reopened last year.  I spend a lot of money here.  My last shopping experience was disappointing and frustrating.  I got home missing several items.  This is the 3rd time this has happened to me at this store.  When I talk to anyone in the store (most recently an asst. manager) about this there are no apologies.  All 3 times were like this.  \nA while ago, I purchased shrimp at Safeway and got it home to find it was spoiled, I returned to the store and the manager replaced double the shrimp and refunded my money.  Now, that's customer service.\nFry's may offer good prices but you can't put a price tag on good customer service.

I'm not sure when this started but tonight I noticed a sign that states from 9pm to 5am there is a 25 cent surcharge on every item sold. The establishment is open 24 hours. It's ridiculous that they would operate in this manner.  Are they paying their employees more in the evening? Highly doubtful. \n\nBread was delicious as usual. Hot and fresh.

Food was awesome but service was terrible.Went on NYE and waited 20 plus minutes for drinks which kinda set the tone for the dinner.Server was OK but the time from which we ordered to when we received our food was much to long.When I questioned the waiter I was told\" Its not my fault they are way behind in the kitchen\" .This is not the response I expect from a place like this.We may go back but why when there are so many other good steakhouses in Vegas.

Agave-how I wish it weren't so:
1. Terrible service- no hostess when we arrived. No utensils when we received our food. No server to take our payment. Everything was just slow. I'm wasn't in a hurry, but having to wait for everything makes any average person a little anxious.
2. Food- Crispy quesadillas - chicken and corn versions: nice corn masa shell but bland fillings. Then we had the fresh fish tacos. They were soggy and a mess. The fish had an old fishy flavor and I couldn't get past it. If I'm able to eat fish sauce like it's ketchup, I think I have a pretty good tolerance of seafood/ocean taste.
3. Ambience- surprisingly nice. From the exterior, I wouldn't never have thought it was that well put-together in the interior. It was a great blend of the colors, the lighting and a Large center bar. But I'm here for food first and thought did not impress.

Worst bar tenders in Charlotte. Inefficient, rude, and mess up a simple orders. I ordered 3 beers and ended up with 3 shots of Fireball. I told her I ordered 3 Two Hearted Ales, she left and I never got my beers even after a bar back told her I was still waiting for my order.
I don't think I saw an employee for the first 10 minutes I was in there. Once I basically ran into one he was helpful.

For Scotland's busiest, most important and the capital's train station it sure was pure chaos.  I took a taxi here to go down to London and the moment I went underground I was amazed at how unorganized this place seems.  Maybe me or maybe it was the construction that was going on.\n\nAll the usual amenities you would expect from a modern train station, you have a pub nearby, the snack shop and all of the other usual suspects are here.  The open roof feeling of being underneath main roads doesn't sit well with me, because it rains here and it is cold here more than it is warm so why an open roof. And being from California being underneath big things that can collapse just rubs me the wrong way, almost as much as finding out that the trains to London are on a track all by itself not with the others. They realize that people drink or wake up way too early to get on trips right?

4 stars for the young bear stuffer guy rockin the converse shoes, he tried his best to keep my birthday girl's attention. She just turned 2 (if you read my reviews she is the one that might be autistic or has adhd and is wild nutz) and she was just all over the place.

Now, this is where I have to take off a star... at the check out... my daughter had a build a bear purse that she stuffed with hearts (both the purse and hearts were BAB, I was not buying them). I quickly snatched it without her looking and put it behind my me and on top of a shelf.... obviously so my daughter would not see it and scream. Well Mr. Lazy from behind the counter (not my cashier) starts yelling MAAAAM give it to me and I will put it away...  HERE GIVE THAT TO ME AND I WILL PUT IT BAAAAAACK. My daughter started wondering what he was yelling about and she was looking around. 
The guy was ridiculous, my husband was paying and he even turned around to see what the guy was yelling at.
2x I replied to him that I didn't want her to see it and then I just walked away.

That jackass should know if a mother tries to hide something away from a child that he should not create a scene. All he had to do was put it back after we left.
I like the back area of the bar outside. The music is pretty good. Didn't get to stay there long. I'll have to try it again some time.

I grew up in Las Vegas so I've been here a zillion times. The security lines can be long during peak travel times (Fri and Sun afternoons), there's a nice variety of food chains and random and expensive stores. I always pray I get to fly out of the A and B gates since it is waaaay less crowded and there's never a line for security. Since it's a big airport, it can take a long time to get from your car to checking in your luggage to your gate, so allow for some extra hiking time. \nOf course there's cheesy Las Vegas crap all over the place and slot machines, but that's what makes this place so... Vegas. The TSA clowns are usually pretty easy-going and apparently the taxi lines are realllly long. So save time ad hire a limo. It probably costs about the same. Also, free Wi-Fi!!

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the delectable offerings of this esteemed establishment on a previous occasion, specifically for a midday repast, and I must say that the culinary experience was truly remarkable. However, my most recent visit, which took place in the evening and was intended to celebrate a dear friend's anniversary of their birth, unfortunately did not live up to my lofty expectations. Our group, which consisted of numerous individuals, gathered in the bar area and occupied the three central tables, which were situated at a considerable height. It is worth noting that the server appeared to be responsible for attending to both the bar patrons and certain tables in the dining area, which may have contributed to the sluggish pace of service that we encountered. 
 After placing my order for a beverage, I waited for an extended period of time, approximately twenty minutes, before it was brought to my attention. It is worth noting that a companion's culinary selection, which was placed at roughly the same time as my drink order, arrived a full ten minutes prior to the arrival of my beverage. Furthermore, our proximity to the bar area did little to expedite the delivery of our orders. Upon inspecting the menu, I discovered that the advertised drink did not align with my expectations, as it was described as a martini-style beverage but was instead presented in a wine glass and possessed a sickly sweet flavor profile. Consequently, I chose to return the drink to the server and requested an alternative selection. Unfortunately, the second drink took an additional fifteen minutes to arrive, further contributing to my disappointment. 
 It is worth noting that the menu selections for dinner, specifically the small plates and entrees, left much to be desired. As a group, we were interested in ordering several shareable dishes, but the options listed on the menu did not appear to lend themselves well to sharing. Moreover, it seemed that every dish featured bacon as an ingredient, which may not appeal to all diners. Additionally, the prices listed for the entrees struck me as somewhat exorbitant, particularly the tilapia dish, which carried a price tag of twenty-two dollars. 
 In conclusion, while my previous experience at this establishment was thoroughly enjoyable, my most recent visit fell short of my expectations. However, I would still consider returning for brunch, as my past experience has shown that this meal period offers a more satisfying culinary experience.

Ah. This place kills me......for two reasons. Firstly, it USED to be amazing...Then all of a sudden, the quality of the food and service kind of crashed. And secondly, what kind of restaurant DOESN'T ALLOW YOU TO TAKE YOUR FOOD TO GO?!??! This is the reason I won't be back. I had gone there with a friend, and we ordered and appetizer to share and then a main dish each. I had the veal with mushroom sauce which in the past was pretty amazing. However, halfway through that dish, I got full (shocking, I know). At the end of our meal, both of us asked for the rest of our dishes to be packed to go and we were told by a very unhappy woman that this would not be possible. Either eat it all here, or too bad. It was SHOCKING. So.....although the food is ok, I won't be returning here. I don't like feeling ripped off, and the fact that they won't give you the rest of your paid-for food, makes me feel totally ripped off.  :|

I must have driven past Franks A Lot one hundred times before I ever thought to give it a chance.  Franks is on the east side of the road that becomes, airlane, right behind the airport.  As I take airlane to work every morning to avoid a few lights, I kept seeing Franks and finally decided to try it for lunch.  

What can I say? A solid hot dog, great price point and an EXTREMELY friendly staff. I haven't pegged if its a family running it from front to back, but I think it is and let me say, they do it well.  There is a drive through as well as basic patio seating.  Make note, they only take cash, but don't worry your lunch wont be more than six or seven dollars anyways.  

Their specialty is the Chicago dog, which is covered in onion, celery salt, sports peppers, and tomatoes.  Grab a side of their freshly made french fries and you are out the door, loving life.  Their menu extends to service polish sausage, cheese fries and even a philly cheese steak, but I have remained loyal to my Chicago dog....for now.  

If you happen to find yourself in the area, I say check it out.

"In the event of a cerebral explosion occurring within the confines of Grandmother's cognitive faculties on a lazy Sunday afternoon, the resulting scenario would closely resemble a sprawling, chaotic array of artistic paraphernalia, replete with an assortment of vibrant paints, versatile adhesives tailored for diverse surfaces and materials, an array of brushes in varying sizes and shapes, picture frames in assorted dimensions and forms, seasonal artistic endeavors, beads and bedazzlers, candles in abundance, irregularly shaped styrofoam blocks, construction paper, wooden shelving units susceptible to staining or coloration according to one's preference, artificial floral arrangements, glass containers, and other miscellaneous crafting supplies. Moreover, for those who harbor an ardent passion for scrapbooking, a visit to Michael's store would likely transpire as a veritable dream come true, offering an extensive array of materials and tools designed to facilitate the creation of unique, personalized mementos."
Bartender was a heinous miserable female but the drinks were bomb!  I would go back just for the gnarly drinks but the service was totally Yucca yucca!

Brass turns into "The Beat" on First Fridays. I'll be back! First Friday is now cool to go to again.

LOCATION: Fremont of course. But instead of being down on Fremont its up on Fremont! (huh?) :) Its actually situated above Hennesy's Tavern. Head upstairs because that's where the party's at. There's a balcony so all you smokers can have a smoke break and watch the crazies walk Fremont. If you want to leave, no problem, Beauty Bar, Vanguard, Insert Coins is just right across Las Vegas Blvd so you can bar hop and mob the rest of downtown. 

MUSIC: I think KidFunk was on decks. And he did not disappoint. It was a constant stream of good tracks. Lots of house & tech house, dropped some electro and dubstep. It was a good night! There's a decent size dance floor for the size of the place. I only went into the main room but on the other side there's an even larger room with a different DJ, possibly different music too? If they keep it up I'll make this a regular stop on First Friday.

BATHROOMS: Were filthy and disgusting. Drinks and other unmentionables all over the floor. Be sure to check if there's toilet paper before you pop-a-squat. The dispensers were always empty so grab a handful of paper towels before you go in.

GOGO: The gogo(s) were 100% disappointing, sorry. Both in looks and in dancing.

GUYS: No dress code, no cover when I went.

Don't forget to RATE & FOLLOW! ;)

Despite my reservations based on the unfavorable reviews, I opted to give this establishment a chance, and my experience validated the prevailing sentiment. The ambiance was visually appealing, but the lavatory presented an unconventional layout. The hand dryer was situated on a single faucet, prompting a sequence of inconvenient delays for patrons awaiting their turn to utilize the facilities while attempting to operate the cumbersome dryer. Furthermore, the absence of sanitary disposal units within the stalls necessitated a departure from the stall to discard items in the central waste receptacle, posing an additional challenge for female patrons. 

My culinary selection was a vegetarian burger, which, although flavorful, was diminutive in stature, inviting comparisons to a slider. The accompanying fries were palatable, yet their portion size was standard, rendering the supplementary fee seemingly unwarranted. Moreover, the minuscule dimensions of the water glasses necessitated a deliberate sipping motion, akin to savoring a fine wine. Following my meal, I remained unsatisfied, capable of consuming a medium-sized popcorn at the cinema without difficulty. 

Regrettably, I must conjecture that this dining establishment may struggle to flourish, given its steep prices and inadequate serving sizes. A revision of their pricing strategy or generosity of portions seems imperative to justify the cost. Notably, the absence of an option to augment the vegetarian patty was conspicuous.

"For individuals who find themselves confined to the vicinity of the convention center, this establishment serves as an adequate venue for consuming alcoholic beverages and traditional pub fare. 

As a scholar pursuing an advanced degree, I have had the occasion to visit this drinking establishment on two separate occasions, concurrent with my attendance at a conference. 

The jalapeno poppers and onion rings possess a certain appeal, while the buffalo wings, though unremarkable, contribute to the overall culinary experience. 

During sporting events, the atmosphere within the establishment becomes particularly convivial, as the large gathering of patrons enhances the sense of camaraderie. 

Therefore, if one finds oneself in the vicinity of the convention center, bereft of transportation and yearning for a beer and snacks, this location is worthy of consideration."

"My dedication towards Sakana remained unwavering for an extensive period of time, up until the momentous occasion of my son's birth. The advent of parenthood introduced a new paradigm, rendering the indulgence of sushi excursions somewhat impractical. Following a hiatus of three years, my spouse and I decided to revive our customary date night ritual by revisiting Sakana. Alas, the experience did not live up to our recollections. The chefs' demeanor exhibited a perceptible shift, manifesting in limited conversation and recommendations, which contrasted starkly with their previously warm and engaging nature. Notwithstanding this disappointment, the scallop dynamite proved to be a resounding highlight, boasting an unparalleled quality that eclipsed all other instances of its kind within the Valley. Likewise, the oranges served as a sweet finale, eliciting nostalgic sentiments that lingered long after the meal's conclusion. It is plausible that my prolonged absence may have unwittingly elevated my expectations, leading to a disparity between reality and my idealized memories."

I like to go here to grab some subs on the way to the river, since it's between our house and the 17. Just because I don't want to go to Subway or Blimpie's.

Mostly, it's a rather expansive Italian market. Need olive oil? They have 20+ different kinds. Pasta? There's a whole aisle. How about one of those wooden thingies for making gnocchi. Got that too.

In the back, a counter runs along the whole length of the back wall. That's where you'll find all sorts of cheeses, cold cuts, and sausauge, plus a few sweets. 

It's also where you order sandwiches. And you'd better know exactly what your want, and fast. The man behind the counter is perpetually surly and curt. It gets worse if you stand there and try to make heads or tails of all the hand-written sandwich combinations taped to the wall. Luckily, the woman who runs the cash register is always very sweet. So that kind of makes up for it.

I want to love their sandwiches. I just don't. They're OK. The meat is always really good, there just isn't enough of it. Maybe I'm just not ordering the right things. 

Until then, I'll continue to support Romanelli's, but they'll only get a so-so rating for the deli. The product selection, however, is top notch.

This establishment provides an adequate dining experience, boasting an agreeable ambiance, commendable customer service, and satisfactory diversion. While the culinary offerings are of acceptable quality, they fail to surpass expectations considering their cost. Specifically, the steaks possess a somewhat advanced stage of maturity, which may not align with my personal preference. However, the potatoes prepared au gratin style prove to be delectable. A diverse selection of wines, suitable for various financial constraints, graces the menu. It remains a viable option for those seeking a pleasant repast within the confines of Green Valley Ranch, although I would advocate for numerous steakhouses located along the Las Vegas Strip instead.

$4 OPI!  Read Carina's review, b/c I didn't want to pay $8.50 at Ulta... geez, so cheap... alot of the OPI colors already have separated (heat?  age?) so make your choice for price over quality... I'm so cool for $4 though.\n\nOn the same end where China Magic Noodle is, same plaza as Lee Lee's.

"We opted to partake in an early evening repast and selected the Pot Roast Sandwich from the menu. Upon the arrival of our meal, we noticed that the accompanying vegetables were not adequately cooked, retaining a raw texture. Notwithstanding, the meat component of the dish was delectable. Following my communication of this observation to our server, she expressed that such an occurrence was indeed commonplace and proffered an additional side dish as compensation. Although appreciative of her efforts to rectify the situation, I couldn't help but feel somewhat muted by the implication that this was a frequent phenomenon. My spouse, on the other hand, relished his chili burger immensely. Furthermore, the beverages we requested were remarkably potent. It is worth mentioning that this establishment tends to experience a high volume of patrons, and it is possible that our choices did not align with the culinary strengths of the restaurant."

Had a carne assada torta.  It was actually not bad.  For the price it was real good.

A few comments/observations...

- Comically unorganized. There is no process for how this place works.  I got my food but if they actually had something that resembled organization I would have got it a lot sooner.

- The grill was a bit on the dirty side.

- The meat while ok was a bit on the fatty/chewy side.  Chopping it into smaller pieces would have been helpful

- Not the cleanest dining area.

Not really a 3, but not a 2 either.  I gave them the benefit of the doubt.

Sat at the bar, no music or sound on the TVs, after I asked for the second time some music was turned on, some sort of low sounding reggae I think, could barely hear it. No food on the happy hour menu, $3 Cuba Libra's, I enjoyed those. Didn't sample the food. Might come back not sure yet.

"Given our considerable distance from the French Quarter, my stomach infrequently impels me towards Cajun cuisine; furthermore, owing to the limited dining options within our vicinity, this establishment emerges as the de facto venue for satisfying my periodic craving for gumbo; while the quality of the fare may be marginally superior to the local average, the tariffs charged are somewhat elevated relative to our expectations."

"I recently had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to this esteemed eatery, and while my experience was largely satisfactory, I must confess that it failed to surpass my expectations in certain aspects. Notwithstanding the captivating ambiance created by the restaurant's meticulously designed interior, I found the variety of options available to be somewhat limited. However, I must commend the establishment for maintaining a high standard of quality in their offerings, and the judicious utilization of individual portion control containers served to enhance the overall dining experience. Nonetheless, I cannot help but feel that this buffet fell short of exceptional, particularly when compared to other superior alternatives in the area. Furthermore, I must express my gratitude for having avoided the weekend buffet, which several patrons have described as overpriced and underwhelming. Instead, we opted for the more reasonably priced Monday brunch option, which, while satisfying, ultimately proved insufficient in satiating my gastronomic desires. In conclusion, while this buffet may boast an impressive physical appearance, its lackluster selection and uninspired menu left me feeling unfulfilled and eager to explore alternative dining options."

Dude, totally didn't realize how many lesboz are in Vegas. But they're like the totally stereotypical mullet-wearing, jean vest with ripped sleeves wearing, big arms type of galz. You know, have you seen that movie Monster with Christina Ricci and Charlize Theron? Well, that type.

Am I seriously the only hot one? Hehe jk.

Sushi's alright. But who pays $15-17 for a roll of fish?
For that money, you can go to Oakland and get yourself some
V
V
V
V
V

"The visual representation of the culinary items, specifically the burgers, appeared remarkably striking and potentially harmful to one's health, yet the serving sizes were surprisingly reasonable and easily consumable by a group of five individuals. Our party opted to share several dishes, including the sashimi 'won-tacos,' triple T fries, the signature ringer burger, and the bacon mac-n-cheese burger. It is worth mentioning that we could have easily accommodated an additional menu item. My personal preferences were the fries and the classic burger, as the former offered an exceptional crispiness and an abundance of truffle flavor, particularly the aioi variety. In contrast, the original burger boasted the flavors I find most appealing, although the bacon mac-n-cheese alternative presented a unique and worthwhile combination. While the burgers at this establishment may slightly surpass the average burger in terms of quality, they fail to rank among my top choices for repeated consumption. In fact, I would argue that Bachi burger or even Holsteins offers a superior dining experience. Unfortunately, the tacos were a disappointment, characterized by a minuscule portion of tuna and a lack of creativity. Ultimately, my assessment of this restaurant leads me to conclude that it is only worth visiting for a beer and a side of their delectable fries."

While the desserts are tasty and well made. The prices and service is not. 

You could tell everyone working their just WISHED they were somewhere else at the moment. They could care less about actually serving you unless you asked for help. 

We ordered the sweet trio and my friend told the worker if we could get the second one as the first one was damaged. For some reason she told another worker to do it instead and did not relay the message at all. It was only after we paid and were seated that we noticed that the dessert was damaged and had to bring it back for them to give us another. 

Though not very difficult, we shouldn't have had to deal with that to begin with.

"Alright, so I had to perform an upgrade. 

I was physically present at the BuyBack$ site in Henderson, near the Galleria Mall, when we were unable to locate the desired item. 

As a result, we contacted the Decatur location to determine whether or not they possessed the film we were seeking on Blu-ray. 

Of course, they did! They possess everything; it's unquestionable. 

We then inquired whether they could retain the product for us, stating that we would arrive shortly to collect it since we were located across town but en route. 

Therefore, we drove across the city, and you know what happened? 

These individuals had the audacity to inform us that the item was, in fact, being held for another person. They asserted that it had been previously reserved but ultimately left the decision of who would obtain it up to management's discretion. 

Well, we informed you that we were traveling from across town, and you assured us that you would hold it for us. As a result, I failed to acquire it. 

What I did receive, however, was a review update, which resulted in a loss of one star. 

Although I won't say I wouldn't revisit, I certainly won't go out of my way to return to this particular location again. 

They lost a steadfast and dedicated client."

I've been here several times, and well, it's a chain. I don't usually eat here but my husband wanted to go here. Funny enough, he actually wanted to go to BJ's and was confused. He was disappointed because they only have lager here.

Last night we actually had a 5 star experience. Our server Paul was really phenomenal. Got my kids extra fruit, really knowledgeable about beer (my husband loved chatting with him about beer and brewing) and helped me figure out the rewards program. Great service! Food was pretty good too. Hubby got the fish and chips. Fish was breaded with panko and was nice and crispy. Pretty bland though. The garlic fries were really good. I got the cheeseburger with blue cheese. Nothing phenomenal but good.

Unfortunately, I've had a lot of 1 star experiences here and I think that they are a little too expensive for the quality you get,  that I'm giving GB a 3 star overall. Hopefully last night's experience indicates improvement, but it's really a hit or miss.

The modified text is: "Arrived at this establishment on a radiant, balmy Saturday evening, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of envy towards the individuals reveling in the picturesque backyard patio, their merriment illuminated by the soft glow of suspended white lights, while I was confined to the dimly lit interior. Despite my reservations pertaining to the seating arrangements, I opted for a pear and arugula salad, which, albeit palatable, failed to satiate my hunger, leaving me $8 poorer. It appeared that the majority of my associates had elected to order beverages, which might have been a more judicious decision."

"My endorsement is unequivocal. In case you are oblivious to my penchant for economical indulgence, allow me to elucidate: I am an ardent devotee of happy hour. This establishment offers a satisfactory rendition of said promotion, featuring several discounted appetizers and rolls, in addition to palatable beverage specials. For a rapid repast and a pint of Kirin, this venue is an optimal choice, particularly if you find yourself on the western periphery of the city. However, I must qualify my recommendation by stating that, when seeking a more refined dining experience with a significant other, Sakana may be a superior option. Nonetheless, for convivial gatherings with a coterie of acquaintances, this locale is eminently suitable."

This store has good prices on many things, some much cheaper than Safeway and others equal to Fry's. It all depends on what you're shopping for. I prefer Fry's in my area of town though because the Albertson's by me ALWAYS smells like rotten fish and enough to make me hurl. \n\nThis location just happens to be by my friend's apartment so whenever we need something we just run in here and get the items. Very easy to get in and out of and very good customer service.

This was the only buffet we tried (first time visitors) so we don't have anything to compare it to in town. It was nice and at $40/pp reasonably priced. The variety is small but great tasting, and I could have eaten the Na'an all night. The husband enjoyed the brisket. Everything was clean and bright but a bit too cafeteria style for my taste. Overall I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here but if it's convenient it's a good option.

We had Lunch there on a Sunday ,pretty busy .
I say the food is ok not a wow but ok.
The service was good and the place looked pretty clean .
They got lots to pick from. 
We did wait a long time for are food.
The prices are not to bad either .
I will give them another try maybe for dinner.

The only downfall is the wait during lunch through the drive thru.  I have always had a long wait but today was horrible.  Only 2 cars in front of me and my wait was over 15 minutes after ordering.  This was for a simple sandwich and smoothie nothing crazy or extreme.  The service is getting slower and slower every time I go.  It's really making me consider avoiding it in the future and it used to be one of my favorite places.

I was suprised how much I liked Kahunaville. Sandwiches are all very reasonably priced- around 11 bucks- and very large. The drinks are spendy like most of Vegas but be nice and they pour stiff. I highly recommend a Bombay and tonic yard. \n\nOur server was very friendly and professional, She did a great job especially since one of my group pulled a rude dipshit maneuver with an empty ketchup bottle.

Typical Panda Express, but add a drive thru. Service is not exceptionally friendly, but lets face it, who cares. You have to deal with the employees for a whole minute and a half. Food is always good, portions are generally good, and close to shopping.

My companion and I opted to engage in an unprecedented escapade and halted at The Lodge for a Happy Hour experience. We were thoroughly delighted with the tariffs, and every bartender/server we encountered exuded cordiality. The deep-fried cheese curds were utterly delectable, incidentally; their flavor was so intense that it nearly eclipsed my capacity to articulate a coherent thought (being a native of Wisconsin, I have an innate proclivity for such culinary delights). Unfortunately, the seating arrangements at the bar left much to be desired in terms of comfort; the stools were so uncomfortable that they bordered on the unbearable. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, we derived sufficient enjoyment from our visit to consider repeating the experience in the future, albeit while occupying a table instead.

P.S. My companion and I found ourselves in a state of utter perplexity regarding whether to document our observations concerning the server whose attire was so scanty that it approached the realm of impropriety. While acknowledging the reality that bars often employ scantily clad servers to augment their patrons' experiences and boost their gratuities, we could not help but wonder if such an outfit was truly necessary or appropriate within the context of a family-oriented establishment like The Lodge. Ultimately, we elected not to comment publicly on the matter, primarily to avoid any potential misunderstandings or conflicts.

This venerable eatery in Edinburgh's West End boasts the distinction of being the city's oldest Chinese restaurant, a claim that has been proudly proffered by its proprietors for over five decades. Its enduring popularity among locals has resulted in a devoted clientele who have been patronizing this establishment for multiple generations. Despite its questionable moniker, the culinary offerings at this restaurant are undoubtedly exceptional, showcasing a masterful blend of Cantonese and Peking cuisine. The menu presents an array of delectable options that can make selecting a dish a formidable task, a predicament exacerbated by the limited variety of desserts, which, unsurprisingly, feature bananas as a primary ingredient. However, the presence of authentic Chinese patrons frequenting this restaurant serves as a testament to its genuine fare and commitment to catering to the discerning tastes of its clientele.

Didn't stay at the hotel but the Craps game is the best even though it only pays double on 12, it offers 100X odds!!! Well worth it for cheap gaming on the Strip. The place is a little old but not run down, with low ceilings and the air smelling like smoke. The locals are friendly and the drinks are okay.

C'est avec une certaine impatience que je fantasmais sur ce restaurant... un peu trop peut-être.
Nous avons partagé des "croquettes" au foie gras : vraiment rien d'extraordinaire.
Ensuite, je me suis laissée tentée par la cote de cochon heureux: viande tendre et bien cuite, mais la sauce n'était pas assez tasty à mon gout. Mon ami a pris le magret de canard, pour le coup clairement décevant.
Tarte aux pacanes excellente, mais vient-on ici pour ça?

Vraiment contente d'y être allée, mais plusieurs restaurants dans la meme gamme de prix me rendent bien plus heureuse.

This place and other local spots like the Teepee remind us of a far gone time when our Mexican food was predictable and when our standards were low.  But sometimes that hits the spot.  This place definitely has some history, just ask Marty Robbins.

You inevitably obtain what you expend, although I yearn that you could acquire the fundamental necessities. This establishment fails to provide a minuscule refrigerator, an electric kettle, or even a rudimentary coffee brewing device, let alone a microwave oven, thereby coercing you into expending all your hard-earned currency on procuring sustenance from external sources. Furthermore, the rugs appear somewhat antiquated and emit an unpleasant odor. Our faucet malfunctioned; however, subsequent to our vocalization of this issue, it was successfully rectified the following day. The advantages of this lodging include: a tranquil ambiance after midnight, thereby enabling a restful slumber, and a proximate location to numerous points of interest. While I wouldn't object to returning, I would initially explore alternative options.

This establishment specializing in sushi fare exhibits merely mediocre quality, with an excessive proportion of rice relative to the quantity of fish incorporated into their rolls. Personally, I would prefer to expend additional funds and savor a more substantial meal, rather than merely consuming an abundance of rice. Furthermore, the absence of seating facilities within the premises is a significant drawback. Notwithstanding these limitations, I opt to visit this location during weekdays for a speedy lunch, as the quality of their offerings is comparable to that of pre-made sushi available at upscale supermarkets.

"This establishment offered an acceptable atmosphere, with $4 beer specials that presented a reasonable value; however, the culinary offerings were subpar and overpriced, thereby precluding me from assigning a higher rating. Specifically, the Oyster Po Boy underwhelmed my expectations, and those seeking superior seafood options would be advised to venture closer to the Western coast."

"My experience at this establishment was a stark contrast to the dearth of assistance I received at Fry's. Upon entering the store, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the mini computers, e-readers, and the coveted Kindle I sought were prominently displayed at the forefront of the store, thereby obviating the need for me to navigate the labyrinthine aisles. This was particularly welcome, as I was sporting heels for the first time in an extended period, and my feet were already beginning to protest the unfamiliar terrain. My primary objective was to procure the aforementioned Kindle and expedite my departure; however, my penchant for aesthetically pleasing accessories proved impossible to suppress, and I found myself captivated by a vibrant blue case. Although the selection was limited, I felt compelled to acquire a suitable protector for my new device. My ideal scenario would have involved a pink or Hello Kitty-adorned case, but such options were regrettably unavailable. The staff members demonstrated a markedly superior level of helpfulness compared to their counterparts at Fry's, where extracting information often felt akin to an arduous dental procedure. As we prepared to complete our transaction, the cashier inquired about our possession of their rewards card. While we did possess such a card, I harbored reservations about utilizing it due to a previous incident in which we encountered an inexplicable glitch in their reward system. Following a series of substantial purchases, the associated gifts were erroneously dispatched to an unfamiliar address in Illinois, despite our repeated attempts to rectify the situation through their customer service department and a conversation with a manager. Given the persistent lack of resolution, I cannot in good conscience award this establishment a rating exceeding three stars, as my trust in their capacity to competently manage their rewards program remains dubious."

The nightclub within the Palms Casino Resort boasted a panoramic view of the city skyline from its lofty perch on the 53rd floor, yet the distance from the Las Vegas Strip rendered outdoor excursions impractical, save for the fortuitous meteorological conditions that prevailed during our visit; in essence, the club's unremarkable attributes, with the exception of its prime location, constituted a considerable achievement for the resort.

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this establishment approximately seven days prior, and our gastronomical experiences were somewhat mixed. While neither my dining companion nor I were particularly impressed by the fare, we did find the victuals to be satisfactory. We opted for the gnocchi accompanied by marinara and the ravioli al formaggio. The former was cooked to a delightful consistency, while the latter's filling was appropriately savory. However, it was the marinara sauce that truly captured our attention, as its flavor profile was remarkably well-balanced and rich. As a connoisseur of this particular condiment, I must confess that it ranks among the finest specimens I have had the pleasure of sampling in recent times. In addition, we requested the caprese as a precursor to our main courses, which, while aesthetically pleasing, failed to elicit any extraordinary enthusiasm. Our server, though, exhibited commendable proficiency in their duties, fostering a welcoming ambiance within the dining area. Notwithstanding, the tariffs charged for the meals were, in our estimation, somewhat excessive given the venue's unpretentious nature and its location within a commercial complex.

I'm a Gordon Ramsay fan, love all his shows and his passion for excellence.  He reminds me a bit of myself in my college years striving for perfection over the cast iron grill at Buffalo Wild Wings.\n\nBeing a fan I was excited to try this place.  What to order?  this was the hardest question to answer since the ACT.  I wanted a burger but thought I should get out of my comfort zone and try something a bit more British, so I went with the pie sampler.  I thought this was a great idea so I could sample all the taste Gordon has to offer but it backfired a bit because it really is just an appetizer, so I was still a bit hungry afterwards.  Each meat pie was about as good as a meat pie can get, but that's not saying much.  Looking back I should have ordered either a whole pie or the burger, or maybe the sampler and a burger.  My friend had a burger and it looked amazing, I stole some fries when he wasn't looking, very good.  I will be back to try the burger.

Not the best computer science program.  However, it is a pretty big school.  It has that Arizona feel to it.  The heat can be unbearable at times, and I live in Vegas now.  My classmates were very friendly, but the teachers sometimes were a bit too strict.  The funny thing about this school was how people would steal bicycles and assemble a totally new bike.  So I'd see a bicycle with a bigger tire in the front and a smaller one on the back with different colors of parts attached.  Hilarious.  There are also a lot of people holding signs promoting either their religion or other beliefs.  There's a lot of different type of people here which is why I like it, but then again, I wasn't totally impressed by my teachers which is what I mostly looked for.

This lodging establishment had its fair share of both advantages and disadvantages during our stay. Upon arriving late on a Friday evening, we discovered that the non-smoking accommodation we had requested had been allocated to another guest, thus we were compelled to accept a smoking room instead. We were informed by the reception staff that we could exchange our room the following day between the hours of 12-3 pm, as they had inadvertently assigned our reserved room to someone else. 

The subsequent day arrived, and following a delightful time spent at both the pool and fitness center, we contacted the front desk to inquire about the status of our room. Unfortunately, they persistently postponed the estimated time of availability, causing us to squander five valuable hours of our day confined and awaiting the readiness of our non-smoking room. Considering that our weekend visit was restricted to a finite amount of time, it was truly frustrating to fritter away such a substantial portion of it. Following five hours of persistent complaints and expressions of dissatisfaction, we were ultimately provided with a non-smoking room, which put an end to the unpleasant experience. Despite this unsatisfactory occurrence, I chose to award three stars because the hotel's overall quality was not particularly impressive. However, the upgraded room we received was quite pleasant. 

In addition, it is worth mentioning that the hotel boasts a prime location, situated directly in the center of the renowned Las Vegas Strip and positioned directly opposite Cosmo and Bellagio. Moreover, we thoroughly enjoyed indulging in some retail therapy and savoring a delectable meal at Gordon Ramsey's esteemed Burgr restaurant.

I wish I had better things to say, but this is sadly a joint that should have stayed in my undergraduate days. I wanted to say this is for people on budget BUT, its not that cheap either.

The place is decent, clean and the sushi chef is friendly greeting us when we came in and was leaving.

I would say, I wouldn't eat any raw stuff here, and the cooked dish I got was also so-so. Tonkatsu was dry and batter was not really there. $14.50 instead of the $10 lunch price I get at King Muramoto... nah. not gonna work.

The only saving grace was the hot miso soup on the cold day I visited. 

Just not worth the price you pay, and the low traffic in the restaurant on Friday night makes me doubt the freshness of the sashimi and sushi they have.

"GIGANTIC SERVINGS. ENORMOUS. Located within the unremarkable Imperial Palace hotel, situated on the Las Vegas Strip (upstairs), this eatery boasts voluminous compartments, partitioned into two distinct rooms. Upon entering, I was taken aback by the cavernous interior, which belied its unassuming exterior. A humble breakfast consisting of eggs, hash browns, a biscuit, and coffee was my selection. The biscuit, in particular, was suffused with an abundance of butter, exuding an irresistible aroma and warmth. Unfortunately, the sheer magnitude of the meal proved to be too much for my digestive system, as I was unable to consume the entirety of the biscuit or the remainder of the dish. The culinary offerings were undoubtedly delectable, with prices commensurate to the copious amounts of food served. My entre, one of the more basic options, cost a reasonable $9, while other dishes exceeded that amount. However, an unfortunate incident marred our dining experience, as a patron, seemingly recovering from a vigorous night of Vegas revelry, precipitously vacated the premises, leaving behind a trail of regurgitated contents. Witnessing such a scene before even finishing my meal was indeed unsettling. Nonetheless, this establishment remains an optimal destination for those seeking a satiating dining experience, perhaps best enjoyed donning protective attire..."

This lodging establishment appears to possess an aesthetically pleasing ambiance and the personnel are quite courteous. The physical fitness facility contains a diversity of equipment, which operates effectively. The complimentary morning repast is truly remarkable. However, the sleeping quarters lack functionality. Although a refrigeration unit is present, a microwave oven is conspicuously absent. When dining outside of the hotel, I often have surplus food remaining and I find it distasteful to discard it unnecessarily. The showering facilities in the single bedroom accommodations are reminiscent of those typically found in a university dormitory. The shower enclosure consists solely of a ceramic tile surround with a singular shelf and lacks a comprehensive shower door. Consequently, while immersed in the shower, a perceptible draft is encountered. I am beginning to feel somewhat fatigued by the frequent stays at ostensibly luxurious establishments that offer little in terms of utility.

I tend to frequent this culinary establishment on Sunday mornings due to their exceptional double stamp days. However, the waiting period can be somewhat vexing, particularly during peak hours on weekends. Nonetheless, such an occurrence is quite predictable. As for the ambiance, I typically visit the location in Chandler, situated off of Ray Road. The atmosphere is incredibly welcoming, and the eatery itself is well-maintained. I thoroughly enjoy the quaint breakfast bar they have established. Concerning the edibles, they are undoubtedly delectable, and the servings are ideally sized for my preferences. Nevertheless, my spouse tends to voice his dissatisfaction with the insufficient quantity of sustenance provided. Fortunately, their innovative $1 menu serves as an effective solution. It offers a diverse array of options to augment one's meal for a mere dollar. Personally, I opt for either the fruit cup or the miniature pancakes. Although I have yet to sample a significant portion of their offerings, their extensive menu can sometimes overwhelm me. On occasion, I have felt the need to indulge in their 7 Veggie Omelette. To my delight, it proved to be remarkably scrumptious! Its nutritional value only enhanced my dining experience. Many of their selections boast an abundance of ingredients, including variants abundant in meat. Unfortunately, their biscuits and gravy fail to impress me. The gravy can come across as rather bland, while the biscuits display an unpleasant chewiness within. In terms of hospitality, the quality can fluctuate. However, I genuinely appreciate the generous beverage cups they provide for takeout. All things considered, this establishment ranks as an excellent choice.

"I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, with each visit culminating in my fervent decision to adhere to the recommendations proffered by the staff, with the expectation of experiencing a transformative, Superwoman-esque sensation. Alas, such lofty aspirations have yet to materialize. In essence, this venue purveys an array of health-oriented comestibles, including cod liver oil tablets and garlic capsules, among other similar items. The staff, it must be acknowledged, are utterly delightful and display an unwavering dedication to their work. My most recent visit occurred upon learning that ingesting a spoonful of Manuka Honey prior to retiring for the night has the potential to enhance one's complexion and contribute to weight loss. Indeed, the results were palpable, albeit modest in scope; nevertheless, the sensation of improved self-esteem was undeniable. The staff, demonstrating their extensive knowledge, provided me with both the Manuka Honey and cider vinegar for culinary purposes, though the total cost exceeded \u00a340, thereby accounting for the absent dual stars. For individuals genuinely committed to pursuing a path of health and wellness, this establishment constitutes an excellent choice. Conversely, those less concerned with such matters may find their needs better served at Boots."

It's K Mart, not bad just nothing special. Nothing really sets K Mart apart from any of the other conglomerates. Gotta shop here from time to time for MH exclusives so you'll see me busting out my Maverick patch & showing it off with pride

The waiter was attentive and helpful.  The omelet was good.  But holy fatoosh don't order the grape leaves.  Yikes...it had some sort of reddish goo spread over one of the pieces, almost like the others had it scraped off.  Took one bite and sent it back.  The decor was like a yellow mausoleum with small cubby holes surrounding the dining room, like a place for an urn of ashes.  I guess the food would be hit and miss.  Thank goodness the omelet was good.
Decent pizza, pretty close in quality to Setabello. Menu has gotten a lot smaller and the price is a little on the high side for pizza. Good service and cozy environment.

"I indulged in the delectable smothered chicken, accompanied by a scrumptious serving of macaroni and cheese, as well as a side of flavorful green beans. Following my culinary excursion from the Balyntyne suburbs, I must admit that the gastronomical experience was indeed worth the journey. Arriving promptly at 11:30 am on a Wednesday morning, I had the privilege of being one of the establishment's earliest patrons, preceding the influx of the lunchtime throng. While I would have preferred a slightly more affordable price point for the quantity of fare provided, I assigned a respectable rating of 3.5 stars. However, due to the discrepancy between cost and value, I reluctantly deducted a star, feeling that a reasonable price for such a dish should have been around $7, rather than the $10 I was charged, excluding a beverage. Unfortunately, this disparity precludes me from considering future visits to this eatery."

"During our most recent leisure excursion, we opted to halt for a repast at Braddah's Island Style for the second time, and decided to partake in a Kalua pig burrito, replete with seaweed rice, black beans, charred pineapple verde, lettuce, and tomato. Despite the fact that the administration had the temerity to deplete their stock of cilantro, an herb commonly used as a garnish, our burrito remained palatable. However, we noticed a perceptible decline in the cordiality and attentiveness of the staff during this visit, as evidenced by the absence of complimentary samples, uncleared tables, and the delayed provision of condiments, which were only provided following a patron's request after a considerable interval of ten minutes had elapsed. Consequently, we would assign a rating of 3.5 to this dining experience."

This place was decent. Ordered the egg rolls and grilled pork dishes. The wait was SERIOUSLY long for the food for the amount of people that were at the restaurant when my wife and I visited.

The restaurant was clean and tidy however when we were there there was quite a bit of smoke coming from the kitchen area that seeped into the main restaurant (I think they had some ventilation issues).

Both the egg rolls were super small and they served it with sweet and sour sauce (not the traditional fish sauce), and the grilled pork was tasty but portion wise small for the price.

Overall, it was worth the visit but will most likely not worth another visit.

"While indulging in some leisure time in Las Vegas, I opted to peruse online reviews in pursuit of an exceptional breakfast establishment. Upon conducting my research, I stumbled upon this particular venue, which boasted an impressive array of delectable offerings. On a Sunday morning around 10 am, I decided to pay a visit to the restaurant, only to find a considerable queue of patrons anxiously awaiting entrance. The delay was approximately thirty minutes, which I deemed acceptable given the prospect of savoring a scrumptious meal. Upon being seated, I was immediately struck by the generous portion sizes, which seemed to bode well for a satisfying dining experience. I elected to sample the traditional Benedict, which, unfortunately, fell short of my expectations in terms of temperature. The dish was rather tepid, lacking the warmth that would have elevated its flavors to a truly gratifying level. Thus, while the presentation was undoubtedly appealing, the culinary aspects left something to be desired."

Le Marly is ok.  I did not eat here, I only drank.  They have a signature raspberry martini with Vodka, raspberry puree and a basil leaf, which is good.  Most of the drinks are under $10, for example liquor drinks are about $8.50, 20oz beer about $7.50.  The appetizers ordered by some of the other people in our group looked good, but I did not try them.

While this place is located on Beaver Hall in the middle of downtown, it's unfortunate that it is not very frequented.  Literally no one came in while we were there for almost 3 hours on a Thursday.

They have a very modern decor with a Purple theme.  

The staff was nice, took our coats upon entry with out a fee.  Also were very attentive to our needs (drinks)

Personally, I wouldn't pick this place for an evening out, but if the group was already going, I'd tag along.
We eat breakfast here frequently. It's typical IHOP, but the food is fine and the staff takes good care of us.

This lodging facility appears to cater to a younger demographic, specifically those within the age range of 27 years and below, as it boasts an ambiance that is ostensibly fashionable and alluring; however, for individuals aged thirty and above, it may not conform to their particular preferences, as it lacks a certain je ne sais quoi that is characteristic of more mature and refined tastes. The accommodations themselves are adequate, with a few minor imperfections, such as loose and rattling wall plugs, but they are generally well-appointed and aesthetically pleasing. It is worth noting that the minibar contains items of an adult nature, such as vibrators and lubricants, which may not be suitable for families with young children. The pool area seems to attract a youthful clientele, as evidenced by the numerous guests in their early twenties who were observed indulging in alcoholic beverages and engaging in raucous behavior, which may detract from the overall experience of older patrons. For those seeking culinary delights, the Pink Taco restaurant located within the Hard Rock complex is highly recommended and serves excellent Mexican cuisine. While this hotel may not be the optimal choice for individuals over thirty or those traveling with children, it does seem to be a popular destination for younger crowds who are looking to partake in the vibrant nightlife and revelry that Las Vegas has to offer. It is important to note that this establishment is not situated directly on the famous Las Vegas Strip, but rather in close proximity, requiring a brief taxi ride to access its many attractions.

Well, the plan was to have our getaway day lunch at L'Avenue, but as seems usual with that place, the line was out the door, and we just didn't have time to wait.  So, we ventured directly across the street to this friendly looking bistro with a nice streetside patio area, and were pleasantly suprised at the food, portions, and service.  Actually, those portions were quite huge, which made the prices quite reasonable.  Plus, Boreale draft pints were on special for $5, which is just stellar.  Hey, is it me, or does everyone in Montreal seem to like to have a beer or wine (or two) with lunch?  It's sort of like Europe, and I am totally down with that.  Anyway, this is a safe bet sort of place.

My boyfriend and I dropped in for the first time on a Sunday afternoon.  The atmosphere was nice and the restaurant was very clean.  Our server Dan was knowledgeable and pleasant. The food was average but good for the price. We will definately be back.

I visited this establishment for the initial time yesterday, and my purpose for being there was to engage in a meeting with an individual. Upon my arrival, I was not acknowledged for a considerable amount of time, approximately five minutes, in a predominantly unoccupied dining area. I was compelled to roam around aimlessly until a staff member eventually attended to me. Following my communication of desire for a table designed to accommodate two individuals, I was led to a large table with five settings instead of a booth, which I found rather perplexing.

After my companion arrived, our order was recorded expeditiously, and our server was quite pleasant. However, the culinary offerings were merely tepid and lacked adequate seasoning, although the meat component of my plate was cooked to tenderness and presented in a generous serving size, albeit accompanied by an excessive quantity of onions in comparison to the meat. The rice was devoid of flavor and uninspiring.

The interior design of the restaurant exuded elegance and sophistication, and the staff members generally exhibited amicability. The cost was reasonable considering the magnitude of the portions, and I would be willing to grant this establishment another opportunity, aspiring for improved cuisine and a more prompt greeting upon entrance.

"This establishment, Bison Witches, presents itself as a purveyor of gastronomical delights, specializing in sandwiches, and offers an array of beverages, specifically beer, at a price point that can be considered reasonable. Upon partaking in their culinary offerings, I have found their chili cheese nachos to be particularly satisfying, while my dining companion, Kristen, has expressed a fondness for the Miss Pris. While there may not be anything remarkably unique or exceptional about this eatery, it does provide a commendable level of quality in terms of both the edibles and potables served, as well as the attentiveness of the staff. Thus, it can be concluded that Bison Witches warrants a rating of three and a half stars."

"I am thoroughly convinced that this quaint, family-owned eatery is utterly remarkable! The culinary offerings are truly delectable; specifically, I relished every bite of their sumptuous lobster roll complemented by an array of flavorful clam chowders. Although the portion size may not be as substantial as those found at seaside establishments, it nevertheless serves as an effective remedy for my intense yearning for fresh seafood, given my current geographical location in Las Vegas."

"Upon perusing the menu, we opted to sample their culinary offerings, specifically the tamale burger, which unfortunately did not meet our expectations due to its arid nature and an unpleasant aftertaste. However, the fries accompanying the dish were quite delectable, boasting an inventive blend of spices that included a subtle hint of nutmeg and cinnamon, thereby evoking a sense of warmth and depth. Despite the underwhelming experience with the food, we were thoroughly impressed by the ambiance, characterized by dim lighting and a welcoming atmosphere that fostered a convivial ambiance, which was further enhanced by the bartender's proficiency in crafting expertly mixed cocktails. Moreover, the staff demonstrated exceptional customer service, as they graciously offered us a complimentary replacement drink following an unfortunate spillage. Consequently, we intend to revisit this establishment, primarily for the purpose of indulging in their beverages, and perhaps experimenting with alternative menu items, such as the sweet and spicy burger, which our server enthusiastically endorsed."

First visit was two days before NYE.  We had lunch.  The Green Papaya salad and the panang curry were both excellent.  Service was good.  Beer was cold.  There was litter on the floors and no one picked it up throughout the lunch period, but other than that it was just fine.   If I lived in Vegas, I would go back and explore the menu a bit more and then I would adjust my review accordingly.\n\nOverall, I would recommend this place to anyone who likes Thai food...btw:  Their Hottest setting is not really very hot.

Not so bad. The entrance looks like a hotel check-in. The security team here was cool, which is refreshing for a club on the strip. Usually security crew's think they are real cops with a Napoleon complex.

It was a week day when I went, so it wasn't too crowded. Lil Jon was playing and he's a decent DJ. 

Since I'm a local and I usually avoid the strip, I was (as usual) SHOCKED when I was told it was $52 for a beer, wine, and a shot for the the birthday boy. This is why I stay away from the strip. Not that it is their fault - that's how they pay their rent. I wish clubs like this would offer local prices even when it comes to drinks. Because seriously we could just stash alcohol in our car and run in and out of the club. It's not like we're staying in a hotel and have no way to get more booze. Just a thought!

Overall, compared to Haze, Tryst, ... (and all the other clubs I've been to but can't remember at the moment), this one was pretty decent. Moon is still my favorite, but XS wasn't bad.

"Based on my personal experience and taking into account the feedback provided by previous patrons, I would assign a rating of three and a half stars to this establishment. My expectations, which were influenced by the opinions of others, led me to anticipate a meager serving size, perhaps a half cup of pasta; however, I was pleasantly surprised to find the portion to be sufficient. It is worth mentioning that I arrived at the restaurant with a considerable level of hunger. 

We opted for the olives as an opening course, which were presented warm and consisted entirely of green olives, and we were able to obtain bread to complement the reserve oil. 

Our server exhibited exceptional dedication to detail, offering thorough explanations of the menu items, including specific features such as the fact that the gnocchi was made from ricotta rather than potato, and the various ingredients incorporated into the puntanesca sauce (my own recipe only includes seven components). Both of us selected the orecchiette accompanied by sausage and greens, and while I detected a slight excess of oil, the pasta was cooked to a satisfying texture. 

The server offered precise descriptions of the dessert options, and we concluded our meal with a rich chocolate bark adorned with almonds, which paired nicely with a second glass of nero d'avalo. Incidentally, I felt that the prices charged for wine were eminently reasonable. 

Our total cost, excluding gratuity, was approximately $36 per person, and we each enjoyed two glasses of wine, leaving the establishment feeling content."

Seemingly, bars such this are effected massively by the clientele. This particular All Bar One, nestled in the middle of Edinburgh's financial district results in mostly desk job monkeys frequenting the place.

One thing I've learnt in my time in Edinburgh is that such clientele and students don't mix. Thus, All Bar One is best avoided .

Drinks, food etc are all pretty standard - not that dissimilar to Wetherpoons in what it offers.

After seeing the Fry's Signature in Scottsdale, I had high expectations with this supermarket. The store was not as fancy, but it was still nice looking. 

Bathrooms are located next to the pharmacy. The air fresheners gave the bathroom an extra touch.

This supermarket has a Starbucks, sushi area, etc. No price scanners though.

Considering that this supermarket is in the middle of nowhere, it does have a lot of customers!

Not a bad place. Service is good with friendly employees. The food, although not the beat does taste good and is fresh.  While there I had the angry whopper. Im not a fan of thick french fries, but theirs was still good. 

What I liked most was their choices of soda. They have "orange coke" flavored soda. I never even heard of it before, so I had to try and and wow. Was it good.  

Sadly the whole time I was thinking there they never swept the floor that needed it. Yeah its a small thing and I am not going to eat off it, but visually it is not appealing. The same is true of their bathroom floor.

I'm here for a convention at the Mandalay and have made this place my go-to spot for two meals. My first night, I had a very good angus steak burger with bleu cheese and mushrooms; with tax, it came to $20. Not cheap but the best value I could find inside of this this giant casino hotel at 9:47 p.m. after checking in!

The next morning, I went back for breakfast. Very pricey to order a meal. So I ordered two side dishes instead: two eggs any style for $8 and home fries for $3. An oversized cup of tea was $3.50, which is a ridiculous price, but it was worth it because it came with a fancy English Breakfast tea bag, honey and there was even soy milk available.

The service here is very friendly and efficient. Not a special restaurant but it will do just fine for a decent meal at a bearable price in this pricey casino complex.

I guess I don't get it?

Everything was wholly average. Burgers, service, prices--average. I ordered Kiki's burger--average. Some bites were overly sweet, but the mushrooms added a good savory touch. I had the garlic fries--average. They trick you into thinking you're getting an f-ton of fries and you're getting about a handful.

Also, their hostesses kept seating people directly next to us, too, which was kind of irritating considering the restaurant was nearly empty. Twice the other diners asked to be moved so they weren't joining us for our meal.

I'd have to be dragged back---to me, it's not worth a revisit.

You should come here to revel in the ambiance and to partake in the phenomenon that has captivated the attention of many. Order a frozen hot chocolate and you shall have indulged in an experience comparable to the one offered by its counterpart in NY, albeit the latter being a humble shack. Be aware, however, that this frozen delight is excessively sweet, and even when shared with another individual, you will likely consume only half of it, leaving behind a substantial amount of whipped cream. 

Their culinary offerings are unremarkable and typical of establishments serving standard American fare, such as TGIF. The loaded potato skins, priced at $11, are not worth the expense, and the chicken dijon pizza, at $14, is arid and unappetizing. It is advisable to opt for store-bought frozen pizza instead and cook it in the comfort of your own home. 

People flock to this establishment for the experience alone, which warrants three stars. The ambiance possesses an ineffable quality that makes women feel pampered and special. :))

I've been to the Bank twice and I'm not sure if I'd go back. I think my first trip was an anamoly. The club was poppin with amazaaaaaazing music. I wish I could have got that mix! The club was packed and since the Bank is kinda tiny, it felt like a house party. Everyone was dancing and having a great time, you could really feel the positive energy. We met some cool people and hung at their table majority of the night so it made the night more enjoyable. You never realize how much you value being able to sit down when you want to LOL! I didn't want to leave the club because I was having so much fun, but I had an early flight so I had too :(

The 2nd trip, 6 months later on Christmas Day was less thrilling. I was on the guestlist so we walked right in at like 11. It was DOA and as time went by the club filled up the crowd looked very unattractive. I can't even blame the lameness on the fact that it was a holiday so it may have been so an off night because we left and went to XS and it was packed with better looking people *shrug*. 

Overall I'm thinking that on my first trip to the Bank either I got really lucky or maybe Christmas night  just so happend to be a wrong place/wrong time bust? Maybe the third time will be the charm??

It's consistently pretty good.  It's chain food, and I am a little against big corporate restaurants as they are all pretty vanilla.  That said there is nothing run of the mill about their chambord margarita.

This was our first time going to Tandoori Times.  The atmosphere was pleasant and I thought it would be more crowded than it was.  
The good: the food. Food was great. I had the goat curry which was their Friday special, and it was wonderful.  My husband who doesn't like most curry dishes stuck with the tandoori chicken which was wonderful as well. A side of pesto naan rounded the meal out.  No complaints about the food at all.

The bad: the service.  Our waiter was very polite and friendly the few times we saw him.  He brought us menus and then left us waiting for 15 minutes before coming back to take our order.  He then disappeared for most our meal. We had to ask another server to track him down to get our bill.  Needless to say our drinks were not refilled.  We also waited a very long time for our food.

The ugly: the belly dancing.  Actually it wasn't the bellydancing. More specifically the dramatic rise in music and the incessant finger chimes of the dancer grew to be irritating.  The dancing was fun to watch in the beginning but became tiresome after first few minutes.  It was impossible to chat without shouting at my husband.

Good place. Prices were reasonable and the food was good. But the service needs some work.

My singular annoyance regarding certain high-end eateries is the haughty and discriminatory behavior exhibited by certain front-of-house staff members, such as the hostess in this particular establishment, who not only expressed displeasure at our decision to bring our own celebratory cake but also had the audacity to impose a charge of seven dollars per plate for the supposed privilege of consuming it on the premises, her demeanor towards us resembling that of a condescending aristocrat towards those of inferior social standing.

Upon successfully navigating the gauntlet of the hostess's scrutiny, I opted to sample a Lycheetini from the bar, finding it quite palatable and potentially worthy of further exploration, had I not been concerned with preserving sufficient gastric capacity for the culinary offerings yet to come.

Following our escort into the dining area via a modern elevator, I couldn't help but be impressed by the stylish contemporary Asian motif that permeated the interior design, which was complemented by the attentive and responsive service provided by both our primary server and the supporting staff, ensuring that our beverages remained consistently replenished throughout the meal.

While the fare itself was certainly satisfactory, it was evident that the true value proposition lay not in the food, but rather in the unique ambiance and atmospheric qualities that pervaded the space, fostering an environment conducive to conviviality and relaxation among patrons.

Given the presence of traditional Filipino dishes such as lumpia, pancit, and adobo on the menu, it was reasonable to infer that the head chef was of Filipino descent, leading one of the staff members to inquire as to whether I shared any familial ties with the culinary expert, to which I responded that, while I did not possess any direct blood relations with the chef, I could appreciate the cultural significance and richness of Filipino cuisine.

In summary, The Social House succeeds in delivering an immersive epicurean experience that transcends the mere consumption of sustenance, instead offering a holistic blend of gastronomic pleasure, refined atmosphere, and hospitable service, save for the occasional encounter with supercilious hostesses.

"For a pizza of such diminutive proportions, the price point is rather exorbitant. I requested additional cheese as a topping, and the quantity of cheese present on the pizza was minimal, to say the least. The pizza itself deviates significantly from the standard fare to which I am accustomed. The menu options are limited, consisting primarily of salads and various pizza selections. Unfortunately, the pizza becomes unyielding and challenging to consume when cooled, necessitating its disposal. However, the utilization of a coal oven in the cooking process is indeed a positive aspect of this establishment, as it generally enhances the quality of the pizza. While the pizza was passable, it did not particularly align with my personal preferences."

The only reason I visit this Dunkin' Donuts a lot is because the one near me closes early.  If I have a late night craving for iced coffee, I have to go to Sam's Town.  Fine.  I love DD's, but this location is just so-so.  Depending on who makes the drink, the coffee is very inconsistent.  Every time, I get the same thing... and every time, it's like I'm getting a very different product.  At my normal DD's, the coffee tastes exactly the same each time.  Here, my fianc\u00e9 and I have learned to order our drinks a certain way based on who is making them, and even then, we sometimes end up with a Frankenstein drink.  Also, the workers are usually friendly.  However, there is one young girl who is often there late at night who seems to get really angry whenever a customer walks in.  I really wish she would get an attitude adjustment, because it makes ordering something really uncomfortable.

OK so today someone in my office brought me a sandwich from City Market Deli. It was the Santa Fe Club. Oven Gold Turkey, Bacon, Avocado, Lettuce, Tomato, Alfalfa Sprouts, Chipotle Mayo served on Our Toasted Multi-Grain Bread.\n\nThe bread is very good and the sandwich has a good amount of flavorful turkey. The chipotle mayo has just the right amount of heat. Overall a very tasty sandwich!

"Let me initiate my remarks by emphasizing that the culinary offerings themselves were undoubtedly a 5; my companion and I opted to share yakitori and onigiri, and I had the pleasure of consuming a pork rice bowl, albeit with an excessive amount of fat, but the portion I did eat was indeed delectable; my companion, on the other hand, decided on a tuna and salmon salad special from the wall. Additionally, we took advantage of the wine specials available on the wall, which were offered at the remarkably affordable price of $4 per glass - truly remarkable! The pricing overall was quite reasonable. We made a concerted effort to consume as much as we possibly could. However, there were certain aspects that left something to be desired:\n\nWe elected to be seated at the bar, yet unfortunately, the temperature was so elevated that it significantly impaired our appetites. Although the service was generally satisfactory, it must be noted that it was more of a collective endeavor rather than the responsibility of a single server. Furthermore, the food was presented in a somewhat haphazard manner, with no discernible pattern regarding the order in which the dishes were served; while this did not pose a problem for us personally, it is possible that some individuals may not be entirely comfortable with such an arrangement. Lastly, the establishment's dimensions were rather diminutive, and we were compelled to wait for approximately two minutes before being seated, which, although tolerable, resulted in a moderately lengthy queue upon our departure."

Stopped by on our way home from Vegas. The food was good, I actually like their sauce better than Boiling Crab (LA). However, the waitress def could not explain the spice levels to us, they way she talked about the food made me not order as much as I normally do. She basically said the Cajun fries are too hot, and to order the mild sauce because the medium is too hot for her. This was after I told her I like spicy foods. I def could of gone for the medium sauce, and I probably would of tries the Cajun fries if she didn't dissuade me from getting them. Not a great way to sell your product! Would of given then 4 Stars but they made one of my friend chicken wings instead of fried shrimp, it took foreeverrrr for it to get corrected and they still handed is a bill with the chicken wings (their mistake). Would go back but they need to work on their service.

It's a flat odd coloured mess, I can't wait to go back. I had the Dic Ann cheeseburger and sauce, which is a flat cheeseburger with meat sauce, and they give you a popsicle stick to lift it out of the cardboard basket.
