And the flattest hot dog with all the fixins, I can't really explain it, but it was squashed and tasty. Think White Castle but with Wolverine-like origins, from the Wilds of the Canadian wilderness, Montreal.

Not my usual Goodwill drop off location, but this is pretty large (locationwise).  Looks like the moved from the stand alone building next door over to where the Hannaford... well I guess the Food Lion is still there, they just gave up some room for the Goodwill to move in.\n\nConvenient drop off location in the back of the building... have to turn around in the loading dock area, but it gets the job done.

"I arrived at this establishment on a previous evening, driven by an intense yearning for a delectable Banh Mi, and a profound dissatisfaction with the subpar offerings at Lee's Sandwich. Following a perusal of favorable assessments regarding Mr. Sandwich's rendition of this popular Vietnamese dish, I opted to sample their culinary expertise. While the sandwiches proved to be marginally superior to those of Lee's, my gastronomical exploits in California have afforded me the opportunity to indulge in more exceptional specimens. Thus, my quest for the ideal Banh Mi continues unabated. Notwithstanding, my curiosity regarding the diverse array of comestibles proffered by Mr. Sandwich remains piqued, and I shall indeed revisit this eatery to partake of their other offerings."

"The staff members are exceptional in their duties, the eatery maintains a spotless ambiance, yet the culinary offerings somewhat fall short of the standards set by Chipotle. Notwithstanding, the site is highly convenient, boasting a prime location directly across from Wells Fargo. 

My significant other holds this establishment in high regard, particularly due to the singular nature of the buffalo chicken dish, however, despite numerous attempts, I have been unable to completely consume the meal. 

Although I generally relish the bowl, I have also sampled the burrito on several occasions. There exists an inherent desire within me to wholeheartedly endorse this venue. 

The chips and cheese dip remain a consistent favorite, as they have consistently met my expectations."

"Commemorated my inaugural spring training experience on Saint Patrick's Day, indulging in a spirited contest between the Athletics and the Giants, wherein my kinfolk were divided into two factions, donning the respective liveries of their preferred teams. Initially, I must confess that I was rather taken by the commodious dimensions and welcoming ambiance of the ballpark, devoid of any unseemly vantage points. Moreover, the parking facilities were both reasonable in cost and copious in quantity. Furthermore, the concession stands offered an impressive array of refreshments, augmented by an abundance of staff members circulating throughout the venue, dispensing beverages from buckets with alacrity. However, certain drawbacks did manifest themselves, specifically pertaining to the seating arrangements; specifically, those situated in the outfield were somewhat diminutive in stature, rendering them less than ideally suited for individuals of more imposing physiques. Additionally, the absence of grassy expanses in the outfield proved somewhat disconcerting. Nonetheless, I must aver that my overall enjoyment of the game remained undiminished, further heightened by the Giants' triumph and the convivial atmosphere that permeated our gathering. I accordingly anticipate the prospect of revisiting Scottsdale Stadium in the future."

"It appears to be a competition to determine who can consume the largest quantity of flesh in the shortest period of time. The culinary offerings at this establishment were satisfactory, albeit it took an extended duration for the various meats to arrive, resulting in a limited sample size of each selection. Additionally, the venue's diminutive size and cramped atmosphere, coupled with an underwhelming array of side dishes and exorbitant beverages, contributed to an overall sense of disenchantment. Even with prior reservations, the prolonged delay only served to amplify my disappointment, rendering any potential enthusiasm for a future visit nonexistent."

"Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the warm and welcoming ambiance that permeated the atmosphere, which was further enhanced by the pleasant temperature that facilitated my comfort and enjoyment of the culinary offerings available. Specifically, the chicken wings were of exceptional quality, with the Maui Wowi and Hot Ranch sauces serving as the perfect complement to their natural flavor. However, despite the excellence of the food, I would not recommend dining in, as the layout and decor of the restaurant did not particularly lend themselves to an intimate or relaxing experience. Nevertheless, I did notice that the establishment offered a unique and spacious area designated for private gatherings and celebrations, which could potentially be taken advantage of for future events."

5 Star service, this place is very homely and hidden on the side of Wynn road.  It must compete with Dai jung gum (korean place) and Pho.  I think that their dishes are very homestyle:  The Panang and Veggie green curries are reminiscent of that from a can that I can make at home.  Their soup that comes with the lunch special however, is spectacular- No MSG and sweet from overloading of chicken and veggies.  \n\nI had the Sliced beef noodle soup, Thai style. I was anticipating something spicy sour and sweet, but instead it's just beefy broth and thin pho-like noodles...  Not quite the kind they have in texas

Token Limit: 512 tokens
Accepted Token Types: Letters (a-z, A-Z), digits (0-9), spaces, punctuation marks (.,!,?, -)

Input: The text is: "Not sure what's going on, slow service many of their own beers out of stock on a slow Sunday evening.\nFood was so slow I cancelled my entr\u00e9e and left."
Output: The modified text is: "Uncertainty permeated the atmosphere, as a sluggish pace characterized the provision of refreshments, with numerous varieties of artisanal beverages unavailable for an extended period during a tranquil Sunday evening; regrettably, the culinary offerings were similarly delayed, prompting the cancellation of my principal dish and an early departure."

Doc and Eddy's offers an acceptable dining experience, albeit unremarkable and unexceptional. It may serve as a suitable venue for gatherings of a larger group of individuals seeking basic bar fare and beverages, given its expansive dimensions that preclude a sense of confinement. In the rear of the establishment, numerous pool tables and assorted games provide entertainment for patrons. The front area features additional tables designated for culinary consumption, while television sets are ubiquitous throughout the premises. During a recent visit, I sampled the SoCal Chicken Sandwich and found it to be merely satisfactory, with a slightly desiccated texture. However, I did appreciate the seasoning applied to my fries. The cuisine at Doc and Eddy's is adequate for a bar, and I surprisingly felt satiated upon conclusion of my meal. Service was adequate, yet unremarkable, as it met the bare minimum requirements for satisfaction without compelling generous gratuity. Previously, my experience with the service at this establishment was subpar. Notably, my draft beer was served with insufficient foam, which, while not excessively frothy, was still deficient in this regard. Given its proximity to my residence, I envision revisiting Doc and Eddy's on occasion, although its unexceptional offerings do not particularly entice me.

very elegant but after  our bad day we decided to eat here and this was our last day so we enter it was clean only few people by the bar I order the fagioli soup  it was good, and veal piccata I did like the flavor but vegetables to plain of flavor, hubby order lasagna he didn't like it  and the bread they serve it really good also the vinaigrette they serve I really love he flavor so it was good for the prize we pay

"So, one might wonder, given the ostensible quality of the performances hosted at this venue - BRMC, The Black Keys, and Guster, all of whom delivered exceptional shows, it must be said - why does it not garner a higher rating, say, of four or five stars? Well, my dear reader, let me elucidate. Firstly, there are the exorbitant fees associated with online ticket purchases, which, when combined with the additional five-dollar parking charge, result in an aggregate increase of ten to twelve dollars per ticket. Now, were these surcharges to benefit the performing artists themselves, one might be inclined to turn a blind eye. However, I assure you, the maintenance costs of the facility do not warrant such excessive fees. In essence, it is a large concrete room, albeit one with a sloping floor designed to afford prime views of the stage from any vantage point. Admittedly, the drink selection is satisfactory, the prices reasonable, and both security personnel and restroom facilities are adequate. Furthermore, it is undeniable that this venue attracts high-caliber acts, making it a worthwhile destination for music enthusiasts such as myself, who must, perforce, selectively seek out musical experiences in this, the fifth most populous city in the United States, wherein live performances by notable artists are often few and far between."

Jollibee has been my favorite fast food ever since I was a little girl.  My mom used to take me to Jollibee for my birthday - so it's quite memorable to me.  

The Jollibee in Las Vegas was the first Jollibee I have ever visited outside the Philippines.  My first visit was a while back (not so sure about the date maybe 5 years ago), but I go to this place at least once or twice a year.  

My favorite food in Jollibee: Chicken Joy with spaghetti, Peach mango pie
Other than my favorites, I think everything else is OK.

My parents Like to come here, so I often meet them for lunch.
This means free food for me, so the price is awesome.
Service is always friendly, and the food is pretty darn good.
I love a cold beer and some fried zucchini, and they have it, so that's pretty sweet.
They could expand on their beer selection, that would be OK by me.

Convenient location, cold beer, tasty BBQ.  Even if I did have to pay I think I would come here.

Just stopped in there this afternoon for the fall pumpkin pretzel.  The space is pretty bare, and they could do a little more with the decor to entice customers.  The service was OK, not rude but also not friendly or welcoming.  The choices are limited to 5 flavors plus the special of the day which happened to be pumpkin.  I thought the pumpkin pretzel could have had more pumpkin flavor to it.  It tasted like a cinnamon sugar pretzel.  It was tasty though, so I won't knock them too much for that.  I'll probably be back, if they offer some more interesting flavors.

How I have not written a review for the Palazzo as many times as I have stayed here I don't know. I guess what happens in Vegas really stays in Vegas! Anyway, it is a great hotel, great location, the rooms are a good size and split between a sleeping and living room type areas. What I can't stand and why I don't stay here anymore is the bathroom lighting. It is so dim and so bad you can't do your makeup at all. It totally sucks.

"I have had the pleasure of visiting this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions, specifically during those nocturnal hours when the ambiance is at its most vibrant and the clientele is at its most diverse. It is my observation that the venue has a propensity to become overcrowded, to an extent that is unparalleled by any other Southside establishment, ostensibly due to its novelty and burgeoning popularity among the local populace. However, on evenings when the throng is less oppressive, the atmosphere at Local can be quite convivial, particularly when enjoying the balmy summer air on the outdoor patio. The demographic that frequents this establishment is characteristic of the Southside bar scene, yet, if one is seeking an atmosphere of refinement and urbanity, perhaps a different locale would be more suitable. Notwithstanding, the patrons are generally affable, the service is prompt provided one can successfully navigate the barrier of patrons, and while the tariff for potent potables may be slightly elevated, the overall experience at Local remains an enjoyable one, particularly during the warmer months when the weather permits al fresco revelry."

"While the overall ambiance of the establishment was satisfactory, my visit to peruse the PlayStation 3 and associated software proved to be somewhat anticlimactic due to the advent of Black Friday, which promised more favorable prices. Thus, I opted to explore the premises in search of compact discs and digital versatile discs, only to find an underwhelming assortment, given the current ubiquity of streaming services and digital acquisition methods. Nonetheless, the store's personnel were quite hospitable and proffered assistance in locating specific items, thereby contributing to a partially redeeming experience."

Got a cotton candy-flavored sorbet superimposed upon a bed of rich vanilla custard, which was embellished with a generous sprinkling of multi-colored sprinkles. The overall taste experience was nothing short of sublime, with the sweetness perfectly balanced to avoid being overpowering. The texture of the custard was remarkably smooth and velvety, possessing a luxurious quality that made me concerned for the structural integrity of the flimsy plastic spoon provided by the establishment. Although the service was generally helpful and accommodating, the demeanor of the servers seemed somewhat lackluster and mechanical, giving the impression that their presence was not entirely voluntary. The interior design of the shop evoked a sense of familiarity and comfort, reminiscent of a Baskin Robbins ice cream parlor, albeit with a slightly more dimly lit atmosphere. To optimize the enjoyment of your visit, it is recommended that you request your order to-go and partake of it in the proximate park, thus enabling you to savor the flavors and textures without being burdened by the constraints of a traditional dining setting.

"The retail establishment in question boasts an adequate square footage, housing an extensive array of affordable items that could be considered stylish, albeit to a limited extent.  A considerable number of patrons were present within the premises, engaged in the act of purchasing a substantial quantity of apparel.  Despite my initial reluctance, I found myself succumbing to the impulse to acquire a novel item for the purpose of transporting it back to my domicile, the rationale behind this decision remaining somewhat nebulous."

We have friends who rave about mu shu. We like it, but not enough to make it regular, and we live just a few blocks away. Price/value is measured in pounds. Friendly service, still it's cafeteria quality

Throughout our numerous excursions to Arizona, we invariably found ourselves passing by Nielsen's Frozen Custard while en route to and from our accommodations and our daughter's residence. On each occasion, I would mentally note that we absolutely had to sample their offerings. Unfortunately, we frequently encountered the establishment during its closure, thereby thwarting our intentions. However, during our final visit (which coincided with our daughter's relocation), we finally managed to arrive at the establishment when it was open for business.

Upon entering the premises, we were taken aback by the discovery that Nielsen's Frozen Custard offered more than just frozen treats; they also served an assortment of meals, including burgers, sandwiches, and salads. Our primary focus, however, remained the frozen custard.

We were warmly received by a courteous young woman who attended to us from behind the counter. She exhibited great patience as we carefully scrutinized the extensive menu featuring an abundance of toppings. Ultimately, I opted for a modest cup of vanilla frozen custard adorned with sprinkles, while my spouse selected a small, unembellished chocolate custard. Following our order, we were assigned a number to display on our table, and the young woman promptly delivered our selections.

Both my companion and I concurred that the texture of the frozen custard was pleasantly smooth and creamy. Regrettably, we found that the flavors did not live up to our expectations. Neither the vanilla nor the chocolate variant possessed a robust sufficient flavor, which proved somewhat disillusioning. Despite this, we do not lament attempting it. Had we not done so, the omission would have persistently troubled me, leaving me wondering if we had missed out on something truly exceptional.

"Amidst the frenzied ambiance of CES week, we opted for a clean yet moderately priced hotel, shelling out approximately $160 per night for a four-night stay. Unfortunately, our room was designated for smoking, which resulted in an audible proximity to the neighboring room's plumbing, unsightly stains in the bathroom and toilet attributed to cigarette burns, and a sitting chair bearing conspicuous white stains. To our dismay, a mere $5 was required to access hot water, an exorbitant price point that seemed incongruous with the otherwise luxurious amenities offered by the establishment. In response, we devised an ingenious solution, utilizing a glass cup and iron to surreptitiously heat water, thus circumventing the egregious fee. Our clandestine maneuver elicited mirth, as we revelled in our resourcefulness, much to the chagrin of the hotel's presumptive attempts to exploit us for every conceivable amenity."

"The Beehive, situated within Edinburgh's historic Grassmarket district, boasts an extensive array of libations and a commodious interior, replete with a sophisticated ambiance that exudes an air of refined conviviality. Patrons seeking a respite from the bustling thoroughfares may opt to indulge in the tranquil delights of the establishment's secluded rear garden during the balmy summer months, while those desiring a more rarefied dining experience can ascend to the second floor, where a serene and intimate setting awaits. Additionally, the Beehive has cultivated a reputation as a stalwart purveyor of unconventional comedic performances during the city's renowned arts festivals, with a diminutive, albeit charming, upper-level space metamorphosing into an inviting and captivating venue for avant-garde and surrealist entertainment. Kudos, Beehive, for your steadfast dedication to catering to the variegated preferences of your clientele."

We tend to visit this particular establishment when we are not particularly inclined to venture forth on an extensive excursion, or alternatively, when we happen to be within the confines of the shopping plaza and are in dire need of sustenance for our reptilian companions in the form of feeder crickets. However, it has been our experience that securing assistance from an employee can be a rather arduous task, even after soliciting the aid of multiple individuals, numbering up to four. Notwithstanding this, the cashiers have consistently displayed a cordial demeanor towards us, and on occasion, have even extended generous discounts to us as compensation for enduring prolonged waiting periods while they endeavored to facilitate the processing of a customer's transaction. Despite these factors, we shall continue to patronize this business for the same reasons that initially drew us to it, although it does not hold the distinction of being our premier choice among establishments specializing in the sale of items related to the care and well-being of pets.

this Frys has come a long way,  there selection of better quality and variety , decent selection of avalible produce organic as well as non and  breads,i can usually find a decent selection of meats, lamb seems to be hit and miss same with fish I dont under stand why they buy farm raised color added salmon ...oh and from the east coast except maybe for the price aspect hey fish buyer for frys the nw is alot closer and offers better quality  salmon but my biggest pet peive w/this store is the service at the deli there slow and incompetent i dont know how many times i have waited way to long to be waited on and ended up just walking away or avoiding the deli all together knowing the outcome .......

I'm not sure why they call themselves barcelona, not very authetic spanish cooking. but the tapas are good. they could have a bigger selection of tapas. service was excelant. check them out on half price night!!! And try the Sangrias, free samples are available...

I don't get the 2+ hour wait? 

The hostess isn't very nice. Had two encounters with her and she's just snobby.

Anyways, the food... Shared a bunch of stuff. The pork belly tacos, bone marrow, tzatziki dip, skewers with chimichurri, a sushi roll. All were okay but nothing super amazing. The skewers were a little bland. 

Had the pistachio ice cream which was good but super melted when it came out.

Again, don't understand the hype. It was okay but don't think I'll be back anytime soon.

"Halted momentarily at a sushi establishment, we immersed ourselves in an ambiance replete with contemporary flair, the sonic accompaniment of boisterous club music serving to enhance our culinary experience, while a vintage Bruce Lee film projection on the wall elicited several chuckles. The sushi itself was fresh, and though we opted for a couple of traditional maki rolls - specifically, spicy tuna and California varieties - both dishes were comparable in quality to those offered by the majority of sushi restaurants. Additionally, the 22-ounce can of Sapporo beer featured a distinctive steel-shaped design that piqued our curiosity."

This small place is not easy to find.  They have a good menu, I ordered the fried beef flat noodle to go.  It was just okay.  \nThe owner speaks Cantonese and I was able to chat with them a bit.  I think I need to order something else next time just so I can provide a better review for this place.  But the first dish didn't pass my test. \nI will go back to try other things.

"My personal opinion regarding Rito's is that the prices they charge are somewhat excessive in relation to the quantity and quality of the food provided. Specifically, the burritos appear large due to the employment of an oversized tortilla, which, upon closer inspection, reveals a relatively meager amount of meat, resulting in a disproportionate ratio of tortilla to filling. In the case of the green chile burrito I had the pleasure of sampling, if the portion size of the meat had been more generous, perhaps the price point of $8 would have been more palatable. However, I must admit that the beans were of superior quality and the salsa, albeit available at an additional cost of 25 cents for a mere two tablespoons, was truly exceptional. Despite these positive aspects, my overall dining experience at Rito's failed to meet my expectations, as the flavors and presentation of the dishes did not differ significantly from those I have enjoyed in the past, prompting a nostalgic desire to embrace my mother.":

I would like to try Richardson's again. I went on a date here and we were going to order a couple things off the menu, but the manager said, "Let me take care of you- you're going to love this". We looked at each other (date and I) and were like, "Ok, I guess".

The manager sent out a garlic plate. It wasn't the worst thing for a date, since roasted garlic isn't stinky, but it was a cheesy heavy gross mess for me. I'm not into that kind of food at all and would have much preferred to choose something different. It was huge as well, we couldn't even finish it and didn't have any room to try any entrees on the menu. 

So, well, next time I know better and will stick to my own palate preferences rather than be persuaded by  a stranger that thinks first date food should be the size and style of a fancy superbowl platter. The dish wasn't gross, but it was incredibly heavy for 2 people. i might order that as an app if I was with a party of 4 or larger.

Overall, the place is beautiful and it's a great date spot. Call ahead and make a reservation though. I hope one day I can go again and try something that I like better.

"This drinking establishment, characterized by its pronounced horizontal orientation and staffed by diminutive individuals, constitutes merely one aspect of the venue's multifaceted nature. The ambiance of Giligin's, reminiscent of a tawdry yet entertaining relative, permeates every detail, from the viscous floor surface to the capricious pendulum suspended in the bar area, the chilled display cases behind the counter resembling a spirits emporium, and the nightly promotional schemes such as the aforementioned goldfish races. Although a menu is available, I must confess that apprehension prevents me from partaking in their culinary offerings. My previous visit to this establishment, which coincided with the fervor surrounding the Super Bowl festivities hosted by FBR, proved to be an exhilarating experience, complete with $1 jello shot specials and an opportunity to capture photographic memories with the Captain Morgan mascot. Subsequently, I found myself meandering within the premises, brandishing a large Coors Light container, while engaging in a spirited game of beanbag toss with a visiting female participant from Wisconsin, ultimately resulting in my defeat."

If I could eat the pepper jack mac and cheese all day long, I would. I get it every time I go. The sandwiches are pretty good too. It's got a great, laid back atmosphere where you can get pretty decent bar food and a have a beer or two.

CVS is known as a great Pharmaceutical chain that also offers everyday grocery items.  This store located off the 215 and Valley Verede is a great addition to this wonderful chain.\n\nThe savings and weekly specials are very hard to beat at CVS.  I have always enjoyed the service and 24 hour drive through Pharmacy at almost every location.  Awesome store!!!
Chicken parm was just average. Field greens salad was great. Wait staff was great. The seating is right under the blue sky and in front of a large fountain in the Forum Shops.

"If this putative golf club is indeed an establishment dedicated to the pursuit of golfing activities, then I must be the legendary yeti, for it appears that no golf balls are being struck with any degree of proficiency within these premises, which ostensibly purport to offer a tranquil ambiance conducive to the enjoyment of a round of golf, but in reality seem to be lacking in the essential elements necessary to facilitate such a sporting endeavor."

"Although my affection for the concept of Sidebar remains intact, my fondness for the venue itself is somewhat mitigated by my underwhelming experiences there. While the beverages they offer are certainly passable, I have found the atmosphere to be less than enjoyable on multiple occasions. Specifically, I have visited the establishment twice, with vastly differing results. During my initial visit, I had the pleasure of being served by a charismatic and knowledgeable bartender who hailed from San Francisco, and I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed his company and the overall experience. However, my subsequent visit proved to be a stark contrast, as the bartender who attended to me was not only unfriendly but also displayed an air of superiority when addressing queries from patrons, which I found particularly vexing and ultimately detracted from my enjoyment of the outing. Suffice it to say, I have not returned to Sidebar since then."

This is a fairly new place.  It's charming and homey.  The restaurant has been very clean both times we visited.  Both times there we sat at the bar, and drinks were made well, however we did not eat.  They do not have beer on tap and carry no craft beers, although one of the owners days that will change soon.  They have a nice bar, however the bar top is not as wife as the foot step on the bottom of the bar, making sitting at the bar rather uncomfortable.  They do have a game room in the back with pool tables, foosball and darts.  They also have a back patio with corn hole and horseshoes.  Being new, the service is a little slow and they don't seen to have enough staff, but maybe that was the time of day we went there each time.  We will definitely go back and try their barbeque.

"Whenever I find myself in the city of Las Vegas, I take great pleasure in indulging in a delectable dining experience at an upscale restaurant. On this particular occasion, my culinary destination of choice was a renowned establishment known for its exceptional fare. Upon perusing the menu, we elected to initiate our gastronomic journey with a pair of tantalizing appetizers - the bone marrow and maple glazed pork belly. Suffice it to say, these initial offerings were nothing short of sublime, boasting a rich, velvety texture that literally melted in our mouths. For our primary courses, I opted for the 8 oz. filet mignon/American Wagyu, while my companion selected the 'A tasting of New York sirloin.' In accordance with our individual preferences, we requested that our steaks be prepared at a medium-rare temperature. To complement our delectable entrees, we also ordered an assortment of sides, including wild field mushrooms, creamed spinach, and broccoli-rapini. Lastly, we paired our meal with a bottle of exquisite red wine (the specific label escapes my memory). As our steaks and sides arrived, I eagerly anticipated savoring the expertly cooked, crustacean delight that lay before me. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, as I found my steak to be overcooked and, thus, not particularly appealing to my palate. Despite the disappointment, I did manage to appreciate the finely crafted wine and the remaining sides we had ordered. It is worth mentioning that, due to my underwhelming experience with the steak, I do not foresee myself returning to this particular dining establishment in the future."

Parking SUCKS.
Everything is over priced. 

It took me 25 minutes to get a cup of coffee, and I wouldn't have minded the wait if someone had acknowledged my presence and given the polite "I'll be with you as soon as possible" report. Clearly, that was too much to ask for.

But if you happen to go when it's not busy (i'm not sure when this is...) I'm fairly certain the ambiance would be delightful. It's an interesting concept. Also, the spaces are WAY too tight for the type of traffic they have in there.

The gelato on the South side of the building is really bland and boring. I'd rather eat store brand ice cream. Their Pizza is really awesome, though.

Great idea - mediocre execution.

Ladies, it is imperative that you exercise utmost vigilance, particularly on a Saturday evening, as the nocturnal atmosphere can sometimes foster nefarious activities. I personally experienced a distressing episode last night, wherein I and a few acquaintances convened at this establishment for some refreshments. We requested beverages from the server, who retrieved them from the interior bar, thereby precluding us from observing their preparation or having any knowledge of who may have had access to them prior to their delivery to our table. Following the consumption of merely one Cosmopolitan, I encountered an unusual sensation of impaired mobility and subsequently felt extremely unwell throughout the night. This anomalous occurrence has never transpired previously, leading me to suspect that some unknown substance may have been surreptitiously introduced into my beverage. Although it is impossible to pinpoint the perpetrator with certainty, it is conceivable that a patron in close proximity to the bar, either intentionally or unintentionally, contributed to this unsettling incident. Fortunately, my associates were present to ensure my safe return home, thus averting any further potential hazards. This experience serves as a poignant reminder to constantly monitor your beverages from the moment they are poured, irrespective of the venue, in order to avert any potential jeopardy to your personal well-being.

"A certain individual within this establishment appears to be nonchalant towards their responsibilities, which is an anomaly among the diligent staff members I have had the pleasure of interacting with during my numerous visits to Bookman's over the years. Perhaps it can be attributed to advanced age or a particularly trying day, but this employee failed to display even a cursory interest in the assortment of items I was presenting for trade, dismissing them outright without so much as a fleeting glance. This lackadaisical attitude is unprecedented, as I have consistently experienced courteous and efficient service at this very store, save for this singular instance. Notwithstanding, I opted to peruse the premises in search of alternative treasures, and indeed discovered two coveted items that had long eluded my grasp. However, in light of the aforementioned disagreeable encounter, I chose to reconsider my purchase and relinquish said items back unto the shelves."

Went here for lunch today for the first time and loved the atmosphere and service. Everyone was super nice and helpful and the booths are so cushy and comfy! 

My friend and I shared the Mushroom and Sausage Pizza and the Chicken Chopped Salad. The crust, mushrooms and sausage on the pizza were excellent. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the red sauce. It needed more development, it tasted a bit like tomato paste out of the can. 

The chicken in the salad was grilled and in nice, small, easy-to-eat pieces. The dressing was a bit watered down and lacking in flavor. 

All in all, it seemed like Nook just needs a little bit of fine-tuning but has great potential. I would definitely be willing to give it another go, mainly based on the excellent service.

"Underwhelming encounter with too much repetition."

The original text describes a person's experience at a bar as average, mentioning the view, location, and drinks. To modify it to use longer and more complex sentences and professional vocabulary, we can rephrase it as follows:

"An experience that fell short of expectations, characterized by a sense of monotony and lackluster surroundings, albeit with a few redeeming features."

This modified text uses longer sentences and more advanced vocabulary, such as "fell short of expectations," "monotony," and "lackluster surroundings," while still conveying the same meaning as the original text. It also maintains the same tone and structure, with a brief description of the experience followed by a mention of the location and drinks.

Here's a breakdown of the modifications made:

* "Pretty average experience" became "An experience that fell short of expectations." This phrase is more formal and implies a certain level of disappointment.
* "Great view" became "A sense of monotony." This phrase suggests a feeling of repetition or dullness, which can be seen in the context of the abandoned buildings and lack of excitement.
* "Until you walk closer to the wall and you see nothing but abandoned buildings until you see South Mountain" became "Albeit with a few redeeming features." This phrase acknowledges that there were some positive aspects to the experience, but they were not enough to overcome the overall feeling of disappointment.
* "It was cool being next to US Airways Arena and Chase field" became "Characterized by a sense of proximity to notable landmarks." This phrase uses more formal language to describe the location of the bar in relation to nearby attractions.
* "For some reason I thought this bar was on the top of the hotel, but it's only on the third floor" became "Boasting an unremarkable altitude." This phrase uses more formal language to describe the location of the bar within the hotel, emphasizing its lack of distinction.
* "Decent spot, drinks were okay, I might come back again if people from out of town are here" became "With a few redeeming features, including an acceptable ambiance and passable beverages, the possibility of future visits remains." This phrase uses more formal language to describe the positive aspects of the bar, while also acknowledging that the experience was not entirely satisfactory.

I admit we went here because of DDD (Guy Fieri).  The dive atmosphere did not disappoint.  Good bartender, even though the bar was wet/sticky.  We ordered wings and pizza.  The wings were very good, as was the pizza, although it took a very long time before the food came out.  \n\nThe food was good, but they don't have the ability to handle the popularity of this place.  It's a tiny kitchen with one person cooking.

"It is rather perplexing, to say the least, that my experiences at Herb 'n Flavors have been so inconsistent, as if an unseen force is dictating the culinary outcomes. While some dishes undoubtedly boast delectable flavors, others fall short of expectations, rendering the entire experience a veritable gamble. The first time I visited this establishment, I opted for the Spinach 4-Cheese Quesadilla, only to be met with a dish that was excessively oily and cheesy, bordering on overwhelming. Mind you, I am cognizant of the fact that the name itself implies a generous amount of cheese, yet there exists a delicate equilibrium that must be struck in order to achieve true gastronomic harmony. In contrast, my companion's rendition of the same dish, ordered on a separate occasion, was much more balanced in its composition. On a subsequent visit, I elected to sample the Veggie Rice Bowl, which, while flavorful, suffered from an unfortunate overcooking of the tofu. Furthermore, our order of the Vegan Spinach & Artichoke Dip proved underwhelming, prompting us to seek alternatives. My friend, however, found great pleasure in their salmon entree, while another acquaintance enjoyed both the Pollo Fresca and the Chicken Shawarma Wrap. During my third visit, I opted for the Veggie Bowl once again, omitting the tofu this time around, and found it significantly improved. The falafel fries, too, were quite satisfying, and the tiramisu, nothing short of extraordinary. It would be remiss of me not to mention the proprietor's exceptional people skills and innate ability to cater to his clientele, fostering a welcoming atmosphere that encourages return visits for those items that truly excel."

The place is fine, but a bit loud when crowded. Plenty of people with laptops and couples chatting away. The coffee was standard fare, as in sugary and tasty. The two things that I noticed are the number of tables made it feel crowded even when the number of people dwindled, and the bathroom was not the cleanest I have seen in other stores. Although not my favorite place, it's a good place to pop in or stay awhile, just a bit tight if at capacity. I would return.

I accompanied my mother to this establishment with the intention of procuring a takeout meal, as she has expressed a predilection for this particular venue. Despite possessing a preferred Chinese restaurant, I opted to acquiesce to her desire. Upon entering the premises, I observed that the ambiance was clean and well-maintained. However, I must admit that the visual representations of the culinary offerings were somewhat perplexing, as I was unable to accurately identify any of the dishes depicted.  

The quality of service was satisfactory, as the server was attentive and responsive to our needs. I requested a Sprite from the fountain beverage dispenser, but upon consuming it, I discovered that it did not conform to my expectations. I brought this to the attention of the counter attendant, who displayed an indifferent demeanor and failed to demonstrate any inclination towards investigating the issue. Subsequently, I sampled the lemonade, only to find that it consisted of nothing more than plain water. Furthermore, upon attempting to discard the liquid, I noticed minute particles floating within my cup. Disheartened by these experiences, I decided to forgo further exploration of the beverage options and instead focused on the food menu.  

It is worth mentioning that this establishment offers luncheon specials during the afternoon hours, which may potentially provide patrons with an economical dining alternative. Unfortunately, due to our late arrival, we were unable to sample these purportedly reasonably priced selections. My meal of choice was Udon soup, which, despite its flavorful nature, left me feeling somewhat uneasy due to my persistent concerns regarding the cleanliness of the food preparation area. As an advocate for supporting local enterprises, I acknowledge the importance of initial impressions and fear that this encounter may have compromised my future patronage.

"Concurring with previous patrons, this bowling alley boasts an agreeable ambiance. We arrived at approximately 5 pm on a Friday evening, only to be met with a considerable waiting period of sixty minutes, which proved to be a slight disappointment. Undeterred, we opted to await our turn while engaging in the entertainment offered within the arcade, which featured modern and well-maintained equipment, albeit at exorbitant prices. For individuals who are willing to invest a modest sum, this venue may offer a satisfactory experience, though it may be wise to consider visiting during a less hectic period, as we intend to do in the future."

Went here for lunch with my 2.5 month old on a Friday because I had a taste for some pasta, plus I had a rewards card coupon. It wasn't crowded at 1:30. Because I had a stroller, I opted to sit in the bar area. It took 5 min. for someone to come over to see what I wanted to drink. Since, it took so long for drinks, I went ahead and ordered when she came over. Food came out fairly quickly and was tasty. However, I only had water and I only got a refill when it was time to bring me my check. 

I thought the bartender/waitress was strictly for the bar area and it would be fast service, but I was wrong. 

Also, they have a good happy hour, so that would be the only reason I would go back.

This eatery exudes an eccentric ambiance redolent of a venue one might encounter in Los Angeles, thereby evoking a sense of familiarity and nostalgia. The hospitality we received was exemplary, as the staff exhibited a proficient and attentive demeanor throughout our visit. Notwithstanding its emphasis on uncooked and plant-based cuisine, the menu offered an array of options encompassing both cooked fare and meat dishes, thereby catering to a wide range of palates and dietary preferences. However, my sole criticism pertains to the excessive saltiness imbuing each dish, which seemed a deliberate attempt to compensate for the absence of culinary preparation. Notwithstanding this flaw, the assortment of sweet treats proved delectable, albeit the pastry crusts displayed an equal propensity towards saltiness. Moreover, I found myself consuming an excessive quantity of water, to the extent of six glasses, which I deemed rather extreme.

My significant other and I had the pleasure of dining at this esteemed establishment approximately two months prior, and while the culinary experience was not without its shortcomings, specifically pertaining to an unfortunate mix-up in our order and that of another table, which, albeit understandable, proved somewhat vexing; the gastronomical offerings, upon closer inspection, revealed themselves to be of satisfactory quality, albeit lacking that certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to the realm of true gustatory excellence. Notwithstanding, we are amenable to venturing forth and partaking in a renewed gastronomical exploration of the menu, with the aim of sample a diverse array of dishes and perhaps even indulging in a spot of avian observation, courtesy of the adjacent bird cages, which, might I add, possessed a certain unique charm.

Was mostly disappointed here.  Had heard good things, but the pizza was mostly uninspiring.  The crust was bland... and too dense/hard/chewy.  I appreciate light and airy crusts and that was what I was expecting, but really nothing like it came through.  The fig appetizer was delicious, but otherwise not really worth the $$ I spent.

Johnny Rockets holds a special place in my heart with memories of mall trips with my friends in high school. This location wasn't as fantastic as those of my past. There's only bar-seating and everything is definitely rushed. They've done well with they space they have, but I truly miss being able to tuck into a booth, listen to our own jukebox and sip on a beautifully pulled milkshake. \n\nUpon our trip we ordered a Big Apple shake and a Dark Chocolate shake. We received one but not the other and had to fight for the attention of the staff to ask for our second shake, which was definitely not even on the radar of being made. Once we actually received the second shake, everything was delicious - but it's just not the experience we were hoping for :/

I stopped in here for lunch today, joined this time by friends Shelley M. & Arlin B.  Here's the long and short of it:

*  The food they serve here tastes great!  (That's one thing, isn't it?)

HOWEVER:

*  The first time I came it was freezing cold inside!

*  The second time I came it was roasting hot inside!

*  This time it was freezing cold inside!

*  The service wasn't as friendly this time as during my previous visits.

*  Our food all arrived on one tray, & it was up to us to try to figure out what was what.

*  They usually give each diner a little tray of cooked onions, peppers, plus lemon & lime slices, but this time we only received two of these trays for the three of us.     :-(

The temperature should be controlled better in here, & it's important for the counter & table service to remain friendly, as it was before!

My order this time was for...

Carne Asada (beef) Taco:  $1.25
Al Pastor (pork) Taco:  $1.25
Pescado (fish) Taco:  $2
Beef Tamale:  $2

"I assure you that I shall endeavor to provide an enhanced assessment of this establishment, as I habitually aspire to compose a laudatory critique of any venue. Their sushi was indeed delectable, despite the fact that I opted to consume it off-premises; it may have been even more scrumptious had I consumed it on location. 

It appears that they offer a satisfactory happy hour menu, which I intend to sample in the near future. 

During my wait, I couldn't help but notice that the music was rather boisterous, making conversation somewhat challenging. The prices, however, seem to be aligned with those of other sushi restaurants in the area. 

Thus, I anticipate the opportunity to indulge in a meal within the restaurant's confines, thereby permitting me to enhance my evaluation."

"A thirty-five minute wait is indicative of a culinary experience of considerable quality, and the complimentary coffee served outside during this interval serves as an additional testament to the establishment's commitment to providing an exceptional dining experience for its patrons. The interior design of the restaurant evokes the warmth and hospitality of a quaint southern cottage, which harmonizes seamlessly with the attentive and personable service provided by the staff, who operate under a unique system in which no server is assigned to a specific table, but rather collaborate to ensure that all guests receive equal attention and care. Upon arriving for breakfast, I was eager to sample the stuffed French toast, but being averse to peanut butter, I requested a modification to incorporate Nutella and bananas instead; much to my satisfaction, this request was accommodated without hesitation. However, upon the arrival of my meal, it became apparent that the Nutella utilized in the dish was not the rich, deep brown variety I had anticipated, but rather a lighter hue that suggested a blend with cream cheese; upon tasting it, my suspicions were confirmed, as the flavor profile was decidedly more cream cheese than Nutella, resulting in a sense of disappointment and underwhelment. In contrast, three out of five members of our party opted for the corned beef hash, which proved to be a superior choice, surpassing my own French toast experience in terms of both taste and satisfaction."

"When I am experiencing an excessive workload and feeling overwhelmed, I occasionally enter a state of efficiency-oriented task management, which I have come to refer to as 'old-people f*#k mode.' This mindset enables me to prioritize the expediency of task completion, superseding any concerns regarding the conventional norms of decorum or aesthetic appeal. It is my suspicion that the culinary staff at AF (presumably acronymic for 'Another Fiasco') adopt a comparable approach during periods of high volume, such as when the establishment is teeming with patrons, as evidenced by my recent experience with the herb roasted chicken sandwich - a longstanding favorite of mine that suddenly became my least preferred option after a single visit. On this particular occasion, the restaurant appeared to be hosting an array of celebratory events, including multiple elderly women's birthday parties, baby showers, and other gender-specific gatherings. The kitchen staff seemed to be overwhelmed, resorting to haphazardly assembling dishes with an unrefined, unrestrained manner, reminiscent of simian creatures assuming culinary duties. The end result was a meal that fell short of my customary expectations. Consequently, I would recommend visiting this establishment during less busy times to optimize the likelihood of enjoying a satisfying dining experience, unaccompanied by the distraction of nearby revelers boasting about their tropical vacations and public displays of nudity."

"Upon perusing the menu and partaking in a meal at this establishment, I must say that while the culinary offerings were satisfactory, they did not warrant such effusive praise.  The closing time of 7 pm on a Saturday evening was particularly vexing, as it precluded the possibility of enjoying a leisurely dining experience.  Furthermore, the portion size of the fried chicken was somewhat meager, despite its juiciness and adequate seasoning.  The macaroni and cheese, regrettably, appeared to be fabricated from a processed, liquid cheese substitute, rather than being prepared with the meticulous attention to detail that would have elevated it to truly delectable heights.  As a consequence, my patronage will likely be directed towards Honey Bears, where the craving for gluttonous indulgence can be satiated more effectively.  It is my conviction that Lolo's could benefit from soliciting external input regarding their cuisine and menu, in order to enhance their competitiveness within a market replete with superior quality establishments offering commensurate or superior service and ambiance."

Starbucks has become quite the institution here in the good ole' USA. As most folks do, I enjoy their coffee. Generally I'm a Venti Mocha, no whip kind of girl but on occasion I will branch out and try a Columbian Roast or a Frappaccino.
The breakfast sandwiches are not the best, but better tasting than McDonald's in my opinion. The bakery items are fine for prepackaged stuff. 
I don't usually go in as it's always crowded, there is a long line (even in the drive thru - plan a few extra minutes for waiting) and for some reason it's always cold. 

All in all I prefer home grown coffee shops or small hole in the wall places but this is, just as it is called, a Starbucks, and nothing more.

I was experiencing an intense yearning for the frozen hot chocolate, which, upon consumption, proved to be of considerable proportions and somewhat formidable in its taste, although it did not entirely align with my previous experiences of the beverage in New York... 

We had also requested a variety of other items such as the nachos, a burger, and a hotdog, all of which were of satisfactory quality, but their prices, in relation to their culinary value, seemed slightly disproportionate, considering the nature of the establishment and the fact that the fare was merely a few notches above what one would typically find at a diner... 
Wishing to save some space for a sweet treat, we opted to forgo dessert on this particular visit, intending to reserve it for a future occasion when we could indulge in it without restraint... 

The service we received was somewhat lacking, as our server's attentiveness waned at times, necessitating our intervention to ensure the timely procurement of certain essentials. Nonetheless, the restaurant did accept Harris' complimentary coupons, which served as a minor redeeming factor.

There are many bigger and better Harris Teeter locations in Charlotte, but if you live in Plaza Midwood or NoDa, this one is your best option. Unfortunately, the produce there isn't great. And the location is pretty small. It's packed and frustrating around 6 pm, when everyone is getting off work and stopping there to buy groceries. I will say, the VIC card rewards are pretty good. You get good deals, and I got free luggage once through the program.

This spot is great had a little trouble checking in as the system went down right when we got there, the free breakfast from 6-9am made up for the lost time will be checking out all the other spots that offer free breakfast for now on now that i know they exsist

There's no doubt that XS is a beautiful club.  But, I really didn't have much of a great time here considering it's suppose to be one the best in Sin City. Maybe, it was the music.  Which was more Techno than Hip Hop.  Or maybe it was the crowd, which I wasn't feeling.  There were some nice ones out of the bunch, but most of them were stuck-up. Although, I have to give it up to security though, because they sure did a good job at making that line move.  I was kinda feelin' bad for the guys during Memorial Day Weekend though.  The cover charge to get in for a guy at XS was $100 and later on that night it jumped to $200 just to get in!  

Ridiculously XS-cessive indeed!

But honestly didn't think it was quite worth all the hype.

Waitstaff was great!   Food was excellent.   \nUnfortunately the manager was not very helpful.   There was a large party seated prior to us and held up the kitchen.  The manager did not come over and explain the situation nor asked what can be done to help the extra long wait.   The manager also did not help out with the last minute confusion at the end of the meal.
Lee's sandwiches are lee's sandwiches iam just excited I don't have to drive all the way to China Town to get my Viet Sandwich fix...Yay!!!
Cafe has new owners that are very nice as well as the staff.  We ordered burgers, fries, salads, and grilled ham and cheese sandwich.  All were delicious!

"The Sunflower store has undergone a transformation following its acquisition by Sprouts, and unfortunately, the changes implemented do not appear to be an improvement. Although this location still offers a limited array of Boar's Head Deli Meats and a few varieties of cheese, the meat and seafood counter has been reduced in size and is now manned by friendly personnel. The majority of the store's floor space is dedicated to showcasing an extensive selection of fresh produce; however, the prices, while not exorbitant, are comparable to or lower than those at Whole Foods. 

It is worth noting that since Sprouts took over, the quality and variety of their supplement selection have diminished. For instance, previously, there were five distinct options for Kava Kava capsules available, but upon my most recent visit, only two remained, and the brands they carried were not ones I would consider purchasing. While this location may serve as a suitable starting point for individuals seeking basic supplements, seasoned supplement users may find the selection to be somewhat disappointing. 

Despite my desire to endorse this store, three stars remain the highest rating I can bestow upon it."

"Meh..not particularly memorable, this dining establishment, although, I must admit, I have partaken in culinary indulgences at this location, as well as the one situated proximal to Arizona State University, albeit, I prefer this venue slightly more, due to its ambiance, which, I must say, is quite pleasant, despite its lack of memorability, in my humble opinion. However, I would only consider satiating my hunger at this eatery if I happened to be strolling past it, and my stomach was growling fiercely, as the fare served here does not exactly qualify as gourmet cuisine, in my esteemed view. Nonetheless, the cookies offered by this establishment are, indeed, delectable, and I must commend them for providing a complimentary cookie with each sandwich purchase, a gesture which I find both thoughtful and appreciated, and, might I add, their selection of Jones Soda flavors, specifically the sugar-free black cherry variety, is quite impressive, and, I must confess, I found myself quite taken by its unique and refreshing taste. However, I must issue a word of caution regarding the roast beef sandwich, specifically the 'Overture' variant, as it arrives adorned with a generous helping of horseradish sauce, which, while undoubtedly delicious, proved almost unbearably piquant for my sensitive nasal passages, causing my nose to transform into a veritable fountain of mucus, if you will, thereby necessitating copious quantities of tissues, and, perhaps, a brief respite from the consumption of solid foods, in order to allow my sinuses to recover from the onslaught of spicy flavors. In conclusion, while this restaurant may possess some redeeming qualities, I would, in all honesty, recommend dining at Opa Grill, situated adjacent to this establishment, as the culinary offerings therein are, in my expert opinion, vastly superior, and well worth the nominal additional expense, if one is seeking a truly satisfying dining experience."

"Gastronomical establishment with an intriguing ambiance, offering a restricted culinary selection at present, which I presume will expand as the venue matures and discovers its niche. My dining companion and I partook of the cheese plate (satisfactory), beets (exceptional), mussels (excellent), and iceberg salad (substantial and flavorful). An adequate assortment of brews was available for our perusal. However, the musical accompaniment was somewhat discordant. I surmise that this aspect, too, shall undergo transformation in due time. The morning meal menu, boasting an array of delectable options, piqued my interest and warrants further exploration during a future visit."

Went here for breakfast last Monday and had to wait almost 20 mins to be seated as it was very busy. This also showed in the food which seemed to be hurriedly prepared. I had the pancake combo and found the turkey bacon to be extremely salty and the pancakes themselves to be flat rather than fluffy. The other members in our group also felt that the food was lacking. So overall a very OK type of meal and nothing like the IHOP that i normally visit in Torrance.

"An exceedingly tranquil and understatedly fashionable district, characterized by an unpretentious ambiance that exudes a sense of relaxed refinement. Strategically positioned in close proximity to a stylish hair salon, providing patrons with the opportunity to indulge in a pampering session, followed by a leisurely sojourn on a comfortable bench situated in front of a picturesque window. The overall experience is reminiscent of the carefree and laid-back atmosphere synonymous with San Diego, California."

"The culinary experience at Delmonico's fell short of expectations, with the quality of the food being subpar. Specifically, the steak, which was advertised as the best in Las Vegas, failed to impress. Despite being cooked to perfection, the seasoning was uninspired and lacked depth, resulting in a mediocre dining experience. Furthermore, the sides, which included creamed spinach and asparagus, were underwhelming and did not live up to their potential. The dessert menu also left much to be desired, further detracting from the overall enjoyment of the meal. However, the wine list was extensive and impressive, showcasing a thoughtful selection of vintages. In light of the high standards set by other establishments in Las Vegas, Delmonico's fails to stand out as a premier dining destination."

"Having had this establishment on my culinary radar for an extended period of time, I decided to pay a visit with a companion subsequent to participating in the National Kidney Foundation Walk. Upon perusing their online menu, I was particularly intrigued by the pear omelet and was eager to sample it. To my surprise, we were promptly seated upon arrival, despite my anticipation of a considerable delay due to the lateness of the morning and the likelihood of a sizable crowd. The ambiance of the restaurant was reminiscent of a private residence, exuding a warm and welcoming atmosphere. However, my enthusiasm was somewhat diminished by the unsettling appearance of the thick gray carpeting, which struck me as unsanitary and questionable in terms of cleanliness. 

The pear omelet, while palatable, did not quite meet my expectations, primarily due to the scarcity of pears within. It seemed to me that the dish's namesake ingredient should have been more prominent. My companion and I couldn't help but notice the delectable appearances of the other patrons' meals, specifically the mouthwatering French toast, which piqued my interest and left me contemplating a future visit. 

In conclusion, our experience at this eatery was merely average, lacking any truly exceptional or remarkable aspects."

"A veritable cornucopia of gastronomical delights at an unparalleled price point, this esteemed eatery offers a diverse array of delectable dishes that cater to a wide range of palates, featuring none other than expertly crafted, hand-scooped ice cream, an unmitigated delight for the taste buds and a true embodiment of value for money. While the meat offerings may not necessarily conform to the lofty standards of haute cuisine, they are by no means inferior, with each dish showcasing a distinct flavor profile that is sure to satiate even the most discerning of diners. An ideal venue for a satisfying repast, especially given the reasonable prices, this restaurant is a veritable gem in the culinary landscape."

"Underwhelming gastronomical experiences were unfortunately abundant during my latest excursion to Montreal, specifically pertaining to the quality of their galettes, which fell short of my expectations and left me feeling disenchanted; however, it is worth mentioning that my local acquaintance, upon learning of my disappointment, responded with an air of vindication, stating 'I told you so'; nonetheless, it would be remiss of me not to acknowledge the establishment's proficiency in their dessert offerings, particularly those featuring chocolate, which Juliette et Chocolat executes with a certain degree of competence, thereby making them a viable option for those seeking sweet indulgences, but it is advisable to exercise caution when considering their dinner selections."

"This diminutive, charming establishment offers delectable pizza in both singular slice and entire pie formats, catering to patrons seeking a rapid, economical dining experience. While the quality of the culinary offerings may not be extraordinary, it surpasses the mediocrity of Sabarro's by an order of magnitude. For those seeking a brief, inexpensive respite from the rigors of travel, this cozy venue is an optimal choice, particularly when awaiting the arrival of associates at the aerodrome."

We enjoy happy hour here. The Tuscan Taster appetizers are very good. The spicy shrimp and eggplant varies from time to time in flavor and preparation ie., crispy vs oily. The burger is always a solid choice.  It would be nice for a healthy appetizer option.\nYou need to stick with the happy hour drinks or else your tab gets sky high quickly.\nAt the San Tan location, the blonde bar manager is efficient but super serious and curt.  We always leave satisfied but not thrilled.

"Wow, this is truly an unfortunate revelation, as my expectations were set on partaking in a delectable midday meal at this establishment, only to be met with an unanticipated impediment in the form of its unexpected closure. It appears that my lack of knowledge regarding its operational status has led to a profound sense of dismay and frustration, which I must now endeavour to overcome."

"Although my dining experience was generally satisfactory, I must express my reservations regarding the pricing policy implemented by this establishment. Specifically, the cost of the menu items appears to be disproportionate to the portion sizes, with the smallest sandwich and two accompanying sides amounting to a total of $11, an exorbitant sum that may deter potential patrons, particularly those with families to support. Furthermore, the additional fee of $1.99 for each drink, albeit a nominal amount, contributes to an overall sense of dissatisfaction with the value received for the price paid. In light of these concerns, it is suggested that management consider adopting a buffet-style format or increasing the quantity of food provided to justify the cost. Notwithstanding the aforementioned criticisms, the culinary quality of the dishes served did meet my expectations."

"The culinary offerings are of considerable quality, however, the selection could benefit from a more extensive array of options. The hospitality is satisfactory, yet the cacophony of sounds permeates the atmosphere, rendering communication with our server occasionally arduous. Despite this inconvenience, we shall undoubtedly revisit this establishment, as its ambiance evokes the essence of a sports bar, albeit with an excessive level of auditory stimulation."

I haven't stayed here but I've been inside. Hotel looks really nice. Nice lobby and very well decorated. Its located at a descent location on the Strip. However, their casino isn't the best. If you are a gambler, might wanna hit up some other casinos.

"An ostensibly salubrious edifice, however, my companions' culinary selections arrived precipitously prior to mine, despite my having placed my order simultaneously with theirs, which led to a considerable delay in satiating my esurient inclinations. Furthermore, I was perplexed by the restaurant's interpretation of'spicy mayo,' which consisted merely of a combination of mayonnaise and sriracha, an unorthodox approach considering the customary manner in which this condiment is prepared; additionally, the 'eel sauce' was mediocre, yet the 'rainbow roll' and 'eel roll' exhibited commendable gastronomical quality, as did my associates' choices ?an 'arizona roll,' a 'crunch roll,' and a 'california shrimp tempura roll.' Notwithstanding, my penchant for sauces remained unsatisfied, as the establishment seemed to be deficient in this particular aspect."

Last week, my sister and I ventured to this establishment, and my sentiments regarding our excursion are somewhat dichotomous. Upon entering the premises, we were greeted by an unoccupied ambiance, as there was no one present, which was rather perplexing. Following a prolonged period of time, a server materialized from the adjacent Z Pizza side, and we were finally able to peruse the menu. I opted for the Pink Spot sundae, which consisted of two copious scoops of kona coffee and hot fudge ice cream. Although the ice cream was somewhat lackluster, the hot fudge sauce was quite delectable and served in generous proportions. My sibling chose the low-fat coffee with chocolate ribbons, and she expressed great satisfaction with her selection. The prices, though not exorbitant, seemed reasonable considering the substantial serving sizes; interestingly, I had previously paid three dollars more for an identical item at Mary Coyle's merely a week prior. While I was not thoroughly enamored with the ice cream, I must commend them for consistently offering at least one low-fat, sugar-free, or sorbet option. Though it may not be my initial choice for an ice cream indulgence, the convenience afforded by their proximity to our location warrants a notable mention.

It required a considerable amount of time for me to deliberate on whether to confer 2 or 3 stars upon Diablo's. Ultimately, I opted for the latter rating, as most establishments of a similar caliber in Las Vegas tend to be quite pricey, and Diablo's offered delectable cuisine in generous portions. However, the service we received was utterly reprehensiblethe epitome of poor hospitality. Our server, during her brief appearances, exhibited blatant rudeness, seemingly intentionally. She displayed exasperation with my companion simply because they requested fresh cheese on their nachos instead of both fresh and processed cheese. The waitress heaved a heavy sigh and responded in an annoyed tone, Its NOT going to taste the same,?while rolling her eyes. Additionally, she grumbled, Well, what do you want??when taking our order, without so much as a greeting or acknowledging our presence. The entire dining experience was plagued by an array of unacceptable delays; our orders were not taken for at least 30 minutes, despite the restaurant being relatively unoccupied. Furthermore, it took over 90 minutes for our meals to arrive, followed by another 30 minutes to receive the check. A planned quick meal for five individuals turned into an excruciating, three-hour ordeal. One star for the abysmal service; five stars for the scrumptious food; and 2.5 stars for the questionable value.

I have had the privilege of visiting The Joint on three separate occasions, with the first instance being in the original venue and the subsequent two times in its newer, expanded iteration. In my opinion, the current layout of the Joint features a well-designed flow of people in and out, although I am perplexed as to why they opted against installing a reversible escalator, which would have enabled a portion of the crowd to descend via escalator and the remainder by stairs.

During my most recent visit to witness a performance by the legendary rock band KISS, I was seated in the balcony section. To my surprise, I found the balcony seating to be significantly more enjoyable than the floor seating, primarily due to the fact that the latter was characterized by an overwhelming sense of claustrophobia, with attendees packed tightly together like sardines. In contrast, the balcony offered plush, theatre-style seating that afforded me a high degree of comfort throughout the duration of the show.

The Joint's sound and lighting systems are truly exceptional, and KISS's elaborate pyrotechnic effects were accentuated by the superb lighting. One minor drawback was that the catwalk, while providing an excellent vantage point for certain sections of the audience, obstructed the view of the stage for some unfortunate individuals.

While there are only a select few performances that I would deem worthy of attendance at The Joint, I would certainly consider returning, provided that I could secure a table seat situated on one of the side balconies. This, in my estimation, would provide the optimal viewing experience.

As a final note, I highly recommend parking in the Paradise garage, as it offers effortless access to The Joint.

Forget the casino where your wallet takes a pounding, this is where your body takes punishment. But look at yourself in the mirror, man, you did it to yourself. Leg of lamb, prime rib, wild boar, kalbi ribs, spicy shrimp, mac-n-cheese, gnocchi, cheeses, salads, breads, and then the... OK stuff, which is too much too mention. Eye in the sky sees you eating like a gluttonous pig. Pace self with sanctity. #foodslut

This eatery has experienced fluctuations in quality, possessing an ambiance that exudes a charming, antiquated charm, particularly during the evening hours, rendering it an ideal setting for a romantic escapade. The culinary offerings are merely adequate, with prices that could be considered somewhat steep, and portion sizes that are either generous or suitable for sharing. However, the primary drawback of this establishment lies in its sluggish, unreliable, and unremarkable service, which significantly detracts from the overall dining experience, warranting a rating of two and a half stars. It is advisable to visit this restaurant on a bustling date night when they have an event scheduled, as it may enhance the experience. Nonetheless, it is not recommended to visit solely for a speedy lunch or for the food itself, given its subpar quality and lackluster service. Despite these shortcomings, the venue boasts a unique, vintage Vegas atmosphere and offers alcoholic beverages, making it a feasible choice for those seeking a nostalgic dining experience.

Decent bubble tea, surly service.  Got a ginger milk tea and asked what type of jelly they have (Didn't see any selections on the menu or on the board).  The woman at the register gave me a really dirty and annoyed look, and said \"What type are you looking for???\".... Not sure why that would cause such annoyance?  Anyways, my ginger milk tea with lychee jelly was OK, a bit too mild for me (just a hint of ginger flavor), and a bit too sweet.  Plus, it was WARM in there!  Please put the A/C on!  (Maybe that's why the cashier was so surly, I would be grumpy in such a warm store too if I had to be in there all the time!)
got two chocolate croissants and 1 mini cake..  \n\nIf i'm paying 2-3 dollar for a croissants at least enough chocolate for taste.

Mr. Lucky's is nothing special - except for their off menu $7.77 Special.  It's salad, steak and shrimp and mashed potatoes for $7.77.  It's a good meal for a good price at a 24/7 location. If you need something to eat and most of the places are closed - get this.\n\nObviously this is the reason to go here - just look at the other reviews!

"Thai Basil, a culinary establishment of Thai origin, offered an edible experience that was satisfactory, yet fell short of exceptional. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the Pad-see-ew, a stir-fried noodle dish, which, to my surprise, exhibited a palatable flavor profile, despite the lack of zest in the accompanying vegetables and poultry. Furthermore, my request for a moderate level of spiciness was not adequately fulfilled, as the dish was noticeably milder than anticipated. However, my beverage of choice, an iced Thai coffee, proved to be a delightful complement to my meal, and the hospitality displayed by the staff was undeniably cordial and attentive, as they kindly accommodated my brief absence to visit an adjacent store. Additionally, the prices charged for the consumables were eminently reasonable, with the total cost of my repast barely surpassing ten dollars. Thus, I shall reserve judgment until further exploration of the menu yields more convincing evidence of the restaurant's gastronomical prowess."
Just passed by this DD the other week, and sad to see it is now CLOSED.  Blame the economy I suppose.

One word: waterfall.
It makes Tryst amazing... especially in the midst of the swarm of drunkards. There was NO WAY anyone could move around.

My girls and I got invited to a table with bottle service, stayed for a few drinks, then wanted to split... and in turn the guy whose table it was STOLE our purses because we didn't want to stay! We spent the better part of an hour trying to track them down, and eventually a guard gave them back to us.
After asking where they were, he simply stated, "Just be happy you have them back." THEN, one of the guys at the table "coincidentally" had my friend's camera in his pocket.
NOT COOL.

I know this isn't the club's fault, but right after this incident happened my friends and I wanted to get the fuck out of there.

On the other hand, the benefits were that we got right into the clubs, got some of our guy friends in with no charge (rare in Vegas), had fun on the pole and on top of tables, and the outside area with the waterfall was breathtaking.

"While the cost may be slightly higher than that of other Chinese buffets, the value proposition remains favorable when compared to dining options in New York; thus, I do not have any reservations about patronizing this establishment. The variety of dishes available is satisfactory, and the presence of sushi and Korean cuisine options is a welcome addition. Furthermore, the ability to customize one's own soup is an appealing feature. However, the remaining dishes are rather unremarkable and lack a certain je ne sais quoi. It is unfortunate that the fish dishes tend to be overcooked, but they remain palatable nonetheless. 

Upon observing the behavior of the staff, it became apparent that they were eager for my family and me to vacate our table, perhaps to accommodate other patrons. Nevertheless, I did not perceive any impending scarcity of seating or imminent waitlist, so I chose to take my time and savor the experience without undue haste. 

In conclusion, while not necessarily a standout among its peers, this restaurant holds its own and warrants a revisit, should the opportunity arise."

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the weekend brunch at this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say that the value offered is truly unparalleled. For those who are local and seeking a reasonably priced meal, I highly recommend taking advantage of the special deals available on Mondays and Wednesdays. For a mere $3.99, $4.99, and $6.99, respectively, you can indulge in a delectable breakfast, lunch, or dinner, provided you present your Hilton rewards card and a valid form of local identification.  

The weekend brunch boasts an impressive array of delicacies, including succulent crab legs, savory prime rib, and an assortment of beverages such as beer, wine, and on certain days, champagne. In addition to the standard breakfast fare, there is also a made-to-order omelet station, complemented by expertly prepared grilled meats and sausages. While the cuisine may not be considered exotic or sophisticated, it is undoubtedly hearty and satisfying. 

At a mere $18, the opportunity to relish prime rib, cocktail shrimp, and crab legs represents an offer that is simply too good to pass up, particularly for those seeking a respectable weekend brunch buffet without the hefty price tag associated with establishments like the Wynn or Bellagio. Although the service may not always meet the highest standards, it is essential to remember that we are discussing a buffet, and thus, such minor shortcomings can be readily overlooked.

Kinda like a family Italian joint but too bright inside. Food is good enough for what it is and service is sufficient. Food is a 6 on a scale of 1 to 10. Not great not bad. Cutesy place with an \"almost\" feel. Experience it for yourself. You will understand what I mean.

"Although I am not one to be overly enthusiastic about culinary establishments that specialize in porcine delicacies, my spouse and I decided to partake in a gastronomic excursion to Salty Sow, primarily due to my innate curiosity regarding their unconventional preparation methods. Unfortunately, our dining experience proved to be somewhat underwhelming, as the dishes we ordered failed to meet our expectations. Specifically, I opted for the candied pork belly, anticipating a crunchy texture; however, it was cooked via braising, which rendered it rather unremarkable.
