My companion's lamb burger, while flavorful, featured an abundance of tapenade that did not particularly appeal to my palate. Furthermore, a considerable delay occurred between our request for the bill and its eventual arrival, which contained errors. In conclusion, our visit to Salty Sow was merely passable."

"Although we conceded that the noodles were somewhat overcooked, it was our expectation that the vegetables would be fresher, rather than frozen, which unfortunately did not align with our preferences. Notwithstanding, it remains worthy of an attempt, yet it fell short of our anticipated standards, particularly when juxtaposed with other build-your-own wok houses we have visited in various locales."

I have had the privilege of firing an assortment of firearms (for further information, please visit http://www.yelp.com/biz/bullseye-precision-indoor-shooting-range-san-rafael), which includes the Uzi, Thompson, and two other automatic weapons, as well as a desert eagle handgun. Additionally, I had the opportunity to discharge a grenade launcher, albeit with a shotgun shell rather than an actual grenade, at a cost of $35 per round. It is worth mentioning that the weapons appeared somewhat worn out, and the ear protection provided by the establishment was inadequate, causing discomfort to my auditory senses throughout the duration of my visit. Notwithstanding, I would suggest this venue as a suitable destination for a group of individuals seeking a diversion from the typical gambling activities, and perhaps even consider renting a limousine for transportation purposes, as securing a taxi back to one's lodgings may prove challenging.

The hubbie's sister and her husband were in town and wanted to try RigaTony's since they have a friend who is a Snowbird and likes the place.  We had not eaten there in a while.  

We've been eating at Olive Garden a lot, mostly because I get $25 gift cards thru work. Having gone to RigaTony's, it will definitely be the go to place when we are dining solely on our dime and want a nice dinner and salad. It is well worth the slightly higher cost per menu item.

I got the chicken with lemon and artichoke...yum.  I love their house salad.  One of my bunco buddies always gets that salad when it's her turn to host.  Hubbie liked the bread (and the salad).  The hubbie got the lasagna and enjoyed it...until later in the evening when he had some major acid reflux.  Getting older sucks.   Stubborn cuss won't try my crystalized ginger remedy...I haven't had a Tums in a looooonnnnng time.

We topped the evening off w/ a trip to Angel Sweet.  Yum.

This establishment appears to be exhibiting evident signs of wear and tear. Upon visiting this venue to observe the cinematic experience known as Avatar in their Imax theatre, I noticed that the seating was somewhat dilapidated and showed visible indications of prolonged usage. Furthermore, the film itself encountered an unexpected interruption during its initiation, owing to unforeseen technical obstacles. Consequently, a considerable amount of time, approximately 10-15 minutes, elapsed before the issue could be rectified and the motion picture resumed. Notwithstanding, I must admit that the culinary offerings at this cinema, specifically their hot dog and nachos, are relatively palatable in comparison to other establishments of a similar nature.

The sushi was surprisingly really good, but the rest of the food was mediocre. The place was clean and service was decent. It's no five star buffet, but my experience was much nicer than the previous reviewers. I would recommend for large parties as there are many options, especially for kids.
Espect\u00e1culo entretenido, las chicas bailan muy bien, pero se ve que los guionistas se fumaron algo cuando idearon el gui\u00f3n.\nMickey es el mas divertido de los actores.

"Mediocre Mexican cuisine, in my opinion. Despite hearing numerous individuals extolling the virtues of this establishment, I struggle to comprehend the hype. Admittedly, it surpasses the quality of Manuel's and Filiberto's, but that's where the praise ends. 

Their Pollo Fundido is palatable, yet it pales in comparison to the exceptional dish offered at Ajo Al's. Moreover, the gaudy purple and teal accents, reminiscent of an 80's renovation, detract from the ambiance. 

The complimentary chips and salsa are satisfying, but the minuscule serving bowls are laughable. 

Furthermore, parking during peak dinner hours is a challenge, and the surrounding Moon Valley area exudes a distinctly impoverished atmosphere."

"Recently, I visited this establishment in conjunction with an acquaintance who possessed a strong desire to consume sustenance from this particular chain, while my own preferences regarding dining locations were decidedly more flexible, as long as nourishment was readily available. 

Upon perusing their revamped menu, I opted for one of their novel, health-oriented selections, specifically the balsamic chicken, while my companion chose a more traditional option, the club sandwich, accompanied by a supplementary green salad and a side of pancakes, the latter of which may seem somewhat incongruous when taken in conjunction with their primary selection. 

Notwithstanding some initial reservations, the culinary offerings proved to be unexpectedly delectable, and the attentiveness of the staff was truly commendable."

Some people will be upset with this review, but when we are asked to write a review, Yelp wants us to be honest right? 
Finally tried out Hash House a go go for lunch yesterday. Had read great reviews and many a celebrity have endorsed it. 
The interior is great and the service is pretty good too. That is why I gave Hash 3 stars, but the food did not appeal that much to me and I consider it forgetable.
I tried the mushroom and goat cheese sandwich and have no complaints about my dish, The potatoes au gratin looked very cheesy, but tasted good as the cheese wasn't not all overpowering as I had expected. My wife tried the chicken and waffles and we both agreed: nothing special! The all white meat chicken and waffles were both too dry and bland and we prefer Roscoe's for sure.  
For the average 'white' person, this food probably tastes great, the presentation looked above par, but for those among us who consider themselves foodies, the wide gamut of Asian food offered in this city is soo much more appealing. And finally their lunch prices are a little high at $38 for two. Again, this is just my honest opinion.

My uncle possesses an eating establishment specializing in barbecued meats that enjoys a certain degree of renown in Memphis, Tennessee; thus, I habitually approach barbecue-related culinary experiences with a heightened sense of skepticism and critical scrutiny. Although my sampling of their offerings has been limited to a pair of sandwiches - specifically, the pulled pork and barbecue chicken breast varieties - I must admit that both exhibited commendable quality, extending even to the bread upon which they were served, which was satisfyingly tasteful without being excessively substantial. However, I did notice the absence of chopped egg in the potato salad accompaniment, a detail that struck me as somewhat conspicuous. Furthermore, my visual perception was tantalized by the delectable appearance of certain dessert items borne by fellow patrons, which unfortunately remained beyond my epicurean reach. Ultimately, the veritable litmus test for any barbecue venue lies in its proficiency in preparing ribs, an item I intend to sample during a future visit, at which point I shall furnish an updated assessment. Until then, I bid you adieu, with the expectation that you will indeed return at some point in the future.
This is a great, quality Taco Bell recently built with fast service and consistant food. I love Taco Bell because it's cheap and yummy!

"The ambiance, wine selection, and culinary offerings at this establishment exude an air of sophistication; however, my dining experience fell short of expectations due to several factors. Firstly, the bread served with the meal lacked the requisite crispiness and texture, appearing uncooked and devoid of any discernible oil flavor. Furthermore, the portioning of toppings seemed haphazard, failing to deliver the anticipated harmony of flavors and textures. Specifically, the bruschetta, advertised as a warm appetizer, arrived at our table uncharacteristically cold, its constituent elements failing to coalesce into a cohesive gastronomic experience. While the menu boasts imaginative pairings and combinations, the execution sadly did not live up to my expectations, leading me to confer a rating of three stars."

"Fundamental victuals, devoid of any extraordinary attributes, yet still managed to tantalize our taste buds with their inherent flavors. A concise culinary catalog, featuring a roster of familiar favorites, albeit lacking in diversity, particularly in regards to the vinous offerings, which failed to include such esteemed Italian varietals as Montepulciano or other customary options. Instead, an assortment of ubiquitous, entry-level vintages were presented, rendering the overall experience somewhat predictable, yet surprisingly satisfying, given its proximity to a well-known thrift store."

This establishment solely merits three stars due to the exceptional quality of its culinary offerings; however, the ambiance and organizational aspects of the venue are somewhat perplexing and convoluted. Upon entering the premises, patrons are met with an array of queues, with the initial two being designated for taco-related purchases; yet, those seeking burritos or fish tacos must navigate to an alternative line, which can lead to confusion and a sense of queue jumping among the clientele. Furthermore, communication difficulties arise from the fact that some employees operate with limited proficiency in the English language, leading to misunderstandings and erroneous deliveries of food items. Despite these drawbacks, the fare offered at this location is truly delectable and reasonably priced, thereby warranting a higher rating; however, the aforementioned issues preclude it from attaining a maximum rating of five stars. Additionally, a visit on a Tuesday evening revealed a chaotic atmosphere, replete with numerous children engaging in boisterous activities, further contributing to an overall sense of disarray.

"If you peruse my Yelp reviews thus far, you will discover that the vast majority of them focus on barbecue establishments. Indeed, we possess an affinity for barbecue. My spouse and I each have a sibling residing in Austin, Texas, thereby enabling us to boast a comprehensive understanding of the authentic variety. Dickey's may not entirely embody the genuine article, but it constitutes a welcome addition to Madison's barbecue scene, and I sincerely hope it endures.  

The meats exhibit a palpable smoky flavor and tenderness, although they are occasionally overcooked. This phenomenon can be attributed to the fact that fast-food/fast-casual establishments like Dickey's may not smoke their meats in-house daily. Instead, they might be smoked off-site and subsequently transported. However, given the affordable pricing, this compromise proves acceptable. The ribs and brisket warrant ordering. The chicken, on the other hand, consists of a grilled breast that can be obtained from any run-of-the-mill eatery.  

The sauces, available in both original and spicy varieties, are presented at a piping hot temperature, much like their Texan counterparts. Their texture adheres to the thinner, characteristic Texas consistency, which I find appealing. Additionally, the opportunity to embellish your meal with jalapenos and onions exemplifies a further Texas-inspired element. Unfortunately, the smoked sausage fails to live up to its Texan counterpart. The slaw and potato salad qualify as adequate sides, while the remaining options prove unremarkable.  

Dickey's offers complimentary soft-serve ice cream, allowing discerning patrons to concoct a root beer float within their ample yellow drink containers. On Sundays, children can partake in a complimentary meal alongside each adult entree purchased. Upon departing, we generally experience feelings of satisfaction. Given the reasonable prices below $20, what more could one reasonably expect?"

We have been coming to the Dragon Noodle for years. The food is good, the prices are a little high and the service is okay. I agree with some of the other Yelpers. If you sit in the back section of the place it is a bit gloomy. We liked the place before the remodel. It had cheesy decor and t-shirts for sale. 

After a long day at a trade show we just want to relax and not venture too far from the hotel. The Dragon Noodle is never that busy so you can usually get a table for any number of sized party. 

We hardly ever order from the sushi menu since the prices look high and we have never have been thrilled with what we have had in the past.

Our group sticks to the Chinese menu and is always satisfied with the portions and taste. Our favorites are the Kung Pao Chicken, Mongolian Beef and Wonton Soup. A group of 6 of us ate last week for $140.

"During my most recent sojourn to Las Vegas, I partook of a culinary excursion at this esteemed establishment, indulging in a delectable assortment of Kobe beef sliders, which, while palatable, did not quite justify the rather exorbitant price point of $13, in my humble opinion. Furthermore, my companion nearly experienced an adverse gastronomical reaction due to the richness of the dish. However, the Shichimi fries proved to be a satisfying accompaniment, boasting a delightful balance of flavors and a pleasant level of piquancy. Additionally, the Yukon Gold mashers were cooked to perfection, contributing further to an overall gratifying dining experience. The mixologists at this venue also demonstrated proficiency in crafting well-balanced cocktails, which served as a fitting complement to the meal. All things considered, I might consider returning to this eatery on a future visit to Las Vegas, provided that my stomach grumbles and I find myself in close proximity."

Came here for a networking event a couple weeks ago. They had some apps out to try and my friend ordered the quesadilla that was on happy hour. Nothing remarkable about this place food wise. I ordered a moscow mule and it was good.

We were outside on the patio which is super cute. Definitely a great place to have some wine and sit outside and enjoy the perfect weather. 

I need to try the main dishes because I wasn't that impressed with the food we had. We tried their chicken wings, ahi avocado salad of some sort, flatbread and parmesan, and then my frriend's quesadilla. It wasn't that the food was bad, it's just not something that I'm ever gonna think about and be like "hey, remember xyz at Kitchen 56?". 

Worth a shot to try but it's just whatever.

One shouldn't expect too much from restaurants centered around the main touristy drag of a city. I've found that these restaurants are typically expensive and low on service but that might just be me.

We started with a tasty platter of cheeses which included four local cheeses I forget the names of. Except for brie, all others were new and I quite enjoyed them, especially the goat cheese variant.

We had a variety of mains. I got the pasta Arrabbiata(don't know why I order that dish), and it was expectedly very ordinary. Others in our group got mussels and a quarter chicken respectively. Overall the portions were decent and the food was A-OK.

I am a hertz gold member so i always go straight to the gold check in area. This location is hit or miss. Sometimes they are very good and the car i have requested is ready to go and easy to pick up and go. Other times they have given me cars that either had too much mileage, one time a car that looked like it had been driven thru rocks, another a car with stickers on it. Also, they are sticklers about the gas tank being full. Due to this fact i always fill right by the airport now. Always check to make sure the car they give you is acceptable and dont be afraid to ask for another one if there is a problem. And check the tire tread. Otherwise the gold service is useful especially when the regular counter line is long.

Today, my hasty movements propelled me towards various destinations, and my stomach yearned for a quick culinary satisfaction.  Given my lack of enthusiasm for burgers, I opted for the convenience of Panda Express.  Although my expectations were not utterly disillusioned, the meal did not qualify as an epicurean experience.  A single staff member attended both the cash register and food service, resulting in a brief delay (during which said employee appeared somewhat harried by the multitude of tasks they faced).  It is plausible that another worker was on hiatus, as a second individual was present upon my departure.  Despite this, the eatery maintained a commendable level of cleanliness, albeit with a few empty stations for utensils and paper products.  The fare, however, exhibited freshness and an agreeable flavor profile, as I had anticipated.  My selection included a two-item combination featuring fried rice, beef and broccoli, and string bean chicken, supplemented by a chicken egg roll.  Families, solo patrons, and couples also partook in repasts within the establishment, and their contentment with their meals was palpable.

"As of September 25th, 2011, at approximately 2:10 p.m., a singular item lunch combo was available for purchase at a cost of $5.50, which included an assortment of culinary delights such as a delectable soup, a savory entree, and a delightful appetizer. However, upon partaking in the Red Curry dish, it was observed that the preparation method resulted in an excessive amount of oil, thereby detracting from the authentic Thai flavor, earning a rating of merely 3/5. In contrast, the Garlic and Pepper Stir Fry demonstrated a more satisfactory execution, garnering a score of 3.5/5. Additionally, two Thai Iced Teas were consumed, with a rating of 4.5/5, and the customer service experience was also found to be satisfactory, earning a commendable rating of 4.5/5."

"We halted our culinary excursion at this eatery today, accompanied by Arlin B, Robyn N, and Mike C. Unfortunately, our gastronomic experience at Scott's was somewhat lacking, as my costly bowl of Kreplach Soup was merely tepid and contained a solitary, minuscule Kreplach, roughly the dimensions of a Ping Pong ball. It is reasonable to assume that even the lesser portion of soup should contain two or three such dumplings. While my corned beef sandwich was palatable, the hospitality we received was only moderately attentive. Taking into account these factors, along with the tariffs charged, I would rate Scott's a mediocre three stars on this occasion."

  Corned Beef Sandwich: $10.95
Bowl of Kreplach Soup: $7.95 (exorbitant!)

I was drove past there this weekend, and then read yesterday on azcentral.com that they have closed their doors.  I had never dined there but the building & decor looks awesome, huge outdoor patio with a glass enclosed fireplace, guess it's just another sign of the struggling economy....

"Perhaps it was the prolonged duration of my journey that induced a state of bewilderment, rendering me incapable of navigating the labyrinthine corridors of the terminal, thereby necessitating a circuitous route to the exit; however, upon encountering the high-velocity tram, I experienced a momentary cognitive dissonance that hindered my ability to comprehend its functionality, leading me to erroneously assume that it would impede my progress. Despite this minor setback, I must commend the airport staff for their cordial demeanor and the meticulous upkeep of the facilities. While it may not boast the same level of grandeur as Portland International Airport, it remains a serviceable and efficient transportation hub."

My colleague endorsed this eatery, thus, I opted to sample its culinary offerings. The Gyro lunch accompanied by fries met my expectations, neither exceptionally remarkable nor disappointing, though I have relished superior fare in the past. Considering the locality and dearth of luncheon alternatives, I envision revisiting this establishment in the future.

The dining area was diminutive, while the staff maintained a cordial demeanor. The bar appeared incongruous, almost as though it did not integrate organically within the ambiance, yet, simultaneously, it was gratifying to possess the choice of savoring a beverage alongside one's meal. By and large, I perceive this restaurant as a convenient venue for a hasty, unpretentious dining experience.

I'm reviewing my rating. After Mor telling me i had to wait for them to come inspect the table (i'm moving dont have time for this) and i left my review, i ended up getting a call the next day from a manager & they actually delivered a brand new table, said the old one turned out to be from a bad batch- 

So overall i'm NOW happy with the customer service- and i'll take their word that it was a bad batch and not bad quality overall.



Old Review: Bought a dinning room granite countertop table from here, within 6 months the legs are cracking, the marble actually stains real easy from heat. Absolute garbage, $800 wasted

"I requested a spider roll, a lobster roll, and Uni, and upon consuming these delectable dishes, I discovered that the rolls possessed an exquisite flavor, particularly the spider roll, which featured a soft crab that was both fresh and crispy due to the expertise of the culinary artist who prepared it; however, my experience with Uni was somewhat different, as its taste was reminiscent of fish, lacking the expected freshness, leading me to surmise that it may be wise to inquire about the quality of this particular dish before placing an order, thereby ensuring a satisfying culinary experience."

The experience was not utterly dreadful, as the young woman appeared somewhat disinterested and eager to be elsewhere, while the male individual endeavored to captivate her attention with an array of diverse subjects, albeit in a manner that struck this observer as excessively assertive and annoying; nevertheless, his efforts did not particularly impress me, and the quality of their work was merely adequate.

I am not a fan of public car washes in general, but compared to some of the rest, Classic Car Spa did a great job! There were no smears on my windows, no water drops, either. With a BMW, you have to have the rims almost spit-shined!  I opted to get the full deal, including my rims. I was really pleased with their attention to detail. \n\nI thought I might note that my little Z4 was probably the least expensive car being washed . . . the line-up was filled with high-end SUVs, a Porsche Panamera and a Maserati. If I could afford a Maserati, I could probably afford to have someone come to my house and wash the car for me! :)

I am originally from NYC, where the Chinese food reigns supreme... and when I moved out here it was hard to find anything that was even remotely close to good.... While China Red is still not NYC amazing Chinese food, it definitely comes close. The portions are nice and big, the flavors are great, and the egg drop soup is fab! They offer lunch specials, which are hard to beat since the price is about $6 for 2 meals worth food :) PLUS, they deliver, which is hard to find out here in AZ!

We visited this past Sunday and had an enjoyable experience overall, with the exception of the culinary offerings, which were not only unpalatable but also exorbitantly priced. Hence, I am compelled to express my dissatisfaction via this review. In light of this, I would strongly advise against purchasing any sustenance within the park and instead recommend splurging an additional $10 for priority parking, thereby enabling you to bring your own provisions. This strategy not only ensures a more satisfying dining experience but also allows you to save money, as the cost of two slices of pizza and a couple of breadsticks was a whopping $14.

SSSSSsssssshhhhhhhhhhh.............. DON'T TELL ANYONE. I like Hooters. 

So, here's the story: We booked a great bargain at the Hilton, but it was only two nights. We needed a place to stay for our last night in Vegas, and we wanted something cost effective and close to the airport because of our ultra-early flight out. Hooters fit the bill. It's at the far South end of the strip, so the cab ride to McCarran is quick. It isn't fancy and there are cheap rooms to be had, so we tried it. 

The guy at the registration desk couldn't have been nicer. We asked for a nonsmoking king on a high floor, and he delivered. We had an amazing view of the Tropicana, Excalibur, and the roller coaster at New York New York. The room was BASIC, but OK. 

You can walk across the street to the MGM and that's what we did for most of the day. 

In the evening, we went back to the Hooters Casino, and guess what? We had a blast!!!! The minimum bets are LOW, so playing feels like PLAYING. It's not as serious as at the high-end casinos. The crowd is young and you don't feel like you have to be "world champion" level to play the tables. Let's face it, I'm not a serious gambler, nor would I want to be, so the atmosphere at Hooters was just my speed.

Bacchanal is okay! They got lots of stations but I can't say much was super memorable and something I must go back to have! Wait... Does dessert count? If so then they do have orange beer sorbet and mango habanero gelato which was a little different from the norm. It was spicy for sure!

Crab legs hot or cold was okay! They plate it for you which isn't bad and keeps from people hogging it so I do like that. Too bad no dungeoness crab tho! Prime rib wasn't bad, lamb chops were good but again... Nothing memorable. I did like the Chinese chicken wings with lots of flavor but a little salty. Oysters were not fresh at all and super obvious for those who eat them on a regular. 

Go on a off hour and you'll be seated in 30-45 minutes otherwise plan on waiting forever!

This is a review for the Tiffany Showroom and the new show "Yesterday - A Tribute to the Beatles."  The showroom is quite nice.  There are three main levels.  The top level has individual chairs and some small round tables.  The next level down has banquettes and chairs.  Finally, the floor level has two rows of banquettes and some small table seating.

The stage is a good size, and the sound and lighting for tonight's show was excellent.  This tribute show has been well planned.

Review for the show itself: the guys have good voices and play wonderfully.  They are best when they sing with some harmony.  A few times when one of the guys was singing alone, the sound was not the Beatles but the individual.  When singing in unison, they sounded much closer to the Beatles.

The show was almost exactly one hour in length. I wish I could give 3.5 stars because 3 is a bit low but 4 would be too high.

"Indulge Burger is an establishment that offers a pleasurable dining experience, where customers can partake in delectable culinary creations and enjoy a convivial ambiance. This eatery boasts a pet-friendly environment, with water receptacles positioned external to the dining area, thereby accommodating canine companions. Our initial visit to this venue was precipitated by the receipt of a promotional document, which we discovered in our postal receptacle. Subsequently, we have returned on multiple occasions, at intervals of several months. The fare served at this establishment is of considerable quality and diversity, featuring an array of options. Particularly noteworthy are the sweet potato fries, onion strings, and garlic chips, which elicit praise from patrons. The burgers, priced between $10 and $14, are substantial, constituting half a pound of savory meat. It is essential to note that coupons may be available, thus it is advisable to seek them out prior to visiting this restaurant. Furthermore, I have recently become aware of a current promotion offered by Yelp, whereby customers can acquire $30 worth of food and drinks at Indulge Burger & More for the sum of $15."

"The Cajun Queen constitutes a veritable epicurean haven for yours truly, boasting an exceptional level of service, particularly within the confines of its convivial bar area. The ambiance, suffused with the melodious strains of live Dixieland jazz, contributes significantly to the establishment's overall appeal. However, a recurring concern has arisen during my numerous visits to this esteemed eatery, pertaining to the kitchen staff's proclivity for imbuing their dishes with an excessive degree of piquancy, seemingly under the assumption that such an approach is intrinsic to the Cajun culinary tradition. Alas, this strategy often results in certain menu items being overwhelmed by an oppressive heat, thereby obfuscating their inherent flavors. A case in point is the crawfish scampi appetizer, which, in its traditional preparation, relies on a subtle infusion of garlic, herbs, and, on occasion, a judicious sprinkling of red pepper flakes to enhance the delicate taste of the shellfish. Unfortunately, the Cajun Queen's interpretation of this dish involves an egregious application of chili, effectively subsuming the crawfish's natural sweetness beneath a fiery blanket of spice. Furthermore, this penchant for extreme seasoning renders the scampi eerily reminiscent of the etouffee, a dish that is intentionally designed to showcase a more pronounced level of heat. Were the culinary artisans at the Cajun Queen to display a modicum of restraint in their utilization of Cajun spices, a greater balance of flavors might be achieved, thereby elevating the gastronomical experience to an even loftier plane of satisfaction."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of considerable quality, particularly considering its affiliation with a larger hospitality conglomerate. The cost of said provisions is quite reasonable, and the quantity provided is indeed generous. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the chicken katsu, which was accompanied by an ancillary dish of gravy fries. The latter was satisfying, albeit lacking a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of richness. The former was notable for its inclusion of corn, a characteristic that, I presume, is a hallmark of Hawaiian cuisine. However, I must confess that the ambiance of the venue left something to be desired. Despite my understanding that renovations have been ongoing, the interior and exterior aesthetics appear to be stuck in a bygone era, evoking the image of a traditional 50's diner. A refurbishment of the premises, coupled with a modicum of tidying, would greatly enhance the overall experience for patrons such as myself."

This place was far from where my friend stayed (West Side), but it was worth a trek out.  The place is clean and the food is made fairly quickly even with the lunch crowd.  On a hot day, you can sit outside under the misters, but I'm from Cali, so this AZ heat it not for me, even under the misters.

Food: Fontina burger with blue cheese was fresh.  The burger was juicy and full of flavor.  The blue cheese definitely enhanced it.  I like the different options for your sides.  The garlic fried were a big too greasy.  The beet salad is a nice refreshing touch.  The strawberry cheesecake from scratch that is not on the menu was just OK.  The fried okra was overly fried.  The BBQ pork sandwich looked tasty and my friend enjoyed it.  

Bottom line: I enjoyed the food and it's worth a try.

This critique pertains to the eatery situated on the upper level:

Upon partaking in the culinary offerings of this establishment, my sentiment can best be described as a profound sense of indifference, verging on utter disappointment, owing to the fact that, despite a few notable exceptions, such as the pork belly, salmon, and beef tartare, which demonstrated a modicum of gastronomical prowess, the majority of the dishes served were, regrettably, forgettable to an alarming degree.

Furthermore, our server, seemingly obsessed with maximizing our expenditure, adopted an overzealous approach, bordering on the impertinent, by insisting we commence our repast with a copious quantity of oysters, twenty-four to be precise, in addition to interpolating several ounces of wagyu beef into the meal, an suggestion that struck me as not only superfluous but also utterly preposterous.

In conclusion, given the plethora of superior dining options available in Las Vegas, it is my conviction that one would be ill-advised to allocate their resources towards experiencing the culinary endeavors of this particular restaurant, upstairs or otherwise.

"This establishment served as a recurrent destination during my formative years in Las Vegas, as it offered an economical and convenient dining experience, allowing me to indulge in their culinary offerings without incurring exorbitant costs. My recent visit proved to be a satisfying encounter, with their rendition of steak and eggs exemplifying the quintessential breakfast staple. However, I must deduct a star from my overall rating due to the price point of $20, which seems somewhat excessive in light of the local standards. Nonetheless, I must commend the attentive service rendered by our server, who graciously provided a bottle of Heinz 57 sauce upon request."

I've been to this yard house 3 or 4 times.  I think if I would have written a review the first or even second time, I would have given 4 stars... But, I just don't think it deserves that high of a rating...

The beer selection is fabulous.. Mostly because they have Triple Karmeliet.. my favorite :)  

The food is pretty darn decent too.  Great place to grab a steak and I am a huge fan of the hawiian pizza.  Good is good.

A little on the pricey side if you are planning to stay for awhile.. which is fine, but I don't like to have to spend 100 bucks for a diner and drinks for two.... especially when it's only a couple of drinks.. Boo on that.  Pretty much my only complaint.. I'll get over it though and go back soon I'm sure. :)

Oh, and one las thing, I love the music selection.. Always playing good tunes.

Ate with a client here today for the first time. Really enjoyed the yellow curry dish medium and the soup that comes before the meal, but the service was slow. It took 16 minutes for my entree to come, although after it came many employees asked if I wanted a drink refill.\n\nNice decor and decent prices

3 1/2 STARS

This is Marriott's TIME-SHARE complex across from their luxury hotel. We traded a time-share for a week here in May. I must say, the place was packed - it appeared to be fully occupied.

Our room was small but just fine for us. The employees were all friendly and the grounds were kept in good shape.

We found this to be a good place to use as a base for a week's holiday while taking day-trips to the Grand Canyon, Sedona, Prescott, Scottsdale, the Phoenix Botanical Garden, and so on...

I would say this place is pretty much like every other nail salon in Charlotte.  The fumes greet you at the door, they have you pick your color, they point to the chair they want you to sit in, they stare at you and smile, attempting to connect with the few English words they know, they do a decent job and slap you with a bill.  Sound familiar?  That was my experience.  It wasn't bad, it wasn't amazing, it was just....familiar.  They did have a very nice selection of colors which was nice but nothing else stood out to me.  They were friendly enough and priced the same as everyone else.  They did a nice job on my cuticles which other places have not been as detailed.  I would come back.

If Spearmint Rhino and Treasures were siblings then Spearmint Rhino would be Charlie Sheen and Treasures would be Emilio Estevez. Spearmint Rhino is a lot more fun with a lot more going on. Treasures is small and booooooring. Bottle service is a lot cheaper though.

My family and I stumbled across this location as we were shopping in Townsquare when we first walked in the ambience is undeniably beautiful we were told by the awesome waitress that happy hour ended in 12 minutes. We agreed we were all going to down the first drinks so we can get the next ones before they doubled in price. Only to be told that when she asked the bar manager Jessica , she said \" no\". We were still well within the time period. When the waitress came back it was two minutes after happy hour. We ordered $160.00 in food, it was fabulous. The service was undeniably outstanding. However, we will not be back because of Jessica. When I find someplace I like I am always loyal and would have return time and time again with my friends and family. I hope the $18 savings was worth it.

This minuscule canine recreational area, confined to a singular expanse of land adjacent to a baseball field, presents a rather limited scope for canine exercise and socialization, which, in conjunction with its questionable maintenance, renders it an inferior choice for discerning dog owners seeking a suitable venue for their pets. Despite the occasional visit from myself and my spouse during our tenure in the vicinity, the dearth of upkeep and the recent, albeit ineffectual, "renovation" have rendered this park somewhat disappointing, particularly in light of the presence of more well-appointed facilities in the surrounding area. Notwithstanding, its proximity to my place of employment shall continue to facilitate my patronage, though an inclination towards alternative, superior destinations persists.

I had unwittingly traversed past this unassuming edifice numerous times prior to discovering the enchanting experience awaiting within. Upon entering the establishment at approximately 9 pm on a Friday evening, I was immediately struck by the captivating sight of ducks and turtles leisurely gliding through the water, thereby creating an idyllic atmosphere that was further accentuated by the presence of amorous couples occupying the alfresco seating area. An elderly gentleman was serenading the patrons with soulful Spanish ballads while skillfully strumming his guitar, thus adding to the already romantic ambiance of El Encanto. The portal leading to this hidden gem seemed to be shrouded in secrecy, and I couldn't help but feel a sense of gratification upon having stumbled upon such an undiscovered treasure.

As for the culinary offerings, I opted to share the pollo fundido with my companion. Although it failed to elicit an overwhelming impression, primarily due to the fact that X Tapa Joe's rendition remains unparalleled in my opinion, the accompanying yellow rice was truly exceptional. Typically, my expectations for the customary dry and lackluster Mexican rice are not particularly high; however, the variant presented at El Encanto was conspicuously distinct, boasting a delightful combination of moisture and rich flavors that closely mirrored the yellow rice I personally prepare. While the margaritas were somewhat too saccharine for my taste, they remained passable. In general, I found the establishment to be an ideal setting for an intimate escapade, steeped in an aura of romance that warranted a three-star rating. My desire to sample additional menu items still lingers, as I am eager to assess their full gastronomical prowess and potentially elevate my appraisal.

Although the culinary offerings, vinous delights, and ambiance are all commendable, regretfully, I must express my disappointment. One of my grievances pertains to the intermittent sluggishness in the service, which has hindered my dining experience on multiple occasions. Furthermore, during a recent celebration of a friend's anniversary, the restaurant unfortunately exhausted their supply of edibles, leaving me with an unpleasant sensation akin to having an angel of darkness hovering over my table, poised to extinguish any prospect of satisfaction. Despite my ardent desire to confer a rating of four stars, owing to the undeniable quality of the cuisine and wine, my past distressing encounter compels me to assign a rating that falls short of excellence. Perhaps, in the future, I shall have the opportunity to revise my appraisal, reflecting the true potential of this establishment.

"As a resident of the surrounding area, I recently had the opportunity to visit this establishment and witnessed a portion of its promotional presentation. My initial impression was that the club card perks were somewhat mediocre, yet still managed to pique my interest upon signing up. The gaming selection featured an agreeable balance of contemporary and vintage machines, which catered to my penchant for more intimate gambling venues. Although my own gaming experience was relatively unremarkable, my spouse enjoyed a streak of good fortune. We opted to utilize the provided coupons and sample the culinary offerings at the on-site deli. The breakfast special I ordered was satisfying, with a generous serving of fresh tomatoes, crispy bacon, and a warm, toasted muffin. My spouse's burger was equally impressive, boasting a juicy patty, crisp lettuce, and flavorful tomatoes, accompanied by a side of golden fries that were cooked to a perfect crispiness. While the quality of the food was undeniably impressive, the true test of consistency lies in future visits."

"On a Tuesday (December 18, 2012), we embarked upon a culinary excursion to an Italian eatery in Edinburgh, which, regrettably, did not live up to our expectations in terms of gastronomic excellence. Despite the presence of some delectable antipasti, the crostini unfortunately exhibited a discernible staleness, thus somewhat diminishing our overall satisfaction. However, the pork belly proved to be a redeeming factor, boasting tenderness and flavor, while the roast potatoes were cooked to perfection, earning them high praise. Unfortunately, the chocolate tart that followed left much to be desired, as its richness bordered on overwhelming. Notwithstanding the shortcomings in the food department, the ambiance of the establishment exuded a certain charm and appeal, rendering it an enjoyable experience for all. Nevertheless, in light of the middling quality of the fare, it remains uncertain whether a return visit would be warranted, especially when considering the abundance of superior, family-run establishments in the vicinity, such as Nonna's in Morningside, which undoubtedly outshine their competitors in terms of sheer excellence."

Is a pretty large storage facility with a lot of different size units. The facility is pretty clean. I use it to store files so I have the smaller unit they offer.  People in the office seem pretty nice. My only complaints I have are how much dust gets into the units and how far away it is from my house.  They could use better doors to seal out the dust.

"As I embarked upon my journey through the bustling streets of downtown Chandler, I chanced upon a singular establishment that piqued my curiosity; a freestanding edifice housing none other than a Jimmy John's franchise. This particular venue boasted an unprecedented distinction - it was the first of its kind that I had ever laid eyes on. 

The menu offered the customary array of delectable items associated with the esteemed sandwich chain, albeit at a marginally lower price point (approximately fifty cents less) in comparison to the Chandler Fashion Center location. My affection for Jimmy John's notwithstanding, I felt compelled to deduct a half-star from my overall rating due to the multitude of distractions that permeated the interior of the store. 

Upon entering the premises, I was struck by the striking similarity to a typical high school cafeteria. Staff members vociferously engaged in banter, their voices raised to an earsplitting volume, while the ambiance was further heightened by the blaring music. Such an environment made it challenging to fully appreciate the culinary experience. 

We have all, at some point in our lives, cherished memories of our formative years spent within the hallowed halls of high school. Have we not, dear reader? For instance, who could forget the inimitable Ferris Bueller and his unforgettable exploits?"

"My predilection for dining at Pei Wei stems from their accommodating policy of enabling adult patrons to order from the children's menu, thereby providing a welcome reprieve from the typically excessive portion sizes that often accompany standard entree selections. Frankly, I find the restaurant's willingness to cater to my dietary requirements and preferences, particularly in regards to rice and sauces, to be a significant factor in my decision to frequent this establishment, rendering it one of the premier options that come to mind when I am in pursuit of satiating my craving for the aforementioned staple. However, I must admit that the ambiance of the parking area leaves much to be desired, which unfortunately detracts from the overall experience and precludes me from bestowing an additional star in my rating."

I have been to Toby Keith's a couple of times over the years. The first time was a couple of years ago for a local concert that became ridiculously overcrowded and claustrophobic but I will disregard that initial experience and review only this experience today. I met my mom here for a late lunch around 3pm because we were in the area so it was convenient. Our waitress was really nice and attentive and we wanted to take our time and she didn't have a problem with that.

I ordered a green chili chicken sandwich (with no bun) and a side of coleslaw. My mom had a turkey club sandwich. My chicken was pretty good. It was a little overcooked but it wasn't bad. Nothing to write home about. My mom's turkey club was a HUGE serving and she said it was just okay.

Overall for a midday dining experience we had an okay experience. The food was okay, the service was good. Would I be back? Maybe...

It wasn't spectacular... Started 10-15 minutes late... The Comedian was the highlight of this show... I'm still googling her youtube videos with no luck... Some girls were really pretty but they weren't in sync much...

We came here because we had a Restaurant.com certificate to use. It was ok, but nothing special. The taco shells were fresh and made onsite and the chicken was delicious. The rice, however, was mushy. And they used preshredded cheddar cheese. Not very authentic but a nice cheap meal.

This place is located in a pretty low end locals casino but with that said it's a fun spot for a quick & hearty breakfast. It's also super cheap! They have a fully stocked bar so having some cocktails with your breakfast is always a good idea. The menu has a little bit of everything but I think the breakfast options are the tastiest. Service is always great as well!

It is utterly arduous to select a venue to indulge in gastronomical delights in Las Vegas, given the plethora of options available, which seem to permeate the culinary landscape. However, the fact that Mon Ami's dining area was brimming with patrons could be construed as a positive harbinger. Upon partaking in their delectable offerings, I discovered that their bread was truly exceptional, presented in a charming manner reminiscent of the quintessential French baguette, albeit served with an unconventional accompaniment - a paper bag, a peculiarity that seems to defy convention in the land of its origin. My taste buds were further tantalized by their beef bourguignon, a dish that would undoubtedly garner the approval of the illustrious Julia Child, even if the noodles accompanying it were regrettably overcooked. Unfortunately, my experience with their mixology was marred by a subpar French 75, a cocktail that fell short of expectations within the context of a purportedly authentic French establishment. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the ambiance of the venue was relatively pleasant, thanks in part to the ambient temperature provided by outdoor heaters, the melodic background music, and the captivating spectacle of the Bellagio fountain display. However, the cramped nature of the patio left much to be desired in terms of spatial comfort. In conclusion, while Mon Ami may not have fully satisfied my epicurean inclinations, I am willing to consider alternative dining options in Las Vegas that can deliver a comparable caliber of cuisine and overall experience, should they exist.

"It appears that Espee has succumbed to the pervasive trend of exorbitant pricing, with a paltry three-item combination commanding an astronomical sixteen dollars, a sum that could easily be expended on a lavish repast at an establishment such as Agave, where the culinary offerings are of a decidedly higher caliber. Furthermore, the tamales at Espee seem to have diminished in size, which is particularly noticeable when contrasted with the previously generous proportions. The salsa bar, once a highlight of the dining experience, has sadly degenerated into an unappetizing state, prompting one to wonder what befell the erstwhile pico de gallo. Although the happy hour specials, featuring two-for-one margaritas and discounted nachos, remain a salient aspect of the eatery's appeal, the steep prices and diminishing portion sizes have regretfully compelled me to downgrade my original four-star assessment to a more modest three stars."

I am fervently desirous of conferring a rating of four stars upon this establishment, as my previous experiences have been largely satisfactory. Upon multiple visits, I have endeavored to sample a variety of items, and each dish has proven to be delectable, to say the least. However, due to my proximity to MTO Cafe, I frequently opt for their delivery services, which regrettably, have proven to be somewhat unreliable, as certain items are often omitted from my order, such as green drinks, salads accompanying chicken and waffles, and side dishes like mashed potatoes, among others. Despite these inconsistencies, the food remains flavorful and nutritious, providing an ideal solution for alleviating hangovers or enjoying a leisurely weekend brunch at home. Furthermore, the recent opening of a second location at the new Summerlin Mall has piqued my interest, and I intend to visit it in the near future.

I have been to many sushi restaurants, cheap to fancy. But at Yokoso, sushi is definitely not their strong point. The sushi pieces were mouthfuls of mostly rice, that too little dry . I ordered a Rainbow Roll and The Pitt Roll. Not good. The prices are OK not very reasonable. I dont know about the other items on the menu, but sushi was meh!\nOnly go here if you are absolutely craving for one.\nBut the service was good and prompt.
The prices are a little high and the food is ok. I have had better pizza. The wings where also ok. The people where nice both times we have eaten there.

Came here a few weeks ago with friends. Breakfast was good, tea was nice, atmosphere ok. I wasn't blown away but I also wasn't disappointed. I love the location and the interior is vintage and original. The outside was ok to have breakfast and enjoy the weather. Moderately priced.

For a place that's supposedly known for wings, it wasn't so good. I was very hungry but couldn't finish the 20 wings I was sharing with my friend. The 10 grilled wings were tossed in this super spicy tangy Cajun sauce. Eeee. Should've had the sauce on the side. The other 10 wings had sauce on the side but the batter was chalky tasting. Eeee.\n\nThe shrimp and spinach salad was good. Tsk. Was so craving good wings though.

"Rio De Janeiro, a city synonymous with vibrancy and extravagance, boasts an array of captivating attractions that warrant a visit from even the most discerning traveler. In order to elevate the experience at this esteemed establishment, certain enhancements are proposed, including but not limited to: looser slots, cordial security staff, additional cute shops, and entertainment tailored specifically for the under 21 demographic. Furthermore, aesthetic improvements, such as glitz and glamour upgrades, would greatly contribute to the overall ambiance. Already renowned for its delectable seafood buffet, spacious accommodations, and lively atmosphere, the implementation of these suggestions would undoubtedly revitalize the Rio, transforming it into a premier destination once again. Needless to say, my return is imminent, thanks in large part to the allure of rewards points."

"The edible sustenance provided by this establishment, while undoubtedly satisfying the hunger of its patrons, fails to elicit any semblance of excitement or originality in its culinary offerings, thereby imbuing the ambiance with an unfortunate dearth of distinctive character; meanwhile, the service proffered by the waiting staff exhibits commendable efficiency and attention to detail, even as the selection of beverages available for consumption boasts a few notable options, yet the overall experience remains somewhat dubious in terms of value received for the price paid."

I attended this establishment on the occasion of a friend's birthday celebration, whereupon I partook in an assortment of delectable victuals, specifically the soft pretzels accompanied by a savory fondue, which were indeed scrumptious. Our server, though attentive, did not expedite the delivery of our repast and potables with sufficient celerity, unfortunately. Notwithstanding, I thoroughly enjoyed my entree selection, the Sweet Corn Cannelloni, whose rich flavors were abundant and gratifying. Furthermore, I appreciated the diverse vegetarian options available. In addition, we received a complimentary dessert, the Monkey Bread, which, despite its unassuming name, proved to be surprisingly delectable. Moreover, the ambiance of the venue was quite pleasant, characterized by comfortable, uniquely designed chairs at each table and magnificent chandeliers that contributed to an overall sense of elegance. However, certain drawbacks did exist, including an excessive delay in the preparation and service of our meals, an excess of noise, insufficient illumination, and portion sizes that seemed somewhat diminutive relative to the cost.

"It is imperative to note that this preliminary assessment has been lingering in a state of dormancy for an extended period (owing to its designation as a draft that slipped through the cracks of my attention); however, I am unable to revise it at this time. Review 1: 2 stars - Subpar service. A protracted waiting period of approximately six minutes ensued before a staff member appeared to take our order. Upon requesting mayonnaise and ketchup exclusively on the burger, the female server exhibited a condescending demeanor, implying that if we had frequented the establishment previously, we would have been cognizant of the fact that ketchup and mayonnaise were readily available on the table. Consequently, the entire burger was prepared incorrectly due to the server's interruption, coupled with her supercilious attitude. Nonetheless, the second female employee whom I interacted with rectified the issue and displayed a pleasing level of cordiality. Review 2: 4 stars - During my younger sibling's birthday celebration at the bowling alley, we partook of a meal. The quality of the service was satisfactory. The culinary offerings were relatively palatable. In conclusion, a generally agreeable encounter."

"Alright, this establishment may have a tendency to become somewhat expensive rather rapidly, but if you possess the ability to optimize your culinary experience by selecting options that offer the greatest value, much like myself, you should be able to navigate the menu without encountering any significant financial difficulties. My acquaintance and I opted for the vegetarian sandwich, which we augmented with an additional portion of roast beef. I must admit that I was thoroughly impressed by the quality of the sandwich, as it was truly deserving of a five-star rating and represented an excellent value considering the cost was merely fifteen dollars. When accompanied by a cup of coffee and a slice of cake, our total expenditure for the two of us was barely above twenty-nine dollars. I would advise that if you are inclined to consume more sustenance than what was provided, it may be wise to consider implementing a dietary regimen in the near future. The quantity of food served was truly sufficient, rendering it unnecessary to take any leftovers with you upon departure. It is recommended to share your meals among your dining companions, as the portions are quite generous and intended for multiple individuals. A satisfying sandwich, complemented by a half-sour pickle and respectable coffee. Additionally, the chocolate cake is truly delectable, while the fries are merely average."

"The venue boasts an endearing ambiance, augmented by a spacious outdoor area featuring a bar, thereby creating a picturesque setting conducive to leisurely dining experiences. Upon visiting during the daytime, I opted to sit outside on the synthetic grass, admiring the string lights that would undoubtedly imbue the atmosphere with a captivating charm come nightfall. While the culinary offerings proved satisfactory, they failed to elevate my dining experience to an extraordinary level. Specifically, my garden salad was unremarkable, and my fellow patrons' chicken panini sandwich, though flavorful, featured chicken breast that lacked succulence, while their strawberry salad showcased mushy fruit. However, what truly hindered my enjoyment was the sluggish pace of the service, as we placed our orders expeditiously only to endure an extended wait for our meals to arrive. In light of this, I surmise that addressing the efficiency of their service would be crucial in realizing the establishment's potential, particularly within a locality that lacks similar stylish and contemporary eateries."

"Peruse the menu, select your preference, and prepare your palate for an authentic culinary excursion, as this establishment's commitment to genuine flavors and traditional preparation methods is unwavering. Although linguistic barriers may exist, the staff's hospitable demeanor and willingness to accommodate curious patrons more than compensates for any potential communication difficulties. Indeed, an inquiry regarding the taste of the barbacoa was met with an offer to sample the dish, graciously provided by the attentive server. The robust flavors present in each taco are a testament to the culinary prowess of the kitchen staff, with the chicken variety boasting a satisfying spiciness and the guacamole maintaining a refreshing simplicity, comprised primarily of fresh avocado and a squeeze of lime juice. However, it would be remiss to neglect mentioning the somewhat questionable state of the seating area, characterized by utilitarian metal chairs and worn, torn booth cushions, with the occasional rusty nail protruding from the frame. Despite these shortcomings, the booths remain a preferable option for those opting to dine in. Unfortunately, the quality of the meat leaves something to be desired, thereby precluding this venue from becoming a regular haunt for this writer, who is admittedly particular about such matters. Nonetheless, the unique experience merits documentation and recommendation to intrepid gastronomes seeking an authentic taste of Mexico."

I had a very pleasant dinner at Fleur de Lys last month but nothing wow'ed me.  I ordered from the $59 prix fixe menu, which includes an appetizer, entree and dessert - all in all, a good value!   

I enjoyed the onion soup, served with shaved truffles and duck.  It was rich and earthy with an unexpected presentation.  Next I had gently heated salmon with juilinee vegetables and a green horseradish sauce.  My salmon was perfectly cooked and the dish looked beautiful, but the sauce, frankly tasted like grass clippings!  Bitter and overpowering.  My friend seemed to enjoy her stout braised short ribs.  The dessert, a "trio of chocolates", was a miss: a dry souffle, a salty peanutbutter shake and Baily's ice cream.  None of the desserts really did it for me.  

I may have expected too much from this place, but hey, it's Hu bert Keller's spot!  Who knows, maybe I caught them on a bad night.  I'd like to return some time and give the regular menu a chance, but with so many INCREDIBLE places to eat in Vegas I can't make any guarantees.

PROS: Great service, Great wine and Reasonable prixe fixe menus. 
CONS: Too many 'miss' dishes for a 4 star

"Subpar, at best, was the quality of the culinary offerings presented before me. Specifically, the buttermilk pancakes, potato pancakes, eggs, and sausage links appeared to lack the requisite level of doneness, despite the expedited manner in which they were delivered to my table, a mere three minutes after placing my order. In fact, I would have willingly tolerated an additional two-minute wait to ensure that my meal was thoroughly cooked. Furthermore, it is worth noting that my mother's pancake recipe remains unsurpassed in its excellence."

This place gets a 3 star because they've never blown my socks off with anything, but I've never had experience with them that made me want to quit pizza. It's pretty close to my house and my nephew loves pizza so I'm here a decent amount. They're very consistent, very friendly and my food is always ready on time. On the single time my order was messed up, they were very quick about fixing it,  which was majorly appreciated. To be honest I have nothing bad to say about them at all. They get the job done

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this establishment on a Thursday evening, bringing along our 14-month-old progeny. Despite the availability of infant seating accommodations, we would advise against introducing young children to this venue, as it is not particularly suitable for their presence. However, we would enthusiastically endorse partaking in gastronomic delights at this location. Our repast began with an order of crabcakes, which, while satisfying, could have benefited from a slightly crisper exterior. This deficiency could have been remedied by extending the cooking duration in the pan. The accompanying spicy aioli presented a delightful complement to the dish.  
I relished in the delectable brie and bacon burger, characterized by exceptional quality bacon and beef, enveloped within a soft, yet robust bun. The burger was cooked to a perfect medium, with an adequate amount of juiciness. Unfortunately, it did not arrive with fries, much to our dismay. My spouse opted for the lobster bisque, which, despite its commendable flavor, was overpowered by an excessive amount of sherry. Additionally, she sampled the beef and blue salad, which emerged as the highlight of the meal. This dish showcased exceptional quality blue cheese, eliciting our utmost appreciation.  We eagerly anticipate our next visit to this culinary haven.

So much better than I remembered.  Last time we had breakfast here and it was horrible.  This time, we tried dinner. 

24 hour buffet pass for $40...how can you go wrong?  Except after the 2nd buffet, you really want to run straight towards a toilet or grab a roll of Tums.  Seriously, no one should be eating more than one buffet within 24 hours.  Heck with it all though, this is Vegas...the city of losing wages and eating just as much as you freakin can!

This was our 3rd buffet on our pass...a dinner stop. 

Highlights:  
CREPES!!!  Yummy delicious crepes...I take em plain with some powdered sugar. Really nice lady making em...the crepes were perfectly chewy...I had 2.  Ugh. 

Seafood.  A combination of crab, shrimp, mussels, and clams.  Not the greatest...but good enough.

Dessert.  Probably the biggest display out of all the buffets we went to.  They're your usual buffet fare...nothing was really wow but enough to satisfy your dessert craving. 

The duck was also pretty good...it was made with orange sauce and rice pilaf.  Can't think of any of the other standouts as the buffets mostly had the same things.  

Pretty decent buffet...#3 on our buffet list.

Whenever my travel itinerary has necessitated that I be accommodated in the vicinity of the renowned Las Vegas Strip, but I have been reluctant to incur the additional expense associated with lodging within the Strip's premium hospitality sector, I have opted to take up temporary residence at this establishment, which, while not situated directly on the Strip, remains conveniently proximate thereto. The amenities available to guests include a refreshing pool and complimentary wireless internet access, both of which are certain to enhance one's stay. Furthermore, sustenance options are readily accessible, mere steps away from the hotel's entrance. Finally, the management has graciously elected to include parking facilities within the cost of accommodation, thereby obviating the need for guests to allocate additional funds for this purpose.

It bears an uncanny resemblance to the Hofbrau Haus in Munich, prompting me to speculate that the only Teutonic individuals present were the musicians performing in the establishment. Our server exhibited commendable proficiency in attending to our needs, and the melodies rendered by the band were quite enjoyable. However, the quality of the beverages was surpassed only by the mediocrity of the culinary offerings. My spouse's Jager Schnitzel was remarkably tough, necessitating considerable effort to slice it with a cutting instrument. The sauerkraut accompanying my wurst plate lacked flavor and exhibited signs of being overcooked. Furthermore, the mashed potatoes possessed a taste suggestive of their origin from a packaged mix. In conclusion, we have undoubtedly partaken of superior German cuisine on previous occasions.

I like the suite at Mandalay Bay its 750 sq the service at the front desk are always friendly, But I dislike it when my room were comp and they still charge me if I didn't look at my credit card the same week I wouldn't catch it that they charge me for 2 nights when those 2 nights are suppose to be free.

This is a great bar for a Tuesday night and highly recommend going after 9pm to get the $3 burger special.  Go early to get a seat because this place fills up slightly after 9. I sat all the way upstairs and the bar was quiet but it was a Tuesday night after all.  They had a great list of draft beers including Pumking which I would have normally gotten but at $10 for a small glass that was a little much for me. I ended up with a bottle of Purple Haze another favorite of mine. The bartender told me there was a glitch in the computer system and it only rang up for $3-nice surprise.  Unfortunately this didn't happen for the second round but the bartender made sure to tell me in advance which was perfectly fine.  I stayed for the 9 o'clock burger special and it was declivous. Pleasantly surprised by the double burger and highly recommend the Stack'd special sauce!

I would give it 3.75. Never would guess a cool little breakfast spot would be located under some shady apartments on 7th street. Sat at the bar and ate. Could see right into the very small kitchen. I only had scrambled eggs and bacon which are nothing to rave about but it's hard to mess those up. Some of the other dishes that came out of the kitchen looked great!  I'll have to try the pancakes next time!  Would definitely come back.

I am utterly perplexed by the exaggerated acclaim surrounding this establishment, as my experience fell short of the lofty expectations engendered by the plethora of 4-5 star reviews on Yelp. Upon entering, I anticipated a culinary masterpiece, only to be disillusioned by a minuscule sandwich that failed to satiate my hunger. The overpowering presence of horseradish contaminated the flavor, leaving an unpleasant aftertaste that further compounded my discontent. My disappointment was so profound that I found myself questioning the credibility of Yelp's rating system. In an attempt to assuage my hunger, I opted for the chicken noodle soup, which proved to be merely average and did little to alleviate my dissatisfaction. It is worth mentioning that my recent dining experiences in Las Vegas had been largely positive, thus making the subpar quality of this particular meal even more conspicuous. In conclusion, I must emphasize that the sandwich underwhelmed me to an extent that left me incredulous, and I cannot fathom how it garnered such an abundance of glowing endorsements.

I had heard several good complements about noca and was excited to have dinner here. Unfortunately I was pretty disappointed. 

All four of us ordered the tasting menu. Two of us had it with wine pairings as well.  The presentation was good. We started with some type of a small palette cleanser. Our first course was either a mushroom soup or a salad. I had the soup and my husband had the salad. It was good though not amazing. Our second course was pasta with meat type sauce. This was the best course by far. Our entree was a flat iron steak. It was good but again not amazing. Dessert was blue cotton candy and chocolate cake w banana gelato. The cotton candy was a nice surprise.

What was very disappointing was the wine pairings. Our waiter knew very little about the wines and strangely did the same pairings regardless of whether we ordered. The soup or salad and the fish or steak entree. The entire wine line-up was completely in the red family. 

Overall the presentation was good, portion size was good, service was ok, food was ok. But nothing spectacular. 

If you are looking for a wow restaurant I would rather recommend alto at the hyatt gainey ranch.

I honestly love the decor in the place really industrial meets classy, but thats just party of the experience. The food here is like any other brazillian steak house. You start with salad and soup ( unlimited offerings even throughout the meal ) , when your ready a flip of a card brings sides and entrees to the table. Steak's of all cut from top sirloin to flay ming yong wrapped in bacon. There is also rib which are excellent, lamb which is fair, chicken. Why anyone would consume more chicken here then steak is confusing but its there and offered wrapped in bacon! Sides are Pao de Queijo ( baked bread rolled into balls with cheese ) , fried bananas, and gralic mash potatoes. Deserts here are pricey but a good way to end a meal. \n\nI am really unimpressed with a few things. Though my service was excellent the food really wasn't. Bacon wrapped steak was good, i've had better and larger pieces at Fago de Chao. The other meats were so so, lack of seasoning and  meat options ; as we came a little after they opened. The lobster bisque was OK. Reading some people who raved over its taste is amazing, because it really wasn't that great and probably the least liked thing by my party.

This McDonald's is conveniently nearby the Pepsi Center.

It opens late, and was perfect for the post-clubbing crowd I was with.

A friend bought me a McChicken sandwich (not sure why, but I appreciated it), which I made short work of - it tasted normal, as expected.

As usual, the food and service is very good here but can you please refinish the floor? It's really showing it age. Worn and discolored, it takes away from the overall experience. The ottomans in the lounge area also need cleaning or even better, reupholstered. \n\nThe place is looking rundown and that's really a shame for a high end, Summerlin dining spot.

"An ostensibly charming location, replete with myriad opportunities for juvenile enjoyment. Nonetheless, upon venturing forth to the pumpkin patch to select gourds, my gaze fell upon a singular specimen situated within the field, bearing a store-affixed label, inclusive of a barcode. While I do not take issue with compensating a premium for pumpkins cultivated locally, I cannot reconcile the notion of remunerating fourfold the amount for a gourd procured from Walmart, which retails for a mere $4. Perceiving the presence of pumpkin vines, indicative of an authentic harvest, I nevertheless felt compelled to restore our selections, given the unsettling sensation engendered by the blending of genuine produce with commercially sourced stock."

"For individuals seeking palatable victuals, Oliveo's presents itself as an optimal destination, irrespective of the time of day, be it during the nocturnal hours or the midday interval. While the prices may be perceived as somewhat elevated, the culinary offerings are undeniably of Greek provenance, thereby justifying the additional expense. My personal experiences with their menu have been nothing short of satisfactory, as I have had the pleasure of indulging in their delectable chicken souvlaki, gyros, and chicken breast plates, all of which have been expertly prepared and bursting with flavor. Furthermore, Oliveo's extends its operating hours well into the late night, making it an ideal choice for those seeking a nutritious repast beyond the conventional fast-food options. Thus, I wholeheartedly endorse this establishment for anyone seeking a satisfying dining experience in a collegiate setting."

"This eatery exudes an ambiance that transcends the conventional 'pub' experience, with a menu that boasts an array of sophisticated offerings. My culinary adventure began with a novel dish, chicken tacos, which presented an unconventional twist on the customary shredded poultry. Instead, each taco encompassed a substantial, deep-fried chicken finger, proffering a satisfying crunch and delightful flavor profile. While the execution was generally successful, the sizeable nature of the chicken piece occasionally hindered the ease of consumption. Furthermore, our table exhibited minor signs of wear and tear, with a subtle stickiness that suggested a need for heightened attention to detail in the cleaning process. A comprehensive approach to sanitizing the surface, involving the removal of all items, would greatly enhance the overall dining experience."

"Gosh darn it! I thoroughly forgot about my significant other discovering an extensive dark-colored strand of human hair in our culinary creation proximate to the point of completion of our repast. How on earth could I have overlooked such an occurrence?! It's absolutely unacceptable for any eatery to have such a disgusting situation transpire, particularly when the victuals were as delectable as they were."

I'm not sure how this made it onto eaters list but I wasn't impressed. I've been a couple times and had different experiences each time. 

Price is decent. Style is fast casual but chicken was too greasy.  Burgers are very messy but decent in flavor. However I would  consider come here before going most fast food places.  Honestly, I've had amazing burgers so I have high expectations. 

I liked the French fries and flash fried veggies... Probably not healthy at all because it was too salty but I give them credit because it very unique.  It's not something I would order frequently though.

"My personal opinion is that the macaroni and cheese dish served at this establishment is perhaps the most delectable item on their menu, particularly when paired with their bologna. It exudes an essence of comfort food that is simply unparalleled. Furthermore, their cheese plate appears to be quite appetizing, and their onion rings, which are abundant in the thinly sliced variety, are undoubtedly a delight for those who relish such delicacies. However, I must express some disappointment regarding their perch, as it fails to meet my expectations as my preferred choice among the fish offerings. Nonetheless, I did have the pleasure of partaking in a bowl of their beer cheese soup during my visit, albeit accompanied by an uninspiring garnish of popcorn. In conclusion, while the remainder of their menu may not necessarily excel in terms of creativity or taste, it does possess a certain charm that is reminiscent of traditional Wisconsin cuisine, whatever that may entail."

I was actually at the Staples next door, but had seen this place several times before and was curious enough this time to stop in, not knowing at all what to expect. I was here in the early afternoon, and it was plenty busy, but nothing like the megacrowds that others are describing, presumably dependent on the time and day. I didn't get a chance to experience the aggressive customer aspect, but most likely because I wasn't shopping in the women's section, and 95% of the other customers were women, who did look a bit frenzied; the four or five men in the store were, by contrast, subdued. I will have to come back again when I have more time to explore what they have, but to say I was "impressed" with the selection of (men's) shoes would be understating itit was wingtip heaven in there! Unlike many of the items in this place, most of these shoes were in great condition, with the worst thing being a missing lace or two, which is an easy fix anyway. I came out with a $30 pair of Maison Forte boots which have no imperfections at all and were originally priced at $215.00! (I should add that I'm not designer/brand aware at all, so I'm mostly impressed that the shoes are gorgeous and don't so much care about their brand names.) Will definitely come back, even if just for more shoes! :)
Good food overall but the storefront could use some work to make for a nicer dining experience. The place was clean and service was fine. I would absolutely order take out or delivery from here.

Decided to have dinner at Tofu Hut tonight. Overall experience was not bad, but I wouldn't call it great either. 

They were a bit short staffed when we first walked in. I would say it took them over 5 mins to even acknowledge our presence even though they did see us walk in.  I expected a "Hello, or Welcome" at the very least.

We passed on the AYCE tonight & went ala carte. We ordered short ribs & spicy chicken. Both orders were good, but nothing memorable or anything to rave about. I did love their banchan offerings! I liked the fish cake, japchae, spicy cucumber, and I don't recall the others but it was yummy!

I would go back.. but don't think I'll be a regular at this place.

I love this hotel, but I think the Bellagio still wins in my book. 
My family and I got upgraded to the 60th floor, which had an amazing view. The rooms are SO cute and clean and there's a TV in the bathroom... lol! However, the TV in the room didn't work at all, despite the "directions" on how to use the TV on the remote control.  
Also, the walls were SO THIN! I could hear people talking in the hallway all throughout the night, plus I could hear the neighbors during the middle of the night (although this might be because they were fighting...). 
Anyhoo, I'm a fan of the hotel itself, La Rev the show, the buffet (for brunch and dinner), and the shops.

"The sushi exhibited palatable quality, however, the service was merely adequate. Notwithstanding, the numerous servers' frequent comings and goings rendered it challenging for us to maintain their individual identities. Furthermore, our dissatisfaction was exacerbated by the fact that the various types of sushi rolls we had ordered were being served in an uncoordinated manner, arriving at disparate intervals rather than being presented simultaneously. Despite the proximity of the Wynn, where we were lodging, we opted to partake of this dining experience."

Picture show has its upsides and its downsides. It's a smaller theater, so they can only show 6-7 movies at once. However, the theaters are super comfy and have a lot of leg room between seats!
