Tall people rejoice! Unfortunately, the lights illuminating the pathways in the theater are so bright they are distracting. It felt like someone was shining a light in my eyeballs the whole movie! Not cool.

The prices are pretty average, but only $5.50 for students, so dig out your old high school ID and trick them by wearing your retainer or something.

Park in the parking garage and walk through the food court to get there!

Seeing as I've been reviewing my recent Vegas adventures, I should probably get this one out of the draft burner.  I have a habit of letting drafts collect dust on Yelp.  So allow me to finish my four month old thoughts:

Zumanity is said to be "adults only," but it's no Absinthe.  It caters to adults with a few raunchy jokes here and there.  And it caters to Vegas with a few topless acts.  But for the most part, it's very tame and even a bit campy.  I didn't find the show pushing the envelop on anything and it didn't appear at all sensual to me.

I brought the boyfriend.  he enjoyed himself but didn't see why I fuss over Cirque du Soleil so much.  On reflection, I should have taken him to see something a bit more awe-inspiring (like "O").  

A lot of the comedy is just heckling the nearby crowd.  And a lot of the acts highlighted in the program were absent during our particular show.  No midgets, no fat twins.  Perhaps that would have added some flavor to an otherwise lackluster evening.  Maybe I was suspecting something too outside the norm and my expectations were bridging on pornographic?  To me, this was a typical Cirque show with some dirty jokes and sexier outfits thrown into the mix.

50% off tickets for military.  So a good deal to fill a few hours of your time.

We made the conscious decision to patronize this culinary establishment based on an abundance of favorable critiques, thus fostering elevated anticipations on our part. Unfortunately, our gastronomical experience fell short of our lofty expectations, as the victuals served were merely adequate. Specifically, the fish taco exhibited a notable lack of moisture and flavor, while the guacamole accompanying the rolled tacos failed to impress our taste buds with its blandness. Furthermore, we sampled the carne asada taco, which, albeit palatable, did not live up to our expectations. Our spouse opted for the steak and eggs, the appearance of which resembled machaca. Although the dining area appeared well-maintained, the state of the lavatory left much to be desired. In light of our underwhelming experience, we would only consider returning to this eatery in the event that it was the sole option available and our hunger was unrelenting.

Holy SMOKE, this place had so much cigarrette smoke in the air it looked hazy.  It made the dining less enjoyable.  We went for the famous \"Steak Special\". And I must say it was pretty darn good.  The green beans and mash potatoes that accompanied it was enjoyable as well.

"Public House, an eatery that embodies the essence of a contemporary gastropub, boasts an interior design reminiscent of dark wood accents and an atmosphere conducive to indulging in delectable dishes such as poutine and foie gras. In keeping with the Las Vegas tradition of incorporating unique features into their establishments, Public House showcases an extensive wine list, readily accessible through a state-of-the-art iPad interface, which allows patrons to peruse and select from an array of exquisite vintages, thereby enhancing the epicurean experience. Additionally, this culinary hotspot demonstrates proficiency in offering lighter fare options, as evidenced by the succulent scallops entre, whose sweetness was complemented by the freshness of the seafood, while the salads, adorned with pomegranate seeds, provided a delightful contrast of flavors and textures."

I am a huge fan of North Kierland, but this was my first time at North Arcadia. Other than the decor of this restaurant (which was beautiful and cool) I was totally underwhelmed. We were there for lunch and we were about the 4th/5th table seated as we were there before 11:30.  There was nothing offensive, but the service was really slow and had a bit of an attitude. The zucca chips (one of my favorites at North Kierland) were over cooked. The $17 lunch portion of bucatini with meatballs was pretty small in size for the price. Nothing here was terrible, but out the door we were at $59.00 for 3 people for lunch with no drinks. Just saying you should go have a less than $20/person lunch at a much better place nearby like T. Cook's or Coup des Tartes.

"City Cafe boasts an array of appealing attributes, including their delectable breakfast offerings, pool table, and affordable beer pitchers, all of which contribute to a convivial ambiance reminiscent of an American diner. However, their big burger challenge is a formidable feat, both to witness and undertake. Additionally, their chips arrive in unique wire fry baskets, adding to the eatery's charm. Unfortunately, their cocktail pitchers lack potency, failing to deliver a satisfactory level of intoxication even after prolonged consumption. Furthermore, their culinary offerings are somewhat unpredictable, with their guacamole-topped nachos tasting eerily similar to mayonnaise and their vegetarian burgers suffering from an unfortunate texture issue that results in a soggy, frothy bun. Despite these drawbacks, I frequent City Cafe and will likely continue to do so, albeit with a preference for pints and chips."

This eatery boasts a prime location within Tivoli Village, featuring a spacious outdoor-indoor bar area that is ideal for enjoying happy hour specials. One of the establishment's most notable aspects is its pet-friendly policy, allowing customers to dine al fresco with their canine companions. While the cuisine does not strictly adhere to traditional Mexican culinary norms, it does offer some unique flavors and combinations. However, the execution of these dishes often falls short, leaving much to be desired. Despite this, the guacamole and chips, prepared tableside, and the complementary salsas remain highlights of the menu. A return visit to Cantina Loredo may be warranted, as there is a lack of satisfactory Mexican restaurants in the surrounding Summerlin area. Ultimately, the three-star rating reflects an average of both authors' opinions, with my husband expressing a greater fondness for the fajitas.

"The culinary offerings and hospitality were satisfactory, albeit not exceptional, and certainly not deserving of commemoration. The cacophony of sounds within the establishment's confines was oppressive, rendering communication between patrons and servers arduous, and necessitating elevated vocalizations on the part of the waiting staff to delineate the day's specials, et cetera. This phenomenon was not exclusive to the bar area, but permeated the dining space as well. Furthermore, the tables were positioned at an uncomfortably proximate distance from one another, making for a less than ideal dining experience when compared to other establishments in the vicinity."

I've been to local Red Robin's in the Bay Area and considering that it's a franchise, they make everything the same at all restaurants. Needless to say, this place isn't all that great. I can come here to eat every now and then, but it's not off the wall where I tend to want to come back more than often.

We ordered an onion ring tower which was HUGE! and ok tasting. I'm not much of a onion ring lover and that might have an impact on why I didn't think it tasted great. Me and the wifey also shared a chicken pasta which wasn't all that tasty in my opinion, probably won't ever order it again. But what I do like about this place is their fish, fries and shrimp sampler appetizer, although we didn't order it at the time we came to this place, I did have it a few times when coming to another Red Robin and I do recommend it to others when coming here.

All in all this place doesn't deserve more than 3 stars as food wasn't that great here when we ate. Sorry Red Robin I just know you can do better.

I have eaten here two times now the first time it was pretty dead in the place and there was what looked like a group of kid's part of the family... My server seemed to cater to that group over me I am a paying customer keep that in mind... I ordered the General Tso's Chicken (Crunchy fried white meat tossed with scallions in a spicy sauce. I was a good meal nothing above and beyond... The second trip was for a lunch and I ordered the Mongolian beef (Spicy marinated beef saut\u00e9ed with scallions and sweet yellow onions served over a bed of crispy rice noodles and sprinkled with sesame seeds... This was a really good meal and great service so let's hope the third this as good.

"In my relentless pursuit of exceptional barbecue, this establishment has emerged as a prominent contender. Its culinary offerings not only boast an impressive flavor profile, but they also refrain from triggering any adverse gastrointestinal reactions, a considerable advantage in my opinion. However, it is crucial to note that the service here can be somewhat lacking. Specifically, I have encountered delays when ordering online and arriving at the designated pickup time, often waiting an additional 15 to 20 minutes beyond the expected duration. Therefore, it may be wise to opt for the takeout counter and place your order directly to avoid unnecessary waiting time."

"I am delighted to be partaking in an evening repast with my dearest kin at this picturesque establishment, the Pointe Hilton Squaw Peak Resort, boasting a tranquil ambiance and delectable culinary offerings. Upon perusing the extensive bill of fare, I was pleased to discover an array of options catering to diverse gastronomic inclinations. Although the service was merely satisfactory, the fare itself was, for the most part, expertly prepared, save for a minor mishap involving the overcooking of the lamb entre for one member of our gathering. In conclusion, while not flawless, our dining experience was, on the whole, acceptable."

The place was a lot of fun because I was with a group of girls and comped drinks kept on coming to our table.

The service and staff were amazingly friendly.  Although I wasn't there for the food, it wasn't too bad.  In fact, I don't remember much of what I ordered but it was only from the appetizer menu. 

The place does get really busy, so make sure you call for reservations.

GRIMALDI's PIZZERIA has a lot going for them with tools and technique at the top of the list. to my sensibilities, a coal fired oven really produces the perfect crust and, at least in my experience, GRIMALID's consistantly does it well.

but the quality of their toppings is really no different than the national chains that dispatch pimple-faced kids to your doorstep when you're too tired to drag your ass to a "real" restaurant and that's kind of disappointing.

and i can't say i'm wild about their sauce either. theirs is raw (and "lightly drizzled" over the other toppings so the crust stays crispy) and i'm partial to a long-simmered version -- i enjoy the additional depth of flavor.

so, the quest for the perfect pizza goes on ...

Ah.. the Flamingo.  First time I was there was back in 1987.  My buddy's parents went to Vegas to gamble and I tagged along to keep him company in the arcade as we weren't old enough to drive yet let alone gamble.  We spent a couple hours on a turbo speed Ms. Pacman machine and walked around the strip.  \n\nI haven't been back in that place since, until last week.  It seemed a bit nicer back in the day.  It's a bit dingy now, and walking in from the parking garage you get hit with a wall of stale smoky air reminiscent of a smoking room at a Super 8 Motel.  Blech.  Circulation is better once you make it through the hall.  The layout is confusing, but I was able to enjoy a few Sam Adams on tap at the bar with the owner of my company who had just flown in from Germany so that was nice.  I refrained from playing here though as I have issues with Harrah's properties after enduring some horrendous customer service at their Rincon San Diego casino.

When I was a resident of the locality, I had the propensity to frequent this establishment with regularity, both for on-premises consumption and takeout purposes. Unfortunately, there has been a discernible decline in quality over the past year, as evidenced by the subpar service during our most recent visits, a reduction in portion size, and an inordinate emphasis on vegetables at the expense of protein. Nonetheless, their Pad Thai remains exceptional.

"It's a novel diminutive eatery, spotless and well-organized, where patrons are required to place their orders at the counter before indulging in their delectable fresh fish fry. The establishment offers an array of savory dips, complemented by expertly cooked French fries that prove to be a satisfying accompaniment to the main attraction. Unfortunately, the venue does not currently offer beer, a disappointing omission that we hope will be remedied in the near future. Despite this minor shortcoming, the generous portions served at this cozy establishment suffice, precluding the need for additional helpings. However, my spouse expressed a desire for a crisper texture and yearned for the inclusion of Texas toast. The fish itself was a delicate white variety, proffering a palate-pleasing flavor profile. The coleslaw, while not exceptional, still managed to contribute a welcome contrast in texture and taste to the meal as a whole. We harbor optimism regarding the longevity and prosperity of this culinary venture and eagerly anticipate our next visit."

Well my first time at the gun range,and I must admit...it was FUN! So here goes my Pros/Cons

Pros:
1. Knowledgeable Staff
2. Plenty of fire power
sadly that's where it ends

Cons:
1.BUSY-that's good thing for them, but you will have a wait! Especially on weekend
2.Small-there were people sitting on the floor, standing in corners. Literally shoulder to shoulder
3.Flustered Range officers-they are not unfriendly, just a lil overwhelmed by the amount of people and trying to keep up with everything going on. I guess I would be too if  30 people carrying rifles and pistols came walking through the door all at once
4. Price-seemed expensive to me. I shared a lane & gun plus ammo with my two sisters for 30 minutes and it came to $88!  All I remember hearing was $15 per gun

Not a bad place to visit if  you've ever wanted to go to a range, just keep in mind the small size and the long lines..

"In pursuit of Shrimp Pad Thai, I conducted a Google search, which led me to this establishment. Upon placing an order for pick-up, I was informed that it would be ready within 15 minutes, much to my delight. However, upon arriving at the venue, I encountered a rather unsettling situation regarding parking. Specifically, the designated parking area was situated down a dimly lit drive-thru/alleyway, which caused me some apprehension due to the presence of a worker who appeared to be smoking in the corner. To avoid any potential discomfort, I suggest that patrons consider parking their vehicles on Spring Mountain and walking around to Valley instead.  

Upon entering the restaurant, I was immediately struck by the warm and welcoming ambiance created by the friendly staff. Moreover, the dish itself was quite flavorful, with a spicy level of four that left a lasting impression on my taste buds. However, I must admit that I was slightly disappointed by the noodles, which were noticeably thinner than what I was accustomed to - almost akin to angel hair pasta, if you will. Additionally, the shrimp used in the dish were of a smaller variety, which didn't quite meet my expectations. Nevertheless, despite these minor shortcomings, the dish remained enjoyable, and I would still recommend it to others. In fact, I might even go so far as to suggest ordering larger shrimp in the future, provided that one has the opportunity to sample the regular dish initially, as I did."

"An abundance of seating options and diverse ambiances within the establishment rendered it an exceedingly comfortable venue, particularly during the warmer seasons when the outdoor patio area can be utilized extensively. However, certain aspects detracted from the overall satisfaction, specifically:  
1. The practice of pouring cream into coffee without first inquiring about preferences regarding dairy substitutes resulted in an unintended addition of half-and-half to my spouse's beverage, despite my desire to customize it with skim milk. Although the staff accommodated my request for a new drink, it would be preferable to have control over the creative process behind my coffee concoction.  
2. The background music consisted of a radio station featuring recurring advertisements, which created an atmosphere akin to being trapped in a shop playing the same irritating tunes and commercials repeatedly. A simple solution would be to curate a playlist or employ an iPod to create a more enjoyable auditory experience for patrons.   
3. While the coffee was satisfactory, the menu items appeared appetizing, but comments regarding the cost have been voiced. Nonetheless, it seems illogical to visit a coffeehouse anticipating a full meal. Prices were only marginally higher than expected.  
4. The availability of beer and the prominent display of a large pizza banner near the entrance raised questions about the establishment's identity. It appears that Hob Nobs may be struggling to define its purpose and target audience. A decision on the type of establishment would alleviate confusion and enhance the overall experience.  
Despite these issues, the visit remained generally pleasurable, with only minor shortcomings detracting from the enjoyment."

I harbored lofty expectations for Cheddatruck, as I possess an unwavering fondness for a delectable burger, which, unquestionably, ranks among my most beloved culinary indulgences. Alas, Cheddatruck failed to captivate my taste buds, leaving me feeling underwhelmed and unimpressed. My companion, who shares my ardor for burgers, eagerly anticipated the opportunity to sample their mac-n-cheese embellished burger, only to be thwarted by the absence of this pivotal ingredient. Thus, he settled for an alternative option, adorned with an egg, while I opted for a straightforward cheeseburger. In addition, we elected to order tots, handcrafted, no less.  

Unfortunately, our burgers proved to be merely passable, with mine suffering from a slight overcooking and a general dearth of flavor. My companion concurred, describing his burger as unremarkable and forgettable. The tots, despite their artisanal preparation, disappointed us, lacking the rich, savory flavors we had anticipated, even with the presence of cheese within them and the accompaniment of an herb-infused cream cheese dipping sauce. Moreover, the price of $3 for a mere seven tots struck us as somewhat exorbitant. 

In conclusion, taking into account the cost, numerous superior burger alternatives exist in the vicinity, rendering Cheddatruck's offerings inferior and, thus, not worth consideration. My apologies, Cheddatruck; your culinary endeavors have fallen short, prompting me to bid thee adieu.

Ate here on a recommendation from a friend while on vacation in Phoenix from Chicago.

I thought the wait was pretty extreme; if I weren't on vacation and willing to just kick it I don't think I would wait 3 hours for a table anywhere.  Luckily hanging at the bar next door was fun, and the wait was bearable due to the circumstances.  

The pizza was very good and the bottle of wine we got was fine - I guess I'm a bit spoiled by Italian pizza (not to be confused with Chicago-style) in my hometown though, as this place seemed solid but not special.  Definitely a quality brick oven pizza with seemingly fresh ingredients though, and an enjoyable evening once you can get in.

I have never gambled here, nor had a meal in any of there Restaurants.  I have really only been here to go see a movie in the theater.  So, with that said.... parking was easy, all of the employees we came into contact with were nice and the signage was easy to follow.  So, I have no complaints nor did I have any expectations.  I will update my review if I ever do anything substantial here.
One of the larger Second Cup around.  Always tons of fresh goods.\n\nCan get busy on Sundays where students come to study.

"I recently partook in a culinary excursion to this establishment, seeking to indulge in their gastronomical offerings, specifically their pizza, as part of my ongoing quest to sample an array of pizza varieties from diminutive, family-owned restaurants. Prior to my visit, I had cultivated a predilection for such establishments, as they often exhibit a more personalized and hospitable ambiance, in contrast to the more impersonal nature of larger pizza chains. Upon entering the premises, I was greeted by a congenial staff who displayed a welcoming demeanor, contributing to an atmosphere that was inviting and pleasant. However, my enthusiasm was tempered by the dearth of patrons, which raised concerns regarding the eatery's popularity and reputation. Following a brief interval of approximately 20 minutes, my pizza was presented, yet its appearance seemed somewhat haphazard, prompting apprehensions regarding its quality. Unfortunately, my concerns were substantiated upon consuming the pizza, as it lacked a certain je ne sais quoi and failed to elicit an extraordinary degree of culinary satisfaction. Despite this, I remain open to revisiting this establishment in the future, as I believe that each dining experience presents an opportunity for growth and improvement."

Came in super late for some munchies and to cure our sweet tooth. I got the bread pudding and my friend got the french toast. The food was solid, but the service was less than desirable. The bartender was more concerned with her phone and gossip than being personable to us.

If the caf out of Eastenders were real, I'm pretty sure this is what it would be like. I've never seen somewhere that better encapsulates the definition of "good old greasy-spoon caf" as well as Brambles.

It's only just opened, and I assumed it would be yet another of these sandwich/wrap/panini type places that Edinburgh is teeming with, but I was very wrong. Although Brambles do offer things like baked potatoes and paninis, their specialty is anything fried served with chips and buttered bread. And I mean literally everything - from traditional chicken nuggets, chips, and beans that are reminiscent of school dinner days, to deep-fried haggis and chips and mushy peas.

They did have some slightly healthier options on the menu, such as lasagne (served with chips, of course!) but it's not really the kind of place you go to consume healthy cuisine. The lace curtains, neon sign in the window, and plastic tables should be the most off-putting thing you've ever seen, but it works in that sort of way that it's so bad it's good. It's kitsch, a bit tacky and dated, despite only being open a few weeks, but it does exactly what it says on the tin and serves good honest junk food at really reasonable prices.

Definitely not as good as Ka or O, but not a bad show to watch in Las Vegas.

Don't get me wrong, the acrobatics were very impressive. However, the show as a whole was kind of slow... (My mom fell asleep a bunch of times). Also, the little acts between the shows were long, and useless (in my opinion).

Anyways, if you are watching a Cirque du Soleil show for the first time, you will be impressed by Mystere. However, if you have seen other shows, I would skip this show and watch something else instead.

My girlfriend and I attend a soft opening dinner. The vibe is very man cave, which was cool with me. This is a great place to grab a burger and drink on a Saturday afternoon and watch the game or take a date on a week night. The Grind is a welcomed dining option for the Arcadia neighborhood! 

The wait staff was super friendly and attentive. Propers to them for having their act together for the opening. 

My girlfriend and I shared the melted rosemary brie with strawberry relish. The brie was cheesy goodness and did take on some of the rosemary flavor. The strawberry relish was flavorful. A balsamic reductions would make this dish. 

We moved onto the BLT burger and the Sweet and Spicy Burger. The 1000 degree coal fire oven does seal in the juices and creates an nice crispy exterior on the patty. All the other ingredients were fresh and tasty. The bun was toasted, yet fresh and spongy on the interior. 

Fries need some improvement, but again this was a soft opening. 

Drink list is inventive and educational. 

Looking forward to coming back.

"Although this establishment possesses certain qualities that are appreciable, it is essential to acknowledge that an analogous dining experience can be obtained at a nearby location, specifically Eastern Pizza, where the culinary offerings are not only comparable but also superior in terms of quality and richness. It is conceivable that the pizza provided at this venue may have been slightly undercooked, resulting in a lack of crispiness, and the flavors may have been somewhat muted. Thus, while consuming food at this establishment may not necessarily result in profound disappointment, it is crucial to recognize that forgoing the opportunity to partake in the gastronomic delights offered by Grimaldi's Pizza, situated in close proximity, would constitute a significant omission."

"The culinary establishment boasted an impressive magnitude, its expansive interior exuding an air of opulence that was further accentuated by the warm welcome we received upon entry. Our server, a consummate professional, promptly escorted us to our table and presented us with menus, his affable demeanor putting us at ease. Opting for the 12 oz New York strip steak, cooked to a medium rare temperature, I eagerly anticipated the arrival of my culinary indulgence. Alas, the duration between placing our orders and the actual serving of our meals proved to be somewhat protracted, approximating thirty to forty-five minutes, which, coupled with the fact that my steak was overcooked to an unfortunate degree, left me feeling somewhat disenchanted. Despite this setback, I chose to maintain my composure and conveyed my dissatisfaction to our server, who expressed regret on behalf of the kitchen staff and extended an offer to prepare a fresh steak. However, given my pressing schedule and ravenous hunger, I elected to forgo this option and instead consume the steak provided, albeit with some reluctance. In spite of this experience, I remain willing to accord the establishment another opportunity to demonstrate its culinary prowess during my future visits to Las Vegas."
 Establishment rating: 4/5
 Waitstaff/Service rating: 4/5
 Cuisine rating: 3/5
 Price rating: 2/5 (lower score indicates higher price)
 Cleanliness rating: 4/5
 Overall rating: 3/5

Vovomeena why were you so hard to find!!! Whether you're driving down McDowell or 7th avenue you won't see it. Maybe we just missed it, but I didn't see any sign whatsoever. The only one was right about their door, but you can't see it well from the street. We got lost and drove around and couldn't find it. I had to text my sister to see where it's at. 

I ordered the banging pocket which I didn't think was very banging. Lol. It comes with sausage and eggs wrapped in a pita with a side of potatoes. It would've been nice with some onions or mushrooms or something. It just wasn't anything great. 

There isn't a lot of seating at the restaurant. You probably have to come early to get a table or you'll end up sitting outside in the hot weather. They should really install misters. The service was really good but it was a far drive for mediocre food.

This establishment would warrant a rating of three and a half stars, taking into account its antiquated Vegas ambiance, reasonable pricing, dazzling illuminated spectacle, and predominantly local clientele. The frozen chocolate-covered bananas available for a mere ninety-nine cents are an absolute delight! Hennessey's restaurant offers an exceptional value with a menu featuring delectable options. The opportunity to engage in twenty-dollar blackjack games and partake in complimentary performances (ranging from mediocre to impressive) further enhances the appeal of this venue. However, it is important to note that the presence of discourteous individuals is ubiquitous and cannot be avoided entirely. Additionally, the low ceilings within the gaming facilities result in an atmosphere heavily saturated with cigarette smoke. While it is not advisable to venture too far away from the light display, it is reassuring to know that there is an adequate number of security personnel present along the main thoroughfare. In summary, this destination presents a refreshing alternative to the contemporary, large-scale corporate character of the Las Vegas Strip, lacking perhaps in gastronomical excellence but simultaneously offering a considerably more affordable experience. Ultimately, it caters to those seeking amusement and entertainment, providing a unique blend of attractions within a compact three-and-a-half block area. It is essential to recall that the essence of Las Vegas revolves around enjoyment and diversion, and the Fremont Street Experience effectively distills these qualities into a concentrated and captivating encounter.

"From a perusal of diverse reviews, it emerges that my encounter mirrored the experiences of numerous others: an ambiance suffused with conviviality, culinary offerings of merit, and yet, regrettably, service characterized by inattention and dilatoriness. 

In pursuit of a replenishment of my coffee, I ascend to the counter, only to discover a staff member stationed before the espresso machine, engaged in the act of self-indulgence, specifically, imbibing successive shots of espresso with seeming relish. Following a brief hiatus, I elect to interrupt this indulgence, addressing the worker with a query regarding the feasibility of securing a refill. The response, though tardy, ultimately materializes in the form of a briskly poured refreshment. 

Despite the barista's tardiness, the coffee and sandwich both proved to be of superior quality, yet, I cannot help but feel that the deferral of my refill until the conclusion of the barista's personal espresso consumption was an unwarranted inconvenience."

It's not a bad hotel for the price.  Really.

The room I stayed in was fine (save for some odd stains on the curtains), the casino and show offerings are about standard (Carrot Top, Criss Angel), and there's a fairly diverse selection of restaurants.

That said, if you want to drop an extra $40 or $50 a night and stay somewhere else, I'd probably recommend doing that.  While I'd take the Luxor over the Imperial Palace, it's certainly no Caesar's or Mandalay Bay.

"Dalkeith Road exudes an air of melancholy, its appearance seeming to convey a sense of resignation and neglect, as if it has been relegated to a state of obscurity and abandonment. The street's length and the presence of other, more convenient thoroughfares running parallel to it appear to accentuate its isolation and inconsequence. Indeed, one cannot help but feel a twinge of commiseration towards this once-vibrant artery, now reduced to a mere shadow of its former self. \n\nIn light of this, C's Tasty Bites, situated along this forlorn stretch, struggles to embody the vivaciousness and allure typically associated with a snack shop. Despite its valiant efforts, the establishment's diminutive stature and cramped interior render it difficult to inhale fully, making it a less-than-ideal venue for lingering over a meal. Furthermore, the prices charged are reasonable, yet the culinary offerings, while adequate, fail to elicit unbridled enthusiasm, ultimately leaving the patron with a lingering sensation of disappointment and disillusionment, mirroring the despondency inherent in the surrounding environs."

Came for a drink after work before I went home to surprise and was told that if was going to pay by debit that I would have to spend $10 minimum. Why can't you pay for what you order regardless of what type of payment you use. Normally I would drink more than $10 worth but today happened to be a day that I can't stay long. And to top it off I asked if I could pay with cash for my one drink with cash, which you can but, the ATM was out of service... Normally I don't care but that I did...

MGM is a decent place to stay if you can get a good rate... Check-in/out is a waiting game, as with any other hotel on the Strip. My room was actually much nicer than I expected, and I especially loved the blackout shades. They really work!... Internet was fairly fast, the minibar selection is good, and I was fortunate to be on a quiet floor.

Their higher-end restaurants were also better than expected, except for Fiamma- blecch

Negatives included boring, often rude blackjack dealers, poor cocktail service in the blackjack area, very little shade available at the pools unless you purchase a cabana (and, you know, it's HOT in the Vegas sun... there was also very limited waitstaff working the pools), the room air conditioner couldn't keep my room cool, and huge crowds everywhere

Overall, if you like staying on the Strip, this isn't a bad place. There are better hotels, and there are certainly worse places

The staff hears what they want to hear. They don't really care what you say or order. I mean, I barely got \"cafe\" out of my mouth and the dude was already gone. What if I didn't want condensed milk, huh? What of that? Same thing for pho orders. And AND the menu had me flustered due to their lack of rice plates. Who does that? Who doesn't have just charbroiled pork as the first thing on the list of rice plates? \n\nDespite my complaints, the egg rolls were excellent! Loads of filling in them! And the coffee was old school, with the metal drip thing and the cup of ice. Pho was good, but something about 105 degree heat makes me not want to eat a big hot soupy bowl of pho.

"The culinary establishment under investigation is situated within the lobby premises of the Westin hotel, where I was temporarily residing; however, I refrained from partaking of their gastronomical offerings due to their subpar ratings on the popular review platform, Yelp. On the final evening of my tenure, I was exhausted and had worked late into the evening, thus opting to sample their fare.  

Upon perusing their bill of fare, I discovered an array of delectable options, including an assortment of seafood and sushi dishes that piqued my interest, although I ultimately settled on a pair of sushi rolls. The quality of the sushi was satisfactory, and their draft beer selection was quite impressive. Based solely on the culinary aspect, I would assign a rating of 3.5 stars, nearing the threshold of four; however, this assessment was derived from a limited sampling of their offerings. Thus, I shall endeavor to partake of their cuisine once more. 

Unfortunately, their service left much to be desired, potentially contributing to their mediocre reputation. The bar area was moderately populated, while the dining area was largely unoccupied; yet, patrons seated at the bar were compelled to signal the bartender to garner his attention, and the preparation time for my meager order of two sushi rolls exceeded 25 minutes. These factors might account for their suboptimal rating. Since I shall likely be extending my stay at this Westin for an indeterminate period, I shall consider giving their eatery another chance in the future."

The good: great flavors- the pork is delicious, different options, clean and friendly team

The bad: this is my first time here so my biggest concern was the temperature of the food. I came for a late lunch, I get it, but didn't feel like the items were super fresh or hot. I think this would have been different should I have come during lunch or dinner hour. My other suggestion: the sauces should've served warm, not cold.

Overall, I enjoyed it and would try it again. Love the concept.

"I had the privilege of indulging in the delectable brisket at a local establishment recently, and I must say that it thoroughly satiated my gastronomical desires. The meat was cooked to perfection, boasting an optimal balance of tenderness and juiciness that left me yearning for more. While I did appreciate the addition of the savory sauce, I would request that it be served on the side during my subsequent visit, thereby allowing me to relish the unadulterated flavor of the brisket without any distractions."

"Expended two hundred dollars on a culinary experience for two individuals at an upscale dining establishment, precipitating elevated anticipations. Unfortunately, my significant other's cut of meat, specifically the steak, was overcooked and lacked succulence, while the supplementary sauces presented were not merely unimpressive but also unpalatable. In contrast, my Beef Wellington was of satisfactory quality, albeit not exceptional. Furthermore, the macaroni and cheese accompanying the dish was excessively arid, prompting inquiry into the cause of such an anomaly. Considering the totality of factors, including ambiance and service, a sense of disappointment permeated our dining experience, leading me to conclude that future patronage would be unwarranted. However, I may opt to sample their burger alternative at a subsequent date."

Located on Flamingo right next door to the Rio. it is in walking distance to the Las Vegas Strip if you like to walk , but it is not such nice walk (on a freeway overpass) . That being said this place is a bit of a gem. Very reasonable rates, although not the swankiest place in Las Vegas. Coast properties tend to have a lot of amenities, making them self-sufficient. In other words you can stay here, not leave and still have a great pick of restaurants and the like. So if you are on a budget and want something a bit laid back give this place a look. Live it up, you are in Las Vegas for cryin' out loud!

Didn't come here to eat just drink but can't really go wrong with 2.50 coronas this is definitely is a college bar and a bit noisy what's wierd is there Oregon duck fans and not ASU fans? Great place for day drinking though

"A typical shopping mall, characterized by an assortment of retail establishments catering predominantly to the needs and preferences of tourists, with prices that are considerably higher than those found at local venues. Despite its reputation as a 'tourist trap,' this mall does feature a select number of unique specialty stores and occasional sales events, rendering it a worthwhile destination for visitors seeking a distinctive shopping experience. Additionally, the mall boasts an exceptional coffee establishment, as well as complimentary yoga classes offered at Lululemon on Sundays, further enhancing its appeal to patrons."
Popped in for a few tacos today... The carne asada was lacking in flavor, no marinade, and pretty bland. The carnitas were very good and I'd eat a dozen at one sitting :)

Nice local establishment with great food and fantastic patio to hang out on in the summer . The interior is dark and the tvs need to be bigger and placed in better viewing areas . If you don't know where this place is , it is Kind of hard to explain to people how to there . Still a nice clean and safe place to hang out .

"This eatery can be classified as a typical Chinese dining establishment, offering culinary fare at a reasonable price point. As part of their lunchtime offerings, a meager $5.95 affords a clientele an entre accompanied by a beverage. The level of hospitality displayed by the staff is commendable, as they exhibit attentive behavior, periodically inquiring about the satisfaction of their patrons and ensuring that glasses remain filled in a timely fashion. Unfortunately, the gastronomical offerings themselves are merely adequate, which is unsurprising given the affordable pricing. Furthermore, it is worth mentioning that the presentation of the food appears somewhat lackluster, as the utilization of Styrofoam containers and absence of serving utensils detracts from the overall visual appeal. In conclusion, this dining establishment is suitable for those seeking a rapid and economical meal, but may not cater to the preferences of more discerning gourmands."

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say that my experiences have been thoroughly satisfactory, with both the service and culinary offerings meeting my expectations. In fact, I recently indulged in their delectable Peanut Buster Parfait, which not only tasted divine but also bore a striking resemblance to the advertised image, a rarity among dining establishments. Consequently, when the craving for a Dairy Queen treat arises and I find myself in close proximity, I will unhesitatingly patronize this particular location for a satisfying repast.

After experiencing such a deplorable episode at Babystacks (refer to previous review), my acquaintance and I opted to venture towards Lulu's, seeking a more satisfactory dining experience. The stark contrast between the subpar service we had endured and the hospitable treatment we received at Lulu's was indeed palpable. Despite the fact that orders are placed at the counter, the eatery offers the convenience of seating in the Metro pizza area, which is particularly advantageous for families with young children. Additionally, the staff kindly delivered our beverages to our table, further facilitating the dining experience for us. When my companion requested that her egg be prepared over hard instead of over easy, the kitchen staff did not display any signs of annoyance or reluctance, illustrating their commitment to customer satisfaction. On previous occasions, the manager has exhibited exceptional kindness and made conscious efforts to ensure that we felt welcome.  

My culinary selection for the morning was the Herman breakfast sandwich, priced at approximately $8, which, although somewhat expensive, offered a satisfying combination of flavors and textures. The sandwich itself consisted of a pretzel bun adorned with a fried egg, sausage, cheese, and a tangy stone-ground mustard. While the chocolate croissant failed to meet my elevated standards, as I am a self-proclaimed connoisseur of the classic French pastry, the lemon tart proved to be a delightful surprise, evoking memories of a delectable sour cream lemon pie crafted by my spouse. The establishment customarily offers complimentary samples of cookies and muffins, contributing to the overall pleasant ambiance.

"While my sojourn in Phoenix was underway, I elected to peruse the evaluations on Yelp to identify an optimal purveyor of donuts that could cater to my unwavering predilection for the delectable treat. Although Lamar's positioned itself as a mid-range establishment, my expectations remained grounded in the hope of securing a scorching hot and fresh batch of classic glazed donuts, which, regrettably, proved unattainable during my visit. However, despite the absence of optimal donut consumption conditions, my overall experience did not descend into utter disappointment."

Specialty food should be special. There should be a reason why you pay a bit extra for a few morsels of goodness. Reid's has a lock on these specialty foods with a nice looking meat department, array of choice cheeses and impressive wine selection. Let's break down this location a bit, shall we?

The Good: As mentioned, it's a great spot to grab a quick bite, snag a bottle of wine, some tasty snacks and get on your merry way. The service is pretty spectacular - whether your seeking said bottle of wine or dining on a sandwich during lunch. Many of the sandwiches and salads I saw coming around looked fresh and delicious. Also, there's a decent sized wine bar next to the wine vault/selection area that could kick your feet up while you taste away. 

The Meh: The parking is pretty much horrendous. Unless you're stealing parking from business across the street, you better be comfortable walking a ways. The sandwich I ate here was underwhelming - the grilled pimento cheese was gut busting-ly greasy (granted, it's grilled pimento cheese) and also missed the zing I was looking for. I barely got through half of the sloppy mess and had to put it down for fear that I may have a heart attack in the shop. 

If I'm walkin' around Selwyn and need to score a few snacks before heading home, Reid's is a fine choice, yet they definitely have plenty of competition in the area if we're talking tasty sandwiches and wine tasting!

"The delectable crepes boast an array of flavors, ranging from the traditional simplicity of lemon juice to the richness of Nutella complemented by bananas. In contrast, the savory crepes appear unimaginative and lacking in inspiration. However, the inviting ambiance of the coffee shop, enhanced by the well-crafted coffee, compensates for the deficiency. Unfortunately, the service has been inconsistent, marred by the presence of a bothersome fly during our last two visits."

"Upon entering the establishment, one is immediately struck by the presence of a mechanical bull, which serves as a central focal point within the venue and lends an air of rugged excitement to the proceedings. The atmosphere is further enhanced by the abundance of masculine patrons, whose boisterous revelry contributes to the overall ambiance of the establishment. The auditory senses are similarly stimulated by the high volume of the musical offerings, which serve to augment the convivial nature of the gathering. Of particular note, however, are the exceptional quality of the lettuce wraps served by the establishment, which truly distinguishes itself from the standard fare typically associated with such establishments. While the author's experience with similar venues may be limited, it is evident that this particular location offers a unique and enjoyable initiation into the local nightlife."

"I have been frequenting this establishment for approximately a decade, and while I have had a strong affinity for their culinary offerings in the past, recent experiences have left me feeling somewhat disillusioned and disappointed. The issues that have been raised by other patrons, such as the limited quantity of meat on the sandwiches, the high prices, and the sluggish service, have unfortunately become increasingly apparent. Furthermore, I must express my dismay at the lack of environmental consciousness displayed by the restaurant, as evidenced by their refusal to reuse punch cards and instead opting to discard and replace them, resulting in unnecessary waste. Despite these criticisms, I may still continue to visit, albeit with reduced frequency."

"The advantages of this establishment include an affordable menu featuring fresh culinary offerings, delectable milkshakes, a pristine dining environment, affable and welcoming staff members, and a unique pepper bar. However, the drawbacks consist of an uninspired and lackluster dining area, an awkward layout within the dining room, unoriginal menu selections, and pre-made salad dressings. While it may be suitable for a rapid burger craving, in my view, alternative burger venues in the locality are preferable."

"This establishment undoubtedly offers an excellent venue for procuring delectable and affordable sushi for a hasty luncheon, thereby catering to individuals seeking a quick and satisfying repast. Nonetheless, it is essential to note that this eatery does not possess the optimal ambiance for a leisurely dining experience, as the seating arrangements are limited and the table settings consist of disposable utensils and Styrofoam cups. Furthermore, the waitstaff may exhibit a certain degree of inattention to detail, as evidenced by the delay in preparing the sushi rolls and the absence of sugar for the tea. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the rainbow roll and green tea offered by this restaurant are indeed exceptional, thereby rendering it a suitable destination for those seeking a satisfying and expedient meal. However, it is not recommended for dates or dinner due to the aforementioned limitations."

Nice seafood place away from the casinos.

Food: 7.5/10 - Nice menu selections. Well prepared.  The flavors will not wow you but they are a solid meal.  

Service: 8/10 - No problems. Nothing spectacular either.

Cleanliness: 8/10 - No visible issues.

Decor: 8.5 / 10 - Sat outside on a beautiful night.  Was very nice.  Inside looked nice as well.

Restrooms: 7/10 - no problems.

Parking: 9/10 - Tons of parking.  

Overall: 7/10 - A nice place to eat.  I personally like the Texas de Brazil located right next door MUCH better.

Upon entering the establishment, it became apparent that the SeaHawkers club had recently vacated the premises, leaving behind a scene of disarray and chaos, with the staff struggling to restore order and tidiness to the dining area, in preparation for the impending arrival of new patrons. Notwithstanding the prevailing bedlam, the restaurant managed to maintain an acceptable level of service, offering delectable fare and potables at reasonable prices, further enhanced by the availability of a discounted beverage promotion through the utilization of the 4Square mobile application, even during the peak hours of the day.

"A hospitable ambiance and proficient service are hallmarks of this establishment, rendering it an ideal setting for patrons seeking respite from exorbitant prices associated with mediocre beverages. Although the selection of draft beers may not boast an extensive array of options, the bartenders demonstrate a commendable level of attentiveness and helpfulness, ensuring that each patron's experience is optimized. Instances of inadvertently dispensed extra beverages are met with considerate explanations, fostering an atmosphere of transparency and customer satisfaction. As a frequent visitor, I have had the pleasure of witnessing such exceptional service on multiple occasions, leaving me with a favorable impression of this business and motivating me to continue offering my patronage."

I gave it a 3 star because overall the hotel was just ok, I did expect It to be better..  First time at the Trump hotel and found mold food in the refrigerator!! Customer service is not that great..Housekeeping took forever to clean my room, I did call early in the morning to inform them I need housekeeping which was provided but finish around 3pm... The hotel is away from the strip..we have to take taxi to and from Caesars Palace even though there was shuttle provided because we have to wait at least more then 25 min. Shuttle does stop at midnight which sucks because we can't enjoy ourselves just worrying the shuttle will stop soon and that's why we have to take taxi which charge us $20 plus tips and taxi driver doesn't want just $1 tip, they want more....
It's best to stay on the strip so no more taxi or shuttle rides !!
Pros:
Quiet, luxurious, doesn't smell, kitchen in the suites, luxurious bathroom
Cons:
just a few minor things. The shuttles stop way too early and it take a long time to pick you up. It's far away from the strip if you were to walk..there's really nothing to do at the hotel..it's just a basic hotel with a pool and a gym..

"Gastronomical indulgences of unparalleled quality, even when forgoing the limitless spaghetti option. Enjoyed an arugula and white bean salad, accompanied by a pair of penne pasta dishes, both of which demonstrated culinary proficiency. Ambient surroundings, reasonable tariffs, and attentive servers further enhanced the overall dining experience."

we have gone to this \"ol'school (of the strip, local)\" restaurant/casino/brewery a ew tims (btw are you confused yet---so am I)\nto say the least it is a jack of all trades but, you cant beat there breakfasts, cheap and good, last time i went it was steak and eggs for $3.99. as i stated previoulsy this is also a brewery and they make there own root beer, yeah its good stuff..this is not a place i would staay at or even gasmble at but its good bang for your buck......last time i went with my pops in law we had a coupon all u can drink for 1 whole hour, no purchase necessary, i think we rocked 22 coronas, pretty awesome...

"Our dining experience was marred by an overwhelmed server who appeared flustered by the numerous tables she was attending to, and we felt somewhat inconvenient when requesting a replenishment of celery sticks, which were scantily provided alongside the delectable buffalo wings that boasted an impressive quality, albeit with varying degrees of spiciness; specifically, the mango-spicy variety was quite piquant, while the garlic Asian version was noticeably milder, and the jerk chicken offering was surprisingly bland, thus rendering the overall enjoyment of the meal somewhat inconsistent; furthermore, we were taken aback by the unexpected charge for additional celery refills, which amounted to $1.20, a sum we deemed disproportionate considering the minimal cost of a single celery stalk."

"The disparity between the quality of experience offered by the Napa Valley establishment and that of Las Vegas is palpable. Specifically, the culinary offerings and hospitality encountered at the bar fell short of expectations, with our server/bartender displaying forgetfulness on multiple occasions, necessitating repeated orders, and engaging in unprofessional conduct by openly attributing blame to the chef for errors in food preparation, which detracted from the overall quality of the dining experience, already found lacking in comparison to previous visits to the region."

"I must confess an unwavering fondness for Trader Joe's; may I be so bold as to express my enthusiasm for this establishment? The prices and quality of their nuts (encompassing almonds, pecans, walnuts, et al.) and nut-based products (including almond butter, and so forth) are, in my humble opinion, unparalleled. Furthermore, their produce is of exceptional quality, and they offer an array of unique items that are simply unattainable elsewhere. Allow me to emphasize my unequivocal endorsement of Joe Joe's; indeed, it is nothing short of magnificent! 

However, I must deduct two stars from my rating due to the following factors:

1. The quest for a parking spot during peak hours (specifically between 12 pm and 1 pm from Monday to Friday) borders on the impossible. Accept the challenge at your own peril, dear reader! 

2. Lamentably, the store's dimensions are rather diminutive, leaving me with an inescapable feeling of disappointment. In spite of these drawbacks, I maintain that Trader Joe's is an outstanding retailer."

Oh Treasure Island, and your old-school pirate show, where have you gone?  Welcome to TI, and the scantily clad pirate show...my have times have changed.  Across the street from the Venetian/Palazzo sits TI.  Definitely has seen better days, and by that I mean pretty much everything.  Rooms, casino, food.  If you want to save a few bucks and stay down at this end of the Strip, this is your place.  Just be prepared to hear the pirate show every night!

You know, after going back to the convention for a second year and eating at the Golden Palace Buffet again, I have to say that ordering off of the menu provided a significant improvement over the buffet.\n\nThe food wasn't nearly as greasy and was actually quite flavorful.  I was pleased with my meal and I'm sure my friends were, too.  My friend, who was wearing a giant costume, was treated with courtesy.

"Preferring a culinary experience characterized by a pleasant combination of texture and flavor, specifically, a dish wherein the tofu is cooked to a satisfying firmness, devoid of excessive softness or squishiness, I placed an order for the yellow curry tofu, anticipating a delightful repast. Unfortunately, the restaurant's interpretation of this popular Thai dish fell short of my expectations, as the tofu was presented in a state of uninspiring softness, lacking the crispy exterior and tender interior that I had hoped for. Instead of being expertly fried or otherwise prepared, the tofu was merely cut into small pieces and added to the curry without further ado. While the rich, well-spiced curry sauce and generous portion of vegetables did somewhat compensate for this disappointment, the overall effect was diminished by the absence of a satisfying textural contrast. Notwithstanding this letdown, the eatery does offer a diverse selection of Thai dishes at reasonable prices during the lunch hour, and the unpretentious ambiance of the establishment, replete with high-top tables by the window and conventional tables inside, provided a suitable setting for a casual meal. However, the dearth of patrons during our weekday visit suggested that the restaurant may struggle to attract a consistent clientele."

"Upon returning to Las Vegas from an excursion to Phoenix, we opted to halt at this particular Subway establishment, strategically positioned on the right-hand side of the thoroughfare leading towards our destination. 

My order consisted of a 6-inch BMT sandwich, augmented with jalapeno cheddar bread, which I requested to be toasted. Furthermore, I customized my sandwich by adding an assortment of vegetables, including tomatoes, lettuce, green peppers, pepperoncinis, mustard, mayonnaise, oil, vinegar, salt, and pepper. The accommodating staff expedited the preparation of my meal, enabling me to partake in it without any significant delay. 

The quality of the ingredients utilized in the sandwich was exceptional, thereby contributing to its delectable flavor. This impromptu dining experience served as an optimal respite during our journey. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that the establishment boasts well-maintained restrooms, which are a welcome amenity for travelers seeking a brief pit stop. In light of the fact that every service station in Wickenberg was brimming with travelers availing themselves of the facilities, it is judicious to consider this Subway location as a viable alternative. 

In conclusion, based on the positive experience we had, it is highly likely that we shall revisit this eatery on future excursions between Phoenix and Las Vegas."

"During our most recent sojourn in Las Vegas, my associates and I opted to take advantage of an offer that allowed us to lodge at Treasure Island at a price that was considerably lower than usual. Upon arriving at the establishment, we observed the presence of a restaurant specializing in Vietnamese cuisine, which we found rather peculiar. Furthermore, we expressed our skepticism regarding the quality of the fare served within said eatery, as evidenced by our derisive comments directed towards those who had chosen to partake in their meals there, and presumably, pay an elevated price for the experience. Ironically, we would later find ourselves returning to the very same venue, albeit under different circumstances, as we sought sustenance to alleviate the unpleasant symptoms brought about by our excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages during the previous night's festivities. In conclusion, while the cost of dining at this particular Pho restaurant may be somewhat prohibitive, it remains a viable option for those seeking nourishment in the midst of a debilitating hangover, particularly for those already lodging at Treasure Island."

I don't know what it is about mainland L&Ls...but the food just doesn't have the same taste as L&Ls back home in Hawaii.  The food is edible and very bland.  Beware when paying, though.  The prices on the menu board say one thing, but check your receipt...you may have been charged more.  I brought this to the attention of the worker who was ringing up my purchase, and his response was \"I can't do anything...that's what it says on the computer.\"  Really?  Businesses need to realize they can't advertise their price publicly, and then charge more at the register.  Very bad business practice!

"I partook in a culinary excursion with a considerable assemblage of individuals. Our host selected a remarkable vintage, the cost of which was undoubtedly substantial. Alas, the gastronomical offerings did not entirely meet expectations. The chopped salad was unremarkable, its flavors overpowered by an excess of red kidney beans. The accompanying table breads and muffins were arid, rendering them somewhat inedible. The duck pancake, saturated with an abundance of saccharine syrup, obscured the bird's natural flavor. However, the porterhouse lamb chops proved to be the highlight of my dining experience, boasting perfectly grilled meat complemented by an unobtrusive sauce. A warm, pudding-like cake, whose name escapes me, constituted the dessert course. Unfortunately, the coffee service was tardy, prompting us to consume the cake before its arrival. Notwithstanding this drawback, the eatery remains a pleasant venue within Caesars, and I would advise future patrons to focus their orders on grilled meats and maintain tempered expectations regarding the remaining dishes."

It's Wal-Mart and it does not disappoint.  This store location just opened recently and I thought, "well, it's somewhat close to ASU, maybe it'll have a different vibe than the typical Wal-Mart experience I'm used to."

Nope

It's your standard issue Wal-Mart with your standard issue merchandise at those low low prices Wal-Mart's famous for.

It also still draws the same type of customers.  They're the ones we've all come to know and love at www.peopleofwalmart.com.  If you're looking for an environment where kids scream out the numbers they know (and failing to exceed 5...I'm serious), if part of your shopping experience includes the oblivious blocking every isle, and if you are enamored by the grandma pace cars you have to follow to get up to the front, then this is the Wal-Mart for you.

This is a 'Superstore' and the biggest close by supermarket for Leith / Shore residents. 

It has 2 entrances one at the Tesco Car park at the back and the back entrance on Duke Street. 

It is a Tesco supermarket and they do what supermarkets do. In addition to that they have also clothes and electricals available.

For a so-called Superstore it is a little small. but it supplies what is needed and it is open from 06:00 till Midnight. 

Be aware that the law of baying alcohol before 10am  and after 10pm also counts for supermarkets.. Some Leith residents tend to 'forget' that rule and get into a discussion a the till. - happened a few times. 

They have a section dedicated to self-service tills and 2 fast lane basket only cashiers. 

They are not as frequently visited by me, certainly after the whole Horse meat scandal. But they are a handy go to for packaged products. Whiskies, spirits, wine and chocolates. - that's about it. 

Not the worst of shops, but not the best either

I'm giving it 3 stars almost solely on decor & atmosphere. 

After reading all of the rave reviews I really expected to be amazed, but sadly, that didn't happen. 

I did get a nonfat chai latte instead of coffee, so maybe that has something to do with it. It was kind of bland, nothing special :( 

But like I said, the company was good, the atmosphere nice & I love the look of the place :) 

If I try it again I'll try the coffee,,, I don't think I want to repeat my chai experience.

Not bad. Better than other fast food joints in Scotland. Actually WAY better than the fast food joints in Scotland. \n\nI kinda expected more, but was won over by the rootbeer float. That was definitely worth going. OMG, you have not experienced American fast food/diner fare til you've had a rootbeer float. Brought me back to the days of Dairy Queen and the likes. Yet the burger wasn't all that. It was ok but it just felt like there was something missing, to make it a home run. Also, I probably should've ordered the cajun fries. I ordered the onion rings. They were good but clearly frozen. So now I'm on a mission to find fresh made onion rings, any rec's?

well i wanted a place at center strip. would i have gone for the flamingo for a little more money, knowing what i know now? yes.

but... hey, can't complain. it was a little shoddy, a little dirty, and totally just fine. we had a balcony! which my sister's suite at the mirage did NOT! so there.

the buffet was fine. nothing to write home about, but so far no food-borne illness, which i'm all about.

so yes, it may not be much of a step up from the motel 6, but it is a step. a good deal at center strip. and if you're spending too much time in your room you're doing something wrong anyway!

"I had the pleasure of dining at this esteemed establishment last evening, and I must say that the culinary experience was nothing short of exceptional. The three-course meal, complemented by a glass of wine, struck me as an excellent value proposition, particularly given the quality of the fare and the attentive service provided by both the greeter and our waitress. My sardine starter and hake main course, accompanied by a side of spinach, were both exquisitely prepared and presented, showcasing the chef's evident dedication to their craft. While I would have liked to award an additional half star for the superlative dining experience, I regretfully deducted a full star due to a few minor shortcomings. Specifically, the cheese board, while adequate, could have benefited from a greater variety of accompaniments, such as oatcakes, and perhaps a fresher slice of brie. Moreover, the cheese knife, though functional, appeared somewhat worn and tired, detracting slightly from the overall enjoyment of the meal. Notwithstanding these minor criticisms, I must commend the restaurant on its well-appointed interior, which, despite its former identity as a Harry Ramsden's, remains tastefully designed and bathed in natural light. Suffice it to say, I am eagerly anticipating my next visit to this gastronomic gem."

"Utopian haven for hipsters. Bring on the 1920s era boots with dungarees that are a perfect match. 

Exquisite ambiance. A magnificent, vintage roaster is showcased and utilized extensively. 

Evidently, there is a scarcity of artisanal coffee in my hometown. A queue extended nearly to the entrance. 

I managed to acquire an espresso. It was presented promptly and proficiently. In my modest opinion, the coffee was satisfactory...not exceptional. An excess of fruitiness/acidity. Insufficient rich, velvety texture reminiscent of chocolate. However, that's merely my taste. Not necessarily everyone else's preference.

Nonetheless, my companion ordered a pour-over. And, pour-overs require a considerable amount of time. Following ten minutes of waiting, we inquired. Oh! We neglected your pour-over coffee! Wait an additional ten minutes. Derrrr...I'm unwilling to wait another ten minutes, but I suppose I must since my girlfriend and I both have an addiction to caffeine and cannot function adequately without it. 

Fortunately, I had the opportunity to sample my companion's brew, and it was delightful. 

In summary, they possess a successful formula, but minor adjustments are necessary. I would certainly revisit."

We partook of a culinary experience at this establishment in the company of our kin, and we must say, the ambiance was quite pleasant, albeit a tad tranquil for a Sunday afternoon. Upon entering the realm of the all-you-can-eat extravaganza, we were struck by an unpleasant olfactory sensation akin to that of a sewage system, which momentarily deterred us from indulging in the gastronomical offerings. However, our ardent fondness for sushi (a staggering fifteen times per mensem, no less!) impelled us to persevere and sample the wares presented. Alas, our expectations were not entirely met, as the quality of the sushi failed to meet the standards of a top-tier establishment, eliciting comparisons to the pedestrian offerings found at your run-of-the-mill grocery store. Notwithstanding, the diversity of options available on the buffet table was quite impressive, and it would have been even more satisfactory had the taste lived up to the price point.

We saw this place on Bar Rescue and wanted to check it out. My wife and I showed up about 9:30 PM. I was starving and planned on eating here. Unfortunately the bartender said the kitchen was closed because they had a slow night. I had one beer and left only because I couldn't keep drinking without getting some kind if food in my belly. Next time in Vegas I will definitely give this place another shot. And maybe more stars. The locals were extremely friendly and greeted us as soon as we walked in. The bartender was also very friendly. Wish I could have experienced the food.

"I thoroughly relished the culinary offerings, specifically the chicken fried steak, which was served with an ample portion of mashed potatoes and a savory gravy that complemented the dish perfectly. Additionally, a side of green beans and a preliminary salad preceded the main course, contributing to an overall satisfying gastronomical experience. However, upon entering the establishment, we encountered a degree of perplexity due to the absence of a clear greeting protocol. Despite the cozy ambiance, it is crucial for the staff to maintain a vigilant attitude towards welcoming patrons and clarifying the waiting process, which currently seems to rely on an informal 'first-come, first-served' basis. Notwithstanding this drawback, my evaluation of the restaurant remains neutral, augmented by my appreciation for its family-owned nature and the palatable fare."

Food and service were okay. Among the dishes I ate were sweet & sour soup and tofu with baby bok choy.\n\nThe decor seemed fancy. I liked the jellyfish lights near the entrance and the wood-covered menus.

"It is patently evident that this drinking establishment boasts an exceptionally pleasant ambiance, further enhanced by the rational pricing strategy implemented for the consumables served. However, it is suggested that the proprietors consider augmenting the seating capacity by introducing two diamond-shaped tables, preferably situated in a proximal location to the existing bar counter, thereby creating an atmosphere conducive to social interaction and potentially generating increased revenue through the accommodation of pool league tournaments and round-the-clock patronage."
Average American restaurant, good food, but nothing special. Safe choice restaurant.   Bar area is loud, a bit difficult to talk and hear.

"Pros: Aesthetically pleasing and well-organized retail space offering an extensive array of unique, second-hand items. \nCons: Lacking clear signage indicating individual booths' discount rates during storewide sales, leading to confusion. Difficulty in distinguishing employees from customers due to absence of identifying attire such as aprons or name tags. Utilizing recycled newsprint instead of clean wrapping paper for purchases. Areas ripe for enhancement to elevate the overall shopping encounter."

"I found this establishment to be quite appealing, with an ambient atmosphere that was thoroughly enjoyable, and the hospitality we received was of an exceptionally high caliber. The beverage I consumed, specifically the mojito, was truly delectable, and the waffles were similarly impressive in terms of their culinary excellence. My offspring, who accompanied me to this venue, was particularly enthused by the red velvet pancakes, which she sampled with great relish. However, there was one aspect of our dining experience that proved to be somewhat prohibitive, and that was the cost - the prices were exorbitant, with a single order of pancakes commanding a fee of $13, a sum that I found to be rather steep and prohibitive for frequent patronage."

A good place to eat, trendy. You can't call ahead or make reservations so expect to wait about 20-30 minutes for a table. The food is good, but when I went there I got an Eggs Benedict and it was more of a hard boiled egg, though it was well-seasoned. \n\nI'll be giving it another try, but I was much more excited about this place before I tried it.

We stopped here for lunch because we were tired and didn't feel like walking any further. We both had the potato leek soup, which was excellent. My Sweetie had the tuna sandwich with fries and I had the plain salad with a side of fries. I was sad my salad had a more than a few not-so-fresh leaves, but the waitress (Dana) did not charge us for it. The fries were crispy and hot and tasty. The food was good but not memorable in anyway. Dana was one of the sweetest waitresses ever. So polite and attentive.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
That's how I would summarize my visit to this Korean BBQ restaurant. Despite my enthusiasm for trying the same menu items I had previously enjoyed in Los Angeles, I was let down by the absence of the anticipated flavor and value.
Notwithstanding, I must acknowledge that the servers were quite hospitable. We opted for bulgogi and ribs, which, while palatable, fell short of my expectations in terms of quality. Moreover, we were not provided with replenishments for the side dishes that accompanied our grill-your-own barbecue table.
Furthermore, I must express my disappointment at having paid an exorbitant amount beyond what I had anticipated, despite utilizing a Groupon promotion. In conclusion, while the establishment maintained a clean atmosphere, the cost did not justify the quality of the food served.

Upstream, an eatery situated in Charlotte, is presumably perceived as one of the premier dining establishments within the city's culinary landscape. As an individual hailing from Philadelphia, a metropolis renowned for its exceptional gastronomic offerings and celebrated chefs, my perspective might be slightly biased. Notwithstanding, the comestibles presented by Upstream were undoubtedly satisfactory, albeit not remarkably extraordinary or astonishing. Each dish, excluding the humble house salad, was regrettably imbued with an excessive quantity of salt, which somewhat marred the overall flavor profile. My spouse indulged in the tuna, while I opted for the seabass. Although both dishes were palatable, they failed to ascend to the lofty heights of truly exceptional cuisine. We would consider revisiting Upstream for its raw or sushi options, but our enthusiasm for the cooked dishes was somewhat tempered. The aforementioned house salad proved to be the zenith of my dining experience, whereas the crab bisque demonstrated considerable gustatory appeal as well. In terms of service, the restaurant's staff exhibited commendable proficiency, although their pace was somewhat languid. Our server, in particular, distinguished himself as one of the most erudite and knowledgeable members of the waiting staff we have had the pleasure of encountering since relocating from Pennsylvania.

After Harlow's down the road was so packed we couldn't park, we decided to give this new breakfast cafe a try.  The portions are extremely generous and overall the food was really good.  The prices are a little high I think, but not so much that I wouldn't return.  I knocked down a star because the ham I received was \"off\" and tasted like it was past it's shelf life, and the oj was just so-so.  They do give complimentary chocolate covered strawberries that are epic!

It's BBQ at an airport.  If you're in the mood for BBQ while in the airport, well friend, you have pretty darn limited options.  This place is affordable for an airport, and decent.  Great BBQ it is not, but it's serviceable, and quite a bit better than your options to the left and right.

I went with the three meat platter.  The brisket was 1/2 fat; I'm pretty sure I got the end chunk.  The pulled pork was decent, and the turkey had a good smoke but was pretty dry.  They have one sauce option...yes or no.  Definitely not mustard-based, but recommended as it's not overbearing.  

For healthy sides...well, you're at a BBQ joint, so good luck with that.

....and boy are my arms tired!

Comedy clubs are easy to review when focusing on the club itself, and not the talent.  You could be in the perfect comedy club and see a horrible act, just as you could see something amazing at a dive bar's open mic night.  

This "club" is really  a conference room that has been converted into a comedy club.  The staff sets up chairs around the room for the patrons the night of the show, adding seats when needed.  There are a few VIP couches, but since this intimate setting is quite quaint, there really is no reason to pay the high price for them.

There are two waitresses who run around frantically trying to fill all the patrons' orders, but be ready to wait for your beverage.  Walking up to the bar in the room is usually a better way to go.  

I saw the late (9pm) show on a Saturday night.  Seating starts at 8:30, so get there early if you want to sit in the front.  Really, there isn't a horrible seat in the house though.  

I saw Todd Paul the night I went in, and laughed my A$$ off.  He was charismatic and hilarious.  His act was a mix of magic, stunts, and comedy.  He did an amazing job of making fun of Las Vegas shows, specifically magic shows.  I would definitely return for another fun night.

We ate here a few weeks ago per a recommendation from the hotel we were staying at.  While I do not eat steak a few of my friends do and they said they liked it.  I ordered the Chicken Peppered Penne which was delicious.  I asked them to make it extra spicy which they did.  The pasta was cooked perfectly, the sauce was creamy, and the dish had a great flavor.  The service was good and the prices were reasonable.

This culinary establishment serves the most delectable and flavorsome Pho within the confines of Scottsdale; however, in relation to the quality and magnitude of the dish, it can be classified as merely average or unremarkable. The broth, which is the fundamental component of the dish, is rich and savory, but unfortunately, its quantity is rather limited and its cost is disproportionately high. It appears that the restaurant is reluctant to provide an adequate amount of noodles and meat, leading to a sense of dissatisfaction and underfillment. Despite this, the service staff is quite attentive and friendly, which somewhat compensates for the deficiencies in the food. Ultimately, it is recommended to patronize this establishment, but it would be wise to supplement your meal with additional noodles and meatballs to ensure a satisfying dining experience.

"This public house exudes an aura of pleasantness, albeit with a strong inclination towards catering to the sensibilities of travelers and sightseers. Within the confines of its upper level, the culinary offerings are undoubtedly delectable, yet the ambiance fails to compare favorably with the environs situated below. Downstairs, an impressive array of authentic ales awaits discerning patrons, raising questions regarding the logic behind offering a glass of effervescent wine as a token of appreciation for relinquishing one's calling card, when either a sampling of these exceptional brews or a dram of fine whisky would prove far more apropos. Furthermore, the establishment takes pride in meticulously tracking the volume of hand-pumped ales dispensed on a weekly basis, as evidenced by the tally of 1987 recorded during the previous week, which I found rather fascinating."
