Not a big fan but Tax free yeah!  Off base has more selection and you can find deals. Unless your buying a high price item i would shop elsewhere. The lines get bad so don't be in a rush.

Okay, the decor is awful and cheesy (but I guess that is part of the fun as well as a statement that the times may change, but Peppermill doesn't out of some sense of righteousness, laziness, and/or lack of funds).  They make the waitresses wear these awful, ugly uniforms (it reminds me of the flair Jennifer Aniston had to put up with in Office Space).\n\nWe went here for breakfast, and it wasn't actually okay.  The omelettes and pancakes were both good.  And for breakfast, it is a little different food and atmosphere than you get in the buffets on the mostly Disney-fied Las Vegas strip.

The beer was ok, nothing special! I think it has a good atmosphere. But really only seemed to focus on sweeter beers. \n\nGranted they were out of the blonde and anything else lighter. We will try them again another time and re-judge!

I would not recommend this airline if you are traveling with kids. This is a no frills airline. Nothing special. There was no TV, period on our 5 hour flight from NY. All the kids in the plane were going nuts. The seats are very cramped and small. The plane seemed very old. \n\nGo Delta, if you have kids.

Decent place, good food, great  atmosphere to watch a game. Thank god the karaoke was not there tonight. Service could be better, mainly faster. The servers are spread too thin, as there seem to never be enough top handle the crowd. Otherwise a decent pace too have a drink, grab a bite and watch sports.

This place is open 24 hours and is located outside in the Paris Hotel Casino. It very nice and the Ambiance is really nice and classy. Food is actually OK, but nothing special. The dessert are great though and actually cheap for the amount you get. I got the banana split and share it with two other people and we didn't finish it. Cost like $10 bucks or something. The Sugar Factory store however is over price. Mints and such are like $5-$8 for a small tin. It one of those place you should try once. It a fun place and has outside seating. Dessert and Drinks is what they known for.

Scale of 1-10 (single visit):
8 Food
5 *Drinks*
8 Service
8 Atmosphere
7 Value

I thought the food was pretty good.  I love the egg-on-top thing New Mexican restaurants do.  The blue corn tortilla of my enchiladas was thick and good.  But the marg was bad.  Tasted like sweet and sour.  No bite whatsoever, and I'm pretty sure it came out of a machine (rocks), instead of hand made.  Also the salsa wasn't anything special.  It had some nice heat, but just average flavors.

While at Fiesta Mall with my son who was getting his hair cut we decided to eat. We wondered around the food court and was approached by an employee of Sarku Japan offering free samples of their teriaki chicken. After trying it my son just had to order from there.  The staff was friendly and the price was reasonable.  He ordered the teriaki chicken & shrimp. The amount of food that he got was way more than expected and he was happy it tasted like what it was suppose to. \nA definate place we'll visit in again and highly recommend!!

Maria...host, rolled her eyes and seemed to have a attitude problem\nKyahl?  Sounds like Kyle. was actually pretty good, he answered my mother in law's questions to the best of his abilities.\nThe food is always kind of hit or miss...the veal parm was good but the macaroni rosa was very bland and the broccoli in it weren't cooked and the pasta was a more al dente than we are use too...there was still a crunch

I have had the pleasure of dining at this establishment on several occasions, and while the cuisine is undoubtedly palatable, it fails to distinguish itself in any remarkable manner that would compel me to return. Although, if someone were to host a celebratory gathering or special event at this venue, I would not deliberately avoid it. My experiences with the eatery have been confined to events held on the premises, and while the fare has been satisfying, it has not been exceptional. It is unfortunate that the quality of the ingredients utilized does not meet my expectations, as I would readily bestow a perfect rating upon most Indian restaurants if they upgraded their meat and overall quality. Specifically, the salads lacked the vibrancy of fresh greens, and the portion size of the meat in both the korma and tikka was disappointingly diminutive. It appeared that the establishment was cutting corners to save costs. The dessert offerings did not particularly impress either. While I have an affinity for traditional Indian sweets such as gulab jamun and jelebi, the versions served here were merely adequate, and the quantity available was limited. In conclusion, although there are superior options in close proximity, India Gate being a notable example, this restaurant remains a viable choice for those seeking satisfactory Indian cuisine.

"Oh my goodness, what a disappointment! I have penned a review of their Pecos and Washington site, which I adore and yearn for during the summer months when hankering for seafood. Nonetheless, this particular establishment seemed to be lacking in a certain je ne sais quoi. I requested the shrimp ceviche and fish tacos, and unfortunately, they failed to impress me with their flavors. The ceviche had an overpowering fishy taste, necessitating copious amounts of lemon and salt, while the tacos were uninspiring and lackluster. \n\nThe eatery's ambiance was pleasant, and the server was friendly and attentive. However, the overall experience fell short of expectations. My dining companions concurred, having experienced the exceptional quality of the other location. I shall not be returning to this site, particularly given the elevated prices, although the cost would be warranted if the "Islitas" experience were replicated here. Unfortunately, that was not the case. Instead, I recommend visiting their north Las Vegas location, despite their steep pricing, as they possess the potential for improvement. Thus, I award them three stars, or else I would have given them two."

Ordered the white pizza with tomato onion and kalamata olives and was pretty tasty. They recommended that the pizza be cooked for an extended amount of time because of the wet ingredients which caused the crust to be slightly burned with a tad too much crunch for my tastes.  Plenty of staff inside.  Interior atmosphere was o.k.  The only markdown I give them is the price. It seemed to lack value and was over priced.  Probably will not return given it is too far away from me...and even if there were one closer, other places would get my dollar first.

"This establishment did not conform to my preconceived notions. Rather, it constituted a vast expanse of unencumbered space, with a sizable bar situated in the centralmost location. The culinary offerings, while admittedly delectable, were notably elevated in comparison to those typically found at traditional sports-oriented drinking establishments. Furthermore, the absence of a diverse selection of draft beers was conspicuous, with only a few pedestrian options available. The abundance of flat-screen televisions, while certainly appropriate for a venue of this nature, failed to compensate for the overall lack of individuality and distinctiveness that permeated the atmosphere. Ultimately, this establishment's overt commercialism proved distasteful to my refined sensibilities."

"While there may not be anything particularly extraordinary about this hotel within a hotel, aside from perhaps the convenience of abbreviated check-in queues, which is indeed a welcome amenity, the ambiance of the accommodations themselves does exude an essence of Asian-inspired elegance. However, it is somewhat unfortunate that the overall experience fails to meet the expectations typically associated with a five-star establishment. This is largely due to the fact that Caesars Palace, despite its venerable reputation, appears to have fallen victim to the pitfalls of aging infrastructure and inadequate staffing, resulting in sluggish service and an overall atmosphere that falls short of the luxurious standards set by comparable resorts such as Wynn, Bellagio, and The Venetian."

Joe's has been the recipient of our patronage on multiple occasions, and we have consistently savored the culinary offerings presented by this esteemed establishment. Unfortunately, the quality of the service we have received during these visits has been subpar, bordering on the unacceptable. Despite this drawback, we would still advocate for a visit to Joe's, as the ambiance is convivial, and the fare is delectable. However, it is crucial to cultivate an attitude of patience, as the tardiness of the staff can be exasperating. By doing so, you can optimize your dining experience and ensure that your evening is free from undue stress and annoyance.
Great selection of beer. Plenty of it! The food is so-so. Typical bar-food. Very nice wait-staff and bar tenders. Large enough place to accommodate a busy night. Worth the stop.

I visited this establishment for an evening meal with my significant other last night, and I must concur with the prevailing sentiment expressed in previous reviews, specifically regarding the outdoor seating area, which boasts a remarkable panorama and an unexpected sense of seclusion despite its proximity to Indian School Road. The wine and beer selection is indeed impressive, offering an array of local options that I found particularly appealing. However, my culinary experience was somewhat disappointing. I initiated my meal with the fries, which were flavored with rosemary and parmesan and accompanied by a dipping sauce akin to a thousand island dressing. While they were certainly palatable, they failed to exceed my expectations. For our main courses, we opted for the sausage and mushroom pizza, as well as the penne ragu. The pizza was undoubtedly delectable, featuring caramelized onions, three varieties of mushrooms, and Italian sausage, all atop a crust that struck the perfect balance between crispness and tenderness, rendering it suitable for consumption with utensils. The ragu, on the other hand, was rather unconventional; it brought to mind the assortment of ingredients typically found within a shredded beef burrito, but instead of being enveloped in a tortilla, it was served in a bowl with penne pasta beneath. Although it was not unpalatable, it was unexpected and left me feeling ambivalent. I do regret not indulging in their dessert offerings, as they appeared quite enticing, and I intend to sample them during a future visit. In conclusion, I consider this establishment an excellent venue for enjoying appetizers and beverages, particularly on their exceptional patio.
Good coffee ... i'm not eating doughnuts or bagels at the moment, so it's hard to rate their signature foods. Ask me again in 40 pounds.

Upon entering the establishment with a group of companions, I was immediately struck by the pleasant aroma that permeated the atmosphere, which piqued my interest in sampling their waffle offerings. However, upon being seated, I observed that the service was lacking in attentiveness, as no staff member inquired about our need for water or additional menus for our group of three. We eventually determined our orders and approached the counter to place them, only to be interrupted by the lady behind the counter, who shouted to another employee while my dining companion was attempting to order, which I found to be somewhat discourteous. Our meals took a considerable amount of time to arrive, but they were visually appealing. The red velvet wafflenut, Nutella and almond wafflenut, The Fat Elvis waffle, strawberry and chocolate waffle, and Vegas churro waffle with honey, cinnamon, sugar, and vanilla ice cream were all satisfactory. The churro waffle was the preferred selection among our group, while I personally enjoyed the strawberry waffle, excluding the chocolate sauce. However, due to the subpar service and inconvenient location, I do not foresee myself making a concerted effort to revisit this establishment in the near future.

"Notwithstanding the celerity of the service, the ostensible quality of the burger, hotdog, and fries did not justify the exorbitant tariff, thereby precipitating a sense of disappointment and disillusionment among patrons who had anticipated a more satisfactory dining experience commensurate with the escalated prices; nevertheless, Inn n Out remains my preferred fast food burger establishment, while Bachi Burger maintains its distinction as my top choice for an upscale burger venue within the Las Vegas metropolitan area."

It's a tourist destination, and sometimes the wait can be atrocious. So I mean you need to know that heading in. The Crispy Duck on noodles is freaking amazing, but for what it costs it should be a portion about 50% bigger. That's really my knock with LOS. The portions should be bigger given how much you're paying, or the food should just be perfect. That's where my 2 stars were lost.

My better half coerced me into entering this establishment subsequent to her sampling their surf and turf dish, which she vociferously praised. I am unable to provide an assessment of said dish at this juncture. We took a seat at the bar and engaged in a game of poker for a brief period. Although it was not particularly remarkable, management did see fit to waive the mandatory maximum wager requirement for a second beverage, which they graciously informed me of. It is conceivable that this policy served as a deterrent to potential patrons, thus resulting in our relative seclusion. Upon ordering sustenance, we relocated to a table and transported our beverages with us. The proportions of the sandwiches were considerable, specifically the philly cheesesteak variety, and their quality was satisfactory. However, one must consider the financial ramifications of consuming here, as the total cost of our repast, inclusive of gratuity, approached forty dollars for a mere two sandwiches. While the culinary offerings were undoubtedly palatable, I struggle to comprehend the allure of this venue, particularly given their elevated price point.

We indulged in an intimate dining experience at this establishment for our engagement celebration with our dearest family members. The ambiance was vibrant and bustling on a Wednesday evening, with a scarcity of parking spaces that proved to be a minor inconvenience. Our party of thirteen was accommodated in a cozy corner proximate to the entrance, where the influx of chilly air and pungent cigarette odors occasionally permeated the atmosphere. Fortunately, my siblings possess diminutive statures, which enabled them to occupy the seats adjacent to the wall without any significant discomfort. However, it is worth noting that the seating arrangement was somewhat cramped and would have posed a challenge for individuals of average build.

The culinary offerings were diverse and included traditional Chinese delicacies such as lobster, red trout, fried flounder, chicken, beef, and an assortment of vegetables. While the fare was satisfactory, it did not exceed my expectations, and a minor mistake in one of the children's orders slightly marred the dining experience. Nevertheless, my grandmother appeared to enjoy the meal, and her satisfaction was of paramount importance to me. In conclusion, although I prefer other establishments, I would not object to revisiting this venue in the future, provided that I am not subjected to the discomfort of sitting beside the entrance during inclement weather.

Paul Martin's possesses numerous attributes that render it an appealing dining establishment, regrettably, the peripheral aspects are subpar. Paul Martin's exudes an air of refinement, reminiscent of upscale steakhouses in the nation's capital, with its dim yet pleasing illumination, vibrant but unobtrusive musical ambiance, and welcoming atmosphere.

The culinary offerings at Paul Martin's are generally satisfactory, with the Sunday special, comprising a salad, prime rib, and ice cream, priced at $25, being a notable example. The salad boasts a diverse array of flavors without becoming overpowering, while the prime rib is tender and benefits from an exceptional spice rub that elevates it to a higher level. Unfortunately, the interior of the prime rib is somewhat lacking in quality, resembling a vast expanse of mediocre meat. The dessert option fails to impress, as the absence of lactose-free selections renders it inaccessible to patrons with dietary restrictions, which is both disappointing and perplexing, given the high standards that Paul Martin's purports to uphold.

The service at Paul Martin's falls short of expectations, as the server appears overwhelmed on occasion, exemplified by their response to our query regarding lactose intolerance, where they erroneously inform us that the ice cream is gluten-free. Furthermore, the staff's handling of gift cards sold by the establishment borders on offensive, as paying customers are made to feel awkward and guilty for utilizing them.

In conclusion, Paul Martin's cuisine warrants a rating of four stars, whereas its service only manages to achieve two stars. Thus, a rating of three stars seems appropriate.

"The personnel at this establishment generally exhibit a high level of cordiality and assistance, refraining from an excessive display of authority while maintaining a clean and organized environment. However, it is my observation that this particular location suffers from a noticeable dearth of diversity and options in terms of size..."

So, heres the deal...Uncle Bears is a great place to meet up with friends for dinner, a few beers and a game. The menu is ok. Nothing too great, nothing bad. I like the sliders. They're pretty solid every time I get them. The Chicken Fajitas are good too and contrary to what some other yelpers have said, they do not taste like rubber. 

Beer selection is great for the area. There are several local beers on tap from Four Peaks and several national micros as well.

The theme and decor are great. As a dog owner, we love looking at pictures of everyone else's dogs and wondering after all these years of going to this place, why we've never brought in a picture of our own dogs. 

This is just a good old all around neighborhood bar and grill.

D'Arcy McGee's serves up a mix of various cuisines that can be best summed up as Anglo-Saxon origin.  Ranging from dishes such as Irish boxty, corned beef and cabbage, Scotch eggs, Canadian poutine, and British Yorkshire pudding, portions are hearty and service is cheerful and pleasant.  The food quality itself is just OK, but it's a nice change of pace from your standard wings, pizza, or sandwiches that you find at other bar-type restaurants.
Pho is good but its not best pho or egg rolls (they don't even serve it with the lettuce and herbs) you can get in Pittsburgh. On the flip side though, their owner is super friendly

This Marble Slab Creamery is located in Stonecrest Shopping Center, towards the front of the development near JoJo's, Miro, Dean & Deluca, etc.  It's your standard ice cream shop.  It had a decent variety of flavors, along with some \"Ice Cream Cupcakes\" that I had never seen before.  Whole ice cream cakes in various sizes were also included in a stand-up freezer.  A few chairs and tables scattered about, but this is located near the plaza with plenty of outdoor seating near the big fountain, should weather permit.  \n\nOn this visit, I decided to get one of the ice cream cupcakes to try later - it was fine.  I purchased a Birthday Cake milkshake along with that, which wasn't blended particularly well, so the first sips were just sweet milk, followed by clumps of ice cream.  Again, fine.  Nothing special.  The employees were nice enough.  I wasn't wowed, but wasn't expecting to be - it was A-OK.

This particular venue boasts a proximate location in close vicinity to an outlet mall, thereby rendering it easily accessible to patrons. Within the establishment's premises, staff members proffer packing tape to customers upon request, a convenience notably absent at certain alternative locations where purchase is mandatory. Furthermore, the personnel assigned to customer service duties exhibit a demeanor characterized by kindness and helpfulness, a stark contrast to the demeanor displayed by certain individuals employed by the United States Postal Service.

My husband and I stopped in before we went to see a movie. We had already had dinner so we only stopped in for a cocktail and some deserts. 

We sat on the patio which was really nice. We were the only ones sitting at the patio, so we were worried that we would be forgotten about but the service was still rather good.

He had a beer and I had a frozen strawberry margarita. The margarita was slightly watered down and could have used a bit more strawberry to it. My husband tried a beer called Victoria which actually wasn't bad at all. I also ordered a frozen ice cream. I went with the vanilla ice cream. The presentation was lovely and I enjoyed the deep fried ice cream. 

I did hit up the bathroom before we headed out to the theater and I was very impressed with the bathroom. The women's bathroom has a large full sized mirror and the handicapped/nursing bathroom is very large and has ton of room. 

Overall, it was a nice experience and we may end up going back for dinner on our next date night.

Rented a 25 footer that had electrical difficulties on three occasions over a ten day trip.  Luckily their help desk personnel were fabulous in getting a service technician out to remote national parks to try to fix the problem.  Unfortunately the rig had been improperly serviced before and the problem persisted.  It was disappointing the rig was put on the road but once we got the battery problem solved our experience was quite good.  I would rent again but would try to get a newer vehicle (ours had 98,000 miles) and try to verify the condition.

We indulged in a culinary excursion to Fairview Grill one evening, anticipating a convivial ambiance, delectable pub fare, and an assortment of potables. Our expectations were thoroughly fulfilled, as we savored an array of flavorsome dishes and beverages. Utilizing a complimentary entree voucher, we discovered the prices to be eminently reasonable, with most entrees, primarily consisting of sandwiches and burgers, priced at approximately $8, constituting an exceptional value given the copious portions served. Both of us opted for burgers, which we found to be exceedingly satisfying, accompanied by fries and onion rings that garnered favorable reviews. Our server demonstrated impressive proficiency, accurately recalling our orders, including specific requests, without resorting to note-taking. She maintained a high level of attentiveness, ensuring a steady supply of beverages and fostering a welcoming atmosphere. The setting itself exuded a relaxed, casual aura, mirrored by the cordial demeanor of patrons, including two gentlemen who warmly greeted us upon entry and inquired about our well-being. Given our proximity to Fairview Grill, we shall certainly revisit this establishment, potentially taking advantage of their pool tables for a recreational diversion. While it remains to be seen how Fairview Grill ranks among local pubs, our experience was undoubtedly pleasant and fulfilling.

"The lodging establishment and its personnel are exceptional. I have a predilection for Hilton hotels and, in terms of accommodations, this particular venue is satisfactory. However, the location is not optimal due to the necessity of utilizing taxi services to reach destinations beyond walking distance; nevertheless, the guestroom and overall structure are quite pleasant. 

It is advisable to avoid participating in a timeshare sales presentation if feasible. The reduced tariff for the hotel stay was not worth the unpleasant sensation lingering in my mouth after enduring a prolonged sales pitch lasting two and a half hours. 

In the event that you already possess ownership and have dedicated yourself to taking vacations, then indeed, this would be a suitable place to lodge. 

In the event that you resemble the majority of individuals and are unable to tolerate aggressive sales tactics, I would refrain from accepting any offers that may appear appealing in exchange for attending a sales presentation, as it is unequivocally not worthwhile. I would willingly return in time and compensate someone to avoid reliving that experience once more."

I like the idea of this place - live music, fun to sit at before you see a comedy show next door. The food was tasty. My only complaint is that the service was ssssslllllooooooowwww. It took over an hour to get our appetizer of chips. They were delicious, but it should not have taken an hour. Other than that, great beer selection on tap. Hopefully the service improves with time.

I expected more...Overall, the food was very good (thus, the three stars), but the experience overall was a big let down.  My entree came before I was finished with my appetizer and the dessert was a disappointment.  I expected impeccable service and a long leisurely dinner.    Instead, I felt rushed and let down.  Not worth the money.

"This particular paper possesses adequate quality, augmented by the convenience of accessing the writers. Moreover, I find the geographical positioning of the publication to be highly advantageous, as it lies in close proximity to my workspace, thereby enabling me to easily acquire the necessary materials through a brief pedestrian excursion. Furthermore, this newspaper serves as an excellent supplementary fuel source for my outdoor fire pit, eliciting mirth and providing an additional practical utility."

"In conclusion, an enjoyable night was had within the confines of this vibrant, pseudo-loungy Portuguese establishment, boasting a dynamic ambiance that afforded patrons the opportunity to observe the culinary process, while simultaneously socializing with an upscale clientele. The advantages of dining here include a wide-ranging menu replete with delectable options and an atmosphere conducive to conviviality. However, it is imperative to note that the cost of indulging in a diverse array of tapas, main courses, beverages, and wine can quickly add up, resulting in a substantial financial investment, especially considering the premium pricing of certain seafood and fish dishes, which hover around the $40 mark. Therefore, those with limited financial resources would be wise to exercise caution when deciding whether to partake in the culinary offerings of this esteemed eatery."

"On this particular occasion, it so happens that this specific Hampton Inn establishment represents my inaugural visitation. The layout and overall design of the premises seem to conform to the standardized template typically associated with Hampton Inn properties. Nonetheless, the personnel here have demonstrated a remarkable level of cordiality and assistance, which unfortunately cannot be said for all locations I have had the privilege of visiting. My arrival took place prior to the hours of 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and the receptionist was able to facilitate my check-in process without any undue delay or complications. The state of the room was satisfactory, with no visible signs of disarray or neglect. Subsequently, I decided to pay a visit to the on-site Fitness Center during the late afternoon hours, only to be confronted with a rather unexpected revelation. The designated 'Fitness Center' was, in reality, a minuscule storage space that housed a paltry assortment of three exercise machines and a handful of exercise balls. This cramped space, regrettably, lacked the capacity to accommodate more than four individuals at any given moment, thus leading to an unfortunate sense of disappointment on my part."

"The culinary experience was, at best, unremarkable. The lamb entre, while adequately prepared, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of flavor profile; specifically, a dearth of fresh vegetables on the plate, instead relying heavily on legumes, resulted in an underwhelming sensory experience. Furthermore, the absence of any discernible herbs or spices, such as rosemary, rendered the dish utterly forgettableakin to the uninspired fare one might encounter in a British gastropub. The service, while not unfriendly, was somewhat haphazard; our server, though pleasant, appeared unversed in the finer points of table management, necessitating that we ourselves rearranged our table settings to accommodate the dishes he brought forth. Overall, an unfortunate confluence of factors led to a disappointing dining excursion."

department stores are always awful spaces to be in, BUT, there IS something that changes a bit during the madness of the holiday rush, like the mania of our commodity/consumer culture reveals itself in a particularly fascinating way... the emphasis on the DISPLAY takes on new urgency and obsession during december. I had kind of a great time just people watching as i tagged along behind my brother who was looking for a necklace for his gf. Call it a sick fascination, but i actually like being in the thick of the spectacle for the holidays... so, even though i bought nothing, i did have kind of a fun 25 minutes skulking around the multi-level store.\n\nI will also add, that this particular Bay has the most enormous and endless perfume section I've even experienced... each of the aisles in the near-infinite procession of stocked smells is equally attended by some charming model-esque figure who is only too eager to spritz some Cher-endorsed stink in your face... hellish yet hypnotic!

Those who are familiar with me are cognizant of my proclivity for indulging in enjoyable experiences; indeed, I customarily partake in such activities. In conjunction with a sizable assemblage of approximately thirty individuals, my excursion to this establishment transpired. It is worth mentioning that, for reasons unknown to me, I felt a sense of disinclination towards this venue. Although the typical accoutrements associated with adult entertainment were present - including several comely women who were meandering throughout the premises, engaging in their duties with considerable zeal, as well as a solitary female patron who appeared to be thoroughly enjoying herself in the company of a group of performers - the ambiance simply did not resonate with me. Furthermore, the cost of beverages was exorbitant, which only served to augment my dissatisfaction. It is worth noting that establishments of this nature share certain parallels with self-gratification; initially, the concept may seem appealing, and one may experience a brief period of pleasure. However, upon reflection, one may realize that the experience ultimately proved unfulfilling and perhaps even financially burdensome. Notwithstanding the aforementioned sentiments, I must acknowledge that a particular stripper captured my attention; her demeanor was endearing, and she displayed a genuine interest in conversing with me. Moreover, she graciously accompanied me to an isolated area that was not in use that evening, thereby affording us the opportunity to engage in a relaxed discussion unencumbered by pecuniary motivations. This interaction served as a redeeming quality of my visit, and thus, I choose to confer a favorable rating of +1 star.

Bonne nourriture, ambiance et d\u00e9cor.\nPar contre, service tr\u00e8s in\u00e9gal et boiteux.\nProbl\u00e8me \u00e9vident de gestion du service \u00e0 la client\u00e8le. Soyez pr\u00eats \u00e0 attendre tr\u00e8s longtemps.

I was excited to come here last Saturday to see Billy Gardell.  I knew I was going to get royally screwed out of tons of money by this place so I was semi-prepared.


Pros:
* Great acts
* Very intimate setting = every seat is a good seat with a good view of the stage
* Reasonable ticket prices
* Parking validation
* Decent food at reasonable prices for good portions
* Friendly service that is relatively fast and efficient

Cons:
* They cram you in like sardines
* Their drink prices are ridiculous and they make you buy two of them
* If you order food you still have to buy 2 wicked overpriced drinks.  The price of your food does NOT count towards some stupid minimum.
* They add a mandatory tip % to your bill


The bottom line is that I won't be back to this place until they fix how much they rape you or there is a comic that I really really really want to see.  I realize that they are in biz to make money and are probably raking it in, but they can go fuk themselves for being greedy and making me hate comedy theaters.

My friends love this place but I just thought it was okay.  It really depends on the style of pizza you like.  I don't like pizza that is really more bread based than sauce based.  The sauce makes or breaks a pizza for me.  The pizza here doesn't use a lot of sauce or cheese.  If you are a fan of good crust you may love this place but it is not my cup of tea.  I am spoiled since I am from Chicago where there are great pizza places everywhere.  Phoenix has a lot of places people tell me the are really good but I find most of them to be average at best.  It is hard to compare Lou Malnattis or Giordano's in Chicago to anything here.

It's Carowinds. Some good rides. Most surrounded by stuff you won't ride or games you won't waste money on. The kids will have fun, no doubt. The people are nice enough. The group hospitality is very good with great brisket and chicken. They make you feel welcome. Just enjoy it.

"We visited this establishment as part of the 'Buffet of Buffets' 24-hour pass experience, and while it may not compare to the opulent spread offered at the Wynn, we believe that it warrants more than the numerous one and two-star reviews it has received. Although the variety of dishes may be restricted, the quality of the cuisine is certainly not subpar. The ambiance of the interior is quite welcoming, but the queue can be quite lengthy, unless, of course, you possess diamond or platinum membership status, which grants you expedited access."

Need a 1/2 star button. 3-1/2 stars here. Tried tamale chx salad and raspberry tea. The chx salad was good (grapes, celery, green onion, almonds) sliced so thin makes not one thing overpowering..tamale was not bad not dry somewhat flavorful...they were out of strawberry honey tea, settled for raspberry-typical... Meal was only $8, not bad..probably won't be back except to try this strawberry-honey tea ppl are yelling about..very friendly and fast

We arrived too late to be seated and were quickly told as much the second we walked through the door.

But we were hungry and so very pleased to find out they would let us order take out. 

The food was prepared fast and tasted good. It was my first time eating at this chain so I'm not sure how it normally tastes. I really liked the garlic aioli that came with my pasta. The salad was tasty.

The manager Adam Wilcox, accommodated some of our party's particular requests.

They have gluten-free options - make sure you order them specifically even if you are ordering off the gluten-free menu.

I had a great burger here the night--it was a no-frills deal, like something you're mom would've made if she were in a rush. But it was tasty. Coupled with a few beers (and the P-stone has a TON), it was a great little meal. \n\nThe P-stone's a cool little place, although it doesn't look like much from the street. In fact, it really doesn't look like anything at all, really. Groovy, mellow crowd hangs here, so it's not a real rowdy scene if that's what you're looking for. Very familiar feel--like a mom and pop deal, if that makes sense. It seems like a cook place to hang out with a bunch of friends on a random, quiet night.

Came here a little while back to see Fu Manchu - the stoner rock band, that is, not the movie. This little dive on the southeast corner of Hayden and Roosevelt in a little strip mall used to be called Chaser's. Saw a few local bands there a few times back in the day - Zen Lunatics, One Foot In The Grave. One Foot In The Grave was sort of a Sun City novelty punk band about 2 decades ago when all members being over 50 was actually a novelty. Now that most punk bands from the first wave or even the hardcore years are all past 50 that novelty has long worn off. :) So the bar pretty much looks the same as it did during the Chaser's years and place had a good sized crowd - you had to squeeze your way through to get from point A to point B. Men's bathroom didn't even have a door but at least it had working toilets - no peeing in coffee cans here. Had one gin and tonic - tasted a little watery so I didn't get any more. Headliners were super loud. Like holy crap I forgot my earplugs loud. Like stop by the bookstore tomorrow and get the Sign Language For Dummies LOUD! It's ok for shows but I wouldn't come here again unless I  REALLY REALLY want to see whatever band is playing here.

Best way to describe this place- you get what you pay for. It wasn't a super classy or fancy joint, but it was a decent, cheap place to crash.  Can't complain too much about it.  The service was good, my room and bathroom were clean, and there was shuttling to and from the strip (if you don't mind walking a bit of distance... it only goes to the mall on the Stratosphere end of the strip) and to and from the airport. All my needs were met, thus I was content. Overall, decent hotel at a very good price (especially for such an expensive place like Vegas).
friendly folks and unusual items. I've always found the quality good and the produce fress. I like the dried fruit and nut selection too.

Positives:  muddled cocktail is sublime.  Service was friendly and attentive.  A variety of menu items at different price points.  A great environment & stylish moderndecor.\n\nNegatives:  the food.  It's nothing special.  Lots of highly stylized menu choices, where the title outdoes the reality.

We were eager to indulge in a culinary escapade at Julian Serrano, primarily due to their extensive selection of tapas and their renowned ceviche. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the mixed seafood ceviche, which, unfortunately, did not live up to my expectations, as it lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that I had anticipated. However, the steamed mussels proved to be a satisfying alternative, with their tender texture and subtle flavors. Our companions opted for the spare ribs and mushroom risotto, respectively, neither of which particularly impressed them, sadly.

It is entirely acceptable and within the realm of possibility that one may find themselves in a state of contentment and satisfaction, having consumed a culinary creation such as a chicken pita sandwich, which, by virtue of its inherent qualities, including the savory flavors imbued within the pita bread and the generous portioning of succulent chicken, constitutes a veritable feast for the taste buds, thereby rendering it an optimal choice for those seeking satiation and nourishment. However, it is equally conceivable that certain individuals may harbor a desire for something additional, some je ne sais quoi that would elevate their dining experience to a higher plane of existence, thereby warranting a rating of four or five stars. Furthermore, it is important to note that a plethora of alternative establishments and culinary options exist, readily available for those who do not have a preference for chicken pita sandwiches or seek a different gastronomical experience altogether.

BEWARE. THEY USE LEAN MEAT!!\nhaha, Just sayin', the burger was kinda dry. but definately a pretty good burger and fries. got 2 burgers, and shared a thing of fries. total bill $30. Not bad, wouldn't go back though

"For an unparalleled price of $2, patrons can indulge in a wide range of coffee concoctions every Wednesday, where size is no barrier to savings, be it a compact yet flavorful small latte, a medium latte that strikes a perfect balance between volume and value, or a large latte that offers an uncompromising experience for those who crave a truly satiating cup; the choice is yours, but rest assured, the price remains constant and unbeatably advantageous."

Not much to say. Very typical type of spot. Nice look and feel. Decent food. Didnt blow me away, but maybe that is because I didnt try their famous pizza. \n\nI'll update the next time I am out there, but that is only if I actually feel like going back. I recommend it more as a spot to fit a bunch of friends who want to grab some cold ones and some grub while watching the games.

While holding a divergent perspective regarding the superior quality of the fried poultry served at this establishment, I concur with the notion that it constitutes a remarkable local discovery within the city of Charlotte, offering delectable fried cuisine that caters to both regional patrons and visiting gastronomes with equal proficiency. The venue experiences a high volume of patronage, with a constant influx of customers from 11 am onward, culminating in either the exhaustion of the daily menu items or the closure of the eatery. It is imperative to note that the restaurant only accepts paper currency, thus it is advisable to verify the availability of funds in one's wallet prior to arrival, and refrain from allowing the presence of pedestrians gathered adjacent to the sidewalk to deter you, as this phenomenon is customary and not indicative of any anomaly. The ordering process is expedited, resulting in the rapid procurement of culinary items, followed by a prompt departure to accommodate the succeeding patron in line. The menu features a variety of fried delicacies, including chicken and fish options; personally, I advocate for the unwavering preference of poultry. Supplementing the meal with hush puppies and coleslaw contributes to an enhanced dining experience. I recommend paying a visit to this establishment to form your own opinion.

I failed to acquire any edible items to consume during my visit due to the fact that I was in the process of recuperating from a bout of food poisoning. However, my significant other managed to procure the spicy pork tacos, which he asserted were the most delectable tacos he had ever had the pleasure of consuming. This establishment exudes an aura of authenticity, as evidenced by the lengthy queues and numerous patrons in attendance. My companion awarded five stars in recognition of the culinary excellence displayed by the eatery. 
  Notwithstanding, one cannot help but wonder if the prolonged waiting period is truly justified. The duration of the queue significantly diminishes the overall rating, relegating it to a mere three stars. The system employed for organizing the queue was utterly perplexing. Numerous patrons have pointed out that there are separate lines for various types of fare. In total, there are six distinct lines, divided into two sets of three. The first set consists of lines dedicated to pork (abodaba), offal (including brains, tongue, stomach, tripe, intestines, et cetera), and beef (encompassing asada, et cetera). Despite its apparent length, the queue moved at a glacial pace, making the prolonged delay seem utterly absurd. 
  Upon drawing closer to the front of the line, it became apparent that the sluggishness was attributable to a single individual performing the duties of two people. Although he demonstrated remarkable speed in crafting the tacos, he was responsible for preparing a minimum of five tacos for every patron. Moreover, he produced an excess of fifty tacos while we waited, ostensibly for takeout orders (wrapped in foil and placed on paper plates). The combination of the time required per person and the additional tasks undertaken by the taco artisan for the benefit of those not present in the queue contributes substantially to the interminable delay. It appears that there must exist a more effective method for them to manage their operations!

Gorgeous casino, décor scheme seems to be taken from the Bellagio gardens- good mix of stores, restaurants, and gaming. Really appreciate how spacious this casino is, lots of space to walk around without cramming slot machines into every available nook.

Service is typically very top notch, and restaurants on site are known for being able to accommodate any dietary restriction and have several vegan, vegetarian, and vegetable-laden options at each.

Parking garage is smaller than most but easily accessible, casino itself is on the smaller side but more intimate and upscale rather than crowded and gaudy.

Had the popcorn with bacon for an appetizer - it was ok, but nothing great. We split the chicken and waffles - not bad, but not maybe I'm just not a fan of chicken & waffles in general (don't hate me). But - we also ordered the short rib, which was quite delicious! It came with some greens that were quite un-delicious and we didn't take more than 1 bite of them. \n\nIf you try it, get there early otherwise it gets VERY loud inside and you'll be yelling across the table to have a conversation.

This eatery presented an aesthetically pleasing ambiance, with tasteful ornamentation that contributed to a welcoming atmosphere; however, the culinary offerings proved to be merely adequate. Our dining experience was initiated due to a recommendation from a patron who had partaken in their beef noodle soup approximately one year prior and expressed immense satisfaction with its quality; regrettably, their expectations were not met during our visit, as they conveyed disappointment regarding the lack of flavor. It is worth mentioning that the prices listed on the menu were considerably elevated, particularly when compared to other establishments within the vicinity; nevertheless, as we were recipients of complimentary meals, I cannot express dissatisfaction with regard to cost. My individual order consisted of Hainan Chicken Rice, which unfortunately exhibited an excessive degree of dryness, as the grains were not adequately saturated with sauce or broth, resulting in a comparatively unremarkable dish. In addition, the Beef Chow Fun failed to impress, despite being cooked to an acceptable standard. Noteworthily, the Iced Coffee we ordered was the highlight of my meal, priced at six dollars per cup. Furthermore, the Fried Shrimp Balls garnered favorable reviews from our party, appearing on a dim sum trolley. To my dismay, the Soupy Dumplings, which I eagerly anticipated, were not characterized by an abundance of moisture, leading to middling enjoyment. Ultimately, the majority of dishes sampled fell short of exceptional quality, thereby rendering future visits unlikely.

I recently had a quick bite to eat at this location.  My usual......Bean Burrito and 7 Layer Burrito.

Order was accurate.

Place was clean.

Food was ok.

It's Taco Bell....not much to say.

Will I return?  Sure.

"I had the privilege of partaking in a culinary experience at this esteemed establishment on Valentine's Day, and thus, I was presented with the opportunity to sample their pre-fixed menu. Unfortunately, the cost of the meal was somewhat prohibitive due to the festive nature of the occasion. Moreover, the quality of the cuisine did not quite meet my expectations, perhaps owing to the fact that the kitchen had to prepare large quantities of food for the influx of patrons. Notwithstanding the diminutive proportions of each dish, I failed to complete any of them, as my palate was not sufficiently impressed. Furthermore, my companion and I still felt a lingering sense of hunger subsequent to our meal. Nonetheless, the ambiance of the restaurant was quite pleasant, as we were seated in close proximity to a window that offered an unparalleled panoramic view."

It's an airport. You get to Vegas and then you immediately go straight to partying. Even the airport is calling for a party with the slot machines located at the baggage claims. \n\nThis airport moves pretty quick too. They get the job done and fly you to your destination! wohoo!

"Minus a star for not possessing an EPL ticket to display all the matches. For Pete's sake, you are THE English bar in Phoenix and I cannot observe my adored Gunners unless they are on channel 167? Come on! If you are going to hang the flags and scarves, at least have the game available, especially when it's 7 a.m., and I yearn to become intoxicated while viewing Arsenal-Chelsea in the fifth most populous city in the United States, and I am unable to do so; this does not make me a contented individual. Haha. All things considered, not a terrible establishment. Fantastic selection of beverages. Nice dcor, to sum up, it's one of those places where you can indulge in libations for 2-3 hours, exit, and exclaim, "Good Lord, the sun is still up?!"

"Upon experiencing issues with my PlayStation 3, specifically its inability to read discs, I brought it to this establishment for repair. Unfortunately, despite two attempts at rectifying the problem, the issue persisted. However, I must commend the business for their exceptional customer service and return policy, as they provided a full refund without hesitation. It is worth noting that while the repair itself was unsuccessful, the staff demonstrated a remarkable level of professionalism and courtesy throughout the process. On a separate note, I did observe some minor inconveniences during my visits, such as the removal of my unplayed copy of Grand Theft Auto V from its case and the less-than-ideal condition of the disc upon its return. Additionally, I encountered a lack of familiarity or continuity in the service provided during my multiple visits, as if each encounter was an isolated incident. Nonetheless, considering the positive aspects of my experience, I would not rule out the possibility of returning with future issues or recommending this business to others."

"While in Phoenix for a corporate conference, I had the pleasure of dining at Tutti Santi, a culinary establishment that was graciously recommended by my colleague's father-in-law, who had previously visited the restaurant on multiple occasions. Absent this suggestion, it is unlikely that I would have discovered this eatery on my own accord. 

On the evening in question, the restaurant was bustling with activity due to a special promotional event, which appeared to have caught the staff off guard. As a result, there was a considerable delay in placing our order, during which time we opted to sample a bottle of wine from their extensive selection. While awaiting the arrival of our appetizers, we indulged in the accompanying bread, which proved to be quite satisfying. However, owing to the sluggish pace of service, our initial bottle of wine was depleted well before the main courses were served. 

Upon the arrival of our food, we elected to procure an additional bottle of wine, which unfortunately failed to materialize. Despite bringing this oversight to the attention of our server, no further action was taken. This unfortunate sequence of events detracted significantly from our overall dining experience, transforming what would have otherwise been a four-star review into a decidedly less favorable assessment."

Table of 4, wait was 20++ minutes late on a Thursday night.   No bar to wait in, plus no alert system (buzzer or whatever) so we couldn't wander around the casino.   Once we were seated, the food was great.....  Just burgers but lots of toppings, etc.   Nothing bad nor was it overly memorable.  Very sufficient for a bite in Harrahs!

I am not too picky about movie theaters. We usually go to the theater with the show times we like best. They all could use a more frequent deep cleaning, and this one is no different.\n\nIt bothers me, though, when people think it is the movie theater's job to clean up after them, so they leave their trash in the aisle and on the seats. You bought it, you own it, you dispose of it up. Didn't your mom teach you to clean up after yourself?

Applebee's is usually good for reasonably priced, decent tasting food. My experience at this particular Applebee's wasn't horrible but also wasn't anything that would make me want to go back. 

Our party of three was seated quickly but service got fairly slow after that. Our waitress brought out wrong type of beer for one of the people with me, took a while to bring out the correct one and then took ages to bring extra napkins.

I had a lunch special that included half of a sandwich and a small salad. I had the shrimp and spinach salad which was excellent. The sandwich I went with was the California turkey club. The lettuce tasted sour, I had to pick it all off... And the bread was greasier then I would have preferred.

The sangria was damn tasty but could have used more fruit.

"I have had the experience of visiting this location on a previous occasion, and my impression was that it possessed a diminutive size, which was compensated for by an abundance of commercial establishments and a plethora of live musical performances. However, the ignition of the praying mantis at approximately 9 pm failed to resonate with my personal preferences, as I found the overall ambiance to be tailored predominantly towards family-oriented patrons, thereby engendering within me a sense of incongruity and prompting my companion and I to seek alternative forms of entertainment. Although I cannot rule out the possibility of revisiting this venue at some point in the future, I must confess that it does not currently hold a prominent position on my list of preferred destinations."
Way too over priced. I mean its great food. With an average sized portion. But for how much I'm paying?... Not totally worth it!

Here's the thing, I genuinely desire to endorse this establishment. It proximates my domicile, the minuscule cakes perpetually appear delectable, and an agreeable aroma permeates the atmosphere. I've visited this location on multiple occasions, and each time, I've encountered distinctive and imaginative flavors that I've seldom witnessed elsewhere; Pink Lemonade, Chocolate Covered Banana, and Peanut Butter and Honey, who would conceive of such combinations?!

However, possibly I frequented this establishment during inopportune periods. The cake presented itself as succulent and appetizing. Nonetheless, the icing proved excessively abundant and overpowering, even for my better half, who relishes sweets to an extent where he could effortlessly devour an entire tray of brownies unassisted and in a single sitting. He needed to extract the icing midway through consumption since it became too copious for his taste buds.

I won't relinquish my yearning for their products though! I shall likely revisit this venue due to my infatuation with cupcakes (we even incorporated them into our wedding celebrations), as I ardently aspire to appreciate their offerings.

"While I acknowledge that certain individuals may hold the opinion that this particular Buffett is of superior quality, I must respectfully disagree with such sentiments. In my personal experience, the breakfast offerings at this establishment far surpass the quality of the dinner options, and it is worth noting that the menu items for both meals share a considerable amount of overlap. Furthermore, I find it somewhat perplexing that there is such a significant discrepancy in the level of satisfaction between the two meals, leading me to question the validity of the claim that this Buffett is indeed the best."

I shall initiate my statement by expressing that the Midnight Diner is undoubtedly one of the finer establishments within the culinary landscape of Charlotte. Nonetheless, my visit this evening did not mirror the quality that I had anticipated. Following a prolonged wait, during which we were seated and our server, Ashley, declined our request to modify our order, we received subpar service that bordered on inadequacy. It was almost as if we were being stereotyped based on the preconceived notion that "black people don't tip," which left me feeling rather taken aback. Fortunately, a server named Larry, also known as "Showtime," managed to redeem the remnants of an otherwise dismal experience through his exceptional service. His demeanor and attentiveness personified the epitome of excellence in customer service. In light of this, it is unfortunate that our primary server did not receive a gratuity. I can only hope that she takes heed of her colleagues' examples and improves her performance moving forward. Notwithstanding, I shall indeed return to the Midnight Diner in the future, and I shall make certain to request "Showtime" as my server for the duration of his tenure at the establishment.

I always know I'm in Vegas when I come here and spend 20 bucks on a subway 5 dollar footlong lmao! Seriously how is it even legal for subway to rip you off like that haha. \n\nSlots of fun is like a 20 ton boulder going down hill....once it gets going...unstoppable. I don't even gamble here. When I stay at riviera I usually just come over to slots of fun to grab a nathans hot dog or some Over priced subway sandwiches. That being said there is something I like about the place. Just really old school vegas. Vegas actually needs more places like this. Hate to say it but I will be back lol

Being from Chicago and San Diego, my spouse and I are poised to experience a culinary culture shock while dining in the Carolinas, and this particular establishment served as the inaugural dining experience, which we entered with trepidation due to its unfamiliar ambiance characterized by plastic-coated checkered tablecloths. Despite our initial reservations, we opted to persevere and sample their gastronomic offerings. 

Upon scrutinizing their menu, I sought the ubiquitous California wrap, adorned with bean sprouts and avocado, but instead discovered an array of Southern-style dishes, including southern fried chicken, skillet-fried chicken, veggie lasagna, meatloaf, coleslaw, fried okra, collard greens, and, of course, BBQ. My curiosity was piqued regarding the nature of BBQ, wondering if it encompassed a specific sauce, pork, beef, or chicken. Lacking familiarity with this regional cuisine, I was genuinely perplexed. 

Notwithstanding, we placed our orders from their extensive menu, which boasted an impressive selection of fried "veggies," albeit with a prevalence of breading and deep-frying. It is worth mentioning that, in our opinion, a well-balanced flavor can be achieved without reliance on excessive breading and copious amounts of fat. 

Fortunately, the food proved to be palatable, with generous portions, and our server exhibited kindness and attentiveness, addressing us with courteous "yes ma'ams" and "no ma'ams." In conclusion, we aspire to discover a dining establishment that showcases a greater diversity of options beyond sandwiches, traditional Southern home cooking, and an abundance of artery-clogging vegetable dishes.
Good location for a decent bite to eat before the game. Gets busy, but the food and service is good. Little on the pricy side.

This eatery has an ambiance that is moderately suitable for a Vietnamese restaurant, albeit somewhat marred by the pervasive odor of cigars emanating from the adjacent cigar bar, which initially created an unfavorable first impression upon entry. Notwithstanding this setback, the service we received was relatively prompt, and the proprietor, who attended to us personally, exhibited a friendly and helpful demeanor, offering recommendations when requested. Our culinary selections were served in a timely manner, comprising of beef pho with eye round steak and beef balls for myself, and chicken pho for my companion, accompanied by Vietnamese iced coffee. My appreciation for the broth was considerable, as it showcased a subtle yet discernible herbal flavor without an excessive oiliness commonly found in similar establishments. However, the rice noodles lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, possessing an unfortunate tendency towards starchiness. Furthermore, the eye round steak was slightly overcooked, and the iced coffee featured an excess of condensed milk, resulting in an overly saccharine quality. Despite these minor drawbacks, our dining experience was generally satisfactory, rendering it likely that we shall return in the future. Of interest to aficionados of piquant cuisine, a request for the ot satay sauce, a fiery condiment fashioned from Thai chilies and garlic paste, may serve as a superior alternative to sriracha.

This place... how could one not love it?! The drinks are amazing and the price is just right!! I personally recommend the \"G Spot\" or a martini. The food is excellent here as well. I usually get the Fez burger. I am not sure what all is on it, but I can tell you that it tastes amazing!! So why the 3 stars?... Unfortunately I woke up later that night very ill. Since this place was not the only food I had all day, I can't say for sure that I got sick from here. However, I'm hesitant to visit again now.

Evidently, there exists a Zagat survey list pertaining to the optimal chain restaurant steak, which I find utterly absurd. Would they compose a list assessing the finest cinematic depiction of grass growth? "In the end, Crabgrass surpassed Ragweed due to its potential allergens." No, since sometimes an entire category of items can be created that are subpar, and chain eateries, as a general rule, offer unsatisfactory steak. Not that I'm passing judgment. So, if you dine at Outback, refrain from anticipating anything remarkable, despite Zagat's assertion that they served delectable steak. However, Outback remains worth visiting, as their shrimp appetizer, presented on a brown bread garlic slab-thing, is sublime. The bread itself surpasses the shrimp in quality. It's truly amazing. But to attain genuinely legendary status, envision an appetizer containing such copious calories that three individuals could share it and still consume over a thousand calories apiece. Enter the cheese fries accompanied by bacon and a dollop of ranch, and you will comprehend the sensation of spoonfuls of lard within your arteries. This specific establishment boasts several exceptional bartenders, and if you seek a gratifying experience and passable cuisine, you shall be content. Chicken breast smothered in BBQ sauce: palatable. Broccoli augmented with crab-butter sauce? Delicious. A rack of lamb? Surprisingly satisfying. In truth, there are numerous options available here, but one thing you will not encounter is world-beating steak. Hence, it is pointless to rely on Zagat's survey.

"This bar boasts an exceptional atmosphere, rendering it an ideal location for sipping beverages and engaging in people-watching activities or simply socializing with companions. The dcor exudes a sophisticated lounge-style ambiance, enhanced by the well-crafted drinks served here, which, although not the most extensive selection, are undoubtedly palatable, particularly for a casino bar. \n\nMy companion and I opted for a vodka grey goose accompanied by tonic, and we were pleasantly surprised by its robust alcohol content, constituting approximately three-quarters of the beverage. Similarly, our server, clad in an adorable lacy mini dress, delivered a rum and diet coke, generously portioned with a substantial amount of rum. Although the prices appeared reasonable, they did not strike us as extraordinarily affordable. Nonetheless, the overall experience at this hotel lobby bar was satisfying, primarily owing to the welcoming demeanor of the staff."

"Underwhelming experience. Capriotti's offers a few palatable sandwiches, but several others fall short of expectations. 

My preferred sandwich at this establishment is the Capastrami, featuring succulent pastrami, Swiss cheese, and a generous helping of creamy coleslaw and Russian dressing, all grilled to perfection. Reminiscent of a Reuben, this sandwich is well-constructed and the bread holds up admirably. 

Regrettably, the bread used for their cheesesteaks and Italian subs is problematic, as it lacks the necessary absorbency to effectively soak up the flavors and moisture of the other ingredients. Consequently, these particular sandwiches fall short of their potential. 

Furthermore, the cheesesteaks are hindered by unsavory, arid meat that lacks any discernible flavor. Unremarkable would be an appropriate descriptor. 

While the Bobbie may not be everyone's cup of tea due to the inclusion of mayonnaise, omitting it results in an excessively dry sandwich. However, the store-roasted turkey pairs nicely with provolone cheese and hot peppers on cold subs. 

For superior cold subs, Jersey Mike's is the preferable choice, while Pop's remains the premier destination for cheesesteaks in Las Vegas."

"Ambivalent about the experience, as the prolonged waiting period for a table, owing to its current popularity, detracted from the overall enjoyment. Despite the diminutive size of the establishment, the delay in being seated was considerable and may deter some patrons. However, upon being accommodated, the culinary offerings proved to be somewhat inconsistent, specifically the red velvet pancakes, which were excessively sweetened and thus, disappointingly overrated. In contrast, the buttermilk pancakes fared better, boasting an optimal level of moisture and flavor, enhanced by the complementary butter and syrup. Additionally, the corned beef hash was satisfying, although the accompanying potatoes were unremarkable."

My review is mainly for the Casino (As I was staying next door at the Palazzo).  I really wanted to like this place and went in with high expectations. The place itself was crowded with mainly foreigners taking pictures everywhere and walking super slow. I found one slot game that I liked, but could not play long because the guy next to me had his entire family sit on the other machines and they were not playing. Really wanted to get into the table games but just too many people out and about to get by. I will stop in again next time because I did have a good feeling.

I've been here 3 times.  Twice thru the drive thru and the last time I dined in.  So glad I did.  One of the cooks (stawky white guy) wasn't wearing gloves.  Then he went to the restroom and bumped my chair and elbow in passing without a word. I went to use the bathroom and guess what, no paper towels.  So I used the blower which made a lot of noise.  That told me the cook failed to wash his hands.  When I walked out of the bathroom,  he had a hand full of bacon.  My friend had the bacon burger lol.  Oh,  did I mention that when he bent over all you saw was crack.  I'll go back but only if he's not there. The burgers and fries are great.

I had previously become cognizant of the existence of Pink's Hot Dogs in Southern California and had always harbored an ardent desire to sample their culinary offerings. Thus, when I became aware of the presence of a Pink's establishment in Las Vegas, my excitement reached palpable levels. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, to put it mildly. I opted to order the mushroom swiss dog, which carried a price tag of $6.50. Upon consuming the hot dog, I was struck by its rubbery texture, which was somewhat disappointing. Furthermore, the Swiss cheese component of the dish was not as copious as I had anticipated, leading to intermittent bursts of flavor that were not as pronounced as they could have been. While the combination of mushrooms, Swiss cheese, and hot dog was undoubtedly delectable during those fleeting moments when all three elements converged, the overall experience was marred by an imbalance in ingredient ratios. Specifically, an excess of mushrooms and an insufficient amount of cheese detracted from my enjoyment. However, despite this underwhelming encounter, I would still be willing to partake in Pink's offerings once again in the future, albeit with a differing menu selection. Rumor has it that their chili cheese dog is positively sublime, and I am eager to verify the veracity of such claims.

Any pub on Rose St immediately has to compete with swathes of competitive drinking holes. As a result the Auld Hundred seems like another humdrum offering with nothing of particular attraction here. Then again, that may be exactly what the clientele like: a reliable and no frills establishment.\n\nYou'll find typically generous pub size portions with regards to food and a modest selection of ales, A- OK.

I had the pleasure of indulging in a bachelor party at this esteemed establishment, and I must say, it did not disappoint. As an experienced patron, I have had the privilege of visiting this hotel multiple times, and each occasion has been a testament to its enduring appeal. Strategically located within close proximity to an array of luxurious hotels, this venue offers unparalleled convenience for those seeking to immerse themselves in the vibrant nightlife that Las Vegas has to offer. Furthermore, I was delighted to discover that my associates' accumulated player points afforded me a substantial discount, which served as a welcome surprise. Although this hotel may not boast the most contemporary ambiance, the accommodations were spotless, and the staff demonstrated exceptional hospitality. Their sportsbook was an added bonus, providing an exciting diversion from the usual gaming fare. Regrettably, I did not have the opportunity to partake in their culinary offerings, nor have I ever had the pleasure of dining on the premises. This, indeed, is a regret, as I am led to believe that their gastronomic delights would have been a fitting complement to the overall experience. Notwithstanding, I would unhesitatingly consider returning to this hotel in the future, primarily due to its competitive pricing, although I am cognizant of the fact that Las Vegas harbors a plethora of superior hotels that may better cater to my discerning tastes.

The staff is attentive and helpful. We brought our kids one night to get dinner. Our food was predictably bar food- fried and heavy but not bad. We visited on a week night and they had a musician playing. We literally could not talk at our table. It was so incredibly loud we couldn't even hear each other. I am giving 3 stars only because of service. \nI would give 2 stars for the ambiance and because I wouldn't go here for date night or with my kids for dinner. It would be great just to watch a game or to go with someone you don't want to talk to.

"Cutting directly to the point, my culinary assessment of this establishment's offerings can be succinctly summarized as follows: the victuals served are merely passable, barely meeting expectations. In the event that you find yourself in close proximity and are seeking a rapid consumable meal, this venue may prove satisfactory. However, if your gastronomical inclinations lean towards genuinely exceptional Chinese cuisine, I would strongly advise venturing elsewhere, perhaps to Spring Mountain or, more specifically, the Golden State itself. Having recently returned from Los Angeles, where I indulged in some truly remarkable Chinese fare, my dining experience at this location proved underwhelming. For categorization purposes, I would relegate this eatery's culinary style to the same realm as Panda Express - while certainly palatable, it falls short of authentic Chinese cuisine."

I had not partaken of Papa John's culinary offerings for at least a year, and thus, my taste buds were eager to indulge in their delectable pies once again. As one of the superior chain pizza establishments, Papa John's boasts a prime location along my route home from work, thereby rendering it a convenient dining option. Furthermore, I had acquired a $10 gift card for the paltry sum of $5 via the online marketplace, Saveology.com, which made the prospect of savoring their large specialty pizzas all the more enticing, particularly given their affordability, with each pie priced at a mere $11. While the large pizza, measuring a scant 14 inches in diameter, may not be considered substantial by some standards, the Spinach Alfredo variety possesses an undeniable appeal, its flavorsome combination of fresh spinach, rich Alfredo sauce, and melted mozzarella cheese rendering it a veritable gustatory delight. However, upon receiving my order, I was dismayed to discover that the butter sauce and pepperoncini, typically included in the pizza box, were conspicuously absent. Nevertheless, I comprehended the reasoning behind this omission, attributable to the establishment's desire to streamline their operations and enhance efficiency. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, the quality of service remained somewhat lacking, as only one of two available registers was manned by a lone employee, resulting in a discernible delay in processing orders, while several patrons idled nearby, awaiting their turns. Despite these inconveniences, I would still consider halting at Papa John's for a pizza en route home, provided the price remains reasonable.

I recently watched this show for the second time since I saw it once w/o my husband and he really wanted to see it. The show is definitely different from your typical cirque du soleil shows. This one is more focused on Asian themed/ sword fighting/acrobatics. Most cirque du soleil show is like watching a dream with really no plot just different acts of crazy "sitting on the edge of chair" acrobatics. But KA actually has a storyline and nothing was really scary cause they used wires.

The language they use and some characters (ie the Tarzan-ish guy) is just hard to take in. Even watching it the second time, it's not my kind of cirque du soleil, so I'm glad for both times I was able to get the tickets for a cheap price.

The only thing I really like about the show is the big platform that can go vertical and move around. The last scene with the fighting on the vertical wall was my favorite, but the other parts didn't catch my attention like the other shows do.

This establishment offers an optimal ambiance for both working and enjoying a meal when one has forgotten their lunch at home. As I arrived during lunchtime and the venue was not particularly busy, the combination of free Wi-Fi and spacious tables for working was precisely what I sought. They boast an extensive variety of dishes, and the service is quite satisfactory. I opted for two salads: one consisting of vegetables and Dijon mustard, followed by the other, which featured vegetables and oriental-style noodles, or, in other words, simply a soy sauce-based dressing. Both were exceptionally delicious, and I thoroughly enjoyed having the option of a bread-free lunch. Additionally, they offer hot dishes and daily specials that appear to change regularly. Overall, this eatery seamlessly blends the atmosphere of a modern caf with that of a casual, laid-back restaurant. While it is moderately priced, there is an ATM located within the caf for convenience.

We visited this establishment for our evening meal on a Friday... Our group consisted of eight individuals, yet despite possessing a prior reservation and the lateness of the hour (9:45 PM), we were compelled to endure a brief delay before being seated, and furthermore, were assigned an outdoor table... in the intense heat of approximately 100 degrees Fahrenheit.  Although the temperature itself did not pose a significant inconvenience, we unfortunately failed to experience the full ambiance and interior design of the venue.  The kobe meatball dish was quite satisfactory.  My personal selection was an eight-ounce filet, which, while satisfying, did not include any additional sides, such as a potato, and so forth... However, the asparagus side dish I chose was both copious and flavorful.  The filet itself was cooked to my precise instructions and seasoned with great care... Most of the other patrons opted for pasta dishes, the quality of which I cannot accurately assess, as their appearances varied.  The service we received was proficient and attentive, with no notable errors committed.  While not excessively expensive, the prices charged were still somewhat elevated... Ultimately, I felt underwhelmed by the entire experience, harboring the sentiment that either a greater expenditure for superior cuisine or a lesser cost for more casual fare would have been preferable.  No major grievances can be reported, yet neither was I particularly impressed by any aspect.

The patrons of this establishment have the option to sample their culinary offerings by purchasing two fish sandwiches for the sum of five dollars, in addition to which they may also opt to acquire a side salad at a cost of one dollar and eighty-nine cents. Upon partaking in these delectable dishes, it became apparent that the bread utilized in the construction of the fish sandwich was excessive in quantity, thereby detracting from the overall quality of the dish. Furthermore, the salad, consisting primarily of iceberg lettuce, did not possess sufficient flavor or nutritional value to warrant future consumption. Despite these shortcomings, the level of customer service provided by the manager, a female individual, was quite impressive and worthy of commendation. The interior design of the restaurant was also notable for its aesthetic appeal, contributing to a pleasant ambiance for patrons. However, it is regrettable to report that the gustatory experience did not meet expectations, thus rendering a return visit unlikely.

"Culinary excellence and an exceptional vinous experience. Superlative pasta dishes, with descriptions that accurately mirrored the actual composition of the dish. Upon requesting a detailed account of the wine from our attentive server, he delivered a precise and comprehensive depiction, leading to an unexpected transformation of our initial plans for a light repast and beverage into a full-fledged gastronomic indulgence. Elegant ambiance, polished service, and an overall atmosphere of refinement and quality."

Paid for a venti green tea lemonade and got a tall green tea lemonade . Reason why I didn't go back was because I had to go to school was in a rush I wish the girls that always take my orders were there
Best donuts in South Phoenix. It is the one thing that makes working over there totally worth it. The maple bar is fantastic.

I have to admit, the only thing that makes this place good is their interesting looking bread, which is unique in appearance and texture and is delicious. Other than that, the sandwiches are pretty plain and expensive for what you get ($5-6 for a small sandwich). 

The service here is pretty lackluster, since there are only a couple people working at any given time. When I've been here, I've found the cashier to be a little impatient when customers are trying to figure out what to order, so now I tend to just hit the drive thru. 

The building is super old and parking is tight since there aren't very many spots out front. There's another small parking area in the back but it's not much larger. I usually get the small original, which is good, but like I said...only because the bread is unique, fresh and tasty. If they used baugettes or "normal" sub bread for their sandwiches, I don't think I would eat here.

The short: Get the \"white cookie\" fresh from the oven, at the front cafe for $5. OMG. OMG. \n\nThe long: inside at the restaurant: long waits, water refills - had to ask each time. \"Sunday pasta\" did a number on my tummy! :-(. Best thing on the menu - the $5 white cookies in front cafe, fresh out of the oven. Wish i spent my groupon on just those cookies.
