The bountiful spread boasted 15 diverse offerings, including two soups, a vegetarian option featuring egg and tofu, and a coconut-based delight with chicken; plain and flavored rice complemented the assortment, accompanied by an assortment of savory hot dishes encompassing chicken, beef, and fish, along with numerous vegetable combinations, totaling an impressive 19 items. 

The culinary experience was generally satisfying, and considering the scarcity of Thai buffets in the area, the establishment's presence is indeed a welcome addition.     :-)

Although the dining ambiance was pleasant, and the table service was adequate, several minor drawbacks marred the experience:

*  A preponderance of poultry dominated the meat selections.

*  Desserts were conspicuously absent from the menu.

*  The eatery enforced a restrictive policy, permitting a single credit or debit card payment per table, which proved problematic for our group, as only one member had sufficient cash on hand.  This particular stipulation seemed inconvenient and counterproductive, prioritizing corporate interests over customer satisfaction.  

                                                                                          `

Lunch Buffet Schedule and Prices:

Tuesday through Friday: $9.99, available from 11:30 AM.
Sunday: $10.99, served from 12 noon."

"I opted for the fish and tofu tacos as my midday repast, and I must say, they utilized corn tortillas, which I deem to be an admirable choice. The fish exhibited a palatable quality, while the tofu blend presented an intriguing flavor profile, yet the tacos themselves did not ascend to an exceptional level of gastronomical excellence. However, the venue's ambiance appeared pleasant, with ample space surrounding the bar and an outdoor seating area that presumably offers a delightful setting during favorable weather conditions."

Quirky interior, clearly popular and possibly the best priced pot of tea in town.


 Could maybe do with opening past 18:00.

"The price point was appropriate. However, my predilection for the culinary offerings of Five Guys surpasses my affection for this establishment. Although the ambiance and gastronomical experience provided by What A Burger may be considered antiquated, it remains my preferred purveyor of burgers. Notwithstanding the crowded atmosphere, the staff at In-N-Out Burger exhibited commendable hospitality, yet the quality of their burgers pales in comparison to that of their competitors, thereby precipitating a deficiency in the overall satisfaction of my dining experience."

I'm pretty sure most of these new reviews are from employees and their families. 

Refused to honor my Groupon (prepaid of course).
This is exactly the same place as before. Their sign even still says Greek Grill & Fry Co. and it's run by the same people. 
The server was polite and made good suggestions,  but failed to alert me that they would not honor the 50% off Groupon before we ate, but instead offering a 20% discount. I always mention any deals on the way in for this reason.

The food was good,  not a huge selection but it was hot and made to order. We seemed to be the only customers that whole day. The Uncle/Grandpa of the family was in the dining area watching TV and talking on his phone. It's a very casual place.

There are some tables and a lot of slot machines. If you live in the area, it could be a good place to go and hang out. I would never recommend a drive from the strip to gamble here, but not bad for a locals hang out. With dollar beer and hot dogs, how can you go wrong!?

"It possesses an Americanized quality, yet it remains delectable; I have a particular fondness for their fried rice and typically opt for that dish exclusively. On one occasion, we decided to partake in takeout and were seated at the bar while awaiting our order. The bartender, in a gesture of generosity, offered us complimentary samples of their lychee-based cocktail, which we greatly appreciated and found quite palatable. Additionally, the establishment is characterized by a lack of crowding, with a tranquil atmosphere and consistent, albeit unremarkable, service. Notwithstanding these positive aspects, there fails to be any truly distinctive or remarkable features that set this restaurant apart from others; it ultimately ranks as a suitable option for takeout."

I don't know about the lounge part everyone else has reviewed, but I had dinner there and was like meh about it. The portions are extremely small for the prices. Even the sake was a bit overpriced, I felt. The waitstaff, as much as I appreciate attentiveness, was maybe a little too overeager to get us the hell out of there. My husband's plate was actually cleared before he was even done eating. We eventually had to tell them to leave the plates until we were finished. While the ambiance is very cool and romantic, I don't think I'd drop another buck in there in the future.

This establishment no longer possesses the identical quality and culinary prowess it formerly boasted in years past. As an ardent patron since the early 1970's, I have witnessed a gradual decline in both the standard of service and gastronomical offerings since the turn of the millennium. It is no longer a viable dining option, failing to provide an adequate value for the price. Despite the persistently cordial demeanor of the staff and an aesthetically stagnant ambiance, my recent dining experience was marred by the unfortunate preparation of my New York strip steak, which was subjected to an unsolicited butterflying process that effectively extracted the inherent flavor and rendered it unpalatable. Lamentably, this once-lauded eatery has relinquished its erstwhile prestige, precluding me from enthusiastically recommending it to acquaintances embarking upon a culinary excursion to Las Vegas.

"Although my culinary preferences do not align with the gastronomical offerings at this establishment, I do appreciate the expansive outdoor seating area, which presents an ideal setting for indulging in a mixed beverage, such as a refreshing cocktail or a glass of wine, at any time."

I'm with everyone when they say that this is not a hike. lol.

It's basically a quick walk with man made steps to see a somewhat view of what is Phoenix. It's right next to the zoo, can't miss it. I liked that it was a stop over and a cute quest for my boyfriend and I to do on our trip, but it's definitely not a hike! 

I was wearing a super cute outfit with dressy boots and was able to walk up this hole hill :)

I was here before the supposed end of the world, and it seemed like everyone here was having a great time.  My gf got a tip from her promoter that got us to get in for free, alongside the complimentary drinks that they offered just before midnight, so it was pretty cool to come in hang out for a bit.\n\nBlush is really small in comparison to XS and Surrender. Blush doesn't have a dance floor, just walkways in between the tables. You can try to dance in those areas, but you'll end up looking kinda awkward dancing in the limited space. The music seemed to be mainstream, with less emphasis on hip hop. We only stayed in there for about 30 minutes and ended up leaving to meet up with the others outside that couldn't get in.

The gastronomical expertise of the culinary artisan, as he endeavors to prepare an assortment of delectable noodle-based dishes in an outdoor setting, serves as a source of fascination for passersby who are drawn to the alluring aroma emanating from the cooking station. Predominantly, the chef focuses his attention on creating a flavorful variety of Pad Thai noodles, complemented by succulent beef strips that tantalize the taste buds of those who partake in this savory indulgence. Despite the unwavering dedication displayed by the culinary mastermind, it becomes apparent that the inherent quality of the consumables cannot be underestimated, as their satisfying essence satiates even the most formidable of appetites, leaving no room for doubt regarding their capacity to gratify the hunger of any individual who has the privilege of partaking in such a delectable feast. However, one must acknowledge that the emotional response elicited by the consumption of these delicacies transcends mere physical sustenance, as the sensory experience engenders a profound sense of satisfaction that cannot be readily dismissed or disregarded.

"Today, I partook in a leisurely hike with a group of acquaintances, followed by a midday repast at a local eatery.  Upon entering the establishment, we were greeted by a welcoming ambiance and an agreeable hostess who promptly seated us.  Our server, an affable young woman, presented us with menus and offered suggestions from the extensive bill of fare.  I opted for a delectable sandwich, which was served steaming hot and overflowing with fresh ingredients.  Unfortunately, my side dish of mixed greens appeared somewhat limp and lackluster, leading me to surmise that it may have been sitting for an extended period.  One of my fellow diners selected a traditional morning meal, which he proclaimed to be both flavorful and plentiful.  Another member of our party chose a breakfast burrito, which he described as'very good.'  However, my own salad proved to be the weakest component of the meal, prompting me to speculate that perhaps it was not the freshest offering on the menu.  Despite this minor shortcoming, the quality of service we received was quite satisfactory, as our server remained attentive and personable throughout our visit.  Additionally, the restaurant provided complimentary carafes of coffee, iced tea, and soda, allowing us to refill our glasses at our discretion.  In conclusion, while the cost of the meal was reasonable, I might recommend avoiding the salad option during lunch hours, but would certainly consider returning to sample other items from their diverse culinary offerings."

we ate here for our last day in vegas. everyone was hung over and we needed some soup to make us feel better. i ordered the fire chicken wings which weren't spicy at all. but it wasn't bad. the dim sum was yummy because they had a good amount of shrimp inside. the duck noodle soup thing was ok. the duck was good. hot and sour soup- a bit spicy, too much pepper. and the chrysanthemum iced tea was delish.

This particular site was in close proximity to Arizona State University. It was devoid of patrons on a festive day. Our attendant was exceptional. The culinary offerings were prepared flawlessly. Furthermore, they offered a designated area for scholastic pursuits, which I believed to be an inspired notion. The sole recommendation proffered by my dining companion was that the server should inform patrons of any supplementary charges beforehand, rather than taking them by surprise on their bill. Although the menu did contain a reference to this practice, it did not explicitly state that an additional two dollars would be added to the cost of eggs upon requesting a slice of cheese.

The prices were great, but they were out of stout...

I was a bit crowded and that left the staff super spread out... Our table faced the kitchen door and it was obvious they only had two cooks in the kitchen, I wonder how the dining room got so croweded?  But for the price I don't mind having to wait for our food, beg for water and the check.

I will say the people watching was priceless!  It looked like perhaps a convention of middle-aged mid-west salesmen had hit the place hard just before we were seated! Hilarious :)

We got a room for $35/night, a Motel-6 price for a better-than-Motel-6 room with much-better-than-Motel-6 amenities.  The pools are awesome.  You get a free drink pass.  Gym is pretty nice, too.  I approve.

Finally, an individual exhibited intelligence and elected to establish a Metro Pizza in Henderson, thereby alleviating the necessity for me to engage in a conflict with UNLV students during their lunch break in order to secure a pleasant booth and a delicious pizza. The novel location, in my opinion, surpasses the original in quality. It features a complete bar section, a private dining area for celebrations, and a customary dining room. Additionally, there is a distinct wing designated for carry-out orders, thereby eliminating the need for me to traverse the entire restaurant while attired in my pajamas and slippers. While the pizza is undoubtedly delectable on its own, the nuclear fries are truly exceptional, possessing a subtle spice and a slight kick that complements a pie perfectly. Furthermore, they offer an assortment of beers on tap, which pair magnificently with pizza. However, it is advisable to avoid visiting during weekend evenings, as the excitement surrounding the new establishment remains prominent, resulting in overcrowding. Instead, opt for the lunch period, when the atmosphere remains relatively peaceful.  
Recommended pizza: Margherita  
Recommended beer: Hefeweizen accompanied by a few lemons.

This is the cheapest option if you are in Paris, which isn't saying much. We'll actually there's a place two doors down that had sandwiches in a display case but for an extra dollar or two we got a much more appetizing sandwich here. \n\nI definitely would not go out of your way for this place. However, if it is 2pm, you just got in from your flight and don't want another airport refrigerated sandwich, then just maybe this is the place for you too.

First and foremost, I don't mind spending money on good coffee.  I do have to say that the ambiance has definitely changed quite a bit in the last 6 months.   I used to walk in and see my favorite baristas and we'd chit chat a little but now they all seem to be gone.  I'm going to assume that's because of the new location?  I'm not sure.  Regardless the coffee now seems to taste less satisfying :(.  It's saddening because we really adored this place but now go elsewhere.  If anything it's a testament to the difference people can make in that sort of environment.

This constitutes an assessment of Flavors, the sumptuous smorgasbord situated within the premises of Harrah's. Every time I venture out to Las Vegas, I make a concerted effort to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment. While the prices may not be considered economical, the vast array of delectable options more than compensates for the additional expense. Patrons can indulge in a diverse selection of enticing cuisines, including Mexican, Italian, seafood, fresh fare, Chinese, and an assortment of mouthwatering desserts. Each visit has yielded a novel gastronomic experience, as the menu boasts an impressive array of innovative additions. The standard tariff for a single individual is approximately $20; however, participation in the timeshare program can result in a substantial discount, with the possibility of securing two admissions for the price of one. Unfortunately, my recent visit proved disappointing, as I discovered that access to the timeshare opportunity is restricted to individuals aged 28 and above. Although I am only 24, I successfully participated in the program during a previous visit a few months ago. It is worth noting that the timeshare promotion is conducted at the casino's entrance, and staff members are proactive in approaching potential participants, particularly couples or those who appear to be part of a pair.

My wife and i went for lunch last week.  The food was so so and the service was a bit slow.  We both got lunch specials that came with soup, spring roll and fried wontons.  The soup was not what I would call a traditional Thai soup, the spring roll was too greasy, and the wontons were bland.  My wife got the yellow curry and I got Panang.  I ordered mine \"Thai spicy\" but it was more like medium.  Next time we go for Thai we'll try the Thai Cafe which is just a mile or so away.

"The fruit and vegetables procured from this establishment may not consistently possess optimal quality, as I have previously purchased a bag of plums from this location at a discounted price, only to discover upon consumption that they had deteriorated in freshness. However, I was able to successfully slow cook them, resulting in an unexpectedly delectable culinary experience. It is essential to exercise caution when acquiring items at a significantly reduced cost or those that are out of season, as there exists a heightened risk of compromised quality. Nonetheless, it is crucial to emphasize that a plethora of satisfactory products can be found among the offerings, thereby rendering it judicious to maintain vigilance in the face of potential disappointment."

I'll start with the food. It was good. My husband enjoyed the steak and I got the halibut. Both really tasty. Baked potato was stellar and they have a 'wine of the month' which you can get for $20 or if you have the hotel coupon book, free.

Service. Was very attentive in some ways, non-existent in others. Served us drinks/wine right away. Never brought bread and we had to ask for our entree after being there about 75 minutes and then rush to make our show. Not a huge deal EXCEPT the server was super defensive about it and made excuses, which I thought was weird as we weren't irritable when we mentioned it, just asked because we needed to get out of there.

Seemed super pricey for South Point too, but if you want a special occasion and are staying there - I'd say try it. It was good.

"It is patently evident that securing a reservation at this establishment during the festive Christmas season is an absolute imperative, particularly for parties comprising more than two individuals. The dearth of vacant tables during our visit underscored the pressing need for a prior appointment, as we were compelled to occupy seats at the bar owing to the absence of availability. The prices charged for the culinary offerings were considerable, with a modest soup costing a tenner and a special combination of soup and pasta setting patrons back by nineteen dollars. Notwithstanding the elevated tariffs, the gastronomic experience was merely passable, as one of my colleagues was obliged to return the special due to the uncooked state of the meat. However, the eatery's personnel demonstrated commendable alacrity in recognizing and addressing the issue, which merited a generous gratuity."

I really like Lavo (as a nightclub)! Have yet to have a meal here though, so this review is for the nightclub only. Space-wise it can get pretty cramped because it's a bit on the smaller side, but nowhere near as uncomfortably packed as Tao. Dance floor is pretty tiny, but honestly, I didn't notice it until the place had mostly cleared out and I got a good look around. They play hip-hop and a lot of old songs, but old in a way that makes you go "oh man, I haven't heard this song in a while, but  it's still awesome," which I think is a nice change of pace from all the clubs that play almost exclusively house music.

Lavo is probably a 3.5 in my book, though I have to admit, part of the reason for that is because we had open bar, courtesy of our wonderful promoter (who also got our guys in for free!) There's a main bar area, but we got all our drinks from the side bar, which was super crowded and only had one bartender working there. But he was a really adorable and sweet bartender, so no complaints.

tl;dr: Everyone in my group had a fairly fun time. Would definitely come back-- especially if we're staying at the Venetian/Palazzo!

"Although certain aspects of this establishment were satisfactory, such as its proximity to the Town & Country shopping center and the ample parking facilities, other elements, including the meager amount of meat and toppings on the sandwiches, left much to be desired. Furthermore, the preponderance of bread in these sandwiches made them seem unbalanced and lacking in substance. While the chocolate milkshake was a notable highlight, it was not enough to compensate for the overall mediocrity of the dining experience. In light of these factors, it is difficult to wholeheartedly recommend this venue, especially when compared to more affordable options such as Subway, where one can expect a greater quantity and variety of ingredients."

I would give this a 3.5. I would expect the pizza to be a lot better just because it is a Pie place. It was good but I've had a lot better. The thing this has is great ambiance. I love how low the lighting is. Dark tables that are turned perfectly so you don't feel like you are apart of other people's dinners. Great fire from the oven and open area bar. Had a good solid wine. We got the cheese board which was good. We both got pizza but like I said it was good just nothing special.

I rarely frequent Fresh and Easy due to the lack of visual appeal of their stores, with the exception of a few select items that pique my interest, primarily snacks such as peanut butter filled salted pretzel nubs, some satisfactory salted kettle chips, and a passable trail mix suitable for hiking excursions. My brief visit to the store yesterday served as a testament to my unfamiliarity with its layout, as I aimlessly wandered the aisles in search of my desired products, not unlike a zombie driven by an unyielding determination to acquire the items on my list. Following a swift checkout process, during which I presented only two items for purchase, I proceeded to venture across the street to Albertsons, whereupon I conducted a more extensive and deliberate shopping expedition.

The gastronomical experience offered by this diminutive yet delectable salsa bar, tacos, quesadillas and burritos establishment is undoubtedly reminiscent of authentic Mexican culinary traditions, a far cry from the homogenized, commercialized fare served at Macayos. However, patrons seeking to indulge in these scrumptious delights must contend with limited seating capacity and an absence of accommodations suitable for larger gatherings or families, while the prospect of parking in adjacent streets elicits consternation and potential vitriol from local residents, who manifestly take umbrage with the notion of their domain being utilized for vehicular stationing, going so far as to threaten the towing of any recurring offenders' vehicles.

The burgers are as good as one could hope for the price and the setting sure makes for good conversation. I like the fact that it's not a chain fast food place, but its missing some beer variety (i.e. other than Molson/Labbatt) and the fries could really be improved.

"Culinary delights are undeniably delectable, yet the quality of customer service leaves much to be desired. Despite this establishment being a personal favorite, the experience at this particular venue falls short of expectations. A prolonged waiting period of 15 minutes ensued, during which time the dining area was largely unoccupied, for a bean burrito to be prepared for takeout. It is truly disconcerting that such an esteemed eatery would fail to meet the standards of efficiency and promptness, especially during a relatively slow period."

"The pizza demonstrated an appreciable degree of culinary excellence, with a flavor profile that was decidedly pleasant and satisfying. However, the experience was somewhat marred by a prolonged waiting period, which, though inconvenient, was ultimately offset by the friendly and accommodating demeanor of the staff. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the pepperonis, while undoubtedly delicious, were regrettably undercooked, thereby necessitating a subsequent visit to Grimaldis in Brooklyn for the purpose of comparing and contrasting the two establishments' offerings. In conclusion, while nothing particularly remarkable or exceptional was encountered during this dining excursion, it is nevertheless evident that the restaurant possesses certain qualities that are worthy of commendation and appreciation."

"For those who relish the prospect of partaking in a Sunday night concert series, an event characterized by an amalgamation of familial units, canine companions, and an assortment of pedestrians meandering aimlessly throughout the vicinity of one's seating arrangement, accompanied by the cacophonous symphony generated by the confluence of blaring train horns and subpar audio equipment, and further exacerbated by the unenviable task of securing a parking space within close proximity to the venue, may find the aforementioned concert series to be an ideal addition to their schedules. My companion and I managed to secure a relatively advantageous position, removed from the central performance area yet still susceptible to the multitude of distractions mentioned previously, none of which proved particularly bothersome to our collective sensibilities. However, it is essential to note that attendance at this event may necessitate tolerance of the aforementioned factors, and potentially, the presence of numerous children and canines under the stewardship of a single individual. Furthermore, it is advisable to arrive prematurely to ensure procurement of a desirable vantage point, ideally situated across the street from the performance arena. It is plausible that the throng in attendance may have been augmented due to the coincidence of a holiday weekend, although such speculation remains uncertain in the absence of subsequent visits to the event."
Went on a night that they had a live band on the patio.....was a nice atmosphere. Drinks were good but food was just okay. May go back if other places are too busy.

"Aesthetically pleasing accommodations, albeit briefly inhabited, rendered an additional tariff of $50 for early ingress. Contrasted with the alternative of slumbering within the confines of our minuscule Honda Insight alongside my spouse, infant, and mother-in-law, this arrangement proved preferable. Notwithstanding, the availability of power outlets for our diverse assortment of mobile devices necessitated a systematic rotation and judicious utilization of the facilities' electrical infrastructure. Lamentably, the queue for registration extended interminably, attended by an insufficient number of personnel to facilitate its expeditious progression... Lamentably, the process of settling our financial obligations similarly degenerated into chaos, as the throngs of patrons vying to vacate the premises swelled to unmanageable proportions during the terminal phase of our sojourn. Gratuities notwithstanding, the absence of a coffee brewing apparatus within our quarters occasioned mild disappointment. Furthermore, the egress protocol struck us as somewhat bizarre, advocating instead for a simplified, hassle-free procedure involving the placement of the invoice beneath the entrance to our abode, followed by a swift and unencumbered departure, devoid of any unnecessary delays or complications. Ultimately, despite some minor shortcomings, our stay at the TI proved satisfactory, yet, given the tariff, we might opt to seek alternative lodgings in the future."

Hit up merts for dinner last night..  Had the Fried catfish and Beef rib combo.  Whole fried catfish was a little tough to negociate the bones and didnt not yeald much fish. \"The beef rib\" was chopped up and in a small pile bones and all.  Like other have said the goodness in in the sides..  Mac and Cheese was real and had a nice crust on the top and the corn bread was good.. athough the piece my wife got looked like it was in the oven a littlel too long and dried out a bit.  Overall decent stop

"My affection for cinematic endeavors directed by John Hughes notwithstanding, this particular establishment purporting to serve breakfast items under the moniker 'The Breakfast Club' fell short of my expectations, which, admittedly, were predicated on the eponymous film. The eggs, while adequate in terms of their culinary execution, unfortunately lacked that je ne sais quoi that would have elevated them to the realm of true gastronomical excellence; the potatoes, referred to as 'O'Brian' in an apparent attempt at novelty, were unremarkable in both texture and flavor, with an unfortunate tendency towards oiliness and an inconsistent distribution of pepper; the jalapeno biscuits, whose conceptual appeal had initially piqued my interest, regrettably failed to deliver upon their promised premise, manifesting instead as somewhat tough and flavorless disk-shaped entities infused with jalapenos; the heuvos rancheros, while perhaps visually unappealing to some due to their resemblance to a feline hairball, were declared palatable by my dining companion. \n\nIn conclusion, my experience at this establishment was, overall, disappointing, primarily due to an excessive greasiness that permeated the menu offerings, as well as an outdoor seating area that, while pleasant in theory, proved to be a mixed blessing given its proximity to a heavily trafficked thoroughfare. However, it must be acknowledged that the quality of service provided by the waitstaff was, for the most part, satisfactory, despite certain unsettling mannerisms reminiscent of the Stepford Wives that were observable in some of the servers."
Overall it's a nice place the reason for only 3 stars is this: $5 to park,$35.99 entrance, $8 small locker, $3 water and only 5 working slides, a wave pool and lazy river. Make up your own minds ...

Fairly typical Chinese food with a Sushi menu and nice restaurant seating area.  I wasn't as wow'd as I was hoping after reading all the rave reviews here on Yelp, but it is a pretty decent offering.

I tried the egg drop soup, which was a good value, the pork dumplings, which were meh - I think the sauce was overly sweet, the kung pao chicken, which was pretty good, and the chicken lo mein noodles, which were meh (but aren't all lo mein noodles pretty meh?).

Overall I would come back and get some take out because it does lie somewhere in between your PFChangs and your strip mall cheap Chinese take out place.  However, I don't believe it's that great of a value offering.  The prices are a bit high for cheap Chinese, and the quality is only just a bit higher.  Doesn't feel like you're getting a great deal.

"The embellishments within this establishment are positively endearing, evoking a strong desire within me to linger and partake in the assorted delights available. Following the lead of numerous patrons who have preceded me, I opted to sample a pair of macaroons, specifically those infused with a mix of berries and raspberries. While not necessarily a novice to such confectionaries, I must confess that my palate was neither blown away nor thoroughly disappointed by the experience, thereby necessitating a future visit to explore alternative flavors and possibilities."

"Although Footlocker may not excite one's senses, it does offer an array of prominent shoe brands, including Reebok, Nike, Adidas, and an abundance of basketball sneakers that could be deemed superfluous. Prices range from moderate to expensive, yet periodic sales provide customers with the opportunity to acquire desirable footwear at a reduced cost. However, these sales often feature aesthetically unappealing shoes that may not be in high demand. As Footlocker appears to cater primarily to male clientele, its inventory is comprised predominantly of men's shoes, leaving a limited selection for women. Thus, while I may visit the store to peruse its offerings, I frequently find myself seeking alternatives that better align with my preferences."

My fianc recommended that I compose a review, and I responded by expressing my ambivalence towards the eatery, describing it as unremarkable and lacking any distinctive qualities that would warrant a positive or negative appraisal. I assigned a rating of 2.5 stars, which I deemed appropriate given the establishment's unexceptional offerings. The service was adequate, eliciting neither praise nor criticism from me. The culinary selections available during the happy hour period featured two tacos for $3, with the chef selecting the varieties. I thoroughly enjoyed consuming the salmon taco, finding its flavors to be quite satisfying. However, my expectations for the guacamole were not met, as I had hoped for a more impressive experience. While the inclusion of dried cranberries added an intriguing element, my preference remains with the superior quality of Trader Joe's guacamole. The food at this establishment could be described as "rico," a term denoting richness or abundance in Spanish, often used as a compliment. However, in this case, the term "rico" applied more to the caloric content rather than the culinary excellence. Although I wouldn't object to returning, my desire to do so isn't particularly strong either.

"It is not a cinematic establishment that I routinely visit, given my residence in NLV, but the alterations implemented since Rave acquired ownership of the venue appear to be advantageous. They have incorporated supplementary armrests between each seat, featuring sturdier cup holders than customary, presenting both benefits and drawbacks; although facilitating the sharing of beverages and snacks, the immobility of the armrests constitutes a hindrance. 

Advantages:
Enlarged armrests
Expanded snack bar relative to others

Disadvantages:
Delayed commencement of the film (White House Down) by approximately twenty minutes, ostensibly due to the absence of an individual in the operational chamber
Insufficient quantity of M&M's within the package procured at the snack bar."

"Indubitably, 'Ja... perfectly fine.' However, there seems to be a certain je ne sais quoi missing from 'Jawohl. I rather enjoy that.' Perhaps it's the lack of a tangible element, such as a location with a similar ambiance to a fast-food chain, but with a more refined and sophisticated atmosphere, akin to a restaurant rather than a bar. Perchance, the concept of offering a build-your-own menu, where customers can curate their own dishes from a selection of premium ingredients, might help to establish a more coherent and well-rounded culinary experience. It's worth mentioning that the service has been consistently friendly and attentive, without being overbearing or intrusive. While the location itself is not necessarily problematic, the overall concept and pricing strategy may benefit from further refinement to fully realize its potential. At present, it appears to be a fusion of a trendy Berlin-Mitte scene restaurant and the currently popular Munich 'Currywurst bars,' resulting in a unique yet somewhat disjointed dining experience. Notwithstanding, the establishment boasts a commendable gender diversity among its staff."

A coterie of individuals, including myself, elected to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment, primarily due to the fact that we had been informed that their burgers were of superior quality. Upon arriving at the venue, we discovered that the comestibles were indeed delectable, yet somewhat greasy and arid. However, it was the unfortunate occurrence of poor hospitality that truly marred our dining experience. Specifically, Olivia, our server, displayed an acrimonious demeanor throughout the duration of our visit, seemingly without provocation. When we requested a container for transporting our food, she carelessly flung it onto the table, an action we perceived as discourteous. Furthermore, we were compelled to request the replenishment of our water vessels thrice before she eventually attended to our needs. Considering the elevated prices charged by this restaurant, a certain level of decorum and attentive service would have been anticipated. In conclusion, while the edibles were undoubtedly savory, the subpar service we received left much to be desired. If one values a satisfying dining experience, they may wish to consider patronizing this establishment with the hope that they will encounter a more competent and affable server.

So I thought I'd drop in for a little afternoon delight. Lots of Yummy Flavors to choose from.
I was looking forward to a real sweet treat with lots of candy on top!
It's March so I  chose Irish creme mmmmm with almond roca topping.

I was enjoying it for about the first 3 bites then all I could think about  was "Twangy Tart"!
All this time I thought I loved the Golden Spoon, that is until I let the Ice Tango do a little dance on my tongue! 

Trust Me once you try the Twang you'll be like Daaaaaang! 
And Nothing else will ever be the same!

Damn You Ice Tango! You have ruined me from enjoying any other Frozen yogurt joint!

Golden Who?

Its good food.  Its just not the greatest food for the price you pay.  I had a spicy chicken of some sort, and they dont mess around when it comes to the spicy stuff.  This stuff was HOT.  I enjoyed it quite a bit, but I just didnt feel like the food justified the price.  $11 for a lunch special?  No thanks.  I would give the food 4 out of 5 stars though.

I only ordered pho there and wasn't impressed at all but I saw some other dishes other people were eating looked pretty good.  It gave me the feeling that it's a more Americanized joint comparing to the ones on spring mtn. I'm willing to try again.

This used to be the best mall in the area.  Then along came Arizona Mills, Chandler Fashion Center, and Tempe Marketplace.  Those three places, in my opinion, seems to have taken at least those patrons who live in Chandler, Tempe and Gilbert.

There are still good stores here, including many of the same stores you will find at the other malls.  We have found that Fiesta is now much less busy and crowded than it used to be.  This is particularly nice during Christmas season/sales.

And they have an area of covered parking which the other malls don't.  Very nice in summer.

I know I said that they were professional and all, but the other day we received a bill for what the insurance wouldn't pay.  It came in a decent envelope, but then we opened it.

Plain sheet of paper with printing.  No tear-off portion, no return envelope (not to mention return postage - I wouldn't expect that from anyone).  Just a sheet, badly folded, printed out on a cheap printer.

So much for professional.  I guess that only extends to examinations - and presumably procedures.  Definitely not to the billing department.  We get a lot of medical bills since we started buying our own insurance, and this is definitely the cheapest of the bunch.

I get that it's only a few cents for an envelope and all - but it can't cost them much more to have some reasonably pre-printed invoices with tear-off return portions, much less a return envelope.  It would just make for a nicer experience, you know?

"An extraordinary location, offering an ambiance that exudes sophistication and elegance, yet remains welcoming and approachable. The Chopped Salad, a culinary masterpiece, undoubtedly reigns supreme among its peers, boasting an unparalleled flavor profile that transcends the mundane and enters the realm of gastronomic excellence. However, its portion size, though adequate for a light repast, falls short of expectations considering its premium pricing. Perhaps, a more generous serving, tantamount to the quality of the dish, might encourage increased patronage.  

Regarding beverages, the flight, while maintaining an acceptable level of potency, unfortunately, requires an interminable waiting period, analogous to the time spent awaiting the arrival of an errant canine on one's lawn. Nonetheless, the BBQ sauce, a tangy and savory condiment, serves as a delightful accompaniment to the main course. The staff, though proficient in their duties, fails to exhibit the exceptional level of hospitality one might anticipate given the upscale nature of the establishment. A gratuity or complimentary dessert, bestowed upon patrons in acknowledgment of merely satisfactory service, could potentially redeem an otherwise unremarkable dining experience and foster customer loyalty. 

In conclusion, this venue, harmonizing seamlessly with the vibrant downtown Scottsdale atmosphere, offers a unique and enjoyable dining adventure. Nevertheless, it is advisable to avoid the buffalo meat, as it may evoke imagery associated with canine visitors and detract from the overall epicurean indulgence."

The food here was really good. It was filling and tasty. However, when compared to other taco joints or mexican food, it is just very average. I love mexican food and the food here lacks the authenticity of other places... But this should be obvious since its in a casino. \nMy problem is that they are very very pricey. For two people, it was $54. The food was good and it was discounted for gamblers, but if I had to pay over $50 for the quality I would be upset.\nDefinetly people should come here and try it out, just know the quality isn't worth the price.

"While the eatery offers palatable cuisine at an affordable cost, my culinary expeditions have acquainted me with superior sushi establishments that offer a comparable price point and occasionally, it is worthwhile to expend additional funds to indulge in exceptional fare. The presentation of their maki rolls frequently appears haphazard and unpolished, and certain types of seafood, such as fresh tuna or yellowtail, may lack the optimal level of freshness. Although suitable for a hasty midday repast, this dining venue does not qualify as an appropriate setting for an elegant evening meal."

"Encountered an individual at this location, with the intention of engaging in a recreational activity on the tennis courts.  To our astonishment, the facilities were in a state of good repair, despite the absence of net straps, which did not deter us from participating in the sport.  Generally speaking, this complex possesses a certain appeal... However, my singular grievance would be the convoluted design of the parking area, replete with numerous curved pathways, thereby creating numerous blind spots for drivers who must reverse their vehicles.  Although this layout may contribute to the aesthetic appeal of the surroundings, it would undoubtedly pose a formidable challenge for maintenance personnel, as the absence of straightforward trajectories necessitates additional effort in upkeep. \n\nObserved that the residential units appeared sturdy and well-constructed, employing brick as the primary building material... Nevertheless, the proximity of the highway resulted in significant noise pollution, permeating the atmosphere and rendering it audible even from the tennis court.  Did not venture inside a specific dwelling, yet the auditory level was considerable, even from a distance."

Applebee's is just one of those boring chain restaurants.  I do really love some chains, but alas, Applebee's is not one of them.   Everything is just ok.  Nothing ever blows my socks off or makes me crave to come here, but it isn't bad either, just blah.

I found myself here yesterday because I was outvoted by the group I was with.  Oh well, it happens.  We went for lunch and it was an ok experience.  I had the Bourbon Black and Bleu Burger.  It was surprising yummy.  It had a lot of kick and I had a small party in my mouth.  It was better than I was expected, which was a nice surprise.  The other people in the party both got the 3 cheese penne and chicken dish.  I didn't sample it, but they both enjoyed it.  My picky eater, my 18 month old did surprise me by eating half of her grilled cheese.  She never eats anything, so that made me happy.  I tried a bite and it was quite good with the bread being a sweet, eggy bread, like brioche.  

The service was really good and we always had what we wanted without having to ask for it, which made for a pleasant meal.

So over all, the food was good, the service was great, but I am still bored with the overall place.  Give me Chili's anyday, but this Applebee's did a good job today.  Way to go Applebee's for slowing changing my opinion about you.

This was my second trip to this location and I noticed their salad bar had fewer items from before.  It was still very good but am disappointed that they seemed to have eliminated some items. I am not a big meat eater and came for the salad bar so I noticed these things. It was still really really good however.

"My culinary experience at Spago was rather divergent, as while I relished my repast, my fellow diners appeared to be more thoroughly enthralled. The wedge salad, though unremarkable in its composition, was nevertheless palatable; conversely, the heirloom tomato and burrata salad special was truly exceptional, constituting the most delectable dish of the evening. We opted to share three pizzas among us, which, regrettably, failed to elicit the same level of enthusiasm due to their relatively lackluster crusts. Specifically: 

The Margherita pizza, with its somewhat undercooked crust and uninspired toppings, could be described as merely adequate; the Proscuitto pizza, featuring a harmonious combination of prosciutto and fromage blanc, showed promise, but was hindered by the aforementioned subpar crust; lastly, the Lamb Chorizo pizza, despite its commendable quality, did not quite ascend to the level of true excellence owing to its incongruous topping arrangement. 

Notwithstanding these criticisms, the service we received throughout our meal was indeed impressive."

Great place for the price. Not the most luxurious place on the strip but the amenities are decent, the service is good, and the location is fantastic. Very good value overall.

This is the 4th or 5th time we've stayed here. The rooms are clean and comfortable, and there is a decent selection of food downstairs ranging from McDonald's to 5 star French, and everything in between. The casino floor is a bit small and smoky, but perfect for when you're not in the mood to get dressed up and go out. The spa is small and reasonably priced. And it's only a few minutes' walk to other casinos, restaurants, and shopping at the many malls nearby.

The only things we didn't care much for were the showers (high pressure mist that's definitely not my idea of pleasant) and on our most recent trip the TV didn't work properly (but we didn't call to have it fixed because it just wasn't that important to us).

Yes, you can stay at a nicer, trendier, and/or more luxurious place on the strip but you'll pay about twice as much. We prefer to stay here, where we're always satisfied, and use the cash we saved to eat, play, and party while we're in town.

Kind of tucked away and hard to notice, especially being next to the really glammed out Ella's Deli. But worth a visit if you're looking for a good gyro or kebab. :]

The donuts are alright too. They have a wide variety! Myself, I really rather like their cookies. They also offer homemade baklava.

Really though I can reccomend their sandwiches with a side of the seasoned fries. Quite yummy! Vegetarian options also available such as potato kahbi or falafel sandwiches. And they had a lot of beverages to choose from too.

Although the location is not ideal, it's worth a stop if you're in that part of town. :]

when this place first opened it was really good, back then I would have given it 5 stars. Now it is just ok. My dad likes to go there, that is why we went. 
We started with the grilled artichoke. Usually this is pretty good. Not so much this time. Maybe artichokes are out of season?. It was hard and not very flavorful. The aioli that accompanied it was tasty. 
The prime rib was ok, the portions get smaller each time I go. Very tender, good flavor. Nothing outstanding. We all had the same cut. Same side of baked potato. No dessert. 
Probably will go again as my dad loves this place.

Barneys is a multifaceted drinking establishment that offers a unique experience for patrons seeking a more relaxed atmosphere than the typical bars in the vicinity. For individuals desiring an unpretentious environment where they can enjoy themselves without the necessity of dressing up or paying covers, Barneys may be the ideal destination.

The second floor of the bar particularly stood out to me as a preferred spot, owing to the hospitable demeanor of the bartender and their promptness in refilling drinks. Although the rooftop area has the potential to be an attractive spot during warmer weather, the presence of smoking therein serves as a deterrent for some.

One notable aspect of Barneys is its innovative method of pouring beer from the bottom up, creating a distinctive and entertaining experience for customers. Moreover, for those who have had a few too many drinks, the bar features an amusing arcade game involving a lobster claw, reminiscent of the classic claw machine found at carnivals and arcades.

Overall, Barneys earns a rating of 3.5 stars for its distinctive ambiance and diverse offerings that cater to various preferences.

My better half indulged in a personal visit to the destination in question, opting to partake in an excursion alongside several acquaintances during a recent weekday afternoon, specifically on a Monday. Her account of the adventure conveyed a sense of underwhelming, as the actuality of the experience did not align with her preconceived notions, boasting fewer fauna than anticipated. Furthermore, the entrance fee of ten dollars for local patrons appeared somewhat exorbitant upon reflection, given the limited scope of the park's attractions. Additionally, the sweltering heat, surpassing one hundred degrees Fahrenheit, coupled with the absence of potable water, raised concerns regarding the well-being of visitors, as every water fountain my spouse encountered displayed signs indicating they were out of commission. Such circumstances pose a significant threat to tourists, emphasizing the necessity for uninterrupted access to hydration.

"As an individual enrolled at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, this eatery presents an extraordinary value, offering five tacos, two sides, and a beverage for a mere $5; the tacos, though diminutive in stature, are abundant in terms of protein, thereby obviating any concern of being shortchanged; it is an ideal venue for socializing with companions, indulging in a pail of fermented beverages, and engaging in lively conversation; the protocol involves ordering at the counter, with the staff summoning one's attention via a vocal announcement when the culinary items are prepared; reportedly, the establishment occasionally features live musical performances or a disc jockey, typically showcasing a Latin-inspired theme, which, while unsurprising given the restaurant's heritage, may strike some patrons as unexpected."

I find myself experiencing considerable ambivalence regarding First Friday, as I hold an ardent affection for communal gatherings, particularly those that showcase artistic expression and cultural creativity. However, my enthusiasm for this event is significantly diminished due to its glaring shortcomings. Despite being situated within the artistic hub of the city, First Friday fails to deliver an adequate representation of artistic endeavors. The scarcity of art galleries and the prevalence of commercialized street vendors, who prioritize financial gain over artistic integrity, contribute to the dearth of authentic artistic expression. Furthermore, the presence of unsavory elements and rowdy juveniles in the downtown area, coupled with the authorities' inability to effectively enforce curfew regulations, serves to further detract from the overall experience. While the culinary stalls during the summer months offer some solace, the absence of such vendors during the winter season only exacerbates the event's deficiencies. Notwithstanding my reservations, I may still choose to attend future First Fridays, albeit with the caveat that I shall arrive promptly before dusk and avoid the nocturnal throngs of unruly youth.

I loved the environment, and the staff was incredible.  

the food wasn't amazing.. just .. good.
and the cost didn't justify what was on my plate.

"I recently had the occasion to partake in a culinary excursion to TMI for an evening repast. While the gastronomical experience was not without its merits, it failed to surpass my expectations in terms of overall satisfaction. Upon initiating the meal, we opted to sample the TMI toast, which, despite some reservations regarding the texture of the bread, proved to be a satisfying commencement to the delectation process. However, my subsequent selection, the Mac & Cheese, unfortunately did not live up to my gustatory standards, as it was noticeably oleaginous and lacking in flavor. It is worth mentioning that I have historically been able to establish a rapport with nearly any iteration of Mac & Cheese, yet the version proffered by TMI unfortunately did not conform to this trend. The remaining members of my dining party opted for sandwiches and salads, the quality of which, according to their accounts, ranged from satisfactory to palatable. Aesthetically, the ambiance of the establishment exuded a certain je ne sais quoi, while the degree of auditory intensity rendered conversation somewhat challenging. Furthermore, the temperature within the premises was uncomfortably elevated. In conclusion, while TMI may possess certain attributes that could potentially appeal to certain gastronomes, my own experience did not warrant an overly enthusiastic endorsement, thereby rendering my return in the proximate future unlikely."

I was surprised to find that had a TON of brand new irrigation supplies. As a gardener, I am always fiddling with the irrigation, and am in constant need of emitters, hose, and connectors to support my filthy habit. They have it all (at least when I went), and at a fraction of what the hardware store charges.

"It serves as an enjoyable venue for social gatherings, facilitating the relational dynamics of communal dining. My culinary inclinations lean towards familial-style sharing, which this establishment accommodates seamlessly. However, our ordered dishes displayed inconsistent quality, with a notable eggplant and goat cheese entre featuring an excessive proportion of cheese that overpowered the subtle flavor of the eggplant. In contrast, a dish comprising eggs, potatoes, and another component (the specificity of which escapes my memory) presented an unbalanced ratio of potato to other ingredients, prompting a sense of disappointment. Nonetheless, both the filet mignon and Thai beef salad showcased remarkable taste, rendering my overall experience gratifying. Despite some reservations, I am content with having visited this restaurant, yet I harbor doubts about returning in the future."

So we hadn't been since this place used to be Cafe Del Sol (yes, a few years ago). We used the Groupon we had purchased about a month ago. It was kind of awkward because there's the main dining room and a separate red-headed step child dining room around the corner, not really attached at all to the main dining room and probably all the excitement. We got there right at the end of happy hour and wifey ordered a glass of Sangria, I had a glass of Tempranillo (that totally blew by the way).  I ended up ordering another glass of wine (don't remember the name) and it was pretty good. I got the cola and pineapple braised short ribs, jalapeno cream corn a chile corn casserole. The sides were good, although the corn casserole was a tad dry. The shorts ribs were great, they didn't have that cheap pot roast taste that some braised short ribs can have. The sauce was a bit thick for my taste, but not a huge deal. Wifey had the grilled shrimp appetizer with avocado and mango sauce appetizer and the empanadas. She loved her food. I wasn't a fan of the empanadas. but the shrimp were pretty good. Overall, I think it's a pretty good place and it's nice to have another option in the area. Would I choose to go back? no, probably not, but I know the wife will make me go back at some point.

"A refreshing submergence into an atmospheric drinking establishment, offering a brief respite from the conventional Las Vegas landscape. We entered the premises on a Friday evening, subsequent to receiving complimentary beverage vouchers on Fremont Street. The ambiance was relatively desolate for a weekend night, which rendered the decibel levels of the bartenders' megaphones marginally excessive and potentially annoying. Nonetheless, the experience was enjoyable, albeit tainted by the realization that the bartenders employed a subtle ploy to coerce patrons into purchasing potations for both themselves and the staff, resulting in an unexpected escalation of our tab."

I have stayed at the Hotel Monte Carlo Las Vegas numerous times, and I'm ready to move on to other hotels.  Its outdated, the food at the main cafe and buffet are so-so, however the rates were pretty fantastic.  Compared to the other hotels, especially the newest arrivals, it shows its age.  

However, I do like it that the concierge will put hotel guests on the VIP list to get into Haze, and other nightclubs in the vicinity.  That was a cool feature we appreciate, and at no cost to the concierge for to get in.  

If its deals you are looking for, and "decent" rooms, it is worth looking into.

"I have had the pleasure of patronizing the establishment located in Henderson on Sunset and the one situated on South Rainbow on multiple occasions, and I must say that my experiences have been thoroughly enjoyable, particularly when it comes to their breakfast offerings, specifically the steak and eggs, which have been cooked to perfection and served with a smile by the friendly staff. Additionally, I have taken advantage of their happy hour promotion at the South Rainbow location, which boasts an impressive selection of $2 draft beers and 1/2 price appetizers, making for a truly exceptional value. However, I must express my disappointment regarding their recently revamped reward card program, which has undergone significant changes to the earning levels, effectively rendering it nearly impossible for me to accrue sufficient credits to redeem a $10 credit within a reasonable time frame, thereby warranting a subpar grade. Consequently, taking into account the substantial disparity between my previous experiences and my current dissatisfaction with their loyalty program, I would assign an overall rating of three stars, which falls midway between an 'A' and an 'F', respectively."

It was ok.... the ordering system was a little confusing, but I am a smart girl and I figured it out. I was looking for a good burger and I found one just the way I wanted it, and the onion rings were good. Its just missing a little personality....?

This was a typical resort restaurant the food was fairly ambitious and the food was pricey. I had the chicken because almost any other entree was really pricey, and almost solidly steak. Never the less the food was pretty good and the service was great. Unfortunately the table next to us lit up and then it was pretty smokey, but we were already done, and we chose to sit outside so that I don't blame them for at all. In the end it was a little too pricey for what your gonna get, some good food but also it was the resort and I wouldn't expect anything different. I probably won't be back, our server was really nice though that's the only reason I feel bad about giving this place 3 stars. Other than that it was all around ok.

It's amazing what a few blocks can do, in this case... not much if you're heading further East. I love me some Lao Laan... never really had Lao prior to moving to Madison. But I just don't get the same attentive service, sweet menu recommendations and authentic experience I so often found on Willy. What gives? The menu is more compact but the dining room is bigger, so it's perfect if you need room to groove, but other than the size, I think Willy is probably you're best bet if you're looking for curry east of the capitol.

"Although the culinary experience at this establishment was satisfactory, the cost of the meal was considerably high in relation to the quantity and quality of the food provided, thereby rendering it a relatively expensive dining option. Furthermore, my attempt to partake in a midday repast was thwarted by the restaurant's limited operating hours, which did not include luncheon service. Notwithstanding this disappointment, the personnel were quite hospitable and the service was adequate, yet the absence of a lunch menu precludes the possibility of future visits."

Nice but the menu it is stil the same  for the past 6 years...we are in Montreal 

Anyways, the best dish for me is the radish oyster  cannot get enough of the stuff. 12CAD$ for 4 oysters is well worth it

the rest to my taste was quite ordinary, not worth the money

I entered the establishment with the intention of acquiring a novel laptop charger and upgrading my operating system to Lion OSX, yet my experience was tainted by an array of inconveniences and illogicalities. Firstly, although obtaining the charger was a straightforward process, I was confronted with the revelation that, due to my current operating system being Leopard rather than Snow Leopard, I would need to purchase two upgrades to attain Lion. This was not only unexpected but also perplexing, as one would assume that a linear progression within the realm of operating systems would be readily available. However, much to my dismay, the retailer did not possess the Leopard to Snow Leopard upgrade disc in stock, leaving me with limited and impractical options. I could either embark on a quest to locate a Best Buy that might potentially possess the coveted upgrade disc in their inventory, or opt to procure it through online means, thereby subjecting myself to an excruciating waiting period. It is utterly confounding that the Apple store, a purveyor of cutting-edge technology, would fail to maintain a supply of such an essential component. Notwithstanding this absurdity, the physical location of the store was acceptable, the atmosphere was clean and well-maintained, and the employee who facilitated my transaction was adequately courteous.

"Culinary experiences that are reasonably priced and of sufficient quality. Enter with the expectation of a restaurant providing typical diner fare and you shall be gratified. The hospitality is adequate, the cuisine is passable, and the cost (particularly considering its proximity to the Las Vegas Strip) is quite favorable."

decent... i had the \"sin city\" burger. i liked it very much. my wife had a classic which i didnt like but i'm not sure what she had on it. she liked it so i guess thats what counts. the sweet potato fries werent that great. i didnt like the way they were seasoned. the regular fries were ok. all in all it was pretty good. its better than most fast food burgers....

"Moderately satisfactory for juveniles, mediocre to subpar for grown-ups.  Congenial personnel, reasonable tariff.  Not particularly delectable, but tolerable in small quantities.  Restricted selection of sweet treats and leafy greens."

If you're looking for a sweet, maybe one with some chocolate or even a big sundae - this is your place. Nice old-fashioned ice cream shop located in old town. This place still has the retro pink vibe and decoration going on inside. \n\nMy friend and I came here when we were looking to splurge with the buster brownie sundae. BOY is It sweet but worth it! Sugar Bowl also serves food, which I was unaware of but probably wouldn't order. Service is friendly.

"I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of this establishment on multiple occasions, both in-house and via delivery, and while the initial excitement has subsided, the quality of the food remains unwavering. The prevalence of five-star reviews may lead one to assume an air of infallibility, but in reality, the restaurant's excellence lies in its ability to deliver a fresh, flavorful wing experience, augmented by the 'awesome sauce' that has become a staple of their menu. My personal preference tends towards the Golden BBQ and Order, though I have also sampled the Citrus Chipotle, Jamaican Jerk, and Sweet Chili options, each boasting a distinct and satisfying flavor profile. The boneless wings, comparable in size to chicken tenders, maintain their appeal, and the delivery process is both expedient and reliable. However, the quality of service varies, with some experiences falling short of expectations, despite the frequency of my visits. Of note, the waffle fries, which I opted to upgrade, were cooked to a crispy perfection, transcending the realm of traditional potatoes and entering the realm of potato chips. In conclusion, while the inflated reviews may be misleading, the restaurant's strengths lie in its diverse array of sauces and consistently satisfying wing experience."

So, I have this weird affliction that makes me feel really uncomfortable when someone puts a HUGE plate of food in front of me. I wanted the chile rellenos, but not the supersized plate! Alas, such is the state of dining in most restaurants these days, but seriously, if I would have known the portions were this big I would have shared my dinner with my friend.\n\nStill, for Vegas we got a table on a Friday night with no wait and no reservation, the service was very attentive, and the bill was reasonable. My mojito was quite tasty also. So go, share, and enjoy!

A Charlotte staple in need of a makeover. Generally solid food but sometimes inconsistent - biggest challenge is the atmosphere which is stale and hasn't kept up with the rest of the Charlotte restaurant scene. You can't go wrong by a visit to PC - especially if the weather is nice and you get to sit on the excellent patio. Salads are great here.

"Halted by this establishment to acquire a potable beverage prior to partaking in an evening meal elsewhere. The atmosphere within was boisterous, verging on cacophonous, owing to the vociferous patrons gathered around the numerous screens displaying some form of athletic competition involving gentlemen gliding across ice surfaces; raucous birthday celebrations manifesting themselves in various areas throughout the premises; and an audio system emitting sonorous melodies at an intensity that bordered on the excessive. Despite its primary focus on gin, the venue's beverage list proved unremarkable in terms of its beer offerings, yet the selection of gin-based concoctions piqued my interest. Following the recommendation of our hospitable server, we opted to sample a particular mixture featuring Ungava gin from Quebec and maple syrup, which, despite my limited affinity for gin, proved quite palatable (it is worth mentioning that any beverage fortified with maple syrup is likely to elicit my approval). A cursory examination of the menu revealed prices that could be described as moderately elevated, with a single beer and cocktail combination costing $20, exclusive of taxes and gratuities, which, I must confess, struck me as somewhat steep. Notwithstanding this, the quality of the service we received was commendable, as our server, despite being occupied with attendance to the multiple large gatherings scattered throughout the establishment, managed to tend to our needs in a timely and attentive manner. All things considered, I am pleased that we decided to visit this locale, as it has been on our list of potential destinations ever since our relocation to this vicinity."

This is easy to confuse with Central Library, but this is hwere they keep the special books - all the special books.  Central Library is just a normal library.

To come read these books you will have to apply at the registration desk for a pass (with ID) that will last for either a few days or about 3 months.

If there is a secific old book here you want to see then you should definitely come here to see it, but if not then this is a lot of fuss over reading a book and you'll be better going elsewhere.

Good sports bar/restaurant--if that's your thing.

Went here when visiting with my dad who suggested it as "one of those new fun places."

The stuffed portabella mushroom appetizer was delicious, though ridiculously decadent.  The carnitas libre pizza was also pretty good, but also extremely rich--i.e. you can taste your arteries clogging.  The pollotate pizza was bland and dry--potatos on pizza is fun in theory, but I'm not convinced.  However, the cook forgot the onions on it, which actually might make a substantial, positive difference.  We okayed the oversight (they've only been open for two months) and they comped our bill a bit, so that was nice.  The service was pretty great, actually.

There's a ton of TVs here and a well-stocked bar with loads of beers on tap.  So if that's your thing, it's probably one of the better sports bar/restaurants out there.  For me, if I'm going to waste the kinds of calories that are packed into these dishes, it had better be for something extra special, which this place just isn't.

Popped in for lunch after a little AM yoga sesh today.  Had been by after my initial trip to Union on opening day - they weren't open when I was there then.  Weirdly, at 11:45 today half the stores in Union were open, half weren't.  Anyway, TDP is super cute.  Love the tables, love the outdoor seating and the small bar.  The staff was super friendly and helpful with our orders.  I could really taste the olive oil on my sandwich and the bread was nice. 

Overall, the food was good, but not great and definitely overpriced. $9 for a Caprese sandwich is ridiculous - and the tomato on this one wasn't ripe.    The meatball sandwich needed more sauce.  The chicken salad sandwich looked great, but again, for such small sandwiches I would expect fruit or salad or something.

I think next time I'll just enjoy the free smells, and buy a bottle of delicious olive oil from their store across the way.

"Although my dining experience at Jersey Mike's did not induce feelings of debilitating infatuation, the restaurant's ambiance was undoubtedly tidy, streamlined, and hospitable. The menu's layout presented a minor challenge for a novice such as myself, prompting a sense of hastened urgency upon ordering; however, the bustling atmosphere during peak lunch hours underscored the establishment's popularity. The diminutive sub sandwich, dubbed'mini,' could easily suffice as a standard portion size, while the larger option proved sufficient for a trio of patrons. The abundance of meat in the club sandwich catered to my carnivorous inclinations, while the subtle distinction between the white and wheat sub rolls remained somewhat enigmatic. Nonetheless, the quality of the bread did not detract from the overall enjoyment of the meal. Of greater curiosity was the assortment of beverage cups, each emblazoned with narratives pertaining to diverse Jersey Mike's locations that have engaged in philanthropic endeavors for worthy causes. While the veracity of these claims warrants further investigation, the notion of supporting an altruistic enterprise undoubtedly resonates with consumers. Though mere branding may be at play, I am intrigued by the possibility of genuine charitable involvement. Sufficiently satisfied with my initial visit, I anticipate returning to sample a spicier variety of sandwich in the future."

Los 7 Compadres has a variety (20) of combination platters for about 7 bucks.  Between my wife and I we had 7 items on our combination platters, which we shared.  7 has been a recurring number for us starting with the OYE at Malee's.  Including the rice and beans, the sour cream and the guacamole this gave us an astounding number of possible combinations for each bite.  

A bite of chicken enchilada.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice.
A bite of chicken enchilada with beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream.
A bite of chicken enchilada with rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with guacamole, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice and beans.
A bite of chicken enchilada with sour cream, rice, beans and guacamole.

Play this out again with the burrito, cheese enchilada, tamale, beef enchilada, bean enchilada, etcetera.  All of the food was good.  Portions were generally large.  I found the tamales to be the least satisfying item.  They were a bit dry and the dominant flavor was just the spice of jalapeno.

Note-even the mild here has a real bite.  Overall I'd give them 3.5 stars.  Good enough for a return trip.

Well, this place is puzzling and I'm not going to save the bad news for last.  They seem to pride themselves on allowing and maybe even promoting smoking.  It's puzzling because the beer selection is extensive.  The menu is above average, as is the food.  Lots of pizzas, sandwiches, appetizers.\n   BUT, who wants to go home smelling like a filthy ashtray?  It would be great if they joined the rest us in the twenty-first century.

"It is with immense exhilaration that I can finally indulge in some delectable V-food in the downtown area of Phoenix. The proliferation of diverse culinary experiences is undoubtedly a boon for the community. Conveniently situated at the intersection of 1st and Adam streets, this establishment offers a unique dining experience, with an open kitchen that allows patrons to observe the culinary process. Upon ordering takeout, I was pleased to discover that all necessary components were included. The promptness of the service was indeed commendable. However, I must admit that my expectations regarding the flavors were not entirely met, as they seemed somewhat less vibrant compared to my usual preferences. Moreover, the prices, while still reasonable, reflected the upscale nature of the restaurant, amounting to approximately 30 dollars for a meal for two, a sum that, although still affordable, surpassed my customary expenditure of 15-20 dollars at other, more unpretentious eateries. Despite this, I shall continue to patronize this establishment when seeking quick and convenient meals or lunches in the downtown area. Nonetheless, my yearning for the genuine and dynamic ambiance of a Vietnamese restaurant will impel me to venture towards the avenues, where established dives proffer a more authentic experience. Of note, I did not have the opportunity to sample their bahn mi, as it was unavailable. Instead, I opted for a standard buhn dice, which, while satisfying, lacked the customary sweetness and abundance of garlic that I have come to expect. The egg rolls were a pleasant surprise, filled with a variety of ingredients rather than mere vegetables. Unfortunately, the spring rolls did not include my preferred option of shrimp. Lastly, the omelette dish presented an acquired taste, one that I shall reserve judgment upon."

Chinatown in Montreal is small (1 - no matter where in the world we go, my mom ALWAYS has to have rice at least once a day 2- they have the fruits my family travels to Canada for) and this is a reliable resource for good, cheap roast pork/duck over rice. Their beef pan fried noodles are not great (as in, not something I would order again). Their wonton noodle soup is pretty good: I got it both times we came here. General Tso'c chicken was pretty good: again, something my family ordered both times we came.\n\nOverall, nothing crazy and nothing that's a must see in Montreal. The service is OK (if you get a waiter that speaks English well, then the service is good, if not, the inability to effectively communicate causes some frustration. The food comes out fast, so if you're starving, this is a good place to go. Their bubble tea is alright: stops a craving, but it's not great. They do get brownie points for giving baby bochoy with everything and for the HUGE food portions.

"Descending to a trio of stellar eminence... Upon my most recent culinary excursion to this establishment, I had the misfortune of encountering a pair of periplaneta americana specimens roaming freely on the primary floor of the eatery. No one appeared to evince any concern, thereby prompting me to take matters into my own hands by stepping on one of the unwanted arthropods. Subsequently, I drew attention to the remaining creature, which was subsequently dispatched by a member of the service staff, albeit with a nonchalant demeanor. While it is indeed arduous to effectively curtail the presence of such pests, the sight of two roaches ambling about unhindered within a bustling dining environment does not exactly engender confidence in the venue's cleanliness and maintenance standards. Furthermore, our server, a loquacious individual, seemed to presume that we were captivated by his vocalizations, when in fact, his excessive verbosity proved a tad annoying. It is worth mentioning that the proprietor of this establishment, who has been known to indulge in alcoholic beverages and frequent the patio area, allegedly fosters a work environment that might be somewhat challenging for his employees. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the cuisine here remains passable, surpassing the quality of rival establishments, although I am actively seeking alternative dining options..."

While $29.99, $32.42 with tax, proved to be too much for this feast.  While there was a lot offered at good quality, it wasn't worth the price as compared to some of the finer hotels.

I was there at 10:15am on a Saturday.  Mimosas are served, and I had two (delicious).  They had a good amount of breakfast and lunch items,  and I had a little of each.  Yes, lunch is already served.  Brunch.

Nothing was outstanding, but all was good.  It isn't an enormously large buffet, but ample nonetheless.

I think I would go back if 1) I was drunk, 2) I had a hankering for AYCE, 3) I was stuck without my car, 4) held hostage, 5) I was drunk.  Oh I said that.  Well, if the price was less...I would go.

"I possess an affinity for both Mexican and Chinese cuisine, thus, it logically follows that I would appreciate a culinary establishment that combines these two distinct gastronomical traditions. The menu, indeed, piques my interest, particularly due to the presence of the Jade Red Chicken, which, I must say, rivals any Orange or General Tso's dish I have had the pleasure of sampling. Moreover, I appreciate the diverse array of options available. The fare, undoubtedly, impresses, especially for those who relish spicy flavors. \n\nHowever, I must express some dissatisfaction with the state of the restaurant's cleanliness. Upon entering, I could not help but notice the unpretentious decor and ambiance, which, while not necessarily unpleasant, does convey a sense of frugality. Furthermore, the seating appears somewhat worn and uncomfortable, and the ceiling exhibits visible signs of wear and tear. Yet, these shortcomings, while unfortunate, pale in comparison to the unsanitary conditions that permeate the restrooms and dining area. The lavatories, in particular, present a scene akin to a truck stop restroom that has suffered a catastrophic event. The doors and walls, regrettably, bear an unsettling resemblance to a neglected state highway facility, marred by numerous handprints and streaks. Additionally, the majority of the trash receptacles overflow with waste, while the tables remain uncleaned. To my knowledge, no staff members appeared to be attending to these issues. Therefore, I must advise that a modicum of investment in maintenance and upkeep would greatly enhance the overall experience. Perhaps the acquisition of newer, more aesthetically pleasing furniture might also contribute to a more satisfactory ambiance. Under the condition that the proprietors address these concerns, I would consider awarding four stars."

Just quickly ran in and grabbed some stuff for dinner. Never been inside of this store until today. It's okay.
