I don't think the fruits and vegetables are the best but they'll do in a time crunch (because the store is located near the house) but I would prefer Safeway for fruits, vegetables and possibly meats. Prices are average - specials on some things but nothing out there that makes this store stand out.

My initial experience was adequate, but it failed to meet my expectations in its entirety. The culinary offerings did not live up to the standards of a reputable steakhouse. Neither my spouse nor I enjoyed the appetizer, specifically the Fire-Grilled Fresh Artichoke, which was marketed as a popular choice yet did not appeal to our palates. My burger was unremarkable and lacked flavor, prompting me to regret not choosing Five Guys instead. My spouse opted for the steak, which was merely satisfactory, and subsequently experienced adverse health effects due to ordering from the gluten-free menu, suggesting a potential issue with cross-contamination. 
  A notable aspect of our dining experience was the exceptional service provided by our server, Cassie. Her attentiveness, diligence in maintaining refreshments, and willingness to address dissatisfaction left us feeling content and appreciative, as we seldom encounter such impressive hospitality while dining out. Following my written account of the visit, the manager expressed his intention to extend a coupon, demonstrating the establishment's commitment to engaging with its clientele. 
  Despite the underwhelming culinary experience, the ambiance of the restaurant elicited positive feelings, and I am open to giving it another chance, contingent upon notable improvements in the quality of the food, which is crucial in securing my patronage.

We were the sole patrons present within the establishment during a Sunday afternoon, which I found rather peculiar subsequent to my acquaintance's effusive praise of this venue. Our culinary selections were served with such haste that it would have been impossible for the staff to prepare them via microwaving and plating, leading me to surmise that all dishes were pre-prepared. While the flavors were passable, the chicken contained an excessive amount of osseous material, and the deep-fried pork was so rigid that it nearly caused me to chip my tooth enamel. I pondered whether this manner of preparation was customary among Cuban cuisine enthusiasts.

Parking facilities are situated at the rear of the building. It is imperative that you secure your vehicle and refrain from traversing the surrounding area unaccompanied.

I would consider revisiting the establishment, but I would endeavor to select an item from the menu that they might prepare fresh, without resorting to pre-cooking or reheating. I awarded them three stars due to their hospitable demeanor, proficiency in both English and Spanish, and their success in avoiding the induction of gastrointestinal discomfort.

"Is this venue currently closed, or merely undergoing revitalization efforts? I have visited this establishment on multiple occasions for lunch, and my culinary experiences have led me to the conclusion that the barbacoa torta is, without a doubt, the most exceptional item on the menu. While I have sampled other offerings, such as the breakfast burrito, I must admit that the balance of potato to chorizo was somewhat lacking, particularly given the cost and dimensions of the dish."

Food was creative, flavored were good. Appetizer portions reasonable for the price and quality. Main courses however is where they fall short. Portions were far too small for the price, about $6-10 more than should be depending on what you order. Bread was a but dry for brioche but a nice light bread to have with the meal. Wine selection is very good and varied. Coming from a food town like Portland, this restaurant is nothing special but is a great addition to the chandler/sun lakes area. I would not return for dinner but would for apps and a glass of wine. They were not very busy for a Friday night either so I suspect many others feel it is overpriced for dinner, too. Would re-evaluate that for longevity.\nNice atmosphere too despite odd strip mall style location.

"A profusion of exceptional cocktails graces this establishment, although certain mixologists excel at their craft more than others. Particularly fond of their mint-infused mojitos. Prices are reasonable, ambiance pleasant, clientele congenial, tunes melodious. Partook in brunch, specifically a lobster omelette. While the dish presented an array of diverse flavors, my fastidious palate found it somewhat overwhelming. However, I surmise that less discerning gastronomes may relish such culinary complexity. Regrettably, the guava mimosa failed to impress."

I am upgrading to a three-star rating due to the exceptional quality of the service; however, there was an approximate one-to-one ratio of servers to guests, which warrants some consideration. Despite my positive experience, this establishment appears to be struggling, and several factors contribute to its lackluster performance. Firstly, the prices are exorbitant, and the meager portions do not justify the cost. For instance, burgers, skewers, sandwiches, and salads are priced around $10, while pizzas range from $10 to $15. Moreover, everything is served a la carte, and the entrees consist of merely three appetizer-sized skewers. The appetizers themselves cost around $10, and desserts are priced at $7, with the option to add ice cream for an additional $1. 

In contrast, the burgers are superior to those offered by the Grind, as they remain intact throughout consumption. The fries, priced at $5, were quite satisfactory, while the pork skewers were unremarkable but adequate. The Dorito potato skins were unimpressive, consisting of a lone wedge of cheesy chip embedded in the middle. The cupcake was palatable, yet the chocolate exhibited a slightly grainy texture. The portion size was also rather diminutive. 

In conclusion, while I may return for happy hour to indulge in their burgers, I am unlikely to visit this establishment again for any other reason.

What a little surprise in the heart of Verdun..

We heard of this place through a friend, and having had authentic spectacular Persian food before, I was quite skeptical. However, Parisa did not disappoint!

Their house soup was really something special (minus the random noodles that seemed out of place).

We had the sauteed mushrooms to start - I expected them to be sweeter, but they were quite good!

We then had the lamb (AMAZING) and the chicken drumsticks (not bad) as our main dish.

The service was great, the host was super friendly, and the atmosphere was nice and quiet. 

For a BYOW place, it's definitely a nice place to go. Try it, and definitely do not miss out on the soup! Super good!

After perusing the menu at this establishment on multiple occasions, I decided to partake in their culinary offerings, primarily due to the copious amount of laudatory reviews I had encountered. Upon consuming my meal, I found the flavors to be quite satisfactory, however, my companion did not share my enthusiasm. It is worth mentioning that this restaurant does not possess an air conditioning system, which resulted in a rather uncomfortable dining experience for me, as I was perspiring profusely throughout my visit.

This place is OK, not too flashy, but OK. Our family of 12 called an hour before for reservations on a busy thursday and managed to get great seating without a wait. The waitress was phenomenal, totally on top of her game and didn't batt an eyelash when she kept being sent too and froo by various sections of the table (we tipped her really well). However, the food was slightly above mediocre. My potatoes were overly cooked, and the sausage tasted wrong. My omlette was also tasting strange and was rubbery. So service was wonderful, but the food was meh.

Decent bar, nice patio though it can be loud on E-Wash.  Good place to relax with a nice beer however I was disappointed they did not have more Belgians after being places like Brasserie V.  It would fit well with the decent bars on Willy street, but has the bonus of being porn-shop adjacent.

"The ambiance of this establishment is truly captivating. The interior design exudes an aura of elegance and sophistication, with subtle lighting that creates an atmosphere of refined intimacy. The seating arrangements are ergonomically designed to provide maximum comfort, allowing patrons to unwind and relax in style. The musical selection presented by the disc jockey on the evening in question was diverse and engaging, albeit the volume level was slightly excessive for a venue of this nature, thereby creating a slight hindrance to effective communication between patrons seated at a distance from one another. However, the outdoor seating area provided a tranquil respite from the sonic intensity within, offering ample opportunities for observation and appreciation of the surrounding environment."

I often stop in this place when Im at Tempe Marketplace to get a drink and relax.  They usually have some decent drink specials and they have a nice big bar.  The bartenders usually take a little effort to order from, not really sure why that is, maybe I just have bad luck.

Hmmm I am American and I grew up in the NYC area, so I am fairly confident that I know good Italian food when I taste it.  I am not saying that the food isn't good, but it definitely did not blow me away.  We came here because it was listed as a Top 10 Best Restaurant in Edinburgh, according to The Guardian and I definitely would not rate this in my top 10.

However, with that being said, the service was fantastic.  Our servers were all very friendly and attentive.  The portions here are enormous and we did feel that they mislead us into ordering more food than we needed because we did ask if the starters were big enough to shared and they recommended that we order two.  Both plates were huge and we certainly could have just shared one between the two of us.  Not to mention the entrees were enough for 2-3 people to share.  So come hungry!

Ambiance has a little bit of a corny feel but also reminded me a lot of any Italian spot in suburban New York / New Jersey, in the sense that there was Frank Sinatra playing in the background the entire time and the servers were a little over the top trying to prove their Italian-ness (actual, and not the macho mobster Guido kind we see over here in the States).

"In the previous fortnight, I have visited this establishment on two separate occasions, seeking medical attention for distinct health concerns. Initially, I sustained a fracture of my coccyx (tail bone), owing to my own foolhardy actions. Following a brief waiting period, I received prompt and comprehensive care. Dr. Guy demonstrated proficiency in managing my situation, requesting an immediate radiograph and subsequently discussing my results, available options, and methods of pain relief. One's appreciation for a particular bodily component is often realized only when it becomes injured, leaving one utterly debilitated and experiencing excruciating pain.  

On a separate occasion, I experienced intense, sporadic abdominal pain. Due to its proximity to my residence, I opted to visit this clinic, necessitating urgent medical attention. Presenting with visible signs of distress, including pallor, trembling, and uncontrollable sobbing, I was surprised by the facility's inability to accommodate me due to an excessive patient load. Considering the gravity of my symptoms, it would have been more appropriate for a physician to tend to my needs temporarily, offering some measure of pain alleviation as I awaited transfer to the emergency department.  

Despite the subpar nature of my most recent encounter, I shall continue to seek medical assistance at this location when necessary. However, the aforementioned experience has illuminated the fact that, in extraordinary situations involving a person's health and well-being, this clinic may not be willing to adapt their policies."

I harbor neither acrimony nor ardor towards it. My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather tepid and noncommittal. Initially, my curiosity was piqued by the visually captivating images showcased on Instagram, which inspired me to visit this venue. My expectations were predicated on the assumption that the snow-based offerings would resemble those available at Hawaiian snow-themed eateries, such as Snow Factory or Frost City. Alas, my experience did not quite live up to my expectations.  

In collaboration with my associates, we sampled three distinct flavors - #3, #4, and #5, respectively. However, I was not particularly enamored with the "popping pearls" incorporated into my #5 selection, so I opted to substitute it with a butterfinger variant instead. While the texture of the snow was somewhat reminiscent of a creamy consistency, the flavors left much to be desired in terms of depth and complexity. I had the opportunity to taste a few other options, including taro, green tea, and the mysterious "kuma snow," but unfortunately, they failed to elicit any profound enthusiasm on my part. 

It is my sincere hope that this enterprise will strive to expand its range of flavors, emulating the diverse array offered by Snow Ono, a mobile food truck specializing in shave ice. In particular, I yearn for the return of the beloved horchata flavor. Notwithstanding my underwhelming experience, I must acknowledge that the interior design of this establishment exudes an endearing quality, replete with vibrant colors and playful accents that evoke an unmistakable air of cuteness. This aesthetic, coupled with the potential for Instagram-worthy moments, served as a significant draw for me. 

In conclusion, while my initial visit did not quite meet my expectations, I remain optimistic about the future prospects of this business. With time, I trust that they will continue to refine and enhance their offerings, thereby warranting my return. Moreover, I am eager to introduce additional acquaintances to this venue, thereby facilitating a more comprehensive assessment of their menu items.

I have heard of this place, but never made it over until now.  I was there to support a fundraiser for an elementary school.  What can I say, it looks just like the skating rinks I grew up with in the 80's.  Not sure what kind of improvements have been since.  The evening we were in there the A/C must not have been working because it was hot as heck and smelled like a gym locker room.  But the concession stand prices can't be beat, the music was current and fun, and ALL the skaters, of every age group, looked like they were having a blast!  And you can even bring in your OWN roller blades if you prefer the single row of wheels versus the four wheels.  They even knock a $1 or so off your price.  So as long as you are looking for an old school joint, and not a modern updated place, check it out!

"An establishment that offered a satisfactory ambiance, with a culinary experience that met our expectations. Upon entering, we were greeted by an atmosphere that exuded cleanliness and warmth. Our meal began with the clear egg rolls accompanied by a delectable peanut sauce, a staple dish that we often indulge in when partaking in Vietnamese cuisine. The flavors were adequately represented, without surpassing our expectations. Subsequently, we opted for the combo pho soup, which presented generous proportions and a commendable execution. Although the broth lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, it was reminiscent of fish sauce, mint, and other indispensable components. One might argue that the soup catered to American palates, with a subtle spiciness that left room for personal adjustments. However, for those seeking a more genuine experience, a more robust foundation would be necessary. The menu, though limited, helped avoid the paradox of choice, but we couldn't help but feel that certain Vietnamese delicacies were absent. The staff provided friendly and efficient service, contributing to an overall positive experience. We may consider revisiting this establishment in the future, curious to witness its evolution."

We organized a farewell celebration for a departing colleague at this establishment, and I must admit that the service we received was quite satisfactory, particularly considering the size of our group, which consisted of 16 individuals and one minor. The avocado-based dip, commonly known as guacamole, was quite palatable, and I was particularly fond of the spicy salsa that they offer upon request. However, the fruit-based alcoholic beverage known as sangria was excessively sweetened, although the house margarita served on the rocks was somewhat more agreeable. The culinary offerings were rather unremarkable; I consumed some uninspired chicken enchiladas that, while not necessarily unpalatable, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Nonetheless, my most enjoyable experience of the evening was visiting the Trader Joe's store located within the same retail complex after our meal.

"The panoramic vista is utterly breathtaking, encompassing a full 360 degrees of unobstructed visual splendor. The atmosphere is decidedly relaxed, with a DJ spinning an eclectic mix of predominantly top 40 and EDM tracks through the sound system on Fridays. However, the late happy hour is restricted to culinary offerings, which serves as a significant factor in the deduction of several stars from the establishment's overall rating. Specifically, the buns accompanying the sliders were excessively firm, possessing sufficient force to shatter glass upon impact, while the calamari exhibited a regrettable lack of texture, likely due to being reheated via microwave for the duration of the happy hour period. Furthermore, the waitstaff displayed a languid approach to customer service, taking an inordinate amount of time to attend to our needs. In fact, it would have been faster to descend to ground level, purchase beverages at a nearby retailer, and then ascend once more to the 107th floor than to await the tardy arrival of our order. Despite these shortcomings, the venue possesses considerable potential, necessitating merely a superficial refurbishment in select areas to elevate its status to the next level."

The people here are super friendly and nice. Yhe reason I gave only three stars is one their liquid flavors was missing somethin.  I think if they remixed a few  flavors it would be a little better. And the second reason is that their liquid is pricey. Like 21 bucks for one bottle.

Heard A LOT of good things about this place but somehow I don't seem what all the good rants about this place where. I came with high expectations due to the fact that friends and colleagues but they have come to disappoint me in Las Vegas. We came around 1 so it was considered to be the brunch time. It was majority breakfast food with some salads, and other lunch options. \nBut what I ca say was good was their chicken wings, saian chow meain and fried rie, the alfredo pasta, and the calamari skewer. Everything else was just plain jane to my eyes and my stomach. All my friends know that i'm a huge dessert fanatic so I went big on the dessert bar, but I only find just a mere of the plates appealing and taste worthy. The chocolate dipped strawberries, cheesecake and the thai ice cream were my favorites out of my whole plate! THE THAI TEA ICE CREAM IS THE ONLY REASON WHY I GAVE THEM AN EXTRA STAR! IT is a must try for all my thai tea lovers out there! \nJust your average buffet for about $30 a person with a okay food, with an exception of a great dessert which was in fact the thai tea ice cream!

"It is with a profound sense of regret and disappointment that we have been compelled to precipitously shutter the doors of our esteemed establishment, the venerable Jim's Joint, a culinary bastion that has long been a cherished fixture in this community and a veritable haven for those who crave delectable comestibles and convivial ambiance. Lamentably, sundry factors, including an unforeseen downturn in trade and an increasingly competitive market, have coalesced to render the continued operation of our beloved eatery financially untenable. We extend our sincerest apologies to our loyal clientele for any inconvenience this closure may engender and fervently hope that they will understand the necessity that has impelled us to take this drastic measure. In conclusion, we bid a fond adieu to Jim's Joint, a venue that shall forever hold a special place in our hearts and memories."

"A pleasant and hygienic smorgasbord, proffering an abundance of accommodations for patrons. Although I did not object to the tariff of thirteen dollars per individual, my satisfaction was somewhat diminished upon discovering that an extensive array of porcine delicacies constituted a significant portion of the offerings. As I am not particularly enamored with swinish cuisine, I might opt to expend my resources elsewhere in the future, perhaps at Buffet@asia, where a greater diversity of options, including an increased emphasis on seafood and Mongolian barbecue, is available."

My wife and I were roaming the industrial and business park area of Phoenix looking for a decent bite to eat, preferably Mexican food. We finally stumbled upon a set of about five Mexican eateries. We decided on Salsitas, which seems to be a chain in the Valley of The Sun.

I wished that the woman had done a better job of speaking and understanding English. The food order was correct, and plentiful, not to mention cheap, but we had specifically asked for forks and were not given any. I had to go to our hotel's front deck and beg the clerk for a couple of plastic forks. 

The burrito was huge and very tasty. I had a couple of Grilled Chicken mini-tacos, and while they were pretty good, they were nothing special and I even found a few pieces of gristle. My wife had a chicken burrito and said it was huge and very good. She could not finish it. They also gave us some hot carrots so that scored well with her.

Ten bucks for all of that, including four salsas and sour cream. Not bad, but I'd like to try more.

It is an acceptable venue, albeit one that I would not have chosen to visit had we not been extended an invitation accompanied by a reserved table. The diminutive size of the establishment, while potentially charming, was unfortunately exacerbated by the presence of a substantial number of patrons, creating an atmosphere akin to that of a crowded subway car in China or New York City. Notwithstanding the cramped conditions, I must admit that the personal hygiene of the clientele was satisfactory, in contrast to the malodorous ambiance often associated with public transportation in urban centers. A plethora of ostensibly synthetic, juvenile females were conspicuously present, rendering the environment somewhat unsettling for a solitary, relatively youthful individual such as myself (being merely 27 years of age). 
  The beverages served at this establishment are quite costly; I opted to procure three shots for our group, as I felt no compulsion to emulate the behavior of certain metrosexual individuals who insist on purchasing drinks for others. Furthermore, I am financially capable of treating myself. However, upon perusing the bill, I was taken aback by the exorbitant price of $36 for a mere three shots. In light of this, I felt compelled to remark on the receipt that "I ain't no rich bitch," and I apologize for any offense caused to the bartender. Nonetheless, considering the steep prices, I believe it is essential to either consume alcoholic beverages liberally before arriving or to accompany someone possessing a platinum credit card, lest one wishes to incur financial hardship. Despite the extravagant costs, the experience remains moderately enjoyable.

This is your perfect place to bring someone after going out.
Instead of going to macdonald or some fast food joint this place is cheaper,healthier and quicker than any fast food store.
Plus you can grab something for breakfast the next day.
No matter what time i go i always see people baking fresh bagel.
I'm more of a conservative guy so i usually take sesame bagel or butter bagel.
Hope this help,

Cheers,

Eric Van Nguyen

As Demetria so astutely observed, this establishment tends to be somewhat inconsistent in the quality of its offerings, with a tendency towards both excellence and disappointment. For optimal culinary experiences, it is advisable to arrive promptly, as the most delectable items often disappear rapidly. The fried chicken, when cooked to perfection, is undoubtedly a highlight, although it occasionally suffers from overcooking or dryness. The six-cheese spaghetti is also a commendable option, but its quality can vary depending on the preparation method. The abundance of sides offers numerous choices, including mac-n-cheese, which, much like the aforementioned chicken and spaghetti, may occasionally be overcooked, resulting in a less than satisfactory dining experience. However, the blackeyed peas and cornbread consistently impress, and their lemonade, arguably the finest in Charlotte, has garnered high praise. A word of caution regarding the volunteers who handle beverage refills: they are renowned for their warmth and generosity, and a adept diner may even secure an additional portion of mac-n-cheese through skillful banter. It is essential to display gratitude via a gratuity at the register. Fare thee well, my friend.

"Cautionary statement: This evaluation is predominantly grounded on the parameters of service and informational proficiency, rather than culinary offerings. We visited this establishment during happy hour and, while intending to confer four stars, a deduction of one star was necessitated due to the absence of communication regarding seating arrangements for said happy hour. Specifically, we were not apprised of the fact that happy hour seating was exclusive to the bar and adjacent bench. Furthermore, our ignorance was not alleviated by inquiring about the protocol, as we were informed to occupy any vacant seat of our preference. Notably, by the time of our departure, a sole couple remained, and they too were oblivious to the proper seating arrangement, thereby resulting in their failure to capitalize on the discounted prices.  

Our culinary experience was satisfactory, albeit not exceptional, with a few notable exceptions. The red sangria was unremarkable, while the lamb, though flavorsome, was diminutive and overpriced. The croquettes were uninspired, whereas the Patatas Bravas, essentially roasted potatoes enrobed in a tomato-based sauce, was straightforward yet gratifying. The total cost of our repast, excluding gratuity, approximated $60, with an additional $20 expended unnecessarily due to our unawareness of the happy hour stipulations. A comprehensive examination of the menu revealed that several items we ordered were available at a reduced rate had we been seated at the bar."

This place is beautiful inside. I really enjoyed the process of watching the owners transform this great piece of historic modern architecture into something a lot of people could enjoy. 

The other location is cool too, sans the DB scene. I found this location to have scary parking, but good valet service. 

The service was good on my Friday 3pm visit. Was there to celebrate a friends birthday. We had some of the apps (The Trifecta, Double Down, and Crabmeat and Artichoke Dip) and they were good. The waitress was always coming by to check on us and even told us when happy hour started. 

You could tell it was getting close to 5pm. The place was a mad house with 40 something dudes trolling for a place to sit all sweaty from a golf outing. The place is chill and there seemed to be no pretencious DB's. Sure there is a healthy mix of an older crowd, but there was a good mix of younger groups too. 

Good amount of TVs so there is always something to watch. It was kind of noisy near the enclosed patio, but we were at a table being loud anyways. There is alot of room to move and enjoy the space, and not to be bumped into. I have only visited just once for a Friday happy hour, stay tuned for a dinner visit.

I would give The Green Owl 4-5 stars for their food, but unfortunately their service really knocks them down. I came here with my boyfriend last week. After we were seated, it took us a little while to flag down our waitress so that we could order. We split an order of crabby cakes; my boyfriend ordered a bowl of chili with sour cream and cornbread, and I ordered the "meatball" sub with kale chips as a side. The crabby cakes came out very quickly, and they were covered with a delicious creamy sauce. We instantly devoured them. My boyfriend is a meat-eating tofu hater, and even he enjoyed these. Upon bringing out the crabby cakes, our waitress told us that our entrees should be out "very soon."

Our food didn't arrive for another 40 minutes, and our waitress never stopped by to assure us that it was on its way or to explain what was causing the delay. Oh well. The food, once it did get to our table, was delicious. My sandwich was piping hot, the bread roll was crispy, and the eggplant meatballs held up well in the sandwich (they weren't mushy) and were flavorful.

I would've liked to try a dessert, but $6 for an average sized portion was a little too steep. 

I will probably come back to the Green Owl. Even though the service is lacking, there are so many more items on the menu I'd like to try!

the food was alright but definitely cost more than it should.  we went for a quick lunch and the service was alright too but the food was not up to par with your typical vegas food.  btw don't get the kim chee, not good.

Came here because Oregano's was packed on a Saturday night.  I wonder how many of their customers are in the same boat.  I was initially craving Mexican food anyway, so I didn't care.  

The service is awesome, the beer was so cold it was almost icy (read: awesome) and the salsa is yummy yummy.  I ordered the specialty chimichanga and my mom got rolled tacos.  The plates were hu-hu-hu-huge.  And can I just say that cream cheese makes everything better, especially chimichangas.  YUM.  

Not the best Mexican joint I have ever been to, but definitely decent enough to visit again (for the locals).

I attended an evening dedicated to the hip-hop genre, but unfortunately, the DJ's playlist did not align with my expectations, as the majority of the tracks he played did not belong to the hip-hop category. Despite this disappointment, I managed to have an enjoyable experience, owing to the lively atmosphere and the opportunity to socialize with other attendees.

This sushi restaurant has fresh fish and is the best I've found for a reasonable price in the valley (This coming from an east coast foodie who LOVES sushi.) However, the service is bad more often than it is good and NEVER go here in a hurry. I've never made it out of there in less than an hour. Once I went in there and asked for an itemized check, it took them 25 minutes to bring the check back AND it still wasnt itemized. In fact, I still don't know what it was. I love their sushi but its about time for me to find a new sushi restaurant after how many times I've had waitresses be rude and even ignore me. \n\nTheir redeeming quality that kept me coming back so long was their happy hour prices Sunday-Thursday. Its a lot of sushi for a small cost. So if you have plenty of time and don't mind a bad waiter or two check it out!

"A satisfactory retail establishment with accommodating personnel, albeit at slightly elevated price points compared to alternative stores. A staff member suggested an appropriate collar for our canine companion, which effectively addressed its tendency to pull on the leash. The atmosphere is welcoming, and the extensive array of products catering to diverse animal needs is impressive. Although the pricing may be perceived as marginally steep, it remains reasonable. However, it is advisable to avoid engaging with Banfield, as their services are associated with costly and unnecessary treatments, according to the experiences of my aunt and ourselves. Their aggressive sales tactics and pressure to procure additional services beyond what is necessary or desired are concerning. Canceling their plans requires persistence, and the purported savings often include substantial costs for services that many individuals would not typically purchase. Instead, consider visiting this store for your pet's exercise needs during the summer months, acquiring food, litter, and other essentials while keeping an eye out for discounted prices. Additionally, you may wish to support the partnered pet rescue organization or treat your pet to a special item."

"-Note* Evaluation pertains solely to gaming/retail/aquatic facilities. Neither extreme fondness nor animosity is harbored towards this establishment. 

Retail: A newly refurbished shopping area has been unveiled, presenting an inviting ambiance and pristine appearance. An exclusive interest in entering the Urban Outfitters store is evident. 
Aquatic: The wave pool embodies a remarkable attraction, boasting a unique blend of sand and surf. A thoroughly enjoyable experience is ensured, further complemented by an optimal number of patrons. 
Gaming: A predictable atmosphere prevails, mirroring that of its Las Vegas counterparts. Appreciation is expressed toward the tasteful installation of chandeliers above, enhancing the overall ambiance. 

Conclusion: A well-maintained casino, with an adequate level of cleanliness, is presented. A neutral sentiment is harbored towards this venue, neither favoring nor avoiding visits. Numerous exceptional dining options are offered, complemented by the presence of the House of Blues. Suitable for families, this resort grants access to the Shark Reef aquarium within its premises."

Nice place to take the parents in Vegas... good food, although a bit on the pricey side. Then again, Vegas isn't the place to start scrimping on pennies. The menu had an interesting variety of selections, but the food didn't taste outstandingly exotic. Just your basic American breakfast with a twist here or there. Service was solid and we were seated fairly quickly (although I noticed a growing line right around the peak time for brunch).

"While the interior may benefit from some modernization, the culinary offerings are undeniably satisfactory. However, I find it somewhat problematic to be charged for supplementary hash browns and an English muffin, particularly when the portion size has diminished, resulting in a higher cost for a relatively reduced quantity of sustenance. Notwithstanding, US Egg remains a reliable establishment, albeit one that may not necessarily warrant being showcased to others as a prime dining destination."

The Chilenita they have the best empanada in town. It's a great place to take out or sit down for lunch. The staff is friendly. The food is so good. The price is affordable. There no other place that has 13 different empanada's to choose from. I love the Chilenita.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are merely adequate, with sandwiches priced between $8 and $10. My dining companion and I opted for a burger augmented with pork barbecue and onion straws, accompanied by an iced tea, which totaled approximately $14. It is my opinion that the prices at this venue are slightly elevated, particularly during the luncheon hour. Notwithstanding, the sole bartender/waitress managed the throng of patrons, numbering around 20 individuals, with proficiency. The eatery boasts numerous televisions, featuring sports and trivia programs, which likely contribute to its popularity. The interior of the restaurant was teeming with customers, which may be attributed to its advantageous position within the USX building."

We visited Red Lobster for lunch at approximately 2:00 PM, and although the establishment was moderately occupied, we were promptly accommodated with a table.  All three of us opted for the Endless Shrimp promotion, which offered an assortment of diverse flavors.  While the dishes were undoubtedly palatable, they failed to elicit any extraordinary praise or excitement.  The service, though not characterized by excessive haste, did not hinder our dining experience.  The staff members exhibited unwavering politeness and cordiality throughout our visit.  At a cost of $57.00 for three lunch specials, the total surpassed my customary expenditure in a locality renowned for its affordable cuisine.  Nonetheless, the charge was not entirely unexpected given the restaurant's reputation for quality seafood.  Ultimately, our dining experience merited a rating of "A-OK," denoting a satisfactory and enjoyable meal.

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment are generally of superior quality, my recent dining experience was marred by a number of unfortunate incidents that detracted from my overall satisfaction. Specifically, my pork kebab contained an excessive amount of cartilaginous material, which made it difficult to consume with any degree of pleasure. Furthermore, I was forced to wait an inordinate amount of time for both my beverage and dipping sauce, which only served to exacerbate my frustration. In light of these issues, I would suggest that patrons who value a seamless dining experience may wish to consider alternative options."
The locations in phoenix have chicken we can add to our meal. This location does not. We drove an extra 10 minutes to get here  to find out they don't have chicken was not a pleasant surprise.

Food is good, service is bad.  Have been here twice...both times our order was screwed up.  The second time we received no apology.  Wait staff is reactive instead of proactive.  Food is decent but expect more for the money.  I really wanted to like this place but I have been given too many reasons to go elsewhere.

"Culinary experiences at this establishment are distinctive and flavorsome, particularly the supreme grilled cheese sandwich. However, the quality of service is subpar, as evidenced by the lackadaisical demeanor of the staff, who appear to be preoccupied with personal conversations rather than attending to the needs of the sparse clientele. Despite the satisfying culinary outcome, the overall dining experience is marred by the perception that the staff seemingly lacks vigilance and dedication to providing an optimal customer experience. Furthermore, it appears that management has made some questionable decisions regarding operational hours, which may potentially impact the longevity of the business. Nonetheless, the pricing strategy for pool play during promotional periods remains attractive."

my best friends girlfriend came for a visit from austin, being an architecture major, this was a place we obviously had to go.\n\nbeing there was obviously amazing... here's my beef... a tour was between $30-$80, seriously.  there was no way we could afford this obnoxious fee so we walked around the house and checked out the gift shop. we were pleased with this, but pretty disappointed not to take the tour.

This culinary establishment constitutes one of our most cherished destinations for a brief gastronomic interlude, especially when we possess Aria resort credits that necessitate expenditure. My personal predilection at this venue formerly consisted of procuring an assortment of baked items and chocolates for my acquaintances and loved ones back home (I have always been particularly fond of the bear claw). However, I have recently opted to sample their crepes, which I find quite delectable. We devoured a savory crepe filled with ham, cheese, and sauteed mushrooms, accompanied by a side dish consisting of leafy greens and diminutive tomatoes. Our preferred dessert crepe contains a filling of vanilla custard cream, topped with a mixture of berries in the form of a rich sauce. The queues at this eatery tend to be rather lengthy whenever I visit, yet the staff manages to process the clientele with remarkable efficiency. Although the prices may be considered somewhat elevated, the quality of the cuisine and the overall experience justify the cost.

Can't understand why this place is always so packed. Well actually, the sound system is probably the best out of any club on mill. So that part I liked. There is room to breathe once you make it to the pool tables, but it's a battle to get there in the first place. There is a good amount of tables. Overall, so so. But I'll visit another time for further review.
Very colorful, especially if you want to smoke weed surrounded by a bunch of weirdos playing African drums...other than that it is rather boring

After perusing an array of favorable critiques, my spouse and I elected to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment, primarily due to her inclination towards consumng Indian cuisine.  This eatery does not boast an extensive capacity, and its format is predicated upon a buffet-style service.  The Mother's Day special included a delectable mango lassi and a dolsa, which consists of a rolled-up pancake containing a lentil filling. 
  The chilled bar presented an assortment of various chutneys, a salad, some fruit, and additional sauces.  Additionally, there were three distinct types of soup available: a tomato soup with a tangy flavor profile, a lentil-based soup, and a piquant soup. 
  This restaurant showcases a diverse array of traditional Indian dishes.  The goat curry particularly stood out to my taste buds, as the meat was tender and easily detached from the bone, complemented by a richly flavored curry sauce.  Furthermore, the tandoori chicken was cooked to perfection, retaining its natural moisture and avoiding the common pitfall of dryness often associated with this dish at other establishments.  The paneer sag (a spinach and cheese dish) also demonstrated notable quality. 
  Although vegetarian options were present, my carnivorous inclinations led me to ignore them.  Ultimately, this dining experience provided me with a satisfying introduction to Indian cuisine without overwhelming my palate with excessively spicy fare, thereby solidifying this restaurant's standing as a respectable venue in my opinion.

A lot of these reviews made me laugh because I'm not quite sure what people were expecting - it's FAST FOOD, (albeit pricy fast food)lol! I had a Groupon so my friends and I went all out so that we could get a variety of things.  I thought the staff here was really friendly, even bringing food to our table.  The shakes are amazing and I love all the topping options!  The veggie burger is tasty and my friends devoured their beef burgers.  Although the curly fries are the most popular, we decided the skinny fries are the best. Thumbs up!

"UltraStar, a novel entrant into the Phoenix region's entertainment landscape, boasts an expansive and welcoming lobby reminiscent of the cavernous interior of an aircraft hangar, thereby exuding an unmistakable aura of corporate sophistication that permeates every facet of the customer experience. Such a meticulously designed ambiance seems to emanate the deliberate, collective wisdom of a committee, fostering an atmosphere that, while undoubtedly well-coordinated, may strike some visitors as slightly sterile or lacking in organic character. Furthermore, the presence of a concession stand and gourmet coffee bar may evoke mirth or incredulity among European patrons who are accustomed to more refined and nuanced cinematic experiences. In terms of seating, the designated area appears decidedly utilitarian and unremarkable, offering scant opportunities for lingering or socializing, and thus may be perceived as somewhat drab or uninviting. However, the theatre itself, while hardly exceptional, managed to deliver a satisfactory viewing experience punctually, which suggests that the UltraStar management might benefit from familiarizing themselves with the operational strategies and best practices employed by Harkins theatres, in order to enhance their overall performance and elevate the quality of their services."

"Satisfactory victuals and the customary servers are occupied but vigilant.  The greenery-based dishes are palatable, yet caution is advised regarding their preparation time, as they tend to require an equally prolonged duration, if not more, compared to other menu items to arrive at your table.  The poultry strips are delectable, and reports suggest that the wraps are exceptional. 

Beyond that, the remaining options are passable but not remarkable.  The potato-based soup is quite tasty, but avoid ordering it with excessive frequency, as it is featured as the daily special approximately 90% of the time. 

A suitable alternative when seeking a respite from fast food in the central business district or desiring something beyond a simple sandwich."

While the restaurant itself was nice and the staff was also very nice the food was nothing that I can say was truly amazing. We were expecting a very 5 star experience when it came to the food and we were surprised when the food came out just a few minutes after we ordered. Most everyone in our party thought the food was average, nothing to right home about. We have a restaurant near us called Frida Mexican Restaurant in Glendale,CA and there food is much much better. On the bright side I did order the Nachos and this seem to be the hit on the table So much so that everyone started munching away at my food \n\nSo heres the deal for me, I am always looking for amazing Mexican Food, something above and beyond what I can expect living in Los Angeles. Diego was not it for me, Great looking place, Friendly Staff, with So-So Food.

Let me start by saying that I LOVE the food and flavor combinations at Layers. Also on the fabulous list is that it's organic :). I have been a fan since this new location opened. However, (and this is why I rated only 3 stars, they used to be 5 in my book) I have been disappointed the last few visits. The baked goods remain awesome, but the \"kitchen\" food isn't as amazing these days. Last time, the pasta has far too much oil which knocked off the entire dish. This time I went for the meatloaf sandwich, The Conservative, and while the flavor combo of yummy meatloaf and carmelized onions snuggled together in a panini were a hit - the presentation was a mess. The bread was so broken and soggy that it really had no business being called a sandwich because I could not pick it up. Had to eat with a fork and knife. I've had this sandwich, or a similar one in the past (when the store opened) and had much more success in getting it from the plate to my mouth in a ladylike fashion.  Maybe the bread was different?  Possibly the chef was different?  Something has changed....\nTo clarify, I would not discourage anyone from ordering anything off the menu, but I just know that Layers can do better than I have recently experienced.  I hope that they will strive for their best because they are one of my favorites!

Make sure they know if u r in a hurry.  Was disappointed bc I called ahead and gave very specific directions (Please make sure the 3 dozen bialy's are in plastic bags bc I need to pack them in my suitcase.  Unfortunately, they were not and I had to make the taxi wait...  costing me more money.  UGH!  In the long run, it ended up costing $72 for 39 bialys (including taxi)

Been here twice... the selection seemed about the same... but not so sure. 
It's like walking into an aunt's house. The workers there are friendly, speak Tagalog to you right off the bat, even if you don't speak it (good or bad? Hmmm) and make sure you're ok for the most part.
I like the pork gisantes they have, and the pancit is pretty tasty! At $7.99/ person there's not much to complain about. They also sell other goodies and snacks at the register.
Probably will be back with the fam soon.

Honorable mentions:
Pusit
Diniguan (dinardaraan)

Ohh, parking is somewhat odd. One way only, so make sure you take the correct entrance! Although the lot is small, I usually find parking right away!

"Upon perusing Yelp in pursuit of a novel culinary experience, I chanced upon this establishment and decided to pay it a visit. Upon entering, I was struck by the diverse array of fresh, authentic Poke available, which exceeded my expectations and piqued my interest. Furthermore, I appreciated the opportunity to sample the various options prior to making a purchase, which allowed me to make an informed decision. Eventually, I opted for the spicy avocado ahi, which proved to be a satisfying choice, boasting a subtle yet palpable level of spiciness that complemented the dish without overpowering it. Indeed, this meal served as the sole sustenance for my midday repast, and I must say that I was thoroughly pleased with my decision to patronize this unassuming eatery. Despite its unpretentious appearance, this venue offers a truly delightful Poke experience that is not to be missed."

After a day at the park I was really hungry and not in the mood for the usual fare on East blvd. so I trekked up to Thai Taste. Walking inside it was the usual traditional Thai decor. The restaurant was small and cozy, but I imagine if I had went at a busier time it might have just felt crowded.

The menu is laid out so you pick your entrée and combo it with choice of meat. I went for the green curry with chicken. Usually when I have green curry it has a decent kick to it due to the paste being made from green chilies and balances out the sweetness of the coconut. This green curry while pretty aromatic seriously lacked some much needed heat. After reading some reviews on here though I'll probably try it again and request it extra hot.

The prices are pretty reasonable and the service is attentive enough to keep my water glass full which is much appreciated! My meal arrived in a very timely manner and I left full and happy. Probably one of the better Thai places I've been to in Charlotte, I'll have to come back and try out their Pad Thai along with a hopefully spicier green curry.
What can I say it's The House of Blues, if you've seen one you've seen them all. mostly standing room unless you pay for bottle service or the balcony is open. Good sound I have no complaints.

"While it is not my customary practice to compose a review for an establishment such as Pizza Hut, nor would I typically bother to check in on Yelp, I felt compelled to offer a testimonial for the carry-out location I intermittently patronize, as recent unfavorable assessments have prompted me to express my gratitude for the staff's consistent display of kindness and dedication to providing quality service despite the constraints imposed by the franchise's parameters, thereby warranting a positive endorsement of three stars, the maximum rating permissible by law for a Pizza Hut."

I've used this restaurant for large dinner parties that were held in their private dining room and they have all been A+ experiences.   This time I made a reservation for 2 in the dining room for a happy birthday dinner.  The restaurant was full and busy and we were seated upon arrival.  Our drink orders were taken promptly but then we waited....

Our waitress took our salad and entree orders and the salad arrived pretty quickly.  She was also assigned to a 10 top table that the chef/owner was hosting so we were ignored by her for the rest of dinner.  We had to flag down the bus person for water refills, asked for additional bread while we waited for our entrees, another request for water refills and a final request for the check.  

The food was okay - I had angel hair with tomato sauce and husband had gnocchi.  Both were good portions and served steaming hot.

D'abord, le bouquet d'\u00e9pices fait acte de pr\u00e9sence. On se souvient de son bouillon, adroitement appr\u00e9ci\u00e9 de clous de girofle, de badianes, de graines de coriandre et de cardamomes. Diverses variantes sur le m\u00eame th\u00e8me. Les Classiques sont plut\u00f4t impersonnelles avec des coupes de viande plus propres et immacul\u00e9es. Les Aventuriers  se prononcent d'une anatomie bovine moins pr\u00e9venante, flancs gras et tripes croustillantes. Si le d\u00e9faut d'asepsie vous emmerde, s'abstenir de la toilette. Je soustrais  une \u00e9toile pour cette raison.

"The culinary experience afforded by the consumption of pasta at this establishment was satisfactory, however, the use of Hershey's syrup as a topping for the tiramisu dessert raised concerns regarding the authenticity and credibility of the restaurant's claims to be an Italian eatery, thereby eliciting a sense of skepticism and incredulity in this patron."

I was impelled to visit this establishment due to the fact that I was the fortunate recipient of a complimentary voucher, courtesy of a radio station contest, and I must admit that I would not have opted to partake in this culinary experience had it not been offered gratis.

Upon perusing the menu, I noticed that there was a sampler entre/mix grill option available for a mere $70, which included an assortment of delectable cuts, specifically filet, kobe shirt, and a New York cut. Although the Kobe shirt was undoubtedly palatable, it is worth mentioning that I have yet to encounter a less-than-satisfactory cut of Kobe beef, thus rendering its quality somewhat predictable.

Furthermore, I opted to sample their trio of mashed potatoes, which featured an array of distinct flavors, including the tantalizing truffle and lobster variety. While these potatoes were indeed quite delectable, I cannot help but feel that they fell short of exceptional.

In conclusion, taking into account the multitude of superior dining options available, I fear that I would not consider returning to this particular restaurant, despite the occasional availability of complimentary vouchers.

"Capriotti's captivating culinary creations have captured my gastronomical inclinations, albeit at an exorbitant expense. Lamentably, their menu lacks the healthier whole wheat bread option, rendering them somewhat antiquated in comparison to their competitors, such as Firehouse Subs, Subway, Port of Subs, Quiznos, et cetera. It is my fervent hope that Capriotti's will remedy this oversight by introducing whole wheat French bread to their offerings, thereby elevating both their nutritional value and contemporary appeal."

"The Mass Transit District (MTD) offers an effective solution for traversing the campus during inclement weather conditions, but it's essential to be cognizant of the fact that the buses tend to operate with a degree of tardiness, hence it's advisable to select a bus that will arrive at your desired destination a few minutes prior to the scheduled time, thereby ensuring a timely arrival. Moreover, it's worth mentioning that MTD buses are complimentary for students, which serves as an added convenience."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."  We have visited this establishment on multiple occasions, and unfortunately, our expectations have not been met.  

The appetizer platter was mediocre, with the mozzarella being the sole redeeming factor.  The bruschetta was overpowered by an excessive amount of pesto, rendering the flavor of the bread insignificant, while the calamari lacked the desired crispiness.  The chicken marsala was unimpressive, with the grilled taste overshadowing the marsala sauce.  The mashed potatoes were satisfactory, but they failed to compensate for the shortcomings of the dish.   It is evident that our preference for pasta at Carrabba's remains unwavering.  

The quality of service, however, has consistently met our expectations.

"WU DINNAE NEED THEM INGLISH! WU CUN LOOK EFTER WURSEL BUCOZ  WUR A NATION!!!!"

"FFFFRRREEEEEDDDOOOOOOMMMMMMM!!!!!!!!!!!!"

The cultural cringe is alive and well.

We opted to patronize Einstein for our morning repast, despite the considerable queue that had formed outside, stretching beyond the entrance and into the street, owing to the popularity of this establishment among the local denizens. It being just shy of 9 am on a tranquil Sunday morning, we pondered the feasibility of seeking sustenance elsewhere, but ultimately elected to endure the delay, which, much to our relief, proved to be relatively brief. Following a mere thirteen minute interval, during which we placed our order and tendered payment, we were able to secure a table in the spacious dining area, whereupon our culinary selections were promptly prepared and presented to us, requiring but a scant four additional minutes of waiting. My personal preference was for the flavorful applewood bacon and cheddar cheese-adorned egg sandwich, served upon a plain bagel, which, while perhaps a tad overpriced in relation to its constituent elements, was nonetheless thoroughly enjoyable and satisfying.

I attended a gathering at this establishment, whereupon our group consisted of approximately twenty individuals, thereby enabling me to sample an array of culinary offerings. While some selections proved to be delectable, others unfortunately did not meet my expectations. However, I must commend them for offering an assortment of European beverages, which undoubtedly contributed to the ambiance. Unfortunately, the arrival of our repast was delayed significantly, despite our reservation being made well in advance. It appeared that the family-operated enterprise was unprepared to accommodate such a sizable assembly. Nonetheless, it is gratifying to note that our patronage supported a local family business, as the proprietors, including both parents and their offspring, were actively involved in the culinary and hospitality aspects of the operation.

First time coming here today and it's a great place if you want something to satisfy your boba craving without having to drive to Chinatown. I got the boba milk tea with jelly which tasted very similar to volcano tea so I was happy with it, my bf got the taro smoothie which he said wasn't good at all. So I guess it really just depends on what you get and I had to dock off points because there isn't much of a selection as other stores and the atmosphere. Inside of the store is small, plain, and very boring. Kinda makes you feel like ordering and getting out, not a place to hang or relax. Wish they also sold snacks.

I was very excited about playing golf here since its firmly entrenched in one of the more exclusive housing areas in Summerlin called The Ridges.  I was here for a fundraiser so we played shotgun.  

The golf course is billed as Jack Nicklaus' best holes in one round.  I can definitely see the potential but this time around, I don't think the potential was actualized.  Granted it was over 100 degrees but the course was very dry and the greens spotty.  It was definitely punched recently but wasn't healing as well as it should.

Checked out the club house to see if there's anything to purchase but the guy working at the counter looked right at me then looked away.  I do not expect to be pampered but a hello would be nice.  Needless to say, I didn't buy anything.

Again, every hole has the potential to be phenomenal with great views of all the beautiful homes as well as views of he strip on a couple of holes.  Unfortunately, I think I caught it during a bad stretch.  I will be back and re-review if I find the experience to be different.

Salads are delicious there jumbo shrimps go perfect on top! There unique dressings to choose from Lime infused ranch was amazing! \n\nCons- Poor customer Service, not helpful when it comes to being undecided or asking for their recommendations

I have had the privilege of visiting the iconic city of New York, where I had the opportunity to indulge in a slice of their world-renowned pizza. Unfortunately, my experience with the pizza at this establishment fell short of my expectations, as it failed to live up to the standards set by its authentic New York-style counterpart. Despite the ambiance and quality of service being satisfactory, I regret to say that I do not foresee myself returning to this venue in the future.

"It is highly unlikely that I would have had my vehicle's oil changed with such regularity were it not for this particular establishment. The convenience of having a single location where both an oil change and a car wash can be obtained has proven to be an invaluable resource. Additionally, the presence of a Wendy's restaurant in close proximity allows for the satisfying of hunger pangs while awaiting completion of the necessary maintenance tasks. Of late, the scope of services provided by this enterprise has been expanded to encompass various other automotive needs, including replacement of headlights and drive belts. My most recent visit entailed an oil change, installation of a new air filter, and a car wash, all for the eminently reasonable sum of $47, inclusive of tax. It is worth noting that a basic car wash is available for a mere $3.99, while a more comprehensive version, dubbed the "super wash," can be had for $7.99. While I have never opted for anything beyond the basic package, I must admit that I have occasionally discovered minor oversights on the part of the service personnel. Nonetheless, the convenience of having all these tasks addressed in a single location cannot be overstated. Furthermore, this establishment offers a 48-hour guarantee on their car washes, which provides an added measure of assurance. Upon completion of any work, customers are presented with a limited-time discount coupon for future services, constituting an additional perk."

John's place is a good local bar. The decor is pleasing and clean. The food is average. You can order from the Mario's Pizza menu (Which is attached via a hallway) or order from a limited bar menu. I actually enjoy their sliders (chicken or cheese burger). Really tasty. There is usually some type of drink special and enough TV's to get a good view of whatever game happens to be on. Service is good although can be spotty at times. Pretty much a regular crowd via many of the neighborhoods around the area. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here but it is a convenient and nice local pub.

"Prior to departing our accommodations, we partook of a delectable morning repast at Gertrude's, situated within close proximity to the botanical garden featuring an exhibition of Dale Chihuly's works. As we customarily endeavor to explore the botanical gardens of the cities we visit, it was quite convenient to have a dining establishment located on the premises. The breakfast offerings were satisfactory, despite my personal reservations regarding the nomenclature'sammie'; the coffee, however, was robust and satisfying. Our sole criticism pertained to the infrequency with which our cups were replenished. We were afforded the opportunity to enjoy our meal on the outdoor patio, which was particularly pleasant given that our journey to this region was motivated, in part, by a desire to escape the inclement weather conditions prevailing in our native locales. The ambiance was tranquil and aesthetically pleasing."

"We recently partook in a culinary excursion to this cozy eatery, and our arrival was met with an arduous queue, which threatened to deter us from our gastronomical pursuits. However, our persistence was rewarded by the hospitable staff's proffering of a delectable tray of lechon kawali (roast pork belly), thereby rekindling our interest in savoring the establishment's offerings. The menu boasted an array of Filipino delicacies, including Filipino-style corned beef and potatoes, as well as oxtail stew (\"kare-kare\"), both of which we indulged in with great relish. The ambiance of the restaurant, nestled within a bustling Chinese plaza, exuded a sense of warmth and familiarity, reflective of the Filipino cultural value of fostering strong connections with one's neighbors, as evidenced by the name of the establishment itself, which translates to \"house-connected.\" The prices, at a reasonable $6.50 for two dishes and rice, only served to further enhance our dining experience."

"The retail establishment boasts an array of luxury items and a sufficient assortment of products, yet, in concurrence with the previous patron's remarks, the personnel would greatly benefit from fundamental instruction in clientele etiquette. Paradoxically, the more mature employees manifest a warm, polite, and accommodating demeanor, whereas their younger counterparts display discourteous conduct, engaging in boisterous personal conversations within earshot of patrons, expressing visible exasperation and impatience, and indulging in disrespectful eye movements or utterly disregarding customers. It is truly perplexing that a business that prides itself on its high-end reputation does not place greater emphasis on instilling corresponding behavioral standards among its staff."

Well, I'm sitting here while my son plays.... Music is so loud you have to shout to communicate.... I asked them to turn the volume down a bit, they did but then turned it back up..... Inappropriate songs come on and staff needs to be told to turn it.... I mean what parent wants their kid listening to a song about a$$ and twerking? Other than these issues (that can definitely be addressed), it's a great place....

"While the Boozery's location may suggest the possibility of an exciting experience, the reality is unfortunately quite disparate, as the bar itself is rather diminutive in size, although it does offer some outdoor seating to compensate for its limited indoor capacity. Despite its modest dimensions, the interior exudes a certain charm and ambiance, yet the cramped quarters somewhat mitigate the potential for an truly enjoyable time. The drink menu is unremarkable, featuring a selection of standard cocktails at prices comparable to those found on Freemont Street ($7-$10), and ultimately, the Boozery fails to distinguish itself from the multitude of other unexceptional downtown bars, offering little reason for enthusiasm or commendation."

I orchestrated a gathering at this venue in collaboration with several female acquaintances for an early evening repast. The edifice housing the establishment is rather diminutive, rendering it easily overlookable, especially for those who are oblivious or momentarily distracted; hence, it is imperative to maintain vigilance lest one becomes disoriented. Furthermore, due to the limited dimensions of the building, parking facilities are somewhat restricted, with only a few spaces available at the forefront and a possibility of additional spaces in the rear, contingent upon their availability. Therefore, it is advisable to harbor minimal expectations regarding the ease of parking.  

Notwithstanding the preceding, the menu proffered by the eatery is relatively uncomplicated, featuring traditional fare such as meatloaf, hamburgers, aquatic delicacies, and salads. However, my culinary experience did not culminate in an exceptional impression, prompting me to select the Veggie Burger and fries. The vegetarian patty was a standard Morning Star offering, thus, failing to elicit astonishment, while the fries accompanying it were merely satisfactory.  

The hospitality we received was indeed commendable, yet I am uncertain whether it would be judicious to accord it precedence for a subsequent visit. Nonetheless, their brunch offerings have garnered positive reviews, thereby warranting a potential future endeavor. We shall defer judgment until a later time.

"The decibel level within the establishment was remarkably high, rendering conversation challenging, albeit suitable for revelers seeking to partake in fermented beverages, sporting events, and grilled culinary delights. Notwithstanding, the selection of artisanal brews was truly exceptional, while the gastronomical offerings, though slightly delayed, were expertly prepared and undeniably savory. Our hospitable server and the proprietor himself extended warm welcomes, and the complementary side dishes, specifically the gravy fries and macaroni and cheese, showcased pronounced flavors. Despite my residence in Glendale, I wouldn't venture across the Valley solely to visit this venue again, however, I would unhesitatingly endorse it to acquaintances residing in close proximity who seek an exhilarating atmosphere to enjoy a football match or two alongside superior quality beverages."

(+)
1. Great location - Located within walking distance to Notre Dame, Old Montreal, Chinatown, Latin Quarters, St. Catherine's, a few arts museums, the metro and a lot of shopping and restaurants.

2. The room was big. Very high ceiling with a king size bed and a small kitchen.

3. Nice and friendly staff. They provided an extra cot with no charge.

4. Free internet - they provide a code to you upon check-in.

5. Free continental breakfast - toast, croissants, cereals, fruits and coffee.

(-)
1. We requested 2 beds and ended up with a room with only one. We went to talk to the front desk and they were out of rooms to switch us to. But they provided the cot at no extra charge.

2. The towels smell. 

3. The parking is $22 a day which is OK. but it has to be valet. If you need something in your car, you have to go through the concierge.

"It is indeed a peculiar circumstance that this establishment has garnered a relatively uncommon three-star rating, and I must admit that my experience at this venue was, in certain aspects, divergent from the conventional buffet encounter; nevertheless, I must emphasize that my culinary expedition at this location was, on the whole, an enjoyable escapade. My nocturnal peregrinations along the famed Las Vegas Strip led me to this eatery, which, upon initial inspection, appeared to offer a diverse array of comestibles that, while perhaps not attaining the lofty standards of haute cuisine, were, nevertheless, palatable and satisfying. A cursory examination of the menu revealed that the crustacean delicacies, particularly the crab legs, were undoubtedly the most exceptional items available, and their quality more than justify the associated tariff of twenty dollars; furthermore, the prime rib, mashed potatoes, and spicy tuna rolls also proved to be delectable alternatives. However, my expectations regarding the salad bar were not entirely fulfilled, as it failed to meet my expectations in terms of both quality and variety; similarly, the assortment of pastries and sweets did not quite live up to my hopes. It is worth mentioning that the ambiance of this establishment exuded a certain kitschy charm, which, given its association with the Imperial Palace, was not altogether unexpected. In conclusion, I would argue that this buffet offers a commendable dining experience, particularly for those who are famished and seeking a diverse selection of edibles at a reasonable price."

I've stayed here twice, and had very different room experiences.  Only one side of the hotel is renovated and that of course makes a huge difference.  My boyfriend and I had a room with a king size bed and it was nicely updated and had a great bathroom.  I booked again with the girls and we had rooms with 2 double beds, very dated, worn furniture, old carpet.  If you're going with friends and don't plan on spending much time in the room then it's a good choice based on location and price.  The other negatives is that you have to pay to use the gym and the pool area is VERY crowded...tough to get a lounge chair.  Gambling is OK...but the drink service is a little slow.
Maybe my expectations were too high - but food was very disappointing.  It was ok - nothing spectacular or noteworthy.  Therefore it was definitely overpriced.  Wait staff was great though.

Just ordered a pizza and wings for delivery. I picked up my pizza before and I got a weird vibe from the staff. They are very unpleasant, thought if I phoned it in I would get a happy tone on the other end.... WRONG! They need to hire delightful people to work the register and take the phone calls. This will be my last time ordering from them until my free pizza coupon is valid lol! Oh and the pizza's not all that bad! Definitely better than Pizza Hut!

Hakkasan is located inside the MGM grand. I was on the GL so we went to the GL line and it was free before 1am, so we had to hurry our asses there! We made it & it was free, thank god! Anywayyys, bouncers were nice and they made our transition inside the club pretty smoothly. Once we got in, I immediately noticed how SMALL it was. The dancefloor was sooooo tiny! :( When I finally made my way over, I could barely move/dance. It was literally body to body ... and this was on a day where there's NO ONE famous dj-ing! So imagine how bad the crowd would get if Tiesto or Hardwell was up there .... I wouldn't wanna be there! \n\nBut that's all I can really say because I got super messed up and I can't remember anything else. Only that I couldn't dance at all because there was no room and the parts where it's kinda open, the security made you move :(

I have been to this particular location for eyebrow threading twice.  On both occasions I walked in without an appointment and was greeting right away.  There was no wait and the desk attendant was very professional.  The brow threading person did an excellent job.  I would recommend that she improve her customer service.  She did not ask me how I would like my brows done or even speak to me at all.  Overall, I would come back again since they did make my brows look great!

"For a smorgasbord, I surmised that this establishment offered a relatively satisfactory culinary experience, with the comestibles being genuinely representative of the authentic Indian gastronomical tradition, and the seasonings and spices being carefully prepared to evoke the distinctive flavors which I have come to associate with genuine Indian cuisine. Notwithstanding my unfamiliarity with a significant portion of the offerings, the variety of dishes available was appreciable, although I must admit that the profusion of flavors ultimately became somewhat indistinguishable from one another, leading me to speculate that in future, I might prefer to patronize a traditional Indian restaurant where I can savor a single dish, such as chicken marsala or curry, in isolation."

"Relatively pricey in comparison to the nearby Gandhi's restaurant, the culinary offerings were satisfactory yet unremarkable, while the atmosphere was somewhat more refined than the typical Indian eatery."

"It is not deceptive to admit that I relished a thoroughly enjoyable experience during my recent visit to this esteemed eatery. The interior design exudes an air of contemporary sophistication, complete with elevated platforms that double as performance areas for scantily-clad dancers to showcase their talents while patrons partake in their culinary indulgences. However, my overall satisfaction was slightly compromised due to a few minor drawbacks. Specifically, the hostesses displayed an excessively stringent demeanor, feigning ignorance of my prior reservation despite the fact that my hotel concierge had already arranged it over the phone. Furthermore, they seemed to be under the impression that they were conferring a favor upon me by accommodating my request, albeit after an extended period of time. In contrast, our server exhibited exceptional proficiency and attentiveness throughout the evening. The cuisine itself was adequate, with the Black Cod appetizer being particularly noteworthy, while the crab cake counterpart fell short of my expectations. The fried shrimp dish was also commendable, and the steak offerings adhered to the established standards associated with the Morton's brand. In conclusion, although my dining experience was generally satisfying, the abundance of exceptional eateries in Las Vegas renders it unlikely that I will return to this specific location in the future."

This is a fun place to eat, but just not my cup of tea.

The service was very good and is what gets it a passing grade.

Unfortunately, the food was very average. Everything was completely over-seasoned, so much so, that i could only eat half the food, and I was starving. Do not get the special hash and the potatoes on the same plate, they are seasoned nearly identically and would require you to drink a gallon of water to even attempt to finish it all. The quality of everything else though is fairly good though and i think this is why it is popular here. Maybe just stick with waffles and pancakes, they did look pretty good.

It is hard to say that i would recommend this place, maybe i would if I knew that person loved over seasoned food. It is a fun place though.

"Having initially been perceived as a mere imitation of Panera, Atlanta Bread has subsequently expanded its menu to include a diverse array of innovative offerings. Upon sampling the Italian vegetable panini on a recent evening, I found the flavors to be palatable, yet the cost was somewhat prohibitive considering the modest serving size. Notwithstanding the complimentary pickle and kettle chips accompanying the dish, I remained slightly unsatisfied. While the ambiance and complimentary wireless internet access are certainly appealing aspects, the quality of service leaves something to be desired. Nevertheless, this establishment remains a viable choice for those seeking a satisfying sandwich experience, although the pasta selections tend to be rather unremarkable."

In a sea of gourmet restaurants sometimes you want something ordinary.
For a cafe, it's not bad. We just wanted something "normal" for a late lunch. Alot of places weren't even open yet, many others had a limited lunch menu. It was Sunday with football games on so, alot of the bar type places were packed.
It really reminded me of Cheesecake Factory. Lots of menu choices. Staff was nice.
I got Fried Chicken with Mashed Potatoes, it wasn't greasy, but it was a bit salty, I've had better, I've had worse. The potatoes were a bit bland, but my salty chicken helped even things out. I ordered a Pear Martini and they were out of the ingredients, so I had a delicious Strawberry Martini. My husband got a Cheeseburger and fries, the fries were good, I didn't try the burger but it looked good, he devoured it, and said it was better than he expected.
I would eat here again if in a pinch, but with so many better restaurants in walking distance, it's doubtful.

This buffet can be considered satisfactory for local patrons, in my opinion. However, if I had to pay for it myself, I might have been more critical since it's merely a mid-range buffet charging over $50 for two individuals. We visited on seafood Friday, and the offerings were unremarkable, with most dishes being standard fare found at many mid-range Las Vegas buffets. Our server was friendly and attentive, though, and the hot crab legs were quite enjoyable.  

However, some aspects were disappointing. The sushi was cold and lackluster, while the cold shrimp was mushy and lacking texture. Although the salmon appeared moist, its taste was underwhelming. The hush puppies were overly salty and crunchy, and the fried catfish had an unpleasant softness due to sitting out too long, despite having a flavor reminiscent of "chicken fried" catfish. The carrot cake and chocolate fudge pieces were also subpar, with the latter feeling almost weightless.  

In summary, the crab was the highlight, and the presentation of the shellfish dishes was visually appealing and flavorful. Everything else we tried was mediocre, neither terrible nor inedible. Children would likely enjoy this establishment, as would those with sufficient funds seeking a leisurely dining experience.
