Unfortunately, our spa experience was slightly marred by the presence of a nude female patron within the women's hot tub area, which engendered a sense of unease and discomfort due to the potential health risks associated with shared facilities. Moreover, we would like to caution prospective guests against utilizing the pool facilities, as we unfortunately contracted a persistent bacterial infection on our legs that required four weeks of antibiotic treatment to resolve."

This is the Grand Lux Cafe situated within the premises of the esteemed Venetian resort. It is worth mentioning that there exists an alternative location of the same establishment in the Palazzo, however, according to local patrons, the quality of service and culinary offerings at this particular branch are deemed superior. For the sake of comparison, it is pertinent to note that the author has had the pleasure of visiting another Grand Lux Cafe situated in the Beverly Center of Beverly Hills; and while both establishments share certain commonalities in terms of their ambiance and gastronomical offerings, this specific location boasts the unique distinction of being open for business on a twenty-four hour basis.

Upon arriving with a sizable contingent of approximately fifteen individuals, the group was able to secure seating arrangements without incident, despite the fact that it was peak dining time and no prior reservations had been made (it is customary to reserve tables at least two hours in advance).

The author and a companion opted to share a pizza pie adorned with sausage, pepperoni, and mushrooms. While the dough was somewhat overly soft and difficult to handle without the toppings breaking apart, the flavor of the crust itself was quite satisfying. As a result, the author and her companion found themselves consuming the crust of each slice, leaving behind the toppings.

It is important to note that the menu at Grand Lux Cafe features an extensive array of culinary options, which bears a striking similarity to that of Cheesecake Factory, given that the two establishments share a common affiliation. Nonetheless, it is recommended that patrons exercise caution when selecting items from the Asian-inspired section of the menu, as the authenticity of such dishes may be subject to debate.
I was a bit dubious about a cafe that advertises coffee that doesn't taste like coffee but the espresso was decent. Not awesome but better than Starbucks.

good food. consistently slow and lousy service.  I had forgotten that it was nearly exactly a year since I'd been here,  and had the exact same experience (and my companions remembered too).  Very attentive manager,  but indifferent servers ... unbelievably slow.   It took an hour and a half since we arrived to go from order to meal.   Twice I had to get up and ask the manager about the status (oh and we ordered sushi, which doesn't need to be cooked!). \n\nFood was very good though.  So if you want great food without caring about the wait,  or attitude of the staff then Kona Grill is the place for you!

My Partner and I flew into Phoenix last week for the Christmas Holiday and we stopped here for lunch before heading out to the family.    I was fairly impressed with the cuisine and the ambiance.

I had a burger with all the trimmings and it was prepared perfectly.  I would have liked a few more fries with the burger, but I probably didn't need them.

I have to say the 80's hair band music videos playing were a little weird though.

If I find myself back in Phoenix, I will eat here again.

This is exactly what I was looking for in a hotel during my one night stay in Pittsburgh. Close to the city, but far enough out to get free parking and a reasonable rate (under $100).

The room was fairly small, but I was only planning on sleeping in it. It was clean so I couldn't ask for much more. The people at the front desk were very friendly too.

If I go back to Pittsburgh, I will absolutely stay here again.

Went to Rigatonys tonight with my sister and niece. Niece and I shared manicotti. It was decent enough, not super fabulous but not the worst I've ever had. My sister had the Mahi special with asparagus and quinoa pasta. She loved it. There was a creamy dill sauce on the fish. The salad was also awesome- nice portion of salami, cheeses, olives, pepperocini etc.. We tried spumoni for dessert and that was legit and a nice portion as well. Bryce was our server and was very nice, knowledgeable and had everything out in a timely manner. He told us about the extra charge for split plate. The meal came with bread as well. It was an overall great experience and we will be back.

I came here on a Saturday for lunch and it was packed so we took our food to go. By the time I was able to eat my torta ahogada, it had already soaked up all the spicy sauce it was swimming in and was soggy and quickly disintegrating. Normally I'm pretty tolerant to spicy foods but all I could taste was spicy. My friend got 3 fish tacos, which were super tiny. He was still hungry afterwards so he had san other full meal. Overall, it did not live up to all the good reviews I kept reading about on Yelp.

"Culinary experiences can be gratifying on occasion, albeit briefly, when the ambiance is revamped to create an atmosphere of sophistication. However, during our recent visit, the service was subpar, specifically with regard to the eggs, which were overcooked and lacked the desired doneness. Furthermore, the demeanor of certain servers bordered on impertinence, epitomized by their reluctance to acknowledge our presence, let alone address our concerns. Notwithstanding, the management's indifference towards our grievances was palpable, as they prioritized the interests of unremunerated patrons partaking in recreational activities over those of paying customers. Perhaps the establishment could benefit from the introduction of a poker club, whereupon we, as patronizers, might be inclined to voice our dissatisfaction and effectuate improvements in the quality of service."

I've made plenty of bad decisions here.\n\nHave you ever been somewhere where it means nothing, but somehow, means everything? I like coming to Maz. They don't have a good selection of beer. Or drinks. They don't have good pool tables. There are plenty of shady things that go on here. But still I find myself here every once in a while; generally I'm in a really crappy mood, or I'm feeling to good to go home and too mashed up to go anywhere else.

The service was a bit slow but the food made up for it. The sushi was delicious and the burger was unique and flavorful. We also got the mixed delux fries basket which was phenomenal. I would definitely come back.

Moderate place to stay in a great location - so close to the conveniences of the mall, movie theatre, etc. and just 10-15 minutes from the main shopping and tourist bits. Also just a couple blocks from the cute and trendy but relatively calm and tourist-free cafes on Broughton Street. Within the hotel there's a nice lounge with a fireplace to spend time in with a beer, cocktail, or coffee. And a full restaurant if you're feeling lazy. \n\nAs for the room itself, the walls are quite thin so you can hear people coming and going quite easily, and the wifi, though free is slow as a snail, maybe slower. Not a place to spend much time, but a fine place to return to after a day of exploring.
Came in. Waiter was alright. Gave me a stair like I didn't know what I was doing. He gave mediocre service. I'm full

Qdoba is merely adequate, as it employs a similar concept as Chipotle Grill, but regrettably, the culinary offerings fail to impress, lacking an indispensable element that would compel repeat visits. Additionally, the uninspired ambiance, characterized by the utilization of concrete floors and metallic tables, contributes to a chilly and somber atmosphere, even during the peak summer months.

I recently went to this restaurant to celebrate my coworkers birthday. I have never had any problems with Applebee's; however, this particular time, I ordered the shrimp and spinach salad and found some type of plastic in my salad. Both the manager and waitress apologized for the incident and were very quick to fix the problem. I was offered a new salad (which I took to go because my coworkers had finished their meal already) and when the food was brought out to me, the manager came back again to apologize. My meal was also free. I gave them a 3 because of how both the manager and waitress quickly fixed the problem. I don't think it was their fault but rather the fault of the cooks who were preparing the foods. My salad was also very good!

I customarily visit this establishment every Sunday during the football season; however, today's visit was an impromptu decision. Upon entering, I sat down at the bar and was greeted by my preferred Asian bartender in the United States. She enthusiastically recommended their delectable chicken wings, which I ordered along with the Kobe burger. Upon arriving home, I opened the box and was utterly dismayed to discover two putrid tomatoes that not only had an unpleasant appearance but also emitted a foul odor reminiscent of organic fertilizer. I promptly returned to the restaurant to request a replacement, only to be informed by the assistant manager that the tomatoes' condition was allegedly "normal." It became evident that this individual lacked a fundamental understanding of culinary quality and customer satisfaction. Fortunately, the general manager was present to mediate the situation and prevent any further dissatisfaction on my part. Notwithstanding, I must express my gratitude towards my bartender, whose exceptional service was the sole redeeming factor of this unfortunate experience, and the primary reason I might consider returning to this establishment in the future.

"Horchata, a beverage of unparalleled flavor and delight, has the propensity to elicit expressions of immense pleasure from those who partake in its consumption. Moreover, the presence of familiar countenances within the establishment contributes to an atmosphere of comfort and conviviality. Furthermore, the culinary offerings, specifically the vegetarian burrito and breakfast burrito, are of exceptional quality and generously portioned. However, it is worth noting that while the prices are reasonable, the guacamole, a crucial component of any respectable Mexican dish, falls short of expectations, thus necessitating further refinement."

I go to this facility usually 3 nights per week at about 2am and love it. Its jot crowded at all, usually having about 3-5 people in it. I can have the basketball court to myself I wanted and move freely through workout stations.

At first glance, this store looks like a tourist trap as it is in old town and they are selling Mexican trinkets. However, I can't say with absolute certainty, the prices seemed to be pretty decent.  I bought a colorful straw sombrero for 5 dollars.  I saw some other items that seemed to be priced right.

You can find all your Mexican things to make for a fantastic fiesta.  Or you can find pieces to decorate your home with in this store -- from the colorful Dia de Muertos Masks to the plates and cups to the garden pieces.  

I did not find the ladies in the store to be friendly at all.  But the store is neat and you will be happy, I am sure, with the HUGE selection of trinkets.

We have been patronizing Pediatric Partners (PP) for an extensive period of seventeen years, during which time Drs. Chiles and Salek have been rendering exceptional medical care to my offspring, having witnessed numerous personnel changes within the facility without any detrimental impact on the quality of service delivered; however, subsequent to the merger between PP and a comparably sized healthcare organization, the ambiance of the office has undergone a transformation, resulting in a diminished sense of familiarity and warmth, despite which, our unwavering loyalty towards the practice remains steadfast, primarily attributed to the continued exceptional care extended by our attending physicians, whose proficiency and dedication have proven invaluable, particularly now that my children have matured, necessitating fewer appointments.

Patience is required as they take their sweet time and it isn't even busy. It's been 30 minutes and I don't know that they'll be done soon. I would come back because it's cheap but definitely not during 'rush' hour.

What a monstrosity.  This place is huuuuuuge!  If you enter from the sidewalk on the strip and try walking all the way through the casino to try to find either the lobby or the monorail, you're bound to become lost.  The signs have arrows pointing this way or that way, but they are sometimes contradictory.  You can end right back up where you started at and not have a clue as to how you arrived back there.

It's a lovely hotel and pretty well maintained, but starting to show its age in some ways.  At one time it had a Wizard of Oz/Hollywood theme.  Now that's completely vanished, and I'm not sure if it even has a theme anymore.  If there is one, it's not apparent.  

Everything is also green.........veeeeeerrryyyy green.

Just wanted to update. Manager contacted us. Was willing to give full refund or have the top installed for free. Seems there was a communication issue. Issue was resolved, even kept the truck box cover. Did have an issue, but company did resolve in a timely manner and apologized for the miscommunication

I'd give Dolce 3.5 stars (if it were possible).  I really like the location and the atmosphere is cozy.  I've never eaten at this location other than some hummus and pita chips.  Based on other reviews, I might increase my rating once I sample the fare.  As a wine bar, I'm always happy to stop in to get a glass of red and talk with friends.  At times, I haven't found the servers to be friendly or warm; however, I haven't had any particular problems.  It's just a vibe.  I also wish they would extend their wine list.  As another reviewer commented, there just isn't a lot to choose from.  If you're in the area, I'd definitely stop in, although I wouldn't drive into NoDa just for this venue.

We stopped here for happy hour as I was lazy and it is close to work. Turns out they have a decent happy hour with assorted drink specials, half off selected apps and a pick 2 food special that runs open to close for $6.99. I selected the Tortilla soup and cheese enchiladas. The soup was good and enchiladas was also good and came with rice and beans. Our server was great and I wish I remembered her name but after a couple of the happy hour Margaritas names escape me.

I can here solely based off a recommendation from a friend who told me this was "the best pizza in Vegas". I consider that something of a dubious distinction since Vegas, to my knowledge, is not known for any pizza places. And if CA can barely get pizza right, I had a hard time believing Vegas could do any better. 

For the record, I live and die by NYC pizza. There is nothing on this planet that even compares. Yes, Chicago, that includes you. 

They were having a special deal where all pies were half off, so we got a large topped with pepperoni, sausage, and black olives. The quality just wasn't there for me. The pizza wasn't crispy enough, for one thing. Every time I folded a slice in half the front would start to droop like it was going flaccid. The sausage and pepperoni didn't help things since both were so greasy the pie was getting soggy. I'm cool with pepperoni, but those little blobs of meat called sausage do nothing for me. I should have vetoed that topping suggestion when it came up. Pretty good crust, though. Nothing that saved the dish but it worked all the same. 

Is this the best Vegas can do? Decent doesn't cut it for me. I can't grade on a relative scale.

"On multiple occasions, I have partaken in culinary indulgences within the confines of both the dining room and hibachi grill at this eatery, and I must say that my experiences have been nothing short of exceptional, particularly when it comes to the quality of the fare and the captivating performances put on by the chefs manning the grill. However, my encounters in the dining room have been somewhat less than satisfactory, marred by prolonged waits for my meals, which have consistently exceeded thirty minutes, despite the staff's acknowledgment of these delays and their attempts at compensation, such as offering complimentary edamame to waiting patrons. It appears that there is a dearth of sushi chefs and/or wait staff, resulting in an inadequate level of service that falls short of my expectations. While I would greatly desire to bestow upon this restaurant a more favorable rating, I fear that I cannot do so in good conscience until such time as I witness a marked improvement in the overall quality of service provided throughout the establishment."

The modified text is: "Commuted my vehicle to the servicing facility for a routine oil alteration, and I must say, I was thoroughly impressed by the efficiency and affordability of the process. The proximity of the establishment to a popular wholesale retailer also afforded me the opportunity to concurrently indulge in some recreational shopping and dining experiences while awaiting the completion of the maintenance work. Of relevance, it is advisable to peruse the business's online presence, specifically their review page, in order to potentially exploit any available financial incentives, as I did, resulting in a gratifying reduction in the overall cost."

This was supposed to be Las Vegas' latest and greatest club... I thoroughly enjoyed the sound and the vibe of the House floor, but it was so crowded that you couldn't dance let alone stand anywhere without it being shoulder to shoulder. We opt to say in the Hip Hop area that was equally as crowded, but luckily we found a small corner to dance in. After a while, we got even luckier as a girl invited us to dance in her table reserve area and Warren G performed. Being West Coast girls my group knew all the songs and had a great time watching his show. We left immediately after because it was just too packed for us.\n\nDon't buy bottled water b/c the small bottle costs $9 talk about rip off.

"My initial experience at this establishment was enjoyable, and I intended to bestow a perfect rating, as the culinary offerings were satisfactory and I consumed them on consecutive days. However, upon my return, I perceived a decline in quality regarding the sandwich I ordered. Specifically, the absence of lettuce in all four Earl's club sandwiches was glaring, and an excess of bacon resulted in an overpowering saltiness. Consequently, my enthusiasm for this venue has waned, and I shall not experience cravings for its fare in the future."

A viable alternative to Pita Jungle, albeit with a tad elevated price point relative to the quantity and quality of the fare in comparison to its competitor. My personal experience has been limited to the Togo option, which, while satisfactory, may not always provide the most pleasant dining experience, particularly when taking into account the ambient atmosphere. Notwithstanding, they accommodate Hooka smoking on the patio, a feature that, although potentially bothersome to some, does not detract from the culinary enjoyment. Upon collection of my Togo order, I must steel myself against the pungent Hooka odor that permeates the outdoor seating area. Despite these minor drawbacks, the cuisine generally meets expectations, leaving room for only slight adjustments to enhance the overall dining experience.
The tacos were greasy and unflavorful. I was quite disappointed with my order. There was also dirt on the floors and the people making the food didn't speak much English

Kitty's cafe is located in the El Cortez Hotel and Casino....... 
and you get the friendly service in here that you can experience everywhere else in this hotel.
It is an old style vegas hotel diner, with booths and the traditional counter service.
The ladies working there call everyone "honey" or they know most of them by name. 

The menu is what you would expect from a downtown hotel diner.
Nothing fancy, but large portions.
I tried the grilled sourdough melt - with turkey and ham.
Large, average.....
On this day there was a "new cook" and the food was slow getting out.

Late at night - it might be the place to get that bite you are needing - (it was for me) ....... otherwise - I am sure you can find better places to eat for the same amount of money.
Yes - all those "old school $1.99 deals" are gone.

This Starbucks is I guess owned by NY NY hotel so they don't use the App...sucky store!! No fare to the app users when you don't have cash on you! Good thing I had money this time and didn't loose to the slot machines here!  \n\nIt's always busy here but goes pretty fast and has a good selection of goods to eat. They open 24/7 which is a good thing. They make their coffee good. Of course, I will be back since this Starbucks is in our hotel but start using the app payment and have them work with Starbucks so we can get our points! Hahaha

"Upon arriving at this establishment, we were immediately greeted by Melissa, our effervescent server, who extended a cheerful salutation, thereby setting the tone for a pleasant dining experience. Following the standard ten-minute delay, which serves as an indicator of quality, we were presented with our beverages; specifically, a robust coffee possessing a full-bodied flavor profile and a diet cola characterized by an optimal level of carbonation. Notably, the expedient delivery of our egg dishes allowed me to complete merely three sentences of this review prior to their arrival, underscoring the efficiency of the kitchen staff. Additionally, our glasses were consistently replenished, ensuring that our hydration needs were met throughout the meal. Overall, this venue offers a satisfying breakfast experience."

"We traversed the distance between the FireSky hotel and the restaurant with ease, commencing our culinary excursion with the green pork chili, which, while possessing an appreciable degree of flavor, lacked the fiery zest we had anticipated. Our order also included the lamb fondue, comprising succulent lamb racks accompanied by a savory squash sauce for dipping. The fondue component of the dish boasted a rich, velvety texture and a subtle sweetness that complemented the lamb nicely. However, upon sampling the braised short ribs as our primary course, we were somewhat disappointed by their relative lack of flavor depth. Despite its generous portion size, the dish failed to impress due to its absence of salt, pepper, and other essential seasonings. While the meat itself was undeniably tender and juicy, the overall taste experience fell short of our expectations. Although the cuisine generally satisfied our palates, we couldn't help but feel that each dish could benefit from a more robust seasoning profile, thereby elevating the gastronomic experience to a higher level of satisfaction. Consequently, we have decided to award this establishment three stars for their efforts."

Tapas great, paella salty.  Never had it before thought it would be good here,  tapas were tasty especially the mushroom risotto ,  oxtail was tender ,  potatoes yummy,  garlic chicken was good but I ate a clove of garlic by mistake vampires beware.  However, the paella was way too salty.  And the service for a restaurant in the Aria was only so so.  Service was alot better in cafe in the Aria

There were limited options for dinner before the show we were seeing at the Luxor. The 20 year old ticket agent suggested T&T. Said it was great. I should have known we would not have the same palate. We started our meal with a set of mojitos. Our waiter indicated they were very good. I order them whenever I can so I have had my share of mojitos. These were very very sweet. I ordered club soda twice to add to our drinks to reduce the sweetness. Nothing saved these drinks. We didn't even finish half of it. Horrible.
The chips and salsa were also not very good which is fairly unusual. Pretty easy to make good chips and salsa. I had tacos for dinner and my friend had a shrimp dish. Both were very average.
Our server was friendly and even came around at the end and offered free tickets to the show. We already had purchased our tickets but the offer was very kind.
I wouldn't go back to this restaurant because if I had known the Asian restaurant had a good menu I would have gone there.

Easily the best meal I enjoyed in Vegas this past week. I was on a vacation with my sisters. Knowing we would be eating out for 6 days we tried to keep the budget in check. This restaurant was recommended by a friend of my sister did not disappoint as far as the food was concerned. It is tucked away in the back of the food court. Location isn't great...I suppose that is how they keep the prices down. \"Outdoor tables\" are actually inside. Lighting in the interior of the restaurant is way too bright.\nService was very average...our waiter was a hyper-macho Italiano who kept himself busy fawning over the young girls eating next to us, and chatting with his buddies out in the food court plaza. At the end of our meal he was so carried away with his buddies that he had totally forgotten about us, and need to be retrieved by a bus boy. \nThe Caeser Salad that we shared was good. Filet mignon meatballs with spaghetti and red sauce were delicious, as was the wood-fired Quatro Stagioni pizza. I highly recommend the food...the service not so much.

"I thoroughly enjoyed recognizing The Dog empire during my prolonged weekend excursion to Edinburgh, as it boasted an exceptional and stylish design, accompanied by remarkable eatery concepts, including The Dog, UnderDog, SeaDog, and Amore Dog. I sincerely wished I had ample time to sample all of their delectable offerings! My flank steak salad was merely satisfactory, possessing a somewhat tough texture, yet the sweet balsamic reduction complemented the bitter arugula with precision. In contrast, my companion's mushroom risotto was exquisitely prepared and indulgent, earning it a well-deserved four stars. Unfortunately, our culinary journey concluded with a less than impressive tiramisu, which lacked the potency of espresso and featured a chilling temperature that I personally prefer for the dessert. Moreover, the dark chocolate cocoa powder overwhelmed the delicate flavor of the dish when consumed in substantial amounts, prompting us to discard the upper layer of the dessert."

"The culinary experience was exceptional, and the prices were quite reasonable, owing to the utilization of a restaurant.com coupon. However, I would have awarded a perfect score of five stars had the server not exhibited an air of haughtiness and abruptness in their demeanor."

"An extensive array of artisanal brews graces the taps at this establishment, yet, if predictability is a patron's preference, they might be dismayed by the constantly shifting roster of craft beverages available. However, the culinary offerings proved to be a pleasant surprise, surpassing expectations typically associated with tavern fare. A convivial ambiance permeated our gathering of numerous companions, facilitated by the provision of entertainment in the form of board games and trivia queries. Unfortunately, the hospitality and ambiance left much to be desired, as an overwhelming crush of clientele necessitated an inordinate wait for a solitary server's attention, resulting in prolonged periods of neglect. Despite these shortcomings, the eatery's redeeming qualities, including its diverse beer selection and delectable victuals, may warrant future visits, albeit sans any gastronomical inclinations."

i've been going here for several years now, and i as long as i see dr. finch, i'm pretty happy. he's done one surgery on dozer (a minor laser procedure to remove a growth from her eyelid but did require anesthesia) and was very reassuring, informational and has a good dogside manner. just found out he'll probably be doing another surgery on her (much more major acl repair) and i'm totally comfortable having him do it.\n\ni only update and drop a couple stars bc 1. i was prob a little too gracious on my first review (i was a new yelper with out a system yet) and 2. other friends talk about how much they LOVE their vets, but i don't have that kind of passion for this place. i keep trying to shop around, but put it off until all of the sudden, dozer needs help NOW, so i want to go somewhere she's got some history on their files.

"Thus far, my culinary experiences at this establishment have been limited to the breakfast menu, specifically the corned beef and farmer's omlette. While the fare has been satisfactory, it fails to elicit any exceptional praise. However, I do appreciate the option to substitute a blueberry muffin for toast. The server has demonstrated politeness and accommodating behavior, exemplified by their willingness to provide ranch dressing with my hash browns, an unconventional yet personal preference. Additionally, this venue enjoys the distinction of being the sole dining option beyond 10 p.m. in close proximity, excluding those situated within gaming establishments, and boasts reasonable pricing. Consequently, it presents itself as a suitable setting for a relaxed meal in the company of a friend. Nonetheless, I must express my disappointment regarding the absence of dark chicken meat on the menu, as the lighter variety tends to possess an undesirable dryness."

"Although the culinary offerings were satisfactory, the prices charged for said edibles were utterly exorbitant, bordering on the outrageous. Eighteen dollars for a serving of enchiladas? Such an amount would be better suited to purchasing a meal at a high-end eatery, not a run-of-the-mill Mexican establishment. Furthermore, the cost of the accompanying chips and guacamole was equally egregious, amounting to nine dollars. While the quality of the fare was undeniable, it by no means warranted such an extravagant price tag. In light of these considerations, it is my belief that this particular dining establishment harbors an inflated sense of self-importance, as evidenced by the presence of cloth napkins and ornate paper menus, which do little to justify the excessive expense. In conclusion, due to the aforementioned factors, I shall not be inclined to return to this restaurant, as there are numerous other options available that provide comparable cuisine at a significantly lower cost."

Mert's can be characterized as an eatery that exudes a distinctly southern ambiance, which would not be out of place in a televised program featuring establishments of its ilk, such as Diners, Drive-ins and Dives. The interior design evokes a sense of quintessential southern hospitality, effectively creating a welcoming atmosphere for patrons who are not native to the area. However, it is not advisable to partake in the midday repast at this establishment, as the portions are generous and the fare is rich, rendering it imprudent to consume anything substantial during the afternoon hours. The quality of service is satisfactory, and while the cuisine may not be exceptional, it remains a passable choice for a casual dining experience.

Harrah's boasts an intelligent business model pertaining to its Carnaval Court, strategically positioned along a heavily traversed thoroughfare that effectively lures tourists into its vicinity. Surrounded by numerous kiosks offering an array of trivial knick-knacks easily accessible to inebriated patrons, even sober individuals such as myself and my companions succumbed to the allure of acquiring those novelty shirts responsive to musical rhythms. These gaudy apparel items symbolized our camaraderie, prompting us to purchase matching shirts. Upon entering the vibrant party arena adorned in our recently purchased attire, we received copious admiration and praise from fellow revelers. The expansive dance floor facilitates unrestricted movement, allowing patrons to fully indulge in their dancing desires. Located outdoors, the venue benefits from increased ventilation, thereby mitigating the potential for overheating typically associated with densely populated dance floors. The flair bartenders put on an entertaining display, complemented by their ability to craft respectable cocktails. Offering a seamless transition between merrymaking and gaming, this establishment features dedicated table games, catering to the diverse preferences of Vegas visitors. In essence, it encompasses all the essential elements sought after by patrons in the city's vibrant nightlife.

It was nice to relax for dinner on night this week and if you want to relax this is the place to do it at.  The view is just amazing and the staff was very friendly.  I had the Rib eye steak and it was cook just perfect.  Blue cheese potatoes were really good but I think the Blue Cheese was a bit over powering for the potatoes.\n\nI also had some cake for desert but the ice cream  had started to melt and the cake was a bit dry.  For the price I expected a bit better on the details like that.  In the end it was worth the trip for the view.

Recommended by a friend. He made it sound exclusive since dim sum was open twice a year, I felt that the dim sum style food could have been better if they focused on that and left the buffet of sea food out. It was tasty but some that came out was cold. They didn't have the chili oil like most Chinese restaurants I go to in San Diego, that was ok though since the items we had were a tad salty. The non dim sum items are  great though, fresh raw oysters, crab legs, lobster, nigiri, I actually asked the guy behind the sushi bar if I could have pieces with out rice, he said they usually don't give it out like that but he made an exception for me, to bad those pieces were so thick. I wanted to ask for a piece of the octopus but felt like I was going to inconvenience him so I walked down the buffet line, there was a yummy octopus and cucumber salad, probably the best thing on the buffet. They had a surplus of fresh fruit, mandarin oranges, cherries, rambutan, I didn't feel like working for my food though. Desert bar was pretty cool, decent, but not great. I really wish they more focused on dim sum though.. Next to sushi, dim sum is my favorite. Maybe I'll go this weekend when I get home to San Diego..

"It's analogous to gambling. Occasionally, one experiences substantial success...while at other times, the outcome is rather meager. 

The production commenced auspiciously. Our Master of Ceremonies was engaging and hilarious, possessing an unwavering comfort in his own skin while utilizing his personal experiences as fodder for his humor, yet maintaining a keen awareness of social conventions to avoid traversing boundaries. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for the subsequent two comedians, whose performances were marred by crudeness, excessive vulgarity, and a tendency to forcefully impose their questionable humor upon the audience, regardless of conspicuous signs of discomfort. At one juncture, a female spectator felt compelled to rise and request that the comedian move on, only to be met with further exploitation of the situation as a means of continuing his set. While employing someone as the focal point of humor may be acceptable, it becomes problematic when literally no one else is participating in mirth. Fortunately, our capable MC effectively applied a makeshift solution to salvage each of these two underwhelming performances. 

The featured act, Jay Reid, significantly redeemed the entire evening...which would have otherwise been a resounding disappointment at $20 per ticket. Mr. Reid capitalized on the stage's potential, incorporating the stool and microphone stand into his routine and presenting jokes pertinent to contemporary affairs and customarily delicate or taboo subjects. His humor was tasteful, and he demonstrated great class and coolness by lingering afterward to interact with the audience."

I came here for my 18th birthday with a few friends. They have a happy hour from 2-6 PM Monday-Friday (unfortunately, we came at 7.) I had the grilled chicken sandwich, and the chicken was kind of pink, but it took about 45 minutes to get and I was hungry so I didn't send it back. We also shared a frozen hot chocolate, which had potential, but I was literally chewing on ice the whole time. The service was pretty slow and it's a little pricier than Cheesecake Factory, but not by much. I'll give it another try soon and hope it's better!

This certainly isn't your grandfather's Flamingo anymore; indeed, I would go so far as to say that it isn't even your overweight, chain-smoking Uncle Larry's Flamingo that everyone knew and didn't particularly care for five to ten years ago. Before my recent visit to the Flamingo, the mere thought of staying there would immediately conjure up images of depressing 1980s decor, overweight fanny pack-wearing gamblers, and the overly exuberant expressions of Donnie and Marie as they gazed longingly into each other's eyes in an attempt to forget about that fateful night in 1977 when things went a bit too far. However, I must say that the Flamingo has significantly improved its act. The new decor is quite pleasant, and the casino floor is spotless and 80% fanny pack-free. While I have yet to stay in a room, I would be perfectly comfortable taking a side chick I wasn't ashamed of, as well as a girl that I've been dating for a while, all the while insisting, "Why do we have to put labels on what we are?" without batting an eye. All things considered, the Flamingo is a perfectly acceptable establishment with a fantastic location that I would readily recommend to anyone strolling along the Strip. Who knows, perhaps you'll be the first person to witness Donnie and Marie finally give in to their pent-up sexual tension and frustration after 35 years!

I've eaten here twice when I was staying at Treasure Island. The Pho is just okay but it'll do in a pinch. It probably smells better than it tastes.

I've tried to veggie spring rolls which were decent, but the peanut sauce is just okay - kind of coco-nutty. 

I got the Pho Tai and my friend got the Veggie Pho.  My soup was not super tasty but had lots of pieces of beef but very little noodles.  My friend enjoyed her soup - had bak choy, mushrooms and corn.  Little pricey for pho as you can get an awesome tasting bowl in LA for like 7 dollars.

Waitress was nice and the place was clean.

"Although I possess a certain degree of ambivalence towards this particular Target establishment, I do acknowledge that its proximity to my residence renders it a convenient option for me to procure the items I require. However, I must confess that the vast dimensions of the store and the considerable number of patrons it attracts tend to create an atmosphere that is somewhat chaotic and overwhelming, particularly when it comes to awaiting my turn at the checkout line. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, I do appreciate the numerous benefits this retail location offers, including ample parking space, a friendly and competent staff, and an impressive array of merchandise that enables me to fulfill all my shopping needs under a single roof."

"It has come to my attention that certain members of our staff are devoting an excessive amount of time engaging in non-work related conversations with one another, thereby compromising their ability to deliver optimal levels of customer service. This phenomenon is particularly prevalent when employees are positioned with their backs facing the clientele, which not only hinders their capacity to respond promptly to patrons' needs but also creates an unfavorable impression of unprofessionalism."

I just happened to be in Vegas this new year and since I saw this place in the past i decided to try it. Salad bar is ok, the meats a bit too salty and really raw (bloody) but I was surely disappointed with the service. Waitress show up only 3 times, when we first sat at the table, when she brought us the drinks and when she gave us the check!, I have to literally ask the servers to bring the meats to our table since the seem to just pas us by, I guess the just want you to eat from the salad bar :( \nIn other words, the price service/quality ratio is not good at all

We stumbled upon this place after failing to go to the Bacchanal because of the nasty line. By the time we found this place, we were starving! This is a cool little cafe place with pretty modern decorations throughout the restaurant. They blast top 20s hits here, so if you're looking for a nice quiet place to chat, this definitely isn't the place.\n\nPortions here are pretty large but we really didn't think anything of the food. Nothing stood out or was spectacular. I got a pastrami breakfast sandwich and I felt like it was missing something. If they had added some extra condiments or had a special sauce it would be much better. It felt like the pastrami, egg, and other ingredients didn't flow that well together. Nonetheless it filled us. I did enjoy the tator tots though, they were crispy, crunchy and delicious.

This is a cool spot and very educational. I loved the way that everything is divided into 4 ecosystems, I would have liked the polar/arctic room to have more though. I think that the entry fee is way too much for what you get. The gift shop is nice. You can find cool things like bags made from recycled juice boxes, insect snacks (yes REAL insects to eat) and small crystals, etc.\n\nDon't waste your time and money to take the elevator to the top of the city. You can essentially get the same view for free from the top of Mount Royal.

Again, this is one of those chains where you can't judge a book by its cover! If you have the time you can find some really great deals here! 

They have pretty much everything here, clothes, paintings and plenty of home decor. When I visited they were changing over some departments it looks like they are going to have a larger selection of rugs and portraits and paintings which will be great or anyone who is looking to update their home.

I enjoyed the visit and would return! Just remember when you go be prepared to search for your good deals!
Well they no longer have the Chicken Strip Cheese sandwich and what they replaced it with pretty much sucks. Other than that its like a normal hooters with some new wing flavors and steak fries.

This lodging establishment caters to individuals who seek fundamental accommodations and are financially constrained, thereby providing a suitable venue for those seeking basic amenities at an economical price point. During our sojourn, we found that it fulfilled its intended function admirably and would unhesitatingly suggest it to others who do not prioritize luxurious appointments or an extensive array of services. Within close proximity, we noticed the presence of eateries such as Pizza Hut, Subway, and Fatburger, as well as a cinema, watering holes, and numerous slot machines. Our stay was primarily characterized by slumber, and we did not partake in any notable activities within the hotel's premises themselves. Furthermore, our culinary experience at Fatburger proved to be disappointing, both in terms of taste and the prolonged duration required for its preparation.

"My decision to dine at this establishment was influenced by its prominent featuring on a popular culinary television network, and I was eager to determine if it could comparatively measure up to my preexisting standards of gastronomical excellence, specifically in regards to the fiery and savory attributes that I have come to expect from a reputable seafood restaurant. While the quality of the seafood served was satisfactory, it unfortunately did not live up to my elevated expectations in terms of spiciness and flavor profile. It is advisable to arrive promptly, as the venue has a tendency to become congested with patrons, particularly during peak hours on weekends. Our visit took place at 11 am on a Saturday, and by the time we completed our meal, a queue of anticipatory diners had formed, awaiting their turn to partake in the culinary offerings."
Solid 3 star red curry tofu.\n\nNot 5 star, not 4 star...but hey!  They did great with the one classic dish I ordered...

The hubby and I stopped by around 8:30 at night. Upon pulling up, we seen that the line was almost out the door. Determined to get some ice cream, I insisted on going in and waiting in line. It took about 15 minutes to get our order, but the place was jam packed so the wait was to be expected.  All the employees were doing their best to keep the line down. I ordered the smallest size, "like it", and the employee actually gave me the next size up at no charge because she said she grabbed too much ice cream. 

There's very little seating at this location,  and the available tables were dirty. But to be fair,  if all hands were on deck making orders, whose left to clean up? We chose to get our order to-go. 

I'm a fan of Cold Stone's ice cream.  I'm accustomed to the long lines. But to me, it's worth waiting to get me some "All lovin' no oven".

This particular venue brought to mind the ambiance of Whiskey River, albeit devoid of the boisterous individuals customarily present along the shore and characterized by a preponderance of relaxed patrons. It appeared that impromptu dance competitions were taking place on the floor, as spectators seemed to be thoroughly enjoying themselves. Additionally, there were apparent offers of 99-cent Jaeger bombshells and, upon further inquiry, I discovered the existence of 99-cent tacos or similar culinary items. A wet T-shirt contest ensued, featuring a mere trio of participants, which, while somewhat disheartening, managed to retain an element of amusement. Under the circumstances, I would consider visiting this establishment once again.

"The Grandview Saloon boasts a spectacular panorama of Pittsburgh from atop Mt. Washington, which can be savored from the establishment's expansive patio area. While the vistas from within the restaurant itself are by no means inferior, they pale in comparison to the breathtaking scenery that awaits patrons who venture outdoors. To complement the visual feast, the Saloon offers an extensive array of libations, as well as a menu that, while unremarkable in terms of culinary innovation, caters to the local palate with an assortment of familiar, comforting dishes. Unfortunately, the interior design of the restaurant fails to live up to the standards set by its picturesque surroundings, with a decidedly lackluster ambiance that detracts from the overall experience. However, with some attention directed towards refining both the aesthetic and gastronomic aspects, this venue could potentially rank among the city's most captivating destinations for dining and entertainment. In summary, while not an ideal setting for momentous occasions such as anniversaries, the Grandview Saloon remains a suitable choice for hosting first-time visitors, providing them with a unique opportunity to appreciate the splendor of Pittsburgh while indulging in a delectable beverage."

"Excellent, amicable, and assiduous service was proffered to us, complemented by a delectable Caesar salad, succulent duck, and a mediocre serving of scallops. Although the salad was scrumptious, the duck was somewhat rich and filling, while the scallops were merely average and not particularly memorable. In conclusion, our dining experience was passable but not particularly remarkable, thereby rendering it unworthy of future repetition."

"I have been frequenting this establishment on a regular basis during the week, and it can be challenging to determine whether it is open for business during inclement weather conditions. Despite this, there are certain aspects of the market that I thoroughly enjoy, while others leave something to be desired. The floral arrangements, for instance, are not only breathtakingly beautiful but also remarkably affordable; however, their longevity leaves much to be desired, typically lasting no more than a few days. Additionally, there are some exceptional deals on fresh produce, with some truly outstanding tomatoes and peaches available during their respective seasons. Nonetheless, it is somewhat disconcerting to note that nearly half of the merchandise on offer is not locally sourced. In fact, I found it quite vexing to locate a locally grown apple, and many of the fruits and vegetables sport SKU stickers indicating their origins in distant states such as California or Washington. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the presence of several local farmers scattered throughout the market renders it a worthwhile venture. Consequently, I shall continue to patronize this establishment with some degree of regularity."

I have a profound affection for The Coffee Bean, as I frequently indulge in their delectable brews. However, this particular establishment seems to have some sort of anomaly affecting the quality of their coffee. It appears that there is an inconsistency in the taste, which I can only surmise is due to the water used in the preparation process. This has led me to question whether there is a deliberate attempt to undermine my mental state or if it is merely an unfortunate consequence of the hotel's water source. Despite my fondness for a robust cup of coffee, I find myself consistently disappointed with the offerings within the Venetian. Notwithstanding, I must acknowledge that the convenience of having a cup of coffee delivered to my doorstep each morning by a particularly attractive and thoughtful individual almost makes up for the subpar quality of the beverage itself. Thus, I have assigned a rating of three stars, comprising one star for the coffee and two additional stars for the exceptional service I received.

Good store with a lot of products that I'd actually use.   It is a really good savings on groceries.  

The place is well laid out, but it can get messy because of the other shoppers.

The only issue I've experienced at the times I've gone is that there is a very long line to check out.  It's a small price to pay for the savings that can be had.  Be prepared to wait up to 15+ minutes to check out!

It is a clean place and they have good service. The Koi pond is pretty cool. The sandwich I ordered was pretty awful, don't get the turkey because it is like packaged meat you can buy at a supermarket. The prices were on par with other delis, but you can get a much better sandwich for the same price elsewhere.

*sigh*  I really wanted to love this, but it was just ok.  After reading all the positive yelps and testimonials on Pop's website, I was expecting a fun and delicious experience.  I imagined myself giving my order to a gruff but charming grill master, who would ask me 'wit' onions? in an authentic Philly accent.  What I really got was a grill master who was just gruff and apparently couldn't hear my order, because when I got my cheese steak home, there were no onions on it at all!   

Ok, the cheese steak itself:  the meat was not fatty or greasy, but slightly bland.  I enjoyed the cheese whiz and the bread was very good.  I think if they had included the onions, things would have been tastier.  Also, in the hours since eating the steak, I have been a bit 'indisposed', but this in and of itself has never been an index of whether I would return to a place if the food tastes good.  (masochist!)

So all in all, I think I would try it again probably.  But I'll also try their competition in town and yelp the results.  :)

Cabo is a very busy place- even on a Tuesday night! Luckily we were a party of 2 and were seated pretty quick. The food tasted good and fresh, but I had very high expectations based on the reputation they have in Charlotte. I was hoping for a little more flavor.

Contrary to some of the other reviews, I didn't feel rushed even though they were jammin'. I went with a friend and we were catching up for quite a while, but our waitress was friendly and didn't rush us, which I appreciated. Parking can be difficult, like most places in NoDa, so plan to cruise around a little. 

Overall I think Cabo has a fun atmosphere for grabbing drinks and something to eat, but it isn't a "go out of your way" establishment.

We were on our way back from a trip to Mexico and Cuba* when we arrived here for a short layover. This airport is easy to navigate, especially when you are coming through immigration -- there are lots of signs telling you exactly where to go. 

There was a long line at immigration but it moved fairly quickly. My honey and I had all of our research license paperwork in order for the Cuba portion of our travels in case we were asked for it** but the not-even-a-hello immigration officer guy just scanned our passports, looked at us with his best stern face, and stamped us on our way. We then picked up our checked suitcases, zoomed right through customs (after handing over our customs form) and rechecked our bags. 

The part that ended up taking the longest amount of time was going back through security, thanks to long lines. I do have to say that the security personnel were working very hard to move everyone along and were really nice as well.

If we had more than 5 minutes to spare, I would have picked up some local BBQ to eat on our San Francisco bound flight. Thanks a lot, security line. 

*You won't hear much more about our trip to Mexico and Cuba since they don't have Yelp. (At least not yet.) I'll just summarize to say that almost everywhere we slept, ate, drank, visited, etc. were unquestionably five star. 

** Apparently Beyonce and Jay Z did as well. http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/09/entertainment-us-usa-cuba-beyonce-idUSBRE93600V20130409

This lodging establishment's external appearance exhibits visible signs of wear and tear, suggesting the need for a comprehensive renovation. The overall aesthetic of the hotel's facade and surrounding areas appears dated and fatigued. In contrast, the guest rooms have undergone updates, albeit inconsistent with the rest of the hotel's aspects, and feature cleanliness issues regarding tile grout in certain quarters. Despite this, the quality of the culinary offerings is surprisingly satisfactory, particularly for a hotel of this caliber. Additionally, the hotel boasts a well-stocked bar featuring an assortment of regional brews, complemented by personable and attentive service. While the hotel's location is reasonably convenient, it remains a considerable distance from the central attractions of the city, necessitating either a leisurely stroll or utilization of the complimentary shuttle service, courtesy of the accommodating and knowledgeable driver, Christian. Notwithstanding, accessibility via I-277 is relatively straightforward. Considering the cost, the experience proved to be adequate.

The restaurant is cozy and somewhat dark with a separate bar area and dining area. Service was quick and attentive. They have some different beers to experiment with and even let you sample some you're not familiar with before you commit. 


Food was OK but not great. I had half a turkey sandwich and salad. My turkey sandwich was a bit dry and bland and the salad was forgettable. As bars go and as bar food goes you could do much worse.

I have been eager to experience this establishment for an extended period of time, subsequent to hearing numerous favorable comments regarding its culinary offerings and perusing its menu. Upon further investigation, it has become apparent that the prices listed on the website are intentionally omitted, as the eatery in question charges exorbitant fees for its dishes.

Upon arriving at the restaurant, we opted to be seated on the patio, as the primary dining area was not yet open for seating at the time of our arrival (6:30 pm). Our server was quite attentive and hospitable, replacing my water glass promptly upon noticing that it contained an unidentifiable substance floating within. Additionally, my spouse's water glass was observed to be unclean, and she expediently provided a fresh glass for him as well.

She presented us with two minuscule sample-sized frozen peach and strawberry margaritas, which we found to be quite delectable. However, we did notice that the rocks margarita was not as impressive as the aforementioned samples. It is worth mentioning that no complementary chips and salsa were offered, which would have been acceptable had the restaurant provided some other form of appetizer or promotion, similar to that of Barrio. Furthermore, there was no happy hour available, much to our dismay.

The street corn served at this establishment was satisfactory, although I have certainly encountered superior renditions elsewhere. The butternut squash tacos, on the other hand, were truly exceptional. My spouse preferred them significantly over his mahi tacos. Nevertheless, I cannot fathom how this restaurant has managed to remain in operation given the exorbitant pricing of their dishes, including three miniature tacos (measuring only three inches in diameter) for the sum of $12. Moreover, they have the audacity to charge $12 for guacamole prepared from a mere two avocados. It is evident that this establishment relies heavily on the tourist trade, as I cannot imagine how they could possibly sustain themselves during the off-season.

"The positive aspects of this establishment include the provision of a magna doodle for young patrons to engage in creative expression, a courteous and attentive wait staff, a pristine dining environment owing to its recent opening, a diverse array of pasta options including whole wheat and rose sauce, the opportunity for patrons to personalize their pasta dishes with various toppings, karaoke amenities available on Friday and Saturday evenings, culinary offerings that are palatable, reasonable prices for those who refrain from adding supplementary toppings, and a distinctive dessert menu."
"However, there are several drawbacks to consider, such as the limited visibility of the children's menu, which is printed on the reverse side of the magna doodle, and the fact that kids' beverages are served in adult-sized to-go cups. Additionally, the cleanup process after a spill was quite sluggish, taking nearly 10 minutes to address my daughter's spilled milk. Furthermore, the menu selections are somewhat restricted, primarily consisting of pasta, pizza, and paninis, with limited variety in terms of entrees. Moreover, the cost of individual pasta toppings is $1.50 each, and my cannelloni dessert was disappointingly unremarkable."
We were less than welcomed at the door. The security guard was extremely disrespectful. We would not have gone in if our birthday bud didn't insist.
Fun store if you are looking for Korean. To the poster that identified this store as Japanese, was wrong. Korean and Japanese foods are similar but not the same.

Red 8 is a pretty good americanized chinese food. I love the Oxtail soup along with their mongolian beef and rice.. The ambiance is really nice and the service is wonderful. The dessert menu can use a bit of work but still ok. The price is a bit expensive , i think your paying for the ambiance and the fact that you are dining at the Wynn.. I don't suggest this place for chinese food. I would only go back here if i was invited, but still glad i checked this restaurant off my list.

It's getting harder to find awesome deals for meals in Vegas.  Gone are the days you can get buffets for $5 or prime rib dinners for $7.99.  Oh Sahara, how I miss you!  

Visiting family in Henderson, we headed over to Sunset Station for some dinner. They had prime rib dinner for $9.99, so I had to get it.  For a Saturday night, it was packed and we had to wait 15 minutes for a table.  

My prime rib dinner was good, but I should've ordered it medium rare, because medium well wasn't as tasty.  

Service was good and food was decent.  I just wished the prime rib dinner was little bit cheaper and then I would've given them a higher rating.  Their t-bone steak dinner special was $12.99, which I thought was a bit high for Vegas.  

Grand Cafe is way better than Denny's, so for a local 24 hour spot, I'd come back to eat.

I really want to like this place, but it was extremely disappointing. Maybe it was overhyped. The food was just okay, nothing sets it apart from other buffets. \n\nBased on other reviews, I might give it another shot next time I'm in Vegas, but I'd rather go back to the seafood buffet at Rio before dining here again.

"The gastronomical experience was satisfactory, with the culinary offerings being of superior quality, specifically the infinite shrimp options (shrimp alfredo duplicated, breaded shrimp, and shrimp scampi) which constituted the most favorable aspect of the dining excursion. However, the waiting period preceding seating and subsequent service was rather prolonged, lasting approximately half an hour for seating and an additional quarter hour for the servers to take our order, thereby hindering the overall enjoyment of the meal and warranting improvement in the realm of customer service to elevate the establishment's rating. Notwithstanding, the comestibles were indeed delectable and arrived at our table piping hot, and the cheddar biscuits presented post-seating were of exceptional quality."

"Although the cost of the sashimi may be perceived as somewhat elevated, the quality of the seafood served at this establishment has consistently met my expectations, with each piece of fish exhibiting exceptional freshness and being presented in an aesthetically pleasing manner. Following three separate visits, I can confidently attest to the consistent excellence of the culinary experience offered here."

"My experience at this hotel was less than satisfactory, and I would not consider staying here again. The room, while aesthetically pleasing and featuring comfortable bedding, had a subpar bathroom that appeared to be from a lower-end establishment. Moreover, the arduous trek to the back tower, which involved traversing the entire casino with one's luggage and crossing a bridge over the pool, was particularly vexing. The casino itself, however, was quite pleasant, boasting a fresh and clean atmosphere, likely due to its recent renovation. Unfortunately, the check-in process was a significant disappointment, taking an unacceptable amount of time and contributing to an overall negative experience. The pool and staff were pleasant, but the issues with check-in and the bathroom left a lasting impact on my impression of the hotel."

"The dearth of options was palpable, with a meager assortment of products available, which was further exacerbated by the cramped and cluttered nature of the store; however, the parking lot, despite its capacity, appeared to be congested, creating an incongruous juxtaposition between the exterior and interior spaces, although the staff members, who were few in number but abundant in cordiality, managed to facilitate a semblance of order amidst the chaos, and I, after conducting a thorough examination of the premises, was able to procure a set of diminutive yet aesthetically pleasing beverage receptacles for the nominal sum of sixty-nine cents, which, given the limited variety and somewhat disorganized ambiance, seemed a veritable bargain."

I recently visited this establishment during a brief sojourn at the Aria, whereupon I indulged in a delectable assortment of pastries and beverages. Prior to my visit, I had been lodging at the aforementioned hotel while attending to some business-related matters. As I was strolling towards my accommodations, I couldn't help but notice the alluring ambiance of the vicinity, which was replete with an array of vibrant colors and tantalizing aromas emanating from the nearby patisserie. My curiosity piqued, I decided to return the following morning, craving a cup of coffee and eager to sample the culinary delights offered by this esteemed establishment. Upon my arrival, I was struck by the visually stunning presentation of the multi-tiered cakes, which seemed to defy gravity with their intricate architecture. This prompted me to ponder the amount of time and effort required to create such edible masterpieces. Following a brief wait, I placed an order for two Americanos, only to observe the barista utilize a machine to efficiently dispense the beverages. While the coffee was palatable, it fell short of my expectations, considering the steep price point of $10. In light of this experience, I would not recommend this venue for coffee enthusiasts seeking a more personalized and authentic experience. Nonetheless, those seeking a variety of baked goods may find this establishment suitable for their needs.

"The ale is merely adequate, but its price point is exorbitant. It would be judicious to await the replenishment of stock at the warehouse club, whereupon you may procure a case for a sum $10 less than its current price at the brewery. The personnel at the establishment were indeed cordial, yet their hospitality alone does not suffice to justify a revisit at present. However, the possibility of an on-site dining establishment materializing in the future renders the venue potentially worthy of a second visit."

This is one of those places that you must try at least one time. It is a fun experience and the meat its regularly pretty good.\nDo not come on a holiday, they do not maintain the same level of service and food quality

"The pricing structure at this establishment is patently exorbitant, with minuscule, tapas-style plates of culinary fare commanding a premium price point in excess of $30, while larger, yet still diminutive entree-sized portions fetch a whopping $50 to $60. Despite my prior awareness of the menu prices, the inflated cost of my meal still managed to surpass my expectations. The ambiance of the restaurant, characterized by a color scheme dominated by red and black hues, was somewhat redeemed by the novelty of witnessing the culinary process firsthand from our perch at the bar. However, the quality of the food, though undeniably satisfactory, fails to justify the egregious markup. If the aim of this dining experience is to foster a sense of casualness, a reduction in prices by at least 25-30% would be imperative."

Is the best bagel place I've been to? No. I came here for a \"to go\" breakfast with my man. As we were waiting for our food, he whispered to me \"this place is filthy\". The vent above the bagel rack was so dusty! The counters, floors and tables looked like they hadn't been wiped down either. We had already paid so we just decided to get our food and go. The guy who helped us was very sweet but incredibly slow. We spent almost 20 minutes waiting for 2 bagel sandwiches and a chocolate chip muffin. The bagel sandwiches tasted good (I tried a tomato basil bagel) and liked it. I also thought the variety in bagels was nice. The muffin wasn't my favorite but was edible. Prices were reasonable but nothing great. Just like my review says, A-OK.

"Underwhelmed experience with too much repetition."
It is with profound dismay that I must convey my utter disappointment with my recent dining excursion to this establishment, which, ostensibly, specializes in "pho," a culinary delight that I, and my companion, were eager to indulge in. However, our enthusiasm was quickly extinguished when the waitstaff, in an almost perfunctory manner, divulged that they were bereft of the aforementioned "pho" at the present time. This revelation struck me as rather anomalous, given the eatery's namesake and its purported focus on Vietnamese cuisine. Had the waitress apprised us of this deficiency upon our arrival, we could have, with relative ease, sought out an alternative venue to satiate our craving for a steaming bowl of "pho." Alas, we were compelled to peruse the menu further, resulting in orders that, regrettably, failed to impress. The lone redeeming quality of this lackluster dining experience was the cordial demeanor of the staff, which, admittedly, salvaged a modicum of respectability. In light of these circumstances, I fear that my patronage of this establishment shall remain a distant memory, never to be revisited.

Although the pungent odor permeating throughout the facility may prove somewhat overwhelming to one's olfactory senses, the exceptional proficiency and dedication exhibited by the instructional staff serves as a notable compensation for the unpleasantness. Unfortunately, the same level of excellence cannot be extended to the front desk personnel, whose demeanor tends to be brusque and unfriendly, thereby creating a stark contrast between the two aspects of the establishment. Were it not for the subpar customer service, this studio might have maintained its appeal as a preferred destination; however, given its remote location and the presence of alternative, more hospitable environments, it becomes increasingly impractical to continue patronizing this particular facility. Notwithstanding the aforementioned drawbacks, the amenities available at this studio do include a well-maintained changing area, complete with two showers that are stocked with complimentary body wash, shampoo, and conditioner for the purpose of revitalizing one's physique following a rigorous class. It is worth mentioning that Summer and Stacy, two standout individuals among the instructional staff, offer unique and engaging experiences that set them apart from their peers.

"Rob and I partook of a morning repast, during which we savored an assortment of delectable comestibles, including ovular eggs, crispy bacon, and fluffy pancakes, albeit not the most scrumptious pancakes I have had the pleasure of consuming, yet still palatable. However, the genuine highlight of the meal was the exceptional sausage gravy that accompanied our feast."

This place wasn't as good as we were expecting.  My pizza (Classic Maggie) was good, but nothing outstanding.  My husband's burger was completely charred and basically inedible.  We didn't bother sending it back as our waitress was nowhere to be found.\n\nIt's your typical bar food with a decent beer selection...nothing more, nothing less.

Been to this establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say, their artisanal brews have piqued my interest and secured my patronage. It's worth noting that they only serve their house-brewed beers, which, in my opinion, is a selling point. While the food menu is adequate, it doesn't boast any particularly remarkable offerings. In fact, their buffalo wings left much to be desired, and I wouldn't recommend them. However, the ambiance is quite pleasant, making it an ideal setting for socializing with companions over a cold beverage or two. It's worth mentioning that their prices are a tad high, but given the location in Ahwatukee, it's somewhat expected. Their in-house brewed beverages, specifically the Uncle Bear's lineup, are undoubtedly the highlight of this establishment. It's worth noting that it's the only type of beer available, but that's part of the charm. Although I won't go out of my way to visit frequently, it's still a suitable venue for casual gatherings with friends, especially considering the abundance of televisions scattered throughout, making it an excellent choice for viewing sporting events. Additionally, they accommodate canine companions on the patio, provided they're leashed and well-behaved. As a unique touch, if you provide an 8 x 10 photograph of your furry friend, they'll even display it in a frame as a memorial. That's certainly a commendable gesture.

"Turkish Kitchen presented itself as a respectable and economical dining establishment, catering to a group of patrons who had not reserved a table in the city center on a Friday evening. Upon being seated, we were served an assortment of bread accompanied by an extraordinary dip, whose flavor profile was so remarkable that it became the focal point of our culinary experience. Not feeling particularly famished, I opted for the Turkish ravioli, which, despite its absence from the menu, was complemented by a side of salad and rice. While the sides were somewhat awkwardly presented and resulted in a degree of waste, they were undeniably delectable. Unfortunately, the ravioli failed to meet expectations, primarily due to its overcooking, causing it to disintegrate upon attempted consumption. Although its taste was passable, it paled in comparison to my previous encounter with Turkish ravioli, which was a considerable disappointment. It is likely that I should have selected a kebab-style dish, as did everyone else, but my craving for something other than a meat-centric meal prevailed. The remaining patrons appeared content with their choices, however. One peculiarity was that our order of beer was served in glasses of varying sizes, smaller than customary pint or large bottle glasses. In conclusion, while Turkish Kitchen offered a satisfactory dining experience for a group seeking a reasonable and convivial meal, it falls short of being Edinburgh's premier Turkish restaurant, in my estimation."

Great place for a Friday happy hour! The chambord marg is top notch, achiote chopped chicken salad is to die for, and the trio appetizer is great ONLY when it's half price during happy hour.  Highly recommend but only hangup is the cocky manager, useless hostests, and unattentive servers.  After two margaritas you get over the staff :)

I have no idea why there was such a huge hype, it was just a typical thin crusted pizza. Seriously!!!!! The toppings were good, pepperoni, sausage, etc... but honestly you can get a better pizza elsewhere.\n\nHowever, if you are dying for a late  night snack after Marquee it's conveniently located.

My experience at this establishment was merely adequate. I ordered the Pho, and although the broth did not meet my expectations of being exceptional, it was still passable. My companion ordered the cashew chicken for the first time, and he thoroughly enjoyed it. My acquaintance had the chicken fried rice, which was also quite satisfactory. The prices at this venue are reasonable for the generous portions, making it an ideal location for budget-conscious college students. I would return to this eatery for sustenance, but I would not order the Pho again.

I am awarding three stars for this review due to two primary factors. Firstly, I requested the Thai iced tea for nearly $3, anticipating a revitalizing and genuine Thai iced tea experience. However, what I received was a minuscule bottled beverage from the refrigerator, which was underwhelming and not worth the cost. The individual behind the counter offered a lackadaisical explanation, stating she was "too indolent to prepare a proper one." Secondly, the dining area was excessively humid and warm, with the entrance open on a steamy rainy day. As a result, I perspired profusely during my dining experience, which was disagreeable. Moreover, there were laborers mending the ceiling tiles or something in close proximity, which I deemed unsuitable for when patrons are consuming their meals mere feet away.

The cuisine was palatable, but the ambiance left much to be desired. Despite this, I will continue to visit this establishment for a speedy Thai culinary fix, primarily due to its accessibility and prime location on Green Street.

went to kings on saturday for an early meal, while out doing the day after xmas shopping!  i have been here a few times for my seafood fix, and time after time the service is very slow, and this visit is the same (at least they are consistent!!)
started the table with the chilled seafood platter for 24.95  comes with 4 dungeness crab legs, 4 oysters, 4 clams and 8 shrimps.  and i think this one of the best deals in vegas for a shellfish platter.
entrees were grilled shrimp and scallop skewars, kids burger and a combo fried platter.   the fried platter was not to good,  over breaded and gummy shrimp and scallops, and 1 little peice of cod/haddock
i usually get the sanddabs or something that is on special,  ill stick with that in the future.  but in all actuallity i just come for the shellfsih platter!!!

I live just north of the Burger Factory, its always busy.  The menu offers a little bit of everything, making it a great place to bring an office group with  different tastes.  \n\nThe food portions are large and if your looking for a greasy spoon the burger factory might be your place for a quick bite.

For an extended period, I have been under the impression that Ping Pong Thai was an eatery catering to adult clientele, featuring Thai cuisine and entertainment, specifically ping pong shows. However, my assumptions were proven incorrect, as this establishment solely focuses on providing delectable Thai fare, sans any ping pong-related activities or equipment. Disappointingly, the Panang curry has failed to impress, lacking depth of flavor and an unfortunate watery consistency. In contrast, the Pad Kee Maw has proven to be a saving grace, boasting sufficient spiciness to satiate my taste buds, albeit at a medium level of heat. This dish remains the primary draw for my patronage, despite subpar service. Dining in yields sluggish service, while takeout orders experience an inverse phenomenon - an abundance of efficiency. Regrettably, both scenarios culminate in a lackluster experience, leaving the customer feeling inconsequential. It is worth mentioning that the restaurant tends to attract sizable crowds during the lunch hour, further contributing to the underwhelming ambiance. Were Ping Pong Thai to incorporate a ping pong table, a novel and engaging element, my rating would undoubtedly increase. It is plausible that the proprietor hails from Thailand, harboring a profound passion for the sport, which would undoubtedly elevate the dining experience.

"Despite its proximity and appealing happy hour offerings, we continue to experience frustration during our repeated visits to this establishment. Specifically, we are dismayed by the limited beer selection, which features only three options on tap. Furthermore, the service has been inconsistent, characterized by overly attentive servers at the onset of the meal, followed by an inexplicable absence during the payment process. This lack of attention to detail raises concerns about potential losses for the restaurant, as it is not uncommon for patrons to depart without settling their bills. Additionally, the cuisine has been variable in quality, with the more affordable selections, such as the calamari, proving to be the most satisfying, while the pricier options, like the elk meatballs, have fallen short of expectations due to their bland and arid texture."

"Wow, such vitriolic appraisals! \n\nI had the pleasure of encountering an employee who was stationed at the counter, and he proved to be quite assistance in facilitating my culinary experience by offering judicious recommendations that led me to a delectable meal. Specifically, the BBQ'd tilapia and Chicken Adobo dishes were particularly savory."

Close to the strip in between harrahs and ballys area in the Linq. Cool new concept, supposely all their slushies have top shelf liquor but I felt it wasn't strong enough, I believe I've gotten more drunk at fat Tuesdays slushies. They have more flavors though and we chose the patron grand mariner because it was sour.The staff is very friendly and cutely dressed, just needs more signs on the cups of drinks. The saxophone cup is seriously amazing! I think its the sexiest and bangest cup there is. ;) Ha ha
